HEADLINE: Beyond Our Means

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle; Louis Uchitelle covers economics for The New York Times.

 BODY:

THE END OF AFFLUENCE
The Causes and Consequences
of America's Economic Dilemma.
By Jeffrey Madrick.
Illustrated. 223 pp. New York:
Random House. $22. 
HISTORICAL accounts are a wonderful tonic in economics. Unfortunately, the din of economic theory usually drowns them out. But the story of what has actually happened to American capitalism since the Civil War offers a better insight into our problems today than theory, which so often portrays the national economy as if it were a morality play.
The old prosperity is gone. Neither historians nor theorists doubt that. But while the theorists promise redemption if Americans have the good sense or the discipline to adjust their behavior, the historians shake their heads: the circumstances that so favored the United States for more than 100 years have disappeared irrevocably.
Theorists dominate the economics profession and the public debate. Economic historians, a small band, have been pretty much confined to publishing in professional journals. But now Jeffrey Madrick in "The End of Affluence" has brought economic history vividly into the public domain. Perhaps his book was inevitable. For nearly 20 years we have counted on the theorists to make us whole again. Their nostrums haven't done that, and Americans inevitably are turning to other voices as living standards deteriorate for tens of millions of them. Mr. Madrick addresses this yearning, but not by offering five easy steps to a higher standard of living. What we need above all, he says, is self-awareness.
From the Civil War to the early 1970's, no other nation, no matter how advanced technologically, matched our gift for mass production or the special circumstances that so multiplied the national wealth. We became in our own eyes a chosen people. And now we resist acknowledging that our status has changed. "Perhaps we can, in our straitened circumstances, remake our lives on a sounder basis than in the past," Mr. Madrick writes. "But we will not do so by optimistically assuming that this new world has remained as accommodating as its predecessor and all that ails us is that we have taken a wrong moral or ideological turn."
Lacking self-awareness, we are overly swayed by the self-flagellation of so many theorists, executives and politicians. They label as causes what the historians say are only symptoms of the economic malaise. For the historians, the deterioration in our schools is a result of the decline. So is the huge Federal budget deficit and Americans' failure to save more -- a failure that the theorists call profligacy, which deprives the nation of the wherewithal to finance vital investment.
Mr. Madrick is not himself a university-trained economic historian. He is a freelance journalist, a graduate of Harvard Business School, whose first book, "Taking America" (1987), was a historical account of the corporate merger phenomenon. Now he has steeped himself in economic history and synthesized the historians' findings, expressing them more pointedly than they themselves have done. So "The End of Affluence" is unusual: it is important for economists, but accessible to general readers. In the tradition of the economists Robert Heilbroner, Herbert Stein and John Kenneth Galbraith, or the journalist William Greider, Mr. Madrick makes sophisticated economics easy reading.
There are weak spots in his book, the most glaring being his vague suggestions for improving the national lot, although the whole point of his book is that there is no way for America's economy to regain its old, singular status. His various suggestions appear in the final chapter, and they can be ignored.
The history definitely should not be ignored. Nothing is more striking in this book than the author's account of economic growth since the Civil War. For 100 years, until the early 70's, the American economy grew at an average annual rate of 3.4 percent, excluding the effects of inflation. That is, all the output of a factory worker, a lawyer, a blacksmith, a drummer, a truck driver and everyone else, valued in dollars, rose on average by 3.4 percent a year.
No other nation fared as well. The steady profits that came with this robust growth encouraged American capitalists to invest heavily in the machinery and technologies of the day, and that helped to make their workers very productive. Every year they turned out more, collecting part of their rising output in higher wages. And this golden march upward continued despite temporary setbacks from crashes and financial panics. Even the Great Depression counts as only a temporary setback.
Over the last 22 years, however, the nation's economic growth has slowed to 2.3 percent a year on average. The decline of 1.1 percentage points, added up from 1973 through 1993, represents $12 trillion in lost wealth, Mr. Madrick calculates. That $12 trillion, adjusted to reflect the dollar's buying power in 1987, would have paid for the health insurance, pensions, new factories, modern infrastructure and rising incomes whose absence so troubles the nation. It is America's lost prosperity. "The enormity of the $12 trillion shortfall since 1973 can be envisioned in many ways," Mr. Madrick writes. "Twelve trillion dollars is more than enough to have bought each of America's homeowners a new house, or paid off all of our government, mortgage and credit card debt, or replaced all of our nation's factories, including capital equipment, with new ones."
Why did this slowdown occur? The answer lies in mass production, which in the 19th century became America's second frontier. Other nations were equal to the United States, or even superior, in science, education and technology. But they lacked the huge quantities of raw materials necessary for mass production, and a customer base anywhere near the size of the American population to purchase all the output.
MASS production, in turn, gave Americans a golden touch in developing other industries and skills. Railroads arose to carry the goods and link the customers. We outdistanced the world in advertising, innovative management and mass marketing. Only after World War II did Japan and Western Europe get the opportunity to become powerhouses in mass production. Rising world trade, falling tariffs and rapid, inexpensive transportation gave them access to the necessary materials and to overseas customers. Japan in particular made inroads in the American auto market, against managers who did not, at first, recognize the danger.
And then the Japanese and the Europeans got another leg up: mass production lost its overarching importance as a generator of wealth. It gave way to a system of flexible production, which developing nations are also mastering. Instead of making one product or model -- a Ford Mustang, for example -- by the tens of thousands on a single assembly line, new electronic machinery made possible "batch" production. Using computers to change tooling, an assembly line can turn out small quantities of many different products and models. That gave rise to parallel changes in other industries, "as products from banking services to specialty clothing became more varied in order to reach targeted groups of consumers."
American corporations responded slowly, and reluctantly, to the new era, in part because flexible production promised lower returns on their investments than mass production. Mr. Madrick should have told this story in more detail. And he should have taken more notice of Government policies, stretching back to the Carter Administration, that have discouraged economic expansion. But his main point, that even in the best of circumstances corporate America no longer enjoys a special advantage, has been ignored for too long.
The United States is still the wealthiest nation. But as Mr. Madrick notes, the hourly output of American workers rose much more rapidly in the mass production era than may ever be possible in the age of the new "batch" system. And this inevitable slowdown in productivity may one day become the most significant explanation for America's nearly stagnant wage growth and the reluctance of corporations to invest as heavily in expansion as they did in the past.
Not all economic historians are as fatalistic on this point as Mr. Madrick, although they tend in this direction. As he puts it, to claim that the new ways can be as enriching for Americans as the old "requires a leap of faith that our economic experience doesn't yet justify."

HEADLINE: What a Zoo!

BYLINE: By Francine Prose; Francine Prose's new novel is "Hunters and Gatherers."

 BODY:

ANIMAL PLANET
By Scott Bradfield.
231 pp. New York:
Picador USA. $22. 
LONG before animal behaviorists thoroughly convinced us that dear Fido and Mittens have secret inner lives of their own, writers were using our furred and feathered friends to express humankind's deepest hopes and fears, to debate our urgent questions and satirize our foibles. The Persian poet Attar summoned "The Conference of the Birds" to discuss the nature of God, and Chaucer's Nun's Priest invited the barnyard to examine the faults of women. Anatole France took on the follies of religion in "Penguin Island," while George Orwell's "Animal Farm" attacked the porcine cruelties of the totalitarian state.
Now, in keeping with our modern, more global perspective, Scott Bradfield has taken the birds and beasts off the island and the farm to populate his new novel, "Animal Planet." In this inventive satire, Mr. Bradfield (whose previous books include "The History of Luminous Motion") tracks a rebellion in which the animals rise up to overthrow their human oppressors and are defeated -- not by the firepower the military deploys, but by the seductions of media fame and corporate marketing strategies.
The novel's rabble-rousing hero is a well-traveled crow named Charlie, whom we meet haranguing the depressed denizens of the London Zoo. Like the rest of us, these unfortunates have watched their creature comforts steadily decline, and have been obliged to subsist on the seepage from trickle-down economics: "Winter came early that year, and the animals began hearing a lot of 'R' words they couldn't pronounce. Words like 'recession,' 'redundancy' and 'rationalization.' . . . The zoo personnel began to look more pale and unraveled than usual."
With help from "a radical-extremist guerrilla faction of Animal Action!" the animals stage an insurrection inspired by Charlie's rhetoric: "You can form your own government, make your own laws, relearn your own culture. Haven't you guys seen 'Spartacus'?" When the "London Zoo Rebellion" is brutally repressed, Charlie decamps to Antarctica, where he finds his most loyal supporter in a dreamy, alienated penguin named Buster. Penguin Island is pre-emptively invaded by a strike force of humans armed with "tanks, barbed wire . . . history books, foreign trade secretaries, corporate spokespersons and a lot of dumb, well-intentioned military grunts just looking for adventure and a good time."
After this lively preamble, much of Mr. Bradfield's novel is spent detailing the all-too-familiar ways in which the animal revolution is defanged by the consumer planet. A consortium of media and marketing powers decides that Charlie may be the hot new product. He's signed on by a tough-talking literary agent named Bunny. It's not long before Charlie's career takes off, nor is it much longer until his 15 minutes of fame are over -- with disastrous consequences for the whole animal kingdom.
Much of this is funny, and Mr. Bradfield is attempting something admirably large. At its very best, his language can recall the hucksterish high energy of a Stanley Elkin sentence. But these bright instants are separated by intervals during which we may wish that the narrative line were moving along more as the crow flies, so to speak.
The finest satires -- like Orwell's -- have the speed, the directness and the classical simplicity of a knife slicing straight to the bone. But this book lingers on the way to animal apocalypse. Mr. Bradfield clutters his story with dispensable subplots and with minor characters (the grungy, thick-skulled, quasi-nymphomaniacal "Eskimo chick" named Muk Luk) who may cause a queasy frisson even in readers who are far from being slaves to political correctness. Muk Luk suggests an R. Crumb character drawn without the artist's evenhanded and oddly redemptive rage.
Scott Bradfield writes beautifully, and it is a pity that his book isn't a bit more streamlined. The fault may be one of simple misapprehension, of what this novel's talented author fails to realize: though we are endlessly fascinated by animal and human behavior, we may have -- as a species -- a somewhat more limited interest in animals denatured enough to behave like humans.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
The Beckner Effect

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
EARLY LAST MONTH, a friend of mine who trades bonds on Wall Street phoned to tell me about something she called the Beckner Effect. As I understood her, there was this journalist in Washington named Beckner whom no one on Wall Street had ever laid eyes on but whose articles about Federal Reserve Board policy regularly sent the whole of the multitrillion-dollar American bond market into epileptic convulsions. "You are sitting at your desk and you think you've got the market all figured out," my friend explained, "and then all of a sudden there's one of these kamikaze events. The market dives, 10 lights start to flash and everyone at once is calling to ask you if you saw the Beckner article."
A colorful mythology has been created on Wall Street to explain this terrifying invisible force: Beckner has special access to the Fed, Beckner is being used by Alan Greenspan, Beckner is Alan Greenspan. He arrives in the markets like a bolt from the blue and launches his rockets directly onto the neon-green screens on New York trading desks, through something called Market News Service, which, you have to admit, sounds very much like a front for the C.I.A. 
 At any rate, my friend was suspicious. She suggested that I fly down to Washington and find out whether Beckner actually exists and, if so, what he looks like. And so, just after 10 o'clock at night on Sept. 5, I called the Washington office of Market News Service. I expected voice mail. I got a live human being.
"Steve Beckner, please."
"This is he."
I explained my intentions, wondering why this titan who shifted around billions of dollars with a single article by day bothered to hang around an office until 10 o'clock at night or, for that matter, answered the company's switchboard. When I'd finished, there was a long pause on the other end of the line.
"I am aware of the Beckner Effect," he said, but not happily. His subtext translated roughly as: "Leave me alone. I am a humble scribe. It's not my fault that I make and break Wall Street careers."
He agreed to have lunch with me the following week and then returned to whatever he was doing. What he was doing became clear a few hours later, when the following brief message from Beckner flashed across Wall Street's trading floors.
 
08:45 EDT 09/06
YELLEN: EASE POSSIBLE
ON LOW INFL EVEN
IF ECONOMIC GROWTH
ON TRACK
It turned out that Beckner had been waiting for a call from Janet Yellen, the newest governor of the Federal Reserve Board. She told him that it might make sense for the Fed to lower interest rates, even if the economy wasn't headed for a recession. He wrote this up, the bond market jumped three-quarters of a point and every trader in New York leaped for his phone. Beckner had struck again.
Now, as it happens, a few months earlier, I'd also interviewed Janet Yellen. Needless to say, our little talk had no effect on the market. She convinced me in her direct, charming, honest way that she possessed no inside information of obvious value. She studies the same economic data as Wall Street analysts, she said, and her ability to influence Fed policy is negligible. If she were permitted to speculate in the bond market from her office at the Fed, she added, she would probably lose money. In other words, if she kept her views to herself they would be worthless. But when she offers these same views to Beckner, who then beams them onto every trading desk on Wall Street, thousands of people in the market believe that they are worth betting on. That is what is so marvelous about the Beckner Effect.
 I WAS DOING THIS kind of reporting for years before anyone took notice of me," Beckner complained a few days later, as he pushed a particularly adamantine piece of rockfish to the side of his plate in Washington's Occidental Grill. "I don't set out to move markets, and I hope you make that clear." He makes a pair of very strong first impressions. The first is of a Southern yeoman in his mid-40's: Duke degree, khaki suit pressed like an Army uniform, cropped black hair, fit but not overly so. The second is of a man who wants badly to be left alone. Irate Wall Street traders call to scream at him for the money they lost because of some article he has written; he takes no obvious pleasure in this. He remains alienated from his powers, a reluctant Prospero.
There is the feeling about Beckner that he is imprisoned in his role by forces greater than himself. By his own admission, he is not the Voice of Greenspan; he merely chats with Fed governors and staff members whom he has come to know and reports what they say. In the old days, when the bond market was small and sleepy, this job was straightforward; now it is not. The great bond market explosion of the last 15 years, caused by the new American delight in borrowing money, has created, incidentally, a casino filled with people looking for a reason to speculate. At the moment, Beckner is the reason; as a result, he must watch his every semicolon lest some semiliterate bond trader misinterpret his copy and collapse the world economy.
Worse, he cannot escape his condition. No matter what he writes these days, people on Wall Street assign magical properties to his words. It no longer matters whether those words live up to the expectations they create. It no longer matters, for example, whether Janet Yellen's views indicate new Fed policies. She herself illustrated this point nicely, a week after she spoke with Beckner, when she told The Wall Street Journal that she was "anticipating a period of moderate growth at sustainable levels." The Journal article concluded "that doesn't suggest an overwhelming need to lower short-term interest rates."
Actually, we have arrived at a point where it doesn't even matter if any bond traders believe that Yellen's views are intrinsically valuable. All that matters is that a sufficient number of them believe that others think they have value, after Beckner writes them up. They will then buy bonds because they expect others will buy bonds. That is the first irony of the Beckner Effect -- the market believes itself to be at its mercy but it is the market that has created it. The second irony is that the Beckner Effect has no real cause.

HEADLINE: HOME IMPROVEMENT

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
ALL those television shows and books and magazines make it look so easy: you, too, can re-floor the kitchen, hang a door, drill out those soffit vents, Sheetrock the new den, build an addition to the doghouse.
But the part they leave out is not how hard it is to get the job done -- not too hard, as it turns out. What you don't find out until it's too late is how hard it is to stop once you get started. 
 The United States is quickly becoming a nation of amateur carpenters, plumbers, roofers and electricians. Last year, Americans spent $87.7 billion to do it themselves, according to the Home Improvement Research Institute, a hardware industry trade group. That figure reflects a 73 percent increase over the last decade, and a more than threefold increase since 1977.
Whether stalking the cavernous aisles of the 102,000-square-foot Home Depot in Secaucus -- which after only one year in business is eighth in volume among the chain's 393 stores -- or rummaging through boxes of antique shutter hinges at an old-time hardware emporium like Finkel's in Lambertville, homeowners here are fixing up in record numbers.
The trend cuts across demographic and economic lines. For members of The Generation That Will Not Live as Well as Its Parents, doing it yourself is a matter of necessity, the affordable alternative to hiring a contractor or buying a newer, bigger house in better shape.
And playing Mr. Fix-It is no longer the exclusive domain of the beefy guy with a tool belt. The hand that wields the hammer is increasingly likely to belong to a woman, or to a first-timer who still doesn't know a mullion from a monkey wrench.
Home improvement seems to have become this decade's secular religion, much as fitness was in the 1980's. Both offer ways for the alienated worker to rediscover the joys of sweat and toil and production, all in the name of self-empowerment.
It's a positive feedback loop of consumer frenzy: shop for tools and materials, fix up, shop some more and fix up some more.
After all, there's no point letting a tool go to waste; better to invent projects to give them something to do. Have a table saw from the time you decided to build the kids' bunk bed? Why not use it to whip up some shelves? Why let half a bucket of perfectly good tile grout go to waste?
Not that coming up with ideas for projects requires much effort. As anyone who has bought a house or condo knows, there is always something that needs to be fixed or replaced, something that cries out to be upgraded. And with more people working and playing at home more often, the reasons to modify should continue to grow.
Here are the owners of three houses -- two encountered recently at a highway hardware palace, one through deeper connections -- who are hard at work on the lifelong project of home improvement.
 
The Walls Come Down
 
RECENT PROJECTS
* Tore out all walls and ceilings
* Replaced kitchen sink faucet
* Stripped banister
* Pulled thousands of nails out of studs
 
IN THEIR TOOLBOX
16-ounce claw
hammer, broom,
dustpan,
wrenches,
scrapers.
In June, when Jon and Janelle Fantell closed on a 75-year-old, two-story colonial on a quiet street in Colonia, they figured they'd take down the paneling, rip up the carpets, paint the walls and move right in. The last Sunday of the summer, however, found Mr. Fantell at the Home Depot in Woodbridge, buying yet another 10-pack of disposable dust masks. For their first-ever do-it-yourself project, the couple are tearing apart their new home.
The Fantells' demolition spree began when they discovered there was no insulation in the perimeter walls. They decided to knock down the plaster-and-lath walls and insulate. While they had the walls down, they figured they'd bring the wiring up to code with the help of a friend who is an electrician.
Then they decided to rewire the walls between the rooms, too.
Then a friend who came to look at the house had some reservations about the ceiling.
"He took one look at the paneling and said, 'That ceiling's got to go,' " Mr. Fantell said. "In half an hour we had ripped the whole thing down."
Two months later, the Fantells and Mrs. Fantell's 16-year-old godson, armed only with claw hammers, have banged down and pried off several thousand square feet of plaster-and-lath walls and ceilings and hauled hundreds of shopping bags of debris out to the trash. Mr. Fantell, a 34-year-old accountant who had never attempted any project more ambitious than assembling a bookcase from a kit until this summer, is still a little amazed at the way the project has taken on a life of its own.
"Every time I think it's time to stop there's a voice that says, you've gone this far; do it."
With that, he prepared to take apart the last remaining room, a former kitchen that will be his office.
After attempting to pry off the baseboard cover, hitting himself in the temple with a crowbar, borrowing a hacksaw from the neighbor, cutting through nailstaping plastic over the radiator fins, Mr. Fantell was ready. He and Mrs. Fantell's godson, Eric Curcio, slipped on their dust masks and began pounding.
Soon the hollow thud of exploding plaster gave way to the satisfying crunch of the lath breaking underneath. In 20 minutes, the 15-foot wall was reduced to a heap of dusty rubble.
Mr. Fantell, a quiet, reflective man who studies martial arts, has a theory about the addictive appeal of fixing up a house. "Everything today moves at a very quick pace, and people feel they're losing control of their lives" he said. "When you get down to it, I think doing home improvement is a microcosmic way of taking control. You see immediate feedback, and you get immediate gratification."
But if Mr. Fantell is the house philosopher, his wife is the visionary. She took one look at the dingy, dog-stained carpets and depressing paneling and saw a dream house underneath.
"This house has charm," she said. "I love the big porch, the wide, curved staircase as soon as you walk in the door, the large room sizes, the high ceilings."
She said her dreams of a pale, pale lavender living room, a somewhere-between-white-and-seafoam dining room and ornate woodwork on the big old porch have kept her going through a summer of heavy manual labor.
"Basically," she said, "at the end of the day, you take a shower, blow your nose 50 times, sleep for a little while and do it over again."
 
Learning by Doing
 
RECENT PROJECTS
* Exposed two brick fireplaces
* Spackled and painted
* Took up kitchen floor with a crowbar
* Stripped kitchen cabinet
* Tiled a contertop
* Redesigned kitchen
* Wired six phone lines
* installed indoor shutters
 
IN HER TOOLBOX
Jig saw, electric
screwdriver,
professional
paintbrushes,
hammers,
pliers, scrapers, sanders.
In the flooring aisle of the Home Depot in Secaucus, Holly Krupp is having a friendly disagreement with Clyde the tile guy. She has just spent the morning covering a new counter in the kitchen of her Hoboken brownstone condo with glossy, snowy white ceramic tile, and now Clyde, her old friend, is trying to tell her she goofed.
"For a kitchen, you should have used matte tile," he tells her. "You put a glass of water on that and it'll slide across the counter."
Ms. Krupp has a lot of faith in Clyde's judgment, but not this time. She shoots him a look and returns her attention to the other tile guy, who is custom-cutting the three tiles that require double cuts to fit around the corners of the cabinet with the beautiful glass-paneled doors -- panels she discovered by scratching off seven layers of paint after friends told her to throw it out.
Ms. Krupp, a 33-year-old saleswoman to the pharmaceutical industry, has only been tiling counters for a few hours, but she knows what she likes. And in any case, she's not afraid to make mistakes.
"I didn't even know how to use the tile cutter I bought," she said. "After I made the cuts, I was trying to break the tiles with my hands before I figured out you have to press down on the handle. It's a little scary, but if you screw it up, you screw it up. The worst thing that can happen is that your friends come over and say, 'What did you do to your countertop?' "
What she did was cleanly tile a many-angled, nine-sided counter in less than half a day, not counting the trip to Home Depot.
In the two years since she bought her condo, Ms. Krupp, who learned to tinker growing up in a family of mechanics and antique dealers, has also spackled and painted the whole place, scraped and regrouted the bathroom floors and walls, retiled the bath, wired all six phone lines for her home office, and liberated a fireplace from behind a thick prison of plaster and brick -- another project her contractor friend told her to forget about.
"When I took the first brick out where it had been bricked over, all this soot fell out onto the floor, and it kept coming and coming," she said. "It was like a black volcano."
One project always leads to another. Turning the kitchen counter into a tiled eating nook meant she had to move a little silverware chest. To get the chest under the cabinets on the other side of the kitchen, she had to saw off the molding. So she bought a jigsaw and did the job in a minute. Now she plans to use the jigsaw to cut a chair rail for her bedroom.
Sadly, though, she will be moving out soon -- she and her boyfriend are planning to get married. "But I'll never sell this place," she said. "I'll always keep it as an investment. It's got a lot of my heart in it."
 
Buried Treasure
 
RECENT PROJECTS
* Repaired roof and cornices
* Rebuilt deck
* Built window casings
* Insulated attic
* Installed kitchen cabinets
* Scraped, primed, and painted exterior

IN THEIR TOOLBOX

cabinet scraper, mill

(rented), miter saw,
dovetail saw, hole saw, table saw, hot gun, drill, electric nail driver, reciprocating saw, power sander, doweling jig.
For their 10th anniversary, my brother Michael bought his wife a router. Practical as it may seem, the gift was an exceedingly sentimental one, a measure of the degree of their devotion to the boxy, 130-year-old handyperson's special along the Delaware that they have spent most of the past five years fixing up.
At the start, most of the work had to be done on the outside -- otherwise, pretty soon there wouldn't have been an inside. "The roofs were all falling apart," Mr. Newman recalled. "All kinds of structural members were rotten. The windows were a disaster. Two back walls had no siding, just tar paper over rotting chipboard. Nobody had maintained it for like 50 years."
The two classical guitarists, both now 37, went to work. Come tar-blistering heat, shattering cold and countless broken nails, assisted only by our younger brother, they shingled, hammered, planed, scraped, flashed, drilled and painted.
The house looks impressive now, done up in colors with old-house-catalog names like Bracken House Biscuit and Dusty Sage, even though it is unmistakably still a work in progress. Vines creep over the stack of spare windows donated by a neighbor. Leftover bricks from a recent patio project -- Laura Oltman now knows how to operate a 65-pound jackhammer -- are piled up nearby. "We've accepted the permanence of having a ratty house," she said cheerfully.
Recently, Mr. Newman and Ms. Oltman have been able to focus more attention on the interior. Ms. Oltman, who now does most of the work, used her router to mill the beads on the historically accurate window and door casings in the kitchen. The job, like many others, was made considerably more difficult by the settled old house's uneven angles, archaic building materials and a previous owner's attempts at restoration. "He did a lot of remuddling, as opposed to remodeling," Ms. Oltman said.
This year, the couple are celebrating their fifth anniversary in the house by scraping and touching up their four-year-old exterior paint job. It gives them a sense of history. They can't imagine ever moving out, though they think the house, newly fortified, might outlive them.

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Signed and Sealed. And Hold the Mustard.

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
CURBSIDE in front of the Essex County Hall of Records in Newark, two customers waited idly under the striped canvas awning at the hot dog truck. Besides hot dogs, the menu offered coffee, soda, cigarettes, meatball and sausage sandwiches, western omelets, egg with Taylor Pork Roll and, in big letters, NOTARY PUBLIC .
Notary public? 
 Sam Kanan, the proprietor, pushed a pile of onions to the edge of the grill with his spatula. "Today you got to do everything to make a living," he explained.
"People used to come up with the papers and ask, where do I get the notary?" he went on. "We always sent them down to the bank, a pretty good walk." He tapped his temple with a finger. "Then I think, O.K., Sam, how come you're not doing that here with the hot dogs?"
So he and his helper, John Ali, working out of an old blue Chevy panel hot dog truck with two ventilators twirling like toy tops on the roof, obtained their certifications and seals, and took on a sideline as notaries.
Do not, incidentally, ask them how business is.
 "Terrible!" cried Mr. Kanan, who immigrated here from Jerusalem.
He dug into a cardboard box above the freezer and pulled out a recent, but very creased, clipping -- an outraged letter to the editor in The Star-Ledger. The writer was a West Orange woman, fuming that when she went to the Hall of Records recently for a business application, a clerk "instructed me to look for the hot dog truck parked outside of the building to obtain a notary seal." There, she wrote, "the man with the notary seal was quite adept at simultaneously mincing onions and witnessing signatures, and the papers were taken care of with nary a dab of mustard to besmirch them."
Sarcasm aside, Mr. Kanan had no problem with that part. He never gets mustard on your papers. What caused trouble was that the letter writer complained about having to wait in a "long line" behind people ordering hot dogs to get her papers notarized.
The hot dog business is extremely competitive. "Everybody sees 'long lines for the hot dogs'!" Mr. Kanan wailed.
" 'Long lines' in the paper!" Mr. Ali said.
"You know what happened?" Mr. Kanan said. "The next day, a new hot dog truck, he reads 'long lines,' he comes in across the street!" Mr. Kanan turned to glare at the competitor's truck. He also scowled down the block at another hot dog man who showed up with a pushcart.
"You see long lines now?" Mr. Kanan demanded.
Mr. Kanan bought the truck 10 years ago. On a good week, he said, it clears $300. (The men charge $1 to $1.25 a page to notarize documents.) Weekdays, they arrive at 6 A.M. and stay till after 4. Mr. Kanan works nights as a security guard. Some weekends, he drives a cab.
Mr. Kanan and Mr. Ali, who both live in Jersey City, arrived in America with the great wave of legal immigration that started in 1965, when a new Federal law opened the gates to millions of non-Europeans.
"First, I wash dishes six days a week," Mr. Kanan recalled. "Twelve hours a day. The pay for a week was $85. But step by step, I saved a few bucks."
As he got on his feet, Mr. Kanan sponsored relatives, including his cousin Mr. Ali.
"I found a job for him in a Greek diner. Hoboken," Mr. Kanan said.
Laughing, Mr. Ali recalled, "I thought I was going to come to America, work hard and get rich in one month."
Nobody got rich. In old urban areas that no longer have the good industrial jobs that gave previous generations of immigrants a leg up into the middle class, you were lucky just to stay off welfare. For immigrants in a post-industrial service economy, there are not many Horatio Alger stories.
"You work for enough money to pay the bills," said Mr. Kanan.
"College someday for the kids," added Mr. Ali.
And somewhere along the line, the American Dream acquired a tinge of irony for the working stiffs.
"One day, maybe next year, we're going to rip out the roof of the truck, put in second floor for a lawyer's office," Mr. Kanan joked. "Raise the rent on a lawyer," Mr. Ali suggested gleefully. "Maybe add an office for selling Lotto."
Mr. Kanan had a better idea. "No! We make a motor vehicles office up there."
But the chatter ended abruptly when a customer appeared at the window. The lunch crowd was on its way.
"Could I have a sausage, no sauce?" the young woman asked.
Mr. Kanan dashed for the grill. "Yes!" he said. "Right away! Pepsi?"

HEADLINE: WHO WILL FACE THE MUSIC?

 BODY:
In response to Elizabeth Kolbert's article "Who Will Face the Music?" (Aug. 27), I would like to offer another take on Social Security and generational shifting.
I think the issue of generational shift is not well understood. Obviously even the whiny Generation X will inherit a gross domestic product that is considerably larger than the one their parents inherited. The pie may not be growing as fast as it did in the 50's and 60's, but it is still growing pretty substantially. The people who make the contributions, sacrifices, investments, inventions, etc. (and suffer the layoffs) that contribute to the bigger pie are essentially laying a claim to it when they retire. If they work 45 years, and the pie is 150 percent of what it was when they started, are they entitled to a piece of the upside? 
 After all, Social Security doesn't work like a piggy bank. We get paid back out of the real economy that exists when we collect it. And when people spend their Social Security money, they create jobs and demand. It's no accident that health care is one of the real growth areas for working-class jobs in the United States.
It is also not a very good point (though often made) that the regressiveness of Social Security taxes is offset by the fact that Social Security provides a larger share of the income of average people than of rich people. That is merely a way of stating that the retired wealthy have a lot more income. The $800 or so per month that Social Security recipients get is not a lot of money. Would it be better if Generation X'ers inherited a large group of indigent elderly? Would that be less of a burden?
Clearly, it would be a plus if all of us saved and invested more. The pie would grow faster. It would be easier to pay us off when we retire. But that is a lot to ask of average Americans, whose income and wealth are stagnant. People do what they must to maintain their standard of living: when the country is in a great growth phase, they save a lot; when the country is in a retrenchment phase, they consume a larger percentage of their income.
 
RICHARD C. LEONE
New York

HEADLINE: Millionaires By the Dozen

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
A FEW years back, Jonathan Yarmis, a personal computer expert, was wooed by the Microsoft Corporation. While Mr. Yarmis was flattered by the overture, he decided not to join Microsoft, the Redmond, Wash., software giant.
"If I went out there, I figured I'd just be another Microsoft millionaire," Mr. Yarmis recalled. "But here, you have real influence. Individually, your views and opinions have a real impact on the computer industry." 
 Mr. Yarmis, after all, is now a vice president of the Gartner Group Inc. Who?
Gartner will probably never be mentioned in the same breath as such marquee brand names of computing as Microsoft, Intel, I.B.M. and Apple. Nonetheless, Gartner, a specialty publisher based here, is a behind-the-scenes power to be reckoned with, even by those industry giants.
Gartner has become the key adviser to corporate America as it wrestles with the chaotic world of information technology. The personal computer revolution and the spread of computer networks, like the Internet, have dispersed and accelerated the pace of technology's advance in the workplace. Years ago, there were a comparative handful of computer-product choices for corporate shoppers to make; now there are thousands. And new versions of products come out every few months instead of several years apart.
To sort through the blizzard of offerings and hype from the computer industry, companies look outside for help and advice. Most often, they turn to Gartner. And so influential are its views about what equipment, software and services to buy -- and to avoid -- that Gartner can help make or break a product. Even Microsoft's eagerly awaited Windows 95 operating system felt Gartner's impact, with corporate sales affected by its early recommendation that most companies wait six to nine months before buying, to allow bugs to be fixed.
Such power has made Gartner envied, and feared. And as its reach expands in a bid for further growth, questions have been raised about whether Gartner's research can stay independent when the company is increasingly analyzing products of customers it is also advising.
While it has rivals, Gartner, by all accounts, is unmatched in the scope of its research, covering everything from the World Wide Web to mainframe disk drives. Its recommendations are shrewdly packaged, typically in punchy two-page notes, sent by E-mail, fax or mail.
Its analysts are encouraged to be provocative and opinionated. And they brag that they are not journalists; no wishy-washy balancing of "on the one hand, on the other hand" for them. For this, and ready access to the analyst-authors, companies pay lavishly, $19,000 a year for each of Gartner's 47 services, though companies taking several services receive discounts. Roughly 600 companies now pay Gartner more than $100,000 each a year.
So far, the Gartner formula has proved successful -- and quite lucrative in the last few years. So lucrative, in fact, that Gideon I. Gartner, who founded the company in 1979 and then walked away at the end of 1990 with an estimated $24 million in total gains, is getting back into the business to challenge the company that bears his name. The battle promises to be an interesting one, given Mr. Gartner's track record and his ability to attract deep-pocketed investors.
For now, though, the company's good fortune has meant sudden affluence for Gartner staff members like Mr. Yarmis. He passed up his chance to be a "Microsoft millionaire" -- one of the many Microsoft employees who have grown wealthy on the runup in the company's stock price -- but the 40-year-old Mr. Yarmis is assuredly a "Gartner millionaire," thanks to his Gartner share options and the surge in that stock. In fact, since Gartner went public two years ago, its share price, including stock splits, has jumped fivefold -- a better performance than Microsoft's during that period.
Manuel Fernandez, the president and chief executive of Gartner, says there are about 150 Gartner millionaires among the company's rapidly growing work force of over 1,000. And he is hoping to see more. Today, 450 employees receive stock options, including all of its 215-member corps of analysts. Of the company's $1.4 billion value on the stock market, about 15 percent is held by management. Indeed, in terms of wealth created for its workers, Gartner may well be the richest publishing house in the world -- a "mini-Microsoft" in its field, though that business, to be sure, is a hybrid niche of publishing.
"One of the things I'm most proud of is that by being successful we've been able to make so many of our people rich," said Mr. Fernandez, 49, who has a gain on his shares of more than $30 million.
Many of the Gartner workers have profited so handsomely in part because of the tumultuous ownership history of the company. Seven years after Mr. Gartner founded it, the company went public -- for the first time -- in 1986. Two years later, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. acquired Gartner in the London advertising agency's ill-starred plan to become a diversified professional services company. Soon after, with losses mounting, Saatchi was forced to sell its nonadvertising businesses.
In late 1990, Saatchi sold Gartner to a leveraged buyout group led by Gartner management, the business publisher Dun & Bradstreet and the venture capital arm of Bain & Company, a management consulting firm. It is mostly those Gartner employees who were with the company by then, or joined shortly after, who are sitting on the biggest gains from their low-cost options -- some granted for as little as 3 cents a share.
Gartner went public for the second time in October 1993, with the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation holding onto a 50 percent stake. Since then, the public shareholders in Gartner have prospered as well, given the fivefold rise in the share price, to $32.75 at Friday's close.
THE runup in Gartner stock reflects the company's rapid growth. In its fiscal year ended yesterday, analysts' estimates are that Gartner's net income will rise more than 60 percent, to $24.5 million, on revenues of $225 million, up 33 percent. And Gartner's stock price-to-earnings ratio of 58 times -- compared with an average for the Standard & Poor's 500 of 17 -- reflects Wall Street's expectation that the company's ascent will continue apace.
"Gartner has a lot of untapped market potential and not a lot of competition," said Eric Philo, an analyst for Goldman Sachs & Company.
Indeed, Gartner has an aggressive growth strategy. The company recently started a computer on-line service, called @vantage, distributed initially over AT&T's Interchange network. But there are plans for perhaps adding another on-line service, like the Microsoft Network, and eventually using the Internet. The on-line offering is a crucial step in Gartner's goal to add more subscribers in large companies and attract new customers in small companies.
Inside Gartner, the growth targets have been set at 25 to 30 percent annually over the next five years. If successful, that would give Gartner annual sales nearing $1 billion by 2000 or so.
"To grow at that rate, we definitely have to perform well, but the underlying demand is there," Mr. Fernandez said. "We're riding the wave of rapid change, as more people within companies have to use and really understand information technology to manage their businesses and survive in today's economy."
But Gartner faces daunting challenges in trying to achieve its goal. There are the internal problems of managing rapid growth in a professional organization, like Gartner, without watering down the quality of the firm's people, research and reputation. Yet there are also coming assaults on its franchise from rivals.
Today, Gartner has no genuine peer. Its competition comes mainly from a group of smaller, private firms, including META Group Inc., Forrester Research Inc. and the Yankee Group. Other well-known technology publishing firms, notably Dataquest and the International Data Corporation, are primarily market researchers that advise computer suppliers instead of assessing products and technology for users.
The largest and fastest-growing of Gartner's rivals, analysts estimate, is probably META, at roughly $30 million a year in revenues. Founded in 1989 by two ex-Gartner staffers, META is also the most direct competitor to Gartner. Forrester offers technology research for mainly top-level corporate executives, while Yankee tends to compete with Gartner only in certain specialties, like telecommunications.
But things are expected to change. The stepped-up competition will likely come from META, which is investing heavily to challenge Gartner, and from a new rival, Gideon Gartner.
When Saatchi bought the company in 1988, Mr. Gartner agreed to stay on through the end of 1990. By then, he was independently wealthy, and he insists his plan had always been to retire early to Aspen, Colo., where he has a home. A philanthropist and an accomplished amateur pianist and French horn player, he figured he had plenty of other interests and didn't need business anymore.
But he admits he changed his mind after a few years. Along with a few ex-Gartner colleagues and a group of investors, Mr. Gartner, now 60, has purchased BIS Strategic Decisions, a small market research firm. Mr. Gartner says BIS, based in Norwell, Mass., gives him a modest going business, but is just a small first step toward taking on his old company.
Mr. Gartner's contractual agreement not to compete with the Gartner Group expired last summer. BIS has already been folded into his new company, Giga Information Group Inc. (The name was chosen, he says, for its techie connotations, as in "gigabyte," a measure of computer memory; but "Giga" is also formed by the first two letters of the founder's first and last names.) Giga, Mr. Gartner explains, will not really be bringing its new service into the corporate market until 1996, so he is saying little about his strategy for fear of tipping his hand to competitors.
But Mr. Gartner did say he plans for Giga to be a $500 million-a-year business within five years, passing META as the No. 2 firm in the field, and becoming "a strong competitor to Gartner."
"I'm not in it to do a small-time operation," Mr. Gartner said.
Marc Butlein, META's chairman, takes issue with Mr. Gartner's assessment. He, not his one-time boss, plans to be the Gartner Group's strongest rival. Mr. Butlein calls Gartner a "superb publisher," but he believes that it has slipped on the follow-up service -- typically one-to-one phone calls by a client to an analyst.
Some corporate customers echo that theme. Robert Gilchrist, the chief information officer for Corning Inc., a specialty glass and optical fiber maker, says he has recently shifted more of its technology-assessment spending from Gartner to META. "For a long time, Gartner was the only one," Mr. Gilchrist explained. "We didn't seem to matter much to Gartner, but we do seem to matter to META."
Still, Gartner's growth both in revenues and in number of corporate accounts, more than doubling in the last four years to 4,980 companies with 63,000 individual recipients of its services, suggests that dissatisfaction with Gartner is not widespread.
Jack Cooper, vice president of information management at the Bristol Myers Squibb Company, is a satisfied customer, subscribing to several Gartner services. "Gartner plays an important role, given all the product introductions and the rate of obsolescence in technology," he said. "And no one has Gartner's depth of research."
Indeed, the complaint sometimes heard from computer hardware and software suppliers is not that Gartner's grip on the market is slipping but that it is too powerful. Some suppliers contend that in their penchant for strong opinions, Gartner analysts can be one-sided and unfair. Last June, Computer Associates International Inc., a large software company, decided to no longer give briefings to Gartner analysts, after a series of negative Gartner reports.
"Gartner just seemed to have some deep-seated bias against us," said Sanjay Kumar, president of Computer Associates. "We think that Gartner is able to do significant damage to our company by slamming our products."
YET most suppliers would not dare shun Gartner because it is such a crucial ingredient in how corporate buying decisions are made.
"Gartner takes positions that you may or may not agree with," said Bob McDowell, vice president of Microsoft's marketing to large companies. "But there's room for honest disagreement. And there's no question that Gartner is a very respected adviser to our customers."
The Gartner research is what corporate America respects most. It is churned out by the company's cadre of analyst-authors, mostly in their late 30's and 40's, who typically come to Gartner after a decade or so of industry experience. Once at Gartner, they go through a one-week boot camp to be schooled in the company's research methodology and culture. They are told to produce "hard-hitting, actionable advice." The pace is quick; projects last from a few hours to a few days. They are coached in public speaking and presentation. "Being an industry guru," one Gartner executive said, "is partly show business."
At Gartner meetings, they speak of "probabilities," "business drivers," "exit strategies" and "scenarios." Confessions of ignorance or indecision are not welcomed.
Scott Winkler, a 38-year-old vice president who specializes in computer operating systems, joined Gartner in 1993, after years at I.B.M. and then Sequent Computer, which makes large commercial computers. He came to Gartner, he says, to be "visible in the industry and become a guru." These days, he works 60-hour weeks, speaking at conferences, meeting with clients and writing research reports -- "mostly on evenings and weekends," he says. Last year, he logged 120,000 miles, traveling as far as Australia and Brazil.
"It's a worldwide job, and you often have to do it face to face," Mr. Winkler said. "For clients, the analyst contact, over the phone or in person, is certainly as valuable as the published material. For us, those contacts are a crucial part of our research."
Mr. Fernandez agrees, and he insists Gartner's network of contacts with corporate users will make the company difficult to challenge.
"The franchise here is the user community that we are part of," he said. "That's the real barrier to entry. Somebody else can throw money at this business, but they cannot duplicate that network of contacts, certainly not easily and certainly not anytime soon."

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Prepared to Pack Up, Investors Await Earnings

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
THE common wisdom is that today's investors are bulls looking for stock prices to continue their seemingly inexorable climb or bears preparing for a big correction any minute. The apparently rare animal in the current Wall Street environment is the deer -- grazing but nervous and ready to bolt at the slightest sign of danger.
"When the market is ready to get spooked, it's going to happen," said Kenneth Fisher, a fund manager based in La Honda, Calif. "But I don't think it's ready. Most people seem to be looking for clues about when to rotate to new sectors of the market rather than when to get out." 
 One development that could change all that, though, would be a heavy shower of disappointments in the third quarter earnings figures that soon will be pouring across the financial wires. The most damaging situation would probably be a combination of disappointments from bellwether stocks in the high-flying technology sector and below-expectations profits from blue chip stocks in those other sectors where many investors instinctively turn when the markets run into trouble.
"If investors saw a weakness in a company like Philip Morris on the same day Intel came in below estimate, that would definitely put some pressure on the market," said Ben Zacks, executive vice president at Zacks Investment Service, a Chicago-based firm that tracks Wall Street analysts' estimates. "But you'd need quite a few results like that within a couple days to really affect the psychology."
The technology sector is the most frequently mentioned because its growth has led the market upward and there are still high expectations for it. Intel, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Micron are all among the 10 stocks that led the rise this year of the S.& P. index of 500 stocks.
The plunge of Advanced Micro Devices, from $33.25 on Sept. 22 to Friday's close of $29.125, after it warned that third quarter earnings won't meet Wall Street's projections, showed how quickly investors will jump ship. But analysts say it would take negative surprises from leaders like Intel, Texas Instruments and I.B.M. to create more than a day or two of consternation. In any other quarter Microsoft might be added to that list, but the heavily promoted debut of Windows 95 has made this quarter's results a poor indicator of pricing and demand for software in general.
A major sector selloff, however, could be ignited by poor results from several secondary high-tech players even if the leaders come through well, according to David Schulman, managing director of investment strategy at Salomon Brothers. "People might assume there is a general weakness that will hit the bellwethers in the next quarter," Mr. Schulman said.
Disappointments in the high tech sector will not really scare Wall Street, though, unless they are coupled with troubles in areas normally seen as relatively safe in a downturn. Should the tech sector falter, the ability of companies like Philip Morris, Kellogg, Anheuser-Busch, Merck, Abbott Laboratories and the larger utilities to meet expectations would become more critical. "People would look at companies like Merck and say, 'If we can't count on the stable earners, who can we count on?' " said Melissa R. Brown, director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities.
Some companies are seen as dual-purpose barometers. Kellogg, for instance, not only represents stable if slow growth but also reflects the impact of currency changes because so much of its business is overseas. Although Kellogg's earnings will be among those reported toward the end of the cycle, it could influence market sentiment because a disappointment would likely include a stronger-than-projected impact of the strengthening dollar (which makes overseas profits look smaller).
"It could be seen as a red flag for other companies likely to be affected by a stronger dollar," said Raymond Urban, chief investment strategist for Duff & Phelps in Chicago.
After high tech, the two sectors that have portfolio managers most twitchy at the moment are probably financial services and commodities. The long economic expansion has Wall Street watching warily for earnings shortfalls that might show that banks have become overzealous lenders or that financial service firms are piling up bad credit, according to E. Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. American Express and BankAmerica would be among the bellwethers, he said.
On the commodity front, Alcoa, International Paper and Phelps Dodge are among those coming in for scrutiny. Safian Investment Research in White Plains, figures that machinery companies that ride the economic cycle, like Caterpillar, are ready for a downturn. But cyclical commodity producers like Alcoa should still be reporting relatively strong earnings. If Alcoa were to report a significant shortfall of the sort Caterpillar warned of recently, it would be much more disturbing, according to Kurt Walter, a Safian analyst.
One thing that's foolish, analysts say, is to project what might happen over all this quarter from the advance warnings issued by Caterpillar and other companies that will come in below expectations. "There were a lot of preannouncements in the second quarter but it turned out well over all," said Ms. Brown of Oppenheimer. "We have another week or so of them to go now and then it's on to the real thing."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
As Mortgage Rates Drop, Choices Rise

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THE menu of mortgage options is becoming a buffet, with nearly every variation conceivable.
While mortgage rates are bouncing around near historic lows, a few home buyers are forgoing the promise of a low fixed-rate loan for 15 or 30 years. This group of borrowers, albeit a small one, is choosing adjustable-rate loans -- often with a twist. 
 The standard adjustable loan carries a rate that adjusts each year. Some others, sometimes called hybrids, carry a fixed rate for 3, 5, 7 or 10 years and then adjust each year. But to convince finicky borrowers that an adjustable-rate loan could be good for them, lenders are promoting a type that adjusts every three years or five years, rather than annually, after the initial period.
"These loans have been around for a while," said Bruce R. Lublin, a mortgage banker with the Homerica Mortgage Corporation, which has offices in Harrison, N.Y., and Westport, Conn. "But they were overshadowed by the other kinds of A.R.M.'s. Recently, though, as buyers learn more about different mortgages, we are finding that more people are taking the 3-3's and 5-5's," which are loans that adjust every three or five years.
The monthly payment is smaller on an adjustable loan than on a fixed-rate loan, accounting for much of the adjustable loan's appeal. But psychologically, the leap is great. Home buyers worry about the havoc an adjustable loan could some day cause for their household budgets. The promise of less frequent adjustments can calm those fears.
 Generally, borrowers pay slightly higher rates for loans that adjust every three years or five years than they would for loans that adjust annually after three or five years of predictable payments.
At Homerica, the difference is 0.25 of a percentage point. Homerica is offering a loan that adjusts every three years at an initial rate of 5.5 percent with 2.75 points down, or 6.25 percent with 1.25 points down. A point is a fee paid by the borrower, generally, at closing, that is equal to 1 percent of the loan amount. If the borrower is willing to accept annual adjustments after three years, Homerica's initial rates fall to 5.25 percent and 6 percent, respectively.
At least 30 lenders across the nation offer loans that adjust every three or five years, said Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president with HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J. "They are dusting the product off, scraping the bottom of the barrel to get people to go with adjustables," he said.
Lenders prefer to make adjustable-rate loans -- except when rates are abnormally high -- because these loans entail less risk than fixed loans. If rates rise, so will a borrower's payments.
For borrowers, an often-used guideline for deciding between a fixed or adjustable loan -- unless rates are very high or very low -- is to take a loan with a rate fixed for the number of years you plan to live in the home. If you plan to stay five years, you can have five years of small payments and not worry about the annual adjustments that would follow. If you are unsure, though, you might like a loan that will adjust after five years, and not again for five more. Only about 23 percent of borrowers chose adjustable-rate mortgages in August, down from 59 percent in January, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board in Washington. Fixed-rate loans have gained appeal as rates have fallen. As of Wednesday, HSH Associates said the interest rate on the average 30-year loan was 7.91 percent, compared with 5.88 percent for a one-year adjustable-rate loan.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
How to Succeed in Nonprofits by Really Trying

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN John Whitehead was co-chairman of Goldman Sachs from 1976 to 1984, it was held up as the epitome of the well-managed Wall Street firm. It made money and it ran smoothly.
Now Mr. Whitehead is trying to bring some of those same management skills to the nonprofit world. In what he calls the third stage of his life, after Goldman Sachs and service as Deputy Secretary of State, he has presided as chairman or president over several venerable institutions, from Harvard University's Board of Overseers and the Brookings Institution, to the Trustees Council of the National Gallery of Art and the Greater New York Councils/Boy Scouts of America. 
 But he is not content simply to bring his own management counsel to the boardrooms of a Rolodex of nonprofit organizations. He has a broader aim: to improve the whole art of managing nonprofit organizations. To that end, he is giving $10 million to the Harvard Business School to endow the John C. Whitehead Fund for Not-for-Profit Management.
His goal is to encourage several developments: research in nonprofit management techniques, teaching of these techniques, and more emphasis on training business school students and managers of nonprofit groups.
"I became fascinated by nonprofits," Mr. Whitehead said. "Their reach is much bigger than I realized. One out of every 10 workers in the United States works for a nonprofit. And if you add in the volunteer time, it's even greater."
"But I came to realize that while people who run nonprofits are fully committed, they are not very good managers, and nonprofits are not very well run," Mr. Whitehead said.
Sometimes they are not on the up-and-up either, as Mr. Whitehead has learned the hard way. Earlier this year, after he had planned his gift to Harvard, he and other prominent businessmen were embarrassed to learn that they had foolishly lent their names to the New Era for Philanthropy, a charity based near Philadelphia that was essentially a giant Ponzi scheme. New Era for Philanthropy filed for bankruptcy protection in May, and it and its president, John G. Bennett Jr., have been charged with fraud.
But the more common problem, one he has seen much of since he became involved in the nonprofit world during his years at Goldman Sachs, is a lack of management expertise. That is something he can offer, although he is quick to add: "Just to show that I don't know everything, I went on the board of a regional theater that went out of business." He declines to name the theater.
He describes himself as a sucker for getting involved in nonprofit groups, and said he has a particular affinity for the ones that need help, "not just the big prestigious ones, but some of the little, weak ones." The list, he says in an embarrassed tone, is too long to enumerate, because someone might think he does not have time for so much.
But he is disciplined in his approach, spending the first hour of each day in his Park Avenue office working on business for AEA Investors Inc., a private investment company of which he is chairman. The rest of the day, sometimes starting with a 7:30 breakfast meeting and going through a late dinner, is devoted to his menagerie of nonprofit institutions.
"He does so many things, but the remarkable thing is that he does it all so effectively," said William Boardman Jr., director of university capital giving at Harvard. "His very special capacity is to focus and not to waste time, and he's very insightful."
Mr. Whitehead has given one other $10 million gift, to Haverford College, "my other first love," where he was an undergraduate, and other nonprofit groups say he has been generous.
He described his own philosophy that good citizens need to be generous in both time and money. Having had the "good fortune to make all this money," he said, "I say somewhat facetiously that by giving it back, it will come out even at the end."
When he started discussions with John H. McArthur, dean of the Harvard Business School, a couple of years ago, he discovered that several faculty members there had been talking about doing more on nonprofit management. Mr. Whitehead held out the prospect of a large gift if they could develop a productive plan.
The group did more than plan. Research has begun to build. Courses have been added (elective courses on Social Entrepreneurship and on Field Studies in Social Enterprise). Case studies are being written. An eight-day advanced management program for executives who run nonprofit groups attracted 50 participants last spring (at a subsidized price of $3,000), and another session will be held next year.
Satisfied that the commitment was there, Mr. Whitehead told the school he was ready to make the gift. Even though Mr. McArthur is stepping down today, to be succeeded as dean by Kim Clark, Mr. McArthur has promised the nonprofit initiative would remain a priority, and that he will stay involved with it.
Despite the new attention, it is unlikely that nonprofit management will ever be a main theme for the school. The M.B.A. class of 1996, for example, has only 40 students out of 807 who came out of government, education or nonprofit jobs. Even though 10 percent of the class of 1995 cited working with a nonprofit group as their career goal after graduation, the school sent only 11 students into those fields. "The financial pressures are very high," Mr. Whitehead said.
But Mr. Whitehead said he did not worry that nonprofit management would be a stepchild at the business school. He said the new course on social entrepreneurship was oversubscribed last spring, when more than 10 percent of the second year class signed up for it, instead of the 60 that had originally been set as the limit.
"Usually elective courses start small and build their reputations," Mr. Whitehead said. "But this was very successful. I was just delighted."
He spoke of the growing interest among business students, who know they are likely to serve as directors of nonprofit groups, as he and so many other business executives do now; and the growing recognition that they should know more when they do.
"I believe more of this kind of program, and more scholarship, will help," he said.
That is not to say that Mr. Whitehead sees such programs as curing all ills. He does not think that better education would have stopped the scandal involving the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy.
New Era persuaded sophisticated executives like Mr. Whitehead to funnel money they wanted to contribute to other charities through New Era, saying that it would be matched after six months. The participation of top business leaders like Mr. Whitehead helped attract other donors.
"New Era was a real tragedy," said Mr. Whitehead, who stands to lose up to $1 million in the bankruptcy. "I doubt that a program like this would have lessened the problem. If you have a dishonest guy, there is not much you can do. I hope we will all be able to put it behind us."
Although the management of nonprofit institutions is a relatively new academic specialty, Harvard is by no means the first university to turn its attention to the subject. There are now more than three dozen centers for the study of nonprofit enterprises at universities around the country, from Yale and Duke to the New School for Social Research and the University of San Francisco, and at least a dozen offer some focus on management.
In addition, there is already one other school at Harvard, the John F. Kennedy School of Government, that focuses on nonprofit enterprise, and sends about a third of its graduates into jobs in nonprofit institutions. It even offers the only course on nonprofit management at Harvard.
While the two schools talked about the possibility of a joint program, Mr. Whitehead's money was ultimately directed to the business school.
"They both have a role to play," he said. "My interest is in teaching managers business skills. The Kennedy School teaches them about the policy issues. There is a different kind of emphasis, and there is room for both."
Those connected with the business school program, the Initiative on Social Enterprise, which was established in 1993, concede that there is much to learn before there is a discipline that offers the depth and breadth of business management. They talk of the overlap between the two fields -- and the differences. And they talk about building new intellectual capital.
V. Kasturi Rangan, a business school professor who is one of the leaders of the social enterprise initiative, talked about the crossover in his own field of marketing:
"Nonprofit management offers its own challenges, but the trick is to bring the core disciplines into these challenges," he said. "We don't have Marketing 1 for toothpaste, and Marketing 2 for computers. Marketing is marketing."
He added, however, that nonprofit groups face a dual customer problem that is unique to them, because they need to concern themselves both with the clients who receive their services, and with the donors who pay for the services with their charitable contributions. The usual marketing discipline, coming out of consumers' choices that weigh benefits against costs, doesn't apply when consumers and payers are separate, he said. So a nonprofit group needs to develop special internal measures to know whether its products are appropriate.
It is analysis like this that excites Mr. Whitehead and makes him feel that his money will be well spent.
"This is fun," Mr. Whitehead said. "This is what keeps me going."
 
 
 
Growth Field In Academia
 THE nonprofit world is one of the growth fields of academe. In 15 years or so, more than three dozen centers have sprung up at universities, and more are added yearly.
Many programs are interdisciplinary, drawing on management experts, economists, historians, theologians and sociologists, but the focus of each varies. Some, like Duke University, emphasize nonprofit economics. Others, like the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, emphasize public policy. Still others, like the City University of New York, focus on issues like philanthropy.
More than half of the schools stress nonprofit management techniques, and some, like Case Western Reserve and the New School for Social Research, offer courses aimed at preparing managers for nonprofit organizations.
Many of the early programs grew out of a desire to understand this little-studied but fast-growing sector of the economy, and to raise the level of scholarship and management in the field. But what is driving the growth on campuses now is the growing interest by students in careers in nonprofit organizations.
"We get a very high proportion of students interested in social and economic change," said Julian Wolpert, a professor at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton, which is weighing the possibility of a nonprofit center. "As government has really cut back in its hiring, more and more of our students are going into nonprofits."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS: INVESTING WITH;
Gail Bardin -- Hotchkis & Wiley Equity Income Fund

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
INVESTORS watching stock prices vault from one peak to the next can come down with a severe bout of vertigo. But cashing out of the market is not the only cure: buying funds that invest in inexpensive stocks that pay healthy dividends can provide some relief. While these funds tend to suffer when interest rates plummet, as they did last year, they also tend to hold up better in any kind of market drop.
The Hotchkis & Wiley Equity Income Fund, for example, follows a strict value discipline that forces it to choose the cheapest stocks in the most neglected areas of the market. Although the fund has gained 28 percent so far this year, making it a top performer in the equity-income group, it does not have pricey technology stocks or hot initial public offerings in its $139 million portfolio. 
 "I think it's particularly timely now because the market is so high," said Gail Bardin, who manages the eight-year-old fund with George Wiley for the Los Angeles firm of Hotchkis & Wiley, which has some $8 billion under management. Ms. Bardin, who joined Hotchkis & Wiley in 1988 as an assistant portfolio manager, was named co-manager a year and a half ago.
 
Buying What's Out of Favor
 To find good stocks at bargain-basement prices, Mr. Wiley and Ms. Bardin limit themselves to stocks that pay a substantial dividend. "Dividends are an important floor under the price of the stocks," Ms. Bardin said in a phone interview last week. "It does reduce our risk." The dividend yield, which is the dividend paid on each share divided by the share price, must be higher than the yield of the overall stock market, now 2.4 percent. The fund's stocks, on average, have a dividend yield of 3.6 percent.
Stocks must also be cheap. A stock's earnings yield, which is its earnings per share divided by the share price, must be three percentage points above the yield on the long-term bond, now 6.5 percent, to reward investors for the risk they take in equities. While the overall market has a price-earnings ratio of 15 based on next year's earnings, the Equity-Income Fund has a P.E. of just 11. This strict criteria generally leads Mr. Wiley and Ms. Bardin to stocks scorned by most other managers -- notably auto and retailing stocks.
The two are betting that the market has overreacted and that the outlook for many of these out-of-favor stocks is not as bleak as supposed. "At the first sign of renewed earnings growth, people will bid up the stocks," explained Ms. Bardin.
 
Cash Hoards
 While many fear that the coming economic downturn and a rising dollar will hurt the Big Three auto makers, Ms. Bardin considers Ford and General Motors great buys. Ford, for example, is trading at a P.E. of 5, while G.M. has a P.E. of 7. "They have piles of cash for the next downturn," she said. Chrysler, though it meets many of these criteria as well, does not make her list because it does not sell as many cars abroad.
 
A Penney Earned
 Ms. Bardin also favors some retail stocks, including two mass merchandisers, J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex.,, and Kmart, based in Troy, Mich. J. C. Penney, which is trading well below last year's high of $59, "is a dominant company in a very tough competitive industry," said Ms. Bardin, who noted the company has been buying back its own shares and has recently raised its dividend. "The danger with buying J. C. Penney is it doesn't do anything for a while," acknowledged Ms. Bardin. But with an above-average dividend yield of about 4 percent, the stock "rewards you while you wait."
 
A Proven Leader
 Kmart, whose stock price has plummeted over the last few years along with its earnings, is another top holding. "We have high hopes for the new C.E.O.," said Ms. Bardin. That is Floyd Hall, who has worked at retailers including B. Dalton, Grand Union and the Museum Company. The stock is trading at just 10 times next year's earnings of about $1.50, according to Ms. Bardin. "They ought to be able to earn $3," she said.
