HEADLINE: A Managed Care Cure-All With Flaws and Potential

SERIES: The Cutting Edge: Tennessee's health care revolution -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
In May 1993, as the Clinton Administration struggled to complete its doomed 1,342-page health care proposal, Tennessee's avuncular Democratic Governor, Ned McWherter, cajoled the State Legislature into approving a health care measure of its own.
It was a paragraph shy of one and a half pages long. 
 Yet it helped accomplish, for better and worse, the most sweeping revolution of a government-financed health care system in the nation.
By the start of 1994, less than seven weeks after gaining grudging approval from Federal Medicaid officials, the state transferred three-quarters of a million Medicaid recipients into private, managed care health plans. Breakneck speed aside, no other state had switched its conventional Medicaid population en masse into managed care.
More astonishingly, with roughly the same money its Medicaid program would have cost, Tennessee committed itself to becoming the first state to give health insurance to every uninsured person who wanted it. Today Tennessee extends that coverage, through managed care plans, to about 300,000 to 400,000 people -- the very people President Clinton had earmarked as the chief beneficiaries of his great lost cause.
As Republicans in Congress push hard to cut Medicaid's growth rate and allow states vastly expanded powers to design their own plans to provide health care to the poor, Tennessee's experiment, called TennCare, stands as an example of the risks and opportunities of health care overhaul at the state level.
With the possible exception of Hawaii, Tennessee's population now has the highest rate of insurance coverage in the country, which has changed hundreds of thousands of lives for the better.
But the price has been enormous. For huge numbers of Tennesseans, TennCare, with 1.2 million participants, has meant more, not less, bureaucracy. That has led to confusion and disruptions of care that, some say, have caused needless illness and, in at least one case, death.
And, faced with a budgetary crunch, the state has at least temporarily shut off the program to most uninsured people who are not now registered, and is proposing charging premiums to some of its poorest participants.
"My closest analogy is what's going on in Eastern Europe and Russia," said Leighton Ku, a senior research associate at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. "There's some incredible fiascoes, and there's incredible good things. It's like an engrossing story that I'd like to get to the end of."
When Jay Reeves, a contractor in the small town of Manchester, endured the saddest of personal sufferings -- his teenage son's death and his own near-fatal injury through carbon monoxide poisoning -- TennCare might have seemed his salvation. He was uninsured before the program was created. But at first his TennCare insurer, for no reason other than bureaucratic bungling, refused to pay for thousands of dollars in emergency medical bills.
Numerous calls and letters went unanswered for months until his lawyer, out of frustration, spoke to the president of the company. Eventually the bills were covered, but the struggle was draining. "Nobody seemed to care," Mr. Reeves said bitterly.
But when Alice Anderson, the assistant manager of a convenience store in Memphis, rushed her 7-year-old son Spencer to the hospital last year with a 105-degree fever, she found that, after some struggle, the more than $500 in bills were covered.
Previously uninsured, she and her husband, Jarrett, are still paying for Spencer's birth. "So," she said, "whatever hoops they make me jump through, I say, 'How high?' "
By forcing people virtually overnight into an untried program, the state unleashed a nightmare for doctors and hospitals, as well as patients, caught in the switch. Doctors in TennCare's main plan, run by Tennessee Blue Cross and Blue Shield, revolted at one point and left the program by the thousands, although most gradually returned.
Public hospitals and clinics that had long been the main medical providers for poor people are staggering because of reduced fees.
And accusations of hucksterism and fraud by managed care salespeople have only added to the difficulties.
Winston Griner, a doctor in private practice in Nashville who treats large numbers of poor people, has concluded: "This is the sale of health care. It's no longer the provision of health care."
So many doctors have balked at working in the program, he said, that "the people who helped train me, I can't get them to see my patients." He added: "Everything is disjointed, dysfunctional."
Yet Gordon Bonnyman Jr., a legal services lawyer and early TennCare advocate, says that for all the difficulties, the plan is one of the few in a period of retrenchment that actually expands services. "Conceptually, it was an extraordinary, maybe aberrant effort for government to make policy for the least powerful elements of the population at the expense of the people who always called the shots," he said.
The advent of TennCare helped cause political disruptions in Tennessee, where the Republican current in politics last year swept in a Republican Governor and two Republican Senators. Although a few states have tried to expand coverage, no state has made a commitment as broad as Tennessee's, and few if any have made such commitments at all during the current budget-slashing era.
There may be only one point on which there is consensus in Tennessee now -- a telling one for other states. As David Manning, the former state Commissioner of Finance and Administration who developed the program for Mr. McWherter, said, "If you're going to attempt to effect real change in the health care system, you'd better hold onto your hat."
 
The Catalyst
Rising Costs Spur A Revolution
 Just as it has in the rest of the country, the health care industry has boomed in Tennessee since the 1980's, even outstripping music as an economic force in Nashville, the state capital. The growth in the state's Medicaid budget since 1987 has been dramatic, with the annual figure rising to $3 billion from $848 million.
With no income tax, and deep resistance to any tax increases, Tennessee was hard-pressed to cope with those rising costs. In late 1992, the situation turned particularly grim when the Federal Government rejected the last of a string of financial gimmicks the state had used to finance much of its vast expansion. For Mr. McWherter, the Governor at the time, the choices seemed bleak: impose taxes or cut benefits in a way no state had tried.
Mr. Manning had other ideas.
He had long believed that the state was paying too much to doctors providing Medicaid services, doctors whose incomes usually were well into six figures. Also, he and other critics said Tennessee's hospitals, with occupancy rates in the 60 percent range, commanded fees from Medicaid that did not reflect their real bargaining position.
"Truthfully," Mr. Manning said, "there was enough money in the system if we allowed the market to allocate those dollars rather than a politicized system."
He and Mr. McWherter became convinced, as have politicians as varied as President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich, that managed care was the solution.
Under conventional Medicaid, doctors and hospitals bill a state for individual procedures under a fee schedule fixed by the Government, which critics say invites unnecessary care and hospitalization.
In managed care, the state pays health maintenance organizations and similar groups a fixed fee per patient per month. If the cost of care rises above that figure, the managed care organization or its doctors must cover the difference, giving plans the motivation to negotiate reduced fees, from hospitals and specialists in particular, and to encourage primary care that is both cheaper and more medically advisable.
In designing TennCare, Mr. Manning was ruthless about keeping monthly fees at roughly two-thirds of the Medicaid levels. Expensive specialty services sustained the largest cuts. The average fee, which started out at just over $100 per patient per month, was so tight that several national managed care companies backed away.
The plan also charged a sliding scale of premiums and co-payments to those above the poverty line who were not eligible for Medicaid.
 
The Politics
The Quick Route To Major Change
 So harmful were the economics to the state's medical establishment -- a major contributor to the election campaigns of state legislators -- that Mr. McWherter and Mr. Manning adopted a stealth strategy intended to slip the $3 billion plan into being when the legislators were out of session.
Mr. Manning developed the plan with a small crew of allies and little public review. The Governor, a hulking, homespun man who is fond of recounting the story of his birth on the kitchen table of a country shack, spent the spring of 1993 selling the plan to legislators as the least of three evils, the other two being raising taxes and gutting Medicaid.
"What you had here was the irresistible force meeting the immovable object," Mr. Manning said. "What they feared more than the wrath of their special interest supporters was the wrath of the taxpayers and the Medicaid recipients."
By May, the Legislature had passed its one and a half page endorsement of Medicaid overhaul, leaving the details to the Administration. "I suggested it was a major reform in the implementation of health care delivery," Mr. McWherter said dryly. "I don't believe they all understood what a major reform it was."
The trick then was to get it up and running before the legislators returned the following January with their axes sharpened. "We knew it would be messy," Mr. Manning said of the hasty start-up, but he and his allies felt it was the only chance they had.
Under Federal law, to put the overhaul into effect they needed approval from Medicaid officials in Washington, who blanched at the speed with which a state with little experience in managed care wanted to get moving.
Bruce C. Vladeck, who directs the Federal Medicaid and Medicare programs, said, "It required an enormous leap of faith on our part with the kind of implementation schedules they had." Other states, like Oregon and Hawaii, had planned less ambitious programs with phase-ins. "A lot of people were real skeptical," Mr. Vladeck said.
With months passing without a decision from Federal health officials, Mr. McWherter recalled, frustration led him to pick up his telephone in early September. "I just called the President," he said.
Friends say Mr. McWherter's ties with Mr. Clinton seemed special, even more so in some ways than his relationship with Vice President Al Gore, who was born and bred in Democratic politics in Tennessee.
Mr. McWherter and Mr. Clinton knew each other for years as Democratic politicians from adjoining states. Some believe that Mr. McWherter may have even been a bit of a father figure for the President, and they remember him greeting Mr. Clinton as "Billy Boy" when he was Governor of Arkansas.
Also, Mr. McWherter recalled that the President had spoken favorably of the kind of changes Tennessee wanted. A few days after his call to Mr. Clinton, the Governor was invited to spend the night at the White House.
On Nov. 18, 1993, after a second visit by the Governor to the White House, TennCare was approved.
On Jan. 1, 1994, 10 days before the Legislature reconvened, TennCare shakily began operation, with 12 managed care companies, newly formed or girding for vast expansions.
On Jan. 2, 50,000 calls poured in to TennCare asking for help.
 
The Beneficiaries
A Safety Net, A Tangled Web
 A few days later, in the Nashville suburb of Ridgetop, James Frederick, 44, was walking across his salvage yard when a chemical compound bubbled from a 226-pound industrial fire extinguisher. Suddenly, the extinguisher shot across the yard, smashing his leg.
Mr. Frederick had never been able to afford insurance before TennCare.
Rebuilding his leg cost $100,000.
Without TennCare, said his wife, Martha, "I guess we would have had to sell everything."
In Nashville, Ginny Welsch, 36, a part-time news director for a radio station, used TennCare to pay for her first complete physical and mammogram. Before the program, she and her husband, a songwriter, could afford only catastrophic coverage with a $1,000 deductible.
But mixed in with stories like these are tales of confusion, outrage and exasperation -- the price in some cases of the strictures of managed care and in others of the sort of speedy start up that experts say may tempt other states with delicate politics and looming budget deficits.
Thousands of enrollees wound up in plans with which their doctors were not affiliated, and Medicaid recipients often bristled at having to receive permission to visit specialists and get hospital care.
Some of the plans lacked specialists and even hospitals in significant population centers. When Barbara Keck, 32, of Maynardville became pregnant with her third child this year, she was told by her managed care plan, Access Med Plus, that the closest obstetrician was 55 miles away. She also called five hospitals in nearby Knoxville, where she had had two other children under Medicaid, to see where she might have her baby delivered. None at that time were affiliated with the plan, leading her to plan her delivery two and a half hours away. Only recently has the plan established links with a Knoxville hospital and a nurse practitioner who is not so far away.
Lynda Johnson said that shortly after the program started Jackson-Madison County General Hospital in Jackson refused to treat her 6-week-old twin daughter, Crystal, because it did not accept TennCare patients. The baby had been born prematurely. Ms. Johnson, who was 27 at the time, said that a day after she was refused treatment, the baby died.
Although state and Federal officials found no wrongdoing by the hospital, Ms. Johnson's lawyer, A C Wharton, a board member of Methodist Hospital in Memphis, said her case showed the problems of quickly starting up a program that has clients who are often poorly educated.
"The state said they sent her a letter informing her of the care available, but we are not sure they did," he said, "and even if they did, we say that to the extent care was available to her, she was not fully informed of it."
Ms. Johnson is suing the hospital for $1 million and the state for $300,000.
Many in TennCare complained that medications they had taken for years were not covered and that they had to make do with inferior substitutes.
And many of the plans' billing systems were overrun.
One plan, Access Med Plus, which grew to 300,000 members from 30,000 within months and brought in roughly $300 million in state payments in a year, started without a computerized billing system, which caused delays of months and months in payments to already disaffected hospitals and doctors.
A survey by the University of Tennessee determined that while the uninsured liked the plan, half the former Medicaid patients found TennCare worse than its predecessor. Only 12 percent found it better.
For some, like Kathy Palmore, a 27-year-old veterinarian's assistant in Nashville who was found to have cervical cancer this year, simply enrolling in the program became an ordeal. She said it took "a week just to get through."
For others, like Tashia Carbins, 20, of Memphis, the waiting came at the doctor's office. Three and a half months pregnant when she visited her doctor last June, she found that the obstetrician he referred her to did not participate in her plan. When she tried to make an appointment with one of the few she could find who did, she could not get one until Aug. 29, when she was five and a half months pregnant.
Two weeks before that, she went into premature labor and was rushed to Methodist Hospital to prevent a miscarriage.
David Wilson, an articulate 17-year-old high school student from Nashville, cited a series of problems. David suffers from an intense psychological disorder that causes him to lose his bearings and sometimes turn violent.
Last year, he and his mother said, his doctors recommended that a hospital mental unit release him to a residential treatment center. But his TennCare plan, Tennessee Blue Cross, disallowed the referral, saying such treatment is covered only as a less costly alternative to hospitalization.
He returned home. Shortly afterward, the local pharmacy would not fill his prescription because his expensive drugs were not on the list authorized by his plan. His mother, Sharon, said she had to argue to get the 72-hour dose permitted under TennCare in disputed cases.
When David became ill again, his mother said, his doctor tried to gain approval for an emergency room admission. But, she said, the organization that handles mental illness problems for Blue Cross never returned the doctor's call. Blue Cross says it tried but could not reach the doctor.
It finally allowed the admission, but that was 10 hours after Ms. Wilson's initial call. By then, David, by his own account, had been hallucinating for hours.
For Dr. Sheldon Korones, who runs a nationally acclaimed center for low birth weight newborns at Memphis's public hospital, the Regional Medical Center, the most discouraging moment came when he tried to get a double hernia operation for 5-month-old Shicara Mona Price. The two pediatric surgeons in Memphis who had been affiliated with her health plan dropped out, saying that $100,000 of their bills had been rejected and the plan had taken too long to pay the remainder.
Infuriated, Dr. Korones went to the press, and the dollars poured in.
Shicara had her operation, but a sour feeling lingers for Dr. Korones. "I submit there's something wrong with a system that precipitates this kind of activity," he said.
 
The Outlook
Promising Signs, Many Skeptics
 With Mr. McWherter subject to a term limit under state law, a Republican, Don Sundquist, was elected Governor last year. In his campaign, Mr. Sundquist criticized TennCare's operation and garnered large donations from doctors. The doctors' political action committee also gave $225,000 to legislative candidates, contributing to 54 winners, some of whom defeated TennCare proponents.
But Mr. Sundquist, while pushing for changes, has turned into a TennCare supporter.
Rusty Siebert, who runs the program for his Administration, has two thoughts for other states: start more slowly and systematically, and cover the uninsured. This, he argues, saves money because it cuts down on expensive emergency room care, the cost of which is often covered by paying customers and large employers through higher hospital charges and insurance premiums.
Mr. Siebert argues that the most egregious foul-ups in Tennessee took place in the early months, and he cites accomplishments like a cut in the growth rate of the Medicaid budget to 5 percent or less a year and a sharp reduction in unnecessary hospital admissions and emergency room visits.
Sharon Wilson, whose 17-year-old son went through such struggles last year, said that to her surprise, "I've seen real changes, much more responsiveness, just in the past month."
But others are not sure. Mr. Vladeck, the Federal Medicaid director, said that although "by the end of the year, they'll have it on more stable footing," he was frustrated by the lack of long-awaited computerized data that he said were needed to evaluate the program.
Hundreds of thousands of recipients are not yet in plans where they have assigned primary care doctors who guide their medical care, a hallmark of the best managed systems. And a General Accounting Office report released last month raised questions about the finances of many of the managed care plans.
The state, for financial reasons, has already stopped enrolling most new uninsured people. It is proposing increases in premiums, including charges for the first time for people below the poverty line who were previously uninsured.
And many institutions that served the poor when few others did have undergone financial ordeals. Dr. Korones's hospital, the Regional Medical Center, has laid off 350 workers since TennCare and reduced its number of beds to 310 from 590. According to its general counsel, Charlotte Collins, the hospital spent $115.7 million last year treating patients who, for various reasons, still had no insurance.
At the Laurel Forks-Clear Forks Health Centers, in the state's depressed eastern Appalachian region, the medical director, David E. McRay, took a $27,000 pay cut and the other five doctors agreed to cuts of $10,000 to $17,000 to keep the operation going without cutting patient care. The National Association of Community Health Centers has sued TennCare in Federal court as a result of such disruptions.
It may be difficult for another state to replicate Tennessee's expansive commitment to the uninsured, even if it wanted to.
For one thing, years of budgetary sleight of hand had left Tennessee with more money, proportionally, coming into its Medicaid program than many other states, and it used those dollars to help fashion TennCare.
For another, the state virtually forced doctors and hospitals to participate in TennCare by making acceptance of program recipients a requirement for providers who wanted to participate in the Blue Cross health plan for state employees.
Doctors hated that provision, and many experts doubt that other states have the muscle to carry out something similar.
And in Tennessee itself, huge questions remain about the program. Marsha Gold, who completed a long study of the program for the Commonwealth Fund and the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, said TennCare was still so fresh that it is more an open book than a lesson plan.
But Mr. Siebert, the TennCare director, did have a prediction for other states looking to reshape Medicaid.
"You're in for exciting times, I promise you," he said.
NEXT: Questions of fraud and abuse.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Look Who's Saying Separate Is Equal

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BACK in 1954, the segregationist doctrine of separate but equal appeared to have been slain by a nine-headed St. George known as the United States Supreme Court. In its landmark ruling in Brown v. Board of Education, the justices overturned what had been for 60 years the legal underpinning of America's system of racial separation.
Four decades later, though, a mixture of white resistance to integration, population shifts, an increasingly conservative judiciary and black impatience and political empowerment seem to be converting separate but equal from a dead dragon into a rising Phoenix. 
 The once discredited doctrine is making a comeback, embraced in varying degrees by such divergent figures as Louis Farrakhan, the head of the Denver school board and Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas.
 
'Desegregation Is Dead'
 In 1954 the Court declared that separate could never be equal; that segregation was meant to hurt blacks (and that it succeeded in doing so) no matter what the quality of particular segregated institutions. Last month, though, some black members of school boards in Denver and Kansas City, Mo., questioned whether trying to force whites to mix with black children was not only demeaning to blacks but unnecessary to achieve equal academic opportunities.
"I think desegregation is dead and should have died a long time ago, if the focus is on trying to have a physical mixing of the races," said Edward J. Newsome, a black member of the Kansas City school board.
While the 1954 decision addressed the impact on blacks in particular, modern supporters of desegregation argue that integration grants children of all races and ethnicities the opportunity to become more familiar with the cultures of other groups. But Mr. Newsome scoffs at the notion that black children benefit academically by rubbing shoulders with whites.
"For a person to believe otherwise simply is adhering to the notion that blacks are inherently inferior," he said, echoing Justice Thomas's opinion earlier this year in voiding a magnet school program to attract whites to the Kansas City public schools.
Whether couched in the oratory of black empowerment or driven by a view that whites will never agree to mix, more academics and policymakers of both races are turning away from integration as a goal and toward enhancing institutions that are predominantly black, by design or not.
"Enhancement is a philosophy of maintaining separate but equal," said Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition, who describes himself as a militant integrationist. "The strategy is to deal with the ghetto or strengthening ghetto housing or ghetto schools because they don't see integration as possible, fashionable or desirable."
And while the motivations may be different, the oratory often sounds oddly reminiscent of Southern segregationists.
 
Was Brown a Mistake?
 Writing in 1993, Professor Alex M. Johnson Jr. of the University of Virginia Law School said integration has failed blacks and that the Brown decision was a mistake. He said he could not have made those statements 20 or 30 years ago because they "would have been so far outside the mainstream that, frankly, they would have been unthinkable by an African-American scholar employed at a prestigious law school. Quite the contrary, the views expressed herein might have been more easily attributed to an avowed racist."
There is clearly a moral difference, though. The old legal doctrine was put in place expressly to subjugate blacks -- separate, in the South, was not equal. It was so much a part of a racist caste system that even if the state maintained segregated institutions or services of comparable quality -- and few schools, buses or even water fountains were -- the separation was still manifestly unequal. Claims of equality were a dodge to justify separation.
Today, things aren't quite so clear. Skeptics -- especially blacks -- who question integration are much more credible when they claim to have the interests of blacks at heart. Still, a bedeviling question arises: Have changing circumstances made the doctrine of separate but equal morally acceptable?
To be sure, the new respectability of separate but equal seems much more a phenomenon of black intellectuals and middle-class elites, many of whom work in integrated offices and send their children to integrated schools. Polls show continued support for integration among most blacks.
"I think I'm in the minority in terms of the leadership," said Mr. Meyers. "And if black leaders don't start speaking up, I'm going to be in the minority among the people."
Perhaps in no area of race relations is the new doctrine of separate but equal gaining more currency than in public education, as much out of a kind of cold-eye assessment of reality as out of ideology.
As whites have fled cities, many urban school populations are overwhelming black or Hispanic. Supreme Court decisions in the 1970's curbed efforts to bus children across county lines to achieve integration unless it was shown that there had been intentional discrimination.
Whites and Asians in Leonia, N.J., last week protested plans to merge their school district with the predominantly black Englewood district. And a wave of lawsuits has been filed maintaining that Denver, Minneapolis, Cleveland, Pittsburgh, Seattle, Wilmington and Indianapolis have done all they could to foster school integration, and asking to be relieved of further obligations.
Meanwhile, about 70 percent of black children nationwide attend predominantly black schools, down only a bit from the 78 percent that attended such schools in 1968.
The current climate has caused not a few black leaders to contemplate alternatives. Some argue that the growth of a black middle class and the greater number of black elected officials have produced more economic and political resources to improve predominantly black schools in certain districts.
"Pre-1954 was separate and unequal," said the Rev. Aaron Gray, president of the Denver School Board, who is black. "The difference today is that you can step into an African-American school and you can see the same amount of resources that are provided to a majority Anglo school."
Even if equal resources materialize more broadly and, above all, lead to greater equality in test scores, a fundamental question remains: is segregation any less damaging to black children now than it was when the Supreme Court chucked it out 41 years ago?
Evidence suggests that children of all races benefit from attending integrated schools. Studies by Jomills Braddock, chairman of the Sociology Department of the University of Miami, indicate that black male graduates of integrated high schools are more likely to hold higher-status jobs and earn higher incomes than blacks who attended segregated schools.
 
Cities vs. Suburbs
 Given this, integrationists assert this is no time to give up.
"It's an approach that is expensive and time-consuming and not yet fully tried," said Arthur Benson, a lawyer who brought the suit to desegregate the Kansas City schools. "But the alternative is to give up and to consign a whole generation of kids to racially segregated opportunities that in the suburbs are enriched and the inner cities are impoverished. We will reap the effects of that if we allow it to happen."

HEADLINE: British Go Metric: Some Won't Yield an Inch

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
Judy Bird, a 60-year-old pensioner, leaned over the butter counter at Sainsbury's on Victoria Street and in her understated way said what she thought: "Bloody nuisance. Why can't they bloody well leave us alone? We always come off worse when they muck around."
This Sunday, throughout Britain, is what the authorities are euphemistically calling "M-day." M does not stand for murder. Or mayhem. Or massacre. But judging from what you hear around town, it might just as well. 
 M stands for metrication.
Sunday is the day when Britain takes a giant step in formally relinquishing its beloved foot and pound and inch and ounce and converting to that new-fangled import from the French Revolution, the metric system.
As might be expected in a land where judges wear horsehair wigs from the 18th century, the Queen has a courtier called the Gold Stick in Waiting and opposing parties in Parliament are kept two swords' lengths apart lest they hurt each other, the changeover is being viewed as a foul Napoleonic wind blowing over from the Continent.
"Once again, one of our cherished British traditions sinks into the swamp of an integrated Europe," was how one of the more reflective Daily Express readers put it in a letter to the editor. "It's time we British fought back."
Fighting back is just what Vivian Linacre, a surveyor who heads a new group called British Weights and Measures Association, vowed to do on Friday afternoon. At a news conference in the basement of a modest club near the Marble Arch, Mr. Linacre promised a "massive campaign of public resistance" that would rival the Russian Revolution. "What we are about today, ladies and gentlemen, is to start another October Revolution -- that's exactly what we're doing."
Take away the portrait of the Queen above Mr. Linacre's head, substitute overalls for his blue pin-strip suit and mentally erase the rows of men harumphing "hear, hear" in the back, and one might have been transported back four score years to Lenin haranging the workers at the Finland railway station in St. Petersburg, a historian in the crowd thought.
Waxing indignant at criminal sanctions in the new law -- in theory a shop owner could be fined 5,000, or $7,700 -- Mr. Linacre predicted martyrs would come forward and multiply. He painted a grim picture of Britain a few years down the road with retailers behind bars for refusing to utter the words "liter" and "kilogram."
"They'll have to set up camps all over the country -- in the Scottish Highlands, the Midlands, everywhere," he thundered, wagging his finger in the air. "They'll be full of hundreds of thousands of small-business people."
The Department of Trade and Industry, which seems caught off guard by the public reaction, is at pains to point out that metrication has actually been under way here since 1972 (it was given 10 years to settle in at the time) and that what is happening on M-Day is simply a watershed.
Beginning Sunday, transactions involving liquid measures and linear measures will have to go metric, so goodbye gallon and yard. As far as weights, any food that is prepackaged will have to be in grams and kilograms. But loose food in bulk -- mostly fruits and vegetables -- will have a dispensation. It will not go metric until January of the year 2000, the idea being, presumably, that perhaps by then the public will learn to make the required mental conversion.
"What we're talking about now is mostly meat, poultry, fish, cheese, anything that comes prepackaged," said Fran Atkins, a spokeswoman for the department. "People don't realize that over 80 percent of what they buy in grocery stores right now is already metric. Funny enough, no one really notices."
And then there are what the department grandly calls "descriptive measures." These are special cases, so deeply embedded in public consciousness that they will be allowed to continue. "You can ask for a nine-by-five rug," she said. "The same with a five-foot bed or a 15 1/2 collar or a 29-inch inside leg or a six-foot bookcase. Also a 3 1/2-inch floppy disk and a 16-ounce steak." And yes, she added, with the air of someone who has fielded the question dozens of times -- McDonald's will still serve quarter-pounders.
The two greatest dispensations of all are the mile, which will remain king of the road, and the pint, as in what you order in a pub. There are certain things you just don't mess around with, unless you want Mr. Linacre's apocalyptic vision to come true.
"How would it sound to barge in and order a .568 liter?" asked Stephen Alambritis, head of parliamentary affairs for the Federation of Small Businesses, which opposes the conversion. "But the strange thing is if you order a shandy or lager top it's got to be ordered in metric." A shandy is part lager, part lemonade and a lager top is lager with lime juice.
"We English are very attached to our pint," Mr. Alambritis continued. "And that goes for the 'pinta' " -- pint of milk -- "on our doorstep. If you get it delivered, it's in imperial. But if you buy it in a shop, it's metric."
"It's utter madness," he said. "And these inconsistencies lead us to believe the ministers don't want it to succeed. They want to go back to Brussels and say, 'We tried it and it didn't work.' The whole thing has been low profile. They know it's an issue that could raise the hackles of Euro-skeptic M.P.'s."
The organization, which represents 75,000 businesses, took an informal survey and concluded that one-third knew nothing about the new law.
Abandoning imperial measurement has been especially hard for poets. One wrote to The Guardian that "music-wise, rhythm-wise, image-wise" phrases like the Merchant of Venice's .4536 kilograms of flesh or the River Alph "8.0465 kilometers meandering with a mazy motion" just weren't the same. The change will affect the measurement that always puzzles Americans, the stone, which is equivalent to 14 pounds, but this measurement is used largely for people's weight.
With Britain out of the box, that leaves only the United States, Liberia and Myanmar, formerly Burma, as non-metric countries. The United States made a pass at the metric system with a voluntary conversion act in 1975 but it didn't get very far. Occasionally there is the odd, old road sign giving distance in both systems.
In Britain, for better or worse, the changeover has become suddenly visible in the last few days. Large supermarket chains like Sainsbury's have posted metric-imperial conversion tables -- they look like thermometers lying on their side -- and this has caused consternation. It reminds many people of 1971, when Britain decimalized its currency, abandoning the archaic system of 12 pence to a shilling and 20 shillings to a pound.
To this day, some blame that conversion for the inflation that followed and feel something fishy was pulled. "I still think Wilson and his lads were up to no good in that one," said Mrs. Bird, the Sainsbury customer, referring to Harold Wilson, then Prime Minister. "Why should this be different? You can't tell me shops won't use it as a way to sneak through a price rise."
But shopkeepers themselves are distraught. "I can feel this cloth, I know it's 13 ounces," said John Davis, a partner in Tobias Tailors on Savile Row, rubbing a Prince of Wales check from a pattern book between his fingers. "How can I do that in grams? I can't. And 60 percent of our clients are American. If I give them their measurements in centimeters they'll just give me a confused look."
Greta Hutcheson, owner of Luc's delicatessen in Mayfair, said, "I feel resentment at the change." She found it hard to visualize servings of pasta, beans, salads and fish. "I can do the conversion in my mind but I don't get a mental picture of how big it is," she said. And a heavy investment in scales might have to go by the boards.
When it comes to the imperial system, which is based upon parts of the body (a foot was roughly the size of an adult's foot, an inch the end joint of the thumb), Britain is the mother country. In the year 1215, weights and measures were defined by royal decree, and they were spread by naval ships and the empire.
That makes its decline especially poignant. Not by coincidence did one protester, a shop owner in the south of England, erect a sign reading, "Rule Britannia -- in inches not meters, pints not liters."

HEADLINE: No Appetite in Washington for a State Dinner Now

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30

 BODY:
When President Li Xiannian of China visited the United States a decade ago, Ronald Reagan got out of his hospital bed to greet him, gave a toast (in Chinese) to his "old friend" and held a formal state dinner in the White House, complete with lobster, veal tenderloin, Elizabeth Taylor and Robert Mitchum.
And Mr. Li was little more than a figurehead. 
 So it was not at all surprising that when President Clinton privately extended an invitation on Wednesday to President Jiang Zemin to stop by at the White House after he addresses the United Nations next month, the Chinese said no, not unless the invitation was for an official state visit.
Mr. Jiang has visited 10 countries as President, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen told a luncheon audience in New York on Friday, and "every one of them was a state visit."
For heads of state, the state visits at the White House are heady affairs, the closest the United States gets to looking royal.
With a state visit comes a red carpet at Andrews Air Force Base, an arrival ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House with a 21-gun howitzer salute, the flying of the national flag of the guest country on lampposts throughout official Washington, the playing of national anthems, the formal review of a color guard and the exchange of expensive talismans of friendship -- all capped by a formal White House dinner with good food and entertainment.
Emperor Akihito of Japan was apparently so impressed by the white ties, the hospitality and Mr. Clinton's haiku recitation during a state visit last year that he broke a rule of royal tradition and offered a dinner toast -- to "the health and success" of his hosts.
At a state dinner held by President Bush in 1992, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia signed menus, sampled the caviar and waltzed with the wife of a prominent C.E.O. Mr. Yeltsin, the first non-Communist Russian leader to visit the White House since Grand Duke Alexis called on Rutherford B. Hayes in 1877, said his visit was "the best day of my life."
For China, a state visit would represent the most concrete sign yet that its relationship with Washington has recovered from the depths of two months ago, before the American human rights advocate Harry Wu was released from a Chinese prison and before Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed an international women's conference in Beijing.
But a high-profile state visit is out of the question, White House officials say. Mr. Clinton does not want to be photographed in a tuxedo toasting a man whose Government undertook the bloody suppression of the democracy movement in 1989 and who has failed to improve his country's human rights record ever since. That, his aides fear, might make Mr. Clinton look as if he was doing the same thing that he once accused Mr. Bush of doing: coddling dictators.
"We have offered the Chinese a visit in Washington because we want to give the Chinese something respectful, dignified, not looking as if we were shunting them aside," one senior Administration official said. "State visits are meant to cap a relationship that has come into its own and is going well. They are reserved for countries that are like close treaty allies."
Besides, Mr. Clinton does not share the same affinity for state visits as his two Republican predecessors, who seemed to be dressing up for one head of state or another almost every month. In his 33 months as President, Mr. Clinton has held only seven such visits.
Japan got one because an Emperor came calling. South Korea was rewarded for its steadfast loyalty as a strategic Asian ally, Morocco and Brazil for their close historic relationships with Washington. South Africa has President Nelson Mandela, who triumphed over apartheid. Ukraine got one after it gave up its nuclear arsenal, and Russia was awarded one when it was still in the honeymoon phase with Washington, before the invasion of the separatist region of Chechnya and before Mr. Yeltsin turned against NATO.
President Jacques Chirac of France has been invited for a state visit in November because, one senior Administration official explained, "He's a comer."
Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader but officially a mere Deputy Prime Minister when the United States and China established diplomatic relations in 1979, was feted with the Harlem Globetrotters, a gala at the Kennedy Center, a reception on Capitol Hill and a state visit in the Carter White House.
So how could Mr. Jiang, who is head of China's Communist Party, commander in chief of a three-million-member army and the head of state of a nuclear power with the world's largest population and fastest-growing economy, settle for less?
For human rights activists and a number of Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill, though, any invitation for Mr. Jiang to visit the White House is anathema.
"I will fight to the end a Communist leader coming to the White House," Mr. Wu said in an interview. "A state visit or not, what's the difference? Please don't let Jiang Zemin dirty the White House carpet."
Representative Nancy Pelosi, the California Democrat who has fought to revoke China's trade status with the United States because of its poor human rights record, said: "It would be more appropriate for this meeting to take place in New York. There's absolutely no justification for a celebratory welcome for Jiang Zemin. It certainly shouldn't be accompanied by a 21-gun salute and a formal celebration. And he doesn't deserve a parade."
Asked if she would go to a state dinner should there be one for him, Ms. Pelosi replied, "Let's put it this way: there's no chance I'd be invited to the White House." Then she paused, adding, "Those kinds of things are not important to me anyway."
Even an ordinary official working visit, which is what Mr. Jiang was offered, is not shabby. It comes with the same security from the Secret Service, hospitality from State Department protocol, lodging at Blair House, the President's guest house, and a salute with guns, although it is only 19 guns at the Pentagon. Even the flags on Pennsylvania Avenue probably would not pose too much of a problem.
The main difference is the meal; instead of a formal dinner, Mr. Jiang would only get a working lunch.
Asked at the daily briefing on Friday whether the two sides had made any progress on narrowing their differences on salutes and menus, Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, admitted, "I really can't tell you whether we're heading north or south on this issue."
But, Mr. Burns added, "I will say that what the important thing is not the flags and the guns and all that -- the important thing is not the trappings. It's the substance, and it's the inclination to have a meeting regardless of the trappings."
But Mr. Qian had indicated that was not enough when Mr. Christopher extended the formal White House invitation in New York on Wednesday.
Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff and China's Vice Foreign Minister, Li Zhaoxing, were given the job of seeking a compromise. This afternoon, after three days of intense meetings, Mr. Tarnoff and Mr. Li finally gave up on a Washington visit and agreed in principle that the two Presidents would have to meet in New York.

HEADLINE: Carson City Journal;
>Old West Is Renewed In a Corner Of Nevada

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ARSON CITY, Nev.

 BODY:
By the time Robert C. McFadden bought the St. Charles Hotel in 1993, the once-grand 19th-century inn had become a civic embarrassment -- the unsteady center of a skid row neighborhood of bars and $35-a-week flophouses perched directly across Carson Street from the magnificent, silver-domed Nevada State Capitol.
And Mr. McFadden's plans to renovate with an Old West theme got a modern-day jolt the night before he bought the hotel, when an irate woman pumped nine bullets into the front door of the building in a tussle with her estranged husband, killing no one but adding to the renovation bill. 
 "We wanted the Wild West," Mr. McFadden said. "Not that wild, though."
But today the maroon-brick hotel is exquisitely redone, with Western and Indian motifs, and is the anchor to a few city blocks of restaurants, antique shops and even a tea room. Lawmakers who would not cross the street a few years ago now book rooms for the entire legislative session.
And, to the delight of city officials here, the area has been transformed from a place of blight, one of the most unattractive neighborhoods within sight of any statehouse in the nation, into a modest attraction that lures shoppers and tourists from Reno and Lake Tahoe, both a half-hour or so away.
"It was an eyesore, and every time the legislators came to town it was, 'Hey, Marv, when are you going to clean up the area?' " said Carson City's Mayor, Marv Teixeira. "So we're not Carmel-by-the-Sea yet, but we sure look a lot better than we did a few years ago."
The rebirth of the hotel has brought the Frontier Antiques Mall and other stores to the area, replacing saloons like Jungle Jim's and a dilapidated apartment building where the Federal Bureau of Investigation once found a fugitive on its 10 Most-Wanted List hiding out.
"That bar on the corner was a wino hangout," said Jack Stovall, owner of Nevada Jack's, an antiques store that sells everything from old Elvis records to old mining equipment. "Now it's a first-class restaurant. This area has been totally turned around."
Mr. McFadden, 45, who was born and reared in Southern California, came to this area near the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada 22 years ago, when his brother was working in Lake Tahoe. "It just felt like a real Western town," Mr. McFadden said. "I got a real kick out of the place. So I stayed."
Well into his career as a real estate broker, selling houses and mobile homes in the area, Mr. McFadden bought the three-story, 27-room St. Charles for $750,000. He has since spent about $300,000 in renovations, with $36,000 of that paid with money from a city development agency.
The hotel itself had a checkered history. When it opened in 1862, a reporter from California, less than thrilled to be on assignment in the remote territory, pronounced it one of the few good things in "a land of silver and gold mines, of dust, of loose six-shooters and bad whisky, of dirty brown hills and sage brush," according to his account in The Sacramento Daily Union, now framed on one of the walls at the hotel.
But the hotel eventually went into a long decline and a series of name changes. By the 1920's, knowing locals would avoid eating there, having found that the chicken listed on the menu was more than occasionally replaced by jack rabbit, purchased by the chef at 25 cents an animal from local boys with slingshots.
Carson City, with a population of 45,000, does not exactly have a rock-solid identity of its own. There is no evidence that the man for whom it was named, the scout Kit Carson, ever even set foot here. And many people seem resigned to living in the shadow of Reno, the booming tourist city 30 miles to the north.
"When we travel and tell people we're from Carson City, they don't even know where that is," said Karen Ouellette, a lifelong resident and owner of the Sierra Rose florist, a new business just behind the St. Charles in a building that had been an auto body shop. "They don't even know it's the capital of Nevada."
But Mr. McFadden says he thinks Carson City could have a great future as part of a tourism circuit that would stretch from the gambling casinos of Reno, through old mining and railroad towns to the shore, and casinos, of Lake Tahoe.
Carson City has developed a downtown tour, marked with a blue line along several blocks of sidewalks, highlighting attractions like the mansion used in John Wayne's last film, "The Shootist"; the Governor's Mansion; the Ferris Mansion, home of the inventor of the Ferris wheel; the Nevada state museum, and the Carson Brewing Company, founded in 1864.
"The Old West reappears around every corner," says a city brochure describing the trail. But the idea of linking Carson City's sights to those elsewhere in the region does not seem to have caught on yet.
"We should have weeks worth of tourism for people who come here," Mr. McFadden said. "We've got a lot to play with, but everyone in Lake Tahoe is kind of holding their cards close to their chest. They don't think regionally, but we've got a gold mine of history to show off."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Robert C. McFadden's St. Charles Hotel in Carson City, Nev., has come full circle. When it opened in 1862 it was a jewel in the area, but later it fell into such disrepair that people avoided it. Now, the building that Mr. McFadden bought in 1993 is leading an economic revival in Nevada's capital city.; The St. Charles Hotel as it appeared in 1862, when it was Carson City's stagecoach stop. Today's advertising literature for the hotel says that in the old days, meals were 25 cents and lodging was 25 to 50 cents. (Photographs by Don Preisler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Builder's Fall Halts Projects In Connecticut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 30

 BODY:
For four years, construction executives watched with dismay as George A. Tomasso again and again underbid them on state projects, transforming a start-up company into the largest road and bridge builder in Connecticut.
While competitors grumbled privately that something was amiss, state officials brushed aside complaints and said the law was the law: contracts must be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. 
 But in recent weeks, as Mr. Tomasso abruptly halted work at 19 sites and was admitted to a hospital for the mentally ill, questions have emerged over whether the lowest bid is always the best bid and whether, in times of budget cutting, officials might be willing to overlook a contractor's problems if he were saving the state money.
The collapse of the George A. Tomasso Construction Corporation has left dozens of subcontractors with at least $13 million in unpaid bills and led to the layoffs of hundreds of workers. In addition, work on some of the state's busiest highways has been delayed, jeopardizing six projects on which paving needs to be be completed before winter.
Some elected officials wonder why Mr. Tomasso's surprisingly low bids did not cause greater alarm sooner.
Company insiders knew something was amiss. Stephen Calabro, a former bid estimator for Tomasso, pointed to one project that the state expected to cost $92 million. Mr. Tomasso's staff said the cost would be at least $85 million, but when told that figure might not insure winning the contract, Mr. Tomasso bid $68 million. The next lowest bid was $103 million.
"George just came up with a number out of the blue," Mr. Calabro said. "He wanted that job, and he didn't care what he got it as."
Nor was it a secret that Mr. Tomasso's behavior was erratic. In 1992, he went to a competitor's office and dismissed everyone, saying he had bought the company. He was taken away in an ambulance.
In the first official challenge to the Transportation Department's handling of the Tomasso situation, State Senator William A. Aniskovich, a co-chairman of the legislature's Transportation Committee, said his committee would hold hearings in February to examine why the state continued to award contracts and pay millions of dollars to Mr. Tomasso when there was evidence his company was overextended.
"This could have been avoided," he said. "The economics of what was happening should have been clear to anyone who took a look at the big picture."
The state's failure to act sooner probably has political roots, Mr. Aniskovich added. Many construction executives say that Mr. Tomasso received special treatment from the administration of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. after hiring a close Weicker associate, John Doyle, as a consultant in 1991. Mr. Tomasso also held a fund-raising dinner for Governor Weicker several years ago and gave all his employees copies of Mr. Weicker's autobiography.
But state officials say that Mr. Tomasso was not shown any favoritism, adding that Mr. Tomasso's low bids saved the state $58 million. They point to his company's history of excellent work, and to the state's caution last February, when, as it became clear the company was not paying its subcontractors, the department refused to accept bids on seven contracts he would have won.
They add that a bonding company is obligated to see that Mr. Tomasso's projects are finished at the price he bid and that his subcontractors are paid.
"One way or another, the jobs will be completed and people paid," said Arthur W. Gruhn, the Transportation Department construction administrator in charge of the Tomasso situation. Already, some subcontractors have received checks, and work is expected to resume this week; thus the projects, which are largely ahead of schedule, will have suffered "minimal impact," he added.
 
Life in the Shadow Of a Famous Family
 Yet, some construction industry experts are skeptical about when work will resume, and Mr. Gruhn acknowledged that the longer the delay, the greater the difficulties.
The rise and fall of George Tomasso is shrouded in mystery.
Mr. Tomasso, 68, comes from one of the state's pre-eminent construction families, yet seems to have spent most of his life in its shadow. His older brother, Angelo Jr., is known in their hometown, New Britain, for his philanthropy. His nephews are prominent developers.
By comparison, George Tomasso is considered something of a recluse.
Angelo Jr., George and two other brothers took over their father's successful business, Angelo Tomasso Inc., in 1949, with Angelo Jr. as president and George as treasurer. The company was sold in 1972 over George Tomasso's objections, several people in the construction industry said. After signing a pledge not to compete in the Connecticut construction industry for many years, they added, he moved to Florida.
While Angelo Tomasso Jr. prospered with the new company and today is chairman of the business that grew out of the sale, Tilcon Connecticut, George Tomasso reportedly pursued his own investments. Then in 1985, he suddenly reappeared in Connecticut.
Mr. Tomasso could not be reached for comment after he was hospitalized, his relatives did not return repeated calls and his lawyers declined to comment.
But Mr. Tomasso's business strategy speaks for itself -- submit the low bid at any cost -- and he aggressively began to pursue it in the early 1990's, when Governor Weicker took office. Since Jan. 1, 1991, he has been awarded 46 contracts for $432.1 million, more than four times his total in the previous five years.
At present, Mr. Tomasso's 19 projects account for about 25 percent of the Transportation Department's construction work.
To corner so much of the market, Mr. Tomasso bid on all jobs regardless of size, and routinely came in 10 percent lower than his nearest competitor, a gap that many in the industry found stunning.
The most remarkable instance was Mr. Tomasso's $68.3 million bid on Sept. 25, 1991, to widen the Founders Bridge between Hartford and East Hartford. The next lowest bid was $103.9 million.
"It was a slap in the face," said a competitor, who refused to be identified for fear of angering the Transportation Department. "There was no way anyone could come in and do the Founders Bridge that much lower than the second, third and fourth bidders. It's like he was saying, 'You folks don't know what you're doing and I'm the big cheese -- I'm going to show you.' "
 
Allowed to Bid, While Overextended
 Mr. Tomasso qualified for a number of bids though his company was already extended beyond its financial capacity rating. In a highly unusual but legal arrangement, he masso backed six jobs with his personal fortune and successfully bid for the projects as a joint venture between his company and himself.
At the same time, Mr. Tomasso cultivated an image of being politically connected. Along with hiring Mr. Doyle, he held a fund-raising dinner for Mr. Weicker at a West Hartford country club and shared a table with the Governor. This year, he bought copies of Mr. Weicker's autobiography, "Maverick," for all his employees, one laborer said.
It now appears that these actions were not simply shrewd business or political maneuvers, but the moves of a psychologically troubled man.
In the construction industry, Mr. Tomasso had a reputation for being unstable, and in one incident in May 1992, he stormed into the office of a competitor, Balf/Savin in Newington, telling employees that they were dismissed and that he had bought the company. He had not. The police were called, and an ambulance took him away, Edward Gilligan, a Balf/ Savin executive, said.
This month, the probate court declared Mr. Tomasso "incapable of managing his affairs and incapable of caring for himself by reason of impairment." Court records showed he was at the Institute of Living, a hospital for the mentally ill in Hartford, and had refused to speak to a court-appointed lawyer.
Mr. Tomasso's health difficulties seem to coincide with his company's growing problems, and with the election of John G. Rowland, a Weicker foe, as Governor.
Because of his low bids, Mr. Aniskovich said, it appears that Mr. Tomasso was relying on a pyramid scheme in which he used money from new contracts to finish the work on old ones.
Mr. Calabro, the estimator, left the company in March 1994, when suppliers required him to pay in advance, even for purchases under $100. "I saw the end nearing and didn't want to get caught in the situation he's in now," Mr. Calabro said.
Over the last few years, Mr. Tomasso often violated state laws requiring prompt payment of subcontractors. Such lapses led the state to deny him any new contracts this year.
Since then, Mr. Tomasso fell even further behind in his payments to subcontractors and suppliers, and at the end of the summer, the bond company, faced with 70 claims from subcontractors, asked the state to cease payments for the 19 projects.
 
State Calls a Halt After Bills Pile Up
 On Sept. 8, the Tomasso company halted work, and the next day issued a release saying, "As the department is our sole client and source of income, our only recourse was to suspend all field operations."
Since then, the National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pennsylvania, the bond company, has sued Mr. Tomasso and his company for millions of dollars.
In a time of fiscal restraint, it is easy to understand the allure of unusually low bids, and Mr. Tomasso, with his background in the construction industry, was viewed by some as a civic-minded maverick breaking the stranglehold that a few companies had on the industry.
While his bids may prove to have been unrealistic, the head of a contractors association in another state remarked that contractors have been known to take innovative approaches to jobs to achieve savings that others thought impossible. And sometimes, a contractor may choose to take a loss on a job.
For these reasons, assessing a low bid is a thorny proposition, one that poses political risk for state officials who can be accused of illegally rejecting the least expensive offer, particularly when it has been guaranteed by a bonding company.
Mr. Aniskovich recognized these complications, but he felt the Tomasso situation was pushing the limits.
"Is it good for the state that George won some bids by lowballing?," he said. "Yes, it is. But is it good that 19 contracts later we have 350 people laid off from his company, subcontractors suffering and the prospect of higher costs?
"Of course not.It's a matter of degree."

HEADLINE: China: The Squall Passes

 BODY:
After a shaky summer, America's relations with China are getting back on track. Last week, Beijing backed off from its plans to sell nuclear reactors to Iran, a deal that carried serious proliferation risks. A little earlier, China returned its Ambassador to Washington after a long protest absence and approved the nomination of former Senator James Sasser to be America's next Ambassador in Beijing. Agreement has not yet been reached on a summit meeting between President Clinton and China's President, Jiang Zemin, but is expected soon.
The euphoria that once characterized United States-Chinese relations is not likely to return soon. Too much divides the two countries, on human rights, proliferation, trade and other issues. But given China's strategic and economic significance it would be a calamity for Washington and Beijing to become adversaries again. The Clinton Administration managed the crisis skillfully, with Secretary of State Warren Christopher leading the way. 
 The quarrel erupted last spring after the Administration, bowing to Congressional pressure, issued a visa to Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, so he could visit Cornell University, his alma mater. But the Administration resisted Beijing's contentions that the visa was the only issue between the two countries and that the United States was clearly at fault.
The roots of recent tensions go back to China's crushing of its democracy movement at Tiananmen Square, its sales of missiles and other advanced weapons in violation of understandings with the United States, and its offensive trade practices regarding prison labor and copyright piracy. For the past year or more, these problems have been aggravated by political maneuvering in Beijing anticipating the death of Deng Xiaoping.
On Taiwan, the original joint communiques and accompanying American legislation governing this issue do not clearly preclude private visits by top Taiwanese officials.
Thus the Administration was right to hold its ground on Taiwan, neither apologizing nor promising not to issue a repeat visa to President Lee. Instead, Washington again acknowledged that the issue was a sensitive one for China and affirmed that America's policy as embodied in the joint communiques remains unchanged.
China, realizing it had pushed things to a dangerous brink, stepped back. In return, Beijing hopes President Jiang will be invited for a state visit to Washington. The Administration understands, however, that what is needed now is not pomp and ceremony but working talks.
These talks need to deal with reports of recent Chinese missile sales to Pakistan and to review enforcement of recent agreements on copyright and prison labor. Washington must also convey its concern over menacing Chinese military exercises in the South China Sea and near Taiwan. The Administration should also continue to speak out in support of the human rights of Chinese citizens, as First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton did at last month's Beijing women's conference. In the past, China suggested that if human rights discussions were not linked to threats of retaliatory sanctions, it might pay them more heed.
Relations between Washington and Beijing are still delicate. The Clinton Administration managed to stabilize them without yielding on important principles, not a simple piece of diplomacy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NYC;
Give Yankees A Government They Deserve

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
HERE'S an idea making the rounds this final day of the regular baseball season:
Condemn the Yankees. 
 Not, as usual, by moaning about the relief pitchers or railing against the latest affront by George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., the club owner. Available evidence suggests that Bronx cheers by themselves wound George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., about as much as they do, say, Saddam Hussein.
What some people talk about instead is legal condemnation, having the city and state take over the Yankees -- players, pinstripes, pennants and all -- just as they might lay claim to any private enterprise deemed essential to the commonweal.
Naturally, the present owners would be compensated at fair market value, and that could involve a few hundred million municipal dollars. But that way, at least, New York would designate the Yankees a vital resource, not something ripe for export to New Jersey. And then it could sell its holdings, or simply turn over management, to private investors more committed to keeping the club in the South Bronx than George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., a man whose literary tastes seem to run to Ogden Nash. ("The Bronx? No thonx.")
"I BELIEVE we can do it," says Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President. The problem at Yankee Stadium is the team's owner, he contends, not the traffic flow or neighborhood crime. So change owners.
"Would the City of New York be a worse manager of the Yankees than Steinbrenner?" asks Kent Barwick, president of the New York State Historical Association, another condemnation advocate. "Frankly, I think it would be a tossup."
Now, both these men know that theirs is a hard row upstream. The Yankees, who insist they have made up their minds about nothing in the future except getting into the playoffs, would no doubt go to court, and so might Major League Baseball. Their lawyers would know that gambits akin to the Ferrer proposal failed to keep football teams in Baltimore and Oakland. Besides, neither this Mayor nor this Governor seems like a man interested in scaring up ways for government to go into the baseball business.
But if nothing else, skygazing about the legal possibilities can be a pleasant diversion for the many Yankee fans appalled by the unhappy choices handed them thus far.
The latest chatter is about a new Yankee ballpark for the far West Side of mid-Manhattan. Price: a billion dollars plus. That strikes many civic-minded New Yorkers as a dubious spending priority for a city that thinks switch-hitting means battering basic services left and right. It is tempting for some of them to say that if George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., really wants to move his club to the New Jersey Meadowlands, let's kick him down the stairs right now and tell him good riddance. ("The Yonx? No thonx.")
While that may salvage a bit of municipal pride, reality suggests that the city cannot afford to be so cavalier.
 WILL New York be less of a great city without the Yankees? Doubtful. Will its economy go straight down the tubes? Same answer. But losing the world's most fabled sports franchise would be an unbearable spiritual blow, especially for the South Bronx, struggling to rebuild and hardly in need of one more reason to feel abused.
Try telling Max Choi he can live without the team. Three months ago, unschooled in Yankee ways, Mr. Choi bought a hardware store on Gerard Avenue, a block east of Yankee Stadium. Suddenly, he discovers that the team may pull up stakes for a sweetheart deal somewhere else.
Is he nervous? "Sure I am," Mr. Choi says, leaving a detailed explanation to Louis Adorno, who cuts hair a few doors away.
"This neighborhood would go right down if the Yankees go," Mr. Adorno says. "Why do you think they give us the cops here, and maintain the train station? You think that'll continue if the Yankees leave? People will move out. Nobody wants to live in a rundown area."
His solution is for the city to try hard to keep the Yankees where they are, but not at any price. That's Mr. Ferrer's point, too. Legally condemning the Yankees and fixing up the stadium area would save the team and cost far less than building a new ballpark, he says.
It would also mean that the interests of George M. Steinbrenner 3d of Tampa, Fla., are not more important to the city than those of Max Choi of Gerard Avenue.

HEADLINE: '95-'96 N.H.L.: ON HOCKEY;
Add Lemieux to the List of Great Comebacks

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

 BODY:
Mario Lemieux's return to hockey is the third such event in 1995, the Year of the Sports Comeback.
The first involved Michael Jordan, the basketball star, who missed more than a season and ended up playing minor league baseball. Maybe it was a coincidence, and maybe it wasn't, that he changed sports during a public examination of his recreational gambling hobby. 
 The second involved Monica Seles, the tennis star, who needed more than two years to recover from physical and psychological wounds after being stabbed in the back by a spectator in Germany. The assailant was never even sentenced to a prison term.
Compared with the uproar over those comebacks, Lemieux's return seems almost routine. He is back with the Pittsburgh Penguins after more than a season on the shelf following recurring back problems and his battle with Hodgkin's disease.
His timing is good. The season he missed was shabby, delayed for 15 weeks by a labor lockout and completed with too many dull games in too few rushed nights.
This one promises to be better, thanks to labor peace and to new officiating policies that will favor talented superstars such as Lemieux. In the seasons before his sabbatical, Lemieux was a frequent critic of the holding, hooking and interference that allowed mediocre players to nullify their betters.
Coaches taught these techniques and referees gradually stopped penalizing many of them. It became a quality-of-life issue, like the gentle extortion of the squeegee men and panhandlers who have decorated the sidewalks of New York. Such behavior, if tacitly allowed, begins to seem almost normal.
In his harshest remarks, Lemieux once called the N.H.L. a "garage league," a description accidentally changed in some accounts to "garbage league," which also seemed to fit his evaluation of his work environment.
Now, the league promises to obstruct the obstructors. Having squandered its marketing momentum last season, the promoters seek a faster, more sleek, more slick show to sell over the Fox Network and the ESPN networks and in Miami and Anaheim and in 24 other markets.
Usually a reluctant celebrity, Lemieux might not be the ideal superstar/salesman for the N.H.L. of the late 1990's, but he might be the best available. The league really has no one with the charisma of Jordan and the exuberance of Seles. It is almost as if hockey is searching.
Wayne Gretzky, the 34-year-old legend whose sublime skills are waning on a bad Los Angeles team, has lost a little luster in recent seasons. He seems weary of the acclaim and attention, hiding out in Hollywood. If he's not yet Norma Desmond, he's borderline Garbo.
Eric Lindros, the young Philadelphia star who last season won his first Hart Trophy as the league's most valuable player, is still wary of the spotlight and may never warm to it. Having resisted exploitation as a teen-ager in Canadian junior leagues and the double-dealing of the first professional team that drafted him, he sometimes comes across as cynical beyond his 22 years, a suspicious and guarded man-child who looks for the hook in every question.
The Russian stars such as Pavel Bure, Sergei Fedorov and Alexander Mogilny can dazzle on the ice. But when it comes to dealing with the news media and, by extension, the fans, their cultural backgrounds don't help. Sometimes, they hide behind their language barrier.
Having grown up in a totalitarian system where reporters were part of party rule, they seem skeptical about the motives of nosy interrogators and about the intentions of authority figures. It's just a hunch, but it seemed as if the young Russians, including Aleksei Kovalev of the Rangers, felt betrayed by the lockout last season, their first brush with the mean streak of capitalism. Sure, they'll play for pay, but don't expect too much more.
So this leaves Lemieux, and the stories from Penguins camp have been optimistic. They say he is in great shape, sculptured, no longer soft around the middle. They say he has been on the ice for every practice, not behind the closed doors of the medical room.
Although Lemieux is not about to grab a microphone and make an MTV video, reporters say he has been available for interviews and, if not colorful, at least accommodating. Perhaps he missed the scene. And when the Penguins were winning the Stanley Cup in 1991 and 1992, Lemieux -- with his big reach, his quick, hard shot and his eerie play-making instincts -- was undeniably the greatest show on hockey earth.
The plan calls for him to play about 60 or 65 times in the 82-game schedule. He will miss some trips and back-to-back games. Such a common-sense approach also might be wise for other players without his health problems, and what better person to use as a test case? He celebrates his 30th birthday this week as the league announces ambitious plans for Olympic participation and economic growth. A healthy, happy Lemieux could help restore the health and happiness of his business. Such serendipity. Happy birthday, Magnifique. Welcome back.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Penguins' Mario Lemieux is playing again after being sidelined with recurring back problems and his battle with Hodgkin's disease. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 721 words

HEADLINE: Simplifying the Tax Code Isn't So Simple

 BODY:
Proposals to overhaul the Federal income tax system share two stated goals: to make the tax code simpler and fairer. But the debate in Washington, and among taxpayers across the country, shows the complexities of making such changes. Peter Passell's look at the proposals ("The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room," Sept. 3) drew many reader reactions, including various responses to its discussion of plans for a so-called flat tax.
 
To the Editor:
The comprehensive article seriously understates the taxes that would have to be paid with the flat tax. The understatement is particularly severe for those with very low incomes and for middle-income taxpayers with incomes as high as $100,000. The very rich, however, would have huge reductions in their taxes. 
 First, the tax rate necessary for revenue neutrality would not be the initial 20 percent claimed by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, let alone the 17 percent he contends would be possible in the future, but rather 23 percent. This is indicated in effect in the original proposal, by the economists Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka, on which Mr. Armey's bill is based, and is confirmed by my own calculations with data from the Internal Revenue Service's Statistics of Income as well as by other economists cited in the article.
Second, and most important, the article misstates the impact of the flat tax by ignoring, as does Mr. Armey, the incidence of the business portion of his flat tax. The current income tax, as of 1993, took 15.71 percent of total income. Of this, the nonbusiness portion of personal income taxes amounted to 9.77 percent and business taxes 5.95 percent. Mr. Armey's flat tax, if it applied the precisely 22.87 percent rate necessary for revenue neutrality, would raise the business tax from that 5.95 percent to 10.91 percent.
But, of course, it is ultimately not businesses but people that pay taxes, and as the proponents of the flat tax recognize -- and indeed boast -- their tax is a tax exclusively on consumption. To calculate the totals paid under the flat tax, then, we have to include the taxes paid by consumers. These would be considerably greater than those paid by consumers under current law where business taxes are much less.
I have compared the total tax incidence of the flat tax and current taxes in a paper to be published shortly by the American Enterprise Institute. I find that even for those with the lowest incomes, presumably exempt from the tax on wages, total flat taxes paid would have been markedly higher. For those with adjusted gross incomes between $10,000 and $20,000, the Armey version of the flat tax would have taken 11.88 percent of total income in 1993, compared with 10.18 percent under current law. For those in the $40,000-to-$50,000 group, the flat tax would have taken 15.76 percent of total income, compared with 14.04 percent under current law. Indeed, taxpayers in all income groups up to $100,000 would pay more under the flat tax.
It is only those in top income tax brackets who would gain. In the $100,000-to-$200,000 group, the tax burden would fall from 18.65 percent of total income to 16.12 percent. And in the $200,000-and-over group it would fall by almost half, from 24.36 percent to 12.69 percent.
A vastly simplified tax does not have to be that way, and I have proposed one that is not. But the Armey flat tax is enormously regressive, essentially for two reasons. First, interest and dividends, capital gains and noncorporate business profits, from which very high-income groups earn very large proportions of their income, would no longer be taxed at the individual level. And second, the vastly increased business tax would hit hard those of modest incomes, chiefly from wages and pensions, who unlike the very rich spend almost all their income on domestic consumption.
What reductions in individual income taxes the flat tax would provide would be far outweighed, for most Americans, by their increased burden from business taxes. Only the very rich would benefit.
 
ROBERT EISNER
Evanston, Ill. Sept. 13
 
The writer is professor emeritus at Northwestern University and a past president of the American Economic Association. He is the author of "The Misunderstood Economy: What Counts and How to Count It."
