SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 339 words

HEADLINE: Simplifying the Tax Code Isn't So Simple

 BODY:
Proposals to overhaul the Federal income tax system share two stated goals: to make the tax code simpler and fairer. But the debate in Washington, and among taxpayers across the country, shows the complexities of making such changes. Peter Passell's look at the proposals ("The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room," Sept. 3) drew many reader reactions, including various responses to its discussion of plans for a so-called flat tax.
 
To the Editor:
No one is watching the debate about tax reform with greater interest than those of us at the Internal Revenue Service, and no one is more dedicated to making our tax system, whatever it may be, more efficient. 
 I was surprised -- and your readers may be misled -- by the comment by Joel Slemrod, director of the office of policy research at the University of Michigan, that it costs a dime to collect a dollar of tax revenue. It certainly doesn't cost the Government a dime. Our data show that our costs are substantially below a penny on the dollar. And we're trying to do better.
Obviously taxpayers have costs as well, but it boggles the mind to believe they are many times larger than ours. Millions next year will file simple returns with a single telephone call that lasts less than 10 minutes. At the other extreme is the 1040, which requires about 12 hours to deal with -- a bit more if collateral forms are added. So those with complex returns are spending about an hour a month on income tax issues.
But many taxpayers are spending less time because they file simpler forms. Fewer than 60 percent use the 1040. And, of course, the minority with complicated economic lives file complex tax returns that take a lot of time to compile. Still, the Slemrod estimate seems very high.
Whatever the reality -- and whatever happens to our tax system -- the I.R.S. will continue to work to bring the cost of tax collection down for everyone.
 
MARGARET MILNER RICHARDSON
Washington, Sept. 8
 
The writer is Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service.

HEADLINE: Simplifying the Tax Code Isn't So Simple

 BODY:
Proposals to overhaul the Federal income tax system share two stated goals: to make the tax code simpler and fairer. But the debate in Washington, and among taxpayers across the country, shows the complexities of making such changes. Peter Passell's look at the proposals ("The Tax Code Heads Into the Operating Room," Sept. 3) drew many reader reactions, including various responses to its discussion of plans for a so-called flat tax.
 
To the Editor:
The article states that Republican plans for simplifying the tax system "should save tens, perhaps hundreds, of billions of dollars now wasted on record-keeping, accountants and misdirected investments." 
 As a certified public accountant, I object to this characterization of accountants' services as being a waste of money. Accountants do not create the complexities that exist in Federal and state tax laws; Congress and state legislatures do. Taxpayers who choose not to engage the services of competent accountants and attempt to interpret the tax code on their own are in many instances making a foolish decision.
Even if the most drastic of the Republican proposals, an all-out flat tax, is enacted, much of the complexity in the tax laws will remain with us. We have 50 states with their own unique tax systems. The states cannot even assign uniform numbers to their tax forms. Wouldn't it be simpler for each state to use the number 1040 for their personal income tax form such as New Jersey (Form NJ-1040), than using inconsistent numbers (New York: Form IT-201, California: Form 540)? The states will be apprehensive to piggyback a Federal flat tax which would result in the elimination of all the unique provisions in each state's law. For example, New York taxes unemployment compensation while New Jersey does not.
A flat tax will not eliminate the controversies that all businesses face and which the I.R.S. continues to pursue vigorously concerning the classification of service providers as either employees or independent contractors. Another area of complexity: a flat tax will have no effect on sales tax at the state level. New Jersey exempts clothing from its sales tax. Regular shoes are exempt but golf shoes are taxable. Hair bows are exempt but hairnets and barrettes are taxable. In many states, cooked food is subject to sales tax but the same item purchased frozen is exempt.
While the various flat-tax proposals may provide some simplification, they are not the cure-all to our complex tax system.
 
NEIL BECOURTNEY
Teaneck, N.J., Sept. 13

HEADLINE: A Russian Scientist Cautions Chemical Arms Safety Is Lax

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
A Russian scientist says in an article to be published tomorrow that his country's chemical-weapon stockpile is more vulnerable to theft and illegal production than the Soviet nuclear arsenal was.
The scientist, Vil S. Mirzayanov, reported in 1991 that Moscow was secretly developing and testing chemical weapons after publicly renouncing them, and he was imprisoned twice -- in 1992 and 1994 -- for writing about the weapons program. 
 He says in the article that security around chemical-weapon storage sites is lax and that Russia does not have the money or technology to destroy its stocks safely. Officials with knowledge of the program and access to chemicals are being laid off and are desperate for money, he adds.
"Russia's stockpile is also a ticking ecological time bomb," Mr. Mirzayanov writes. He added that safety standards are routinely violated and that Russian workers have been contaminated. In 1993 and 1994, he writes, scientists tried to destroy stocks of binary weapons by detonating them in the open air at the Shikhany test site, in the Saratov region. Binary weapons combine two separate compounds at the point of delivery and yield some of the most poisonous agents ever developed.
Mr. Mirzayanov's article appears in "Chemical Weapons Disarmament in Russia: Problems and Prospects," to be published by the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington, an independent organization for research into weapons.
Several dozen private Russian organizations and groups from the United States will meet in Saratov from Oct. 20 to Oct. 23 to consider the health and environmental consequences of further destruction of chemical arms, said Craig Williams, a spokesman for the Chemical Weapons Working Group in Berea, Ky., which opposes disposing of nerve gas by incineration.
Among those taking part will be Pacific Islanders concerned about the potential danger from an incinerator for chemical weapons opened in 1990 by the United States on Johnson Atoll, 700 miles southwest of Hawaii. Opponents of the incinerator say there are safer and cheaper ways to dispose of the chemicals.
Mr. Mirzayanov, 60, worked for the Soviet Government in chemical weapons research for 26 years and lost his job after he revealed information about the program. Unable to get a new job in Russia, he is in the United States looking for work. In the Stimson Center article, he gives details for the first time of the extent and size of Russia's binary weapons research, which he believes has now ended.
In 1989 the Soviet Union and the United States exchanged information about each other's chemical weapons programs for the first time. Washington declared that it possessed 30,000 tons of material; Moscow reported that it had 40,000 tons, though some independent scientists believe the stocks were larger.
By that time, both countries had renounced the use of such weapons, and Russian officials denied accusations Mr. Mirzayanov first made in 1991 and 1992 that the chemical weapons program had continued.
Moscow's program to produce binary weapons, code-named Novichok, or newcomer, began as an effort to match American research into binary chemical weapons, Mr. Mirzayanov writes, adding that tons of binary compounds were produced and tested from 1989 to 1993. Several of these were 5 to 10 times as powerful as the known so-called "nerve gases," a droplet of which can kill within a minute either by inhalation or through the skin.
Mr. Mirzayanov's earlier writings, in the Moscow newspapers Kuranty in 1991 and Moscow News in 1992, have been used by both sides of the debate in this country and abroad over the fate and importance of an international treaty barring the manufacture, sale, possession or use of chemical weapons. The treaty, the Chemical Weapons Convention, has been signed by 159 nations.
Only 39 nations have ratified the treaty, however, out of the 65 that are necessary to bring it into force. It is awaiting action in both the United States Senate and the Russian Parliament, which many experts believe is waiting to take its cue from Capitol Hill. Staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee say there is virtually no chance of a vote in the full Senate this year.
Opponents of the treaty in the United States Congress and some research institutions say that it cannot prevent the spread of chemical weapons, which are easier to conceal and move around than other weapons. Supporters of the treaty say that without it there would be no international tools to use against traffickers or nations seeking to stockpile these arms by buying them on the black market. Mr. Mirzayanov initially opposed the treaty, but now supports it.
While Congress has allocated money to help Russia reduce its nuclear materials and to find work for unemployed nuclear scientists, no similar program has been introduced for the chemical weapons industry.
In late October, the United States Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations will hold hearings on the spread of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
In an interview last week, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia, who is pressing for ratification, said that if Parliament returns to Moscow in a serious mood next week after a break, "positive signals from Congress would be very, very beneficial." He added, however, that if the Parliament members turn their fall session into an extension of the political campaign for the Russian elections in December, the treaty will be "a lost case."
In a separate article in the Stimson publication, Amy E. Smithson, a senior associate at the center, examined in detail the safety of Russian chemical weapons storage sites. Like Mr. Mirzayanov, she says the sites are vulnerable to theft and to environmentally dangerous deterioration.
"In all candor, many American homes have more sophisticated physical security than was observed at some Russian chemical weapons storage sites," she wrote.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 4, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about chemical weapons in Russia misstated the fears expressed by the author of a report on the subject. The scientist, Vil S. Mirzayanov, said the chemical stockpiles were vulnerable to transfer, sale or theft. He did not refer to the further production of such weapons. They are no longer produced in Russia.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Big Retailers Are Taking The Bronx - And S.I. Too

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TO Barry Greenberg, it was a no-brainer: Discovery Zone, then a Chicago-based chain of indoor playgrounds, wanted to expand. The Bronx, with its dense population, seemed perfect. "I knew their sales would be off the charts there," said Mr. Greenberg, a vice president of the New Spectrum store brokerage.
But when Mr. Greenberg broached the idea to Discovery Zone's management three years ago, he slammed into a wall of fear. Never mind that the company already had one successful Bronx facility. Movies like "Fort Apache: The Bronx" and media reports about carnage in the borough had taken their toll. 
 So Mr. Greenberg took a group of Discovery Zone executives on a bus tour of the dread borough. "While we rode, I talked about rents of $70 and $80," Mr. Greenberg recalled, referring to annual rents per square foot. "They laughed. But once we hit the Caldor store on Fordham Road, the laughter was gone."
It was replaced, Mr. Greenberg says, by awe at the hordes of people carrying shopping bags -- and scores of children playing in the Discovery Zone on Valentine Avenue, two blocks from Caldor. "They immediately told me to look for another Bronx site," Mr. Greenberg said.
Mr. Greenberg played host to a similar bus tour in Brooklyn and Queens. The upshot: Discovery Zone now has stores in each borough, another under construction in Brooklyn, and -- provided it gets past its current financial problems -- wants to open half a dozen more, spread throughout New York.
It may have trouble finding sites for them. It seems that everyone, from retailers to real estate brokers, from developers to city officials, is waking up to the vast amount of buying power that exists in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx. They know that the rents are high, that crime can be a problem, that getting building permits can take forever, that they may have to settle for inadequate parking and strangely shaped, multilevel stores.
But those drawbacks are overshadowed by the sheer volume of New York City shoppers who, study after study shows, are flocking to Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey to shop. A recent Gallup poll of 1,000 New York households showed that 32 percent of them had shopped outside New York in 1994, that they averaged 22 shopping trips in the year, and spent an average of $154 per trip. Most telling: 78 percent of those shoppers said they would have shopped in their own boroughs, if only the stores were available.
"We export $3.4 billion a year in sales across city lines, and we are losing more than 15,000 good jobs and millions of dollars of tax revenue," said Joseph B. Rose, the director of the Department of City Planning, which is trying to ease the regulatory burden on new stores.
Retailers, meanwhile, may be missing out on swollen sales. "Pathmark can do $1,000 in sales per square foot in the inner city, while competitors two highway exits away do $500," said Paul G. W. Fetscher, president of Great American Brokerage in Manhattan.
Developers are recognizing that, too. One recent example: Forest City Ratner has finally broken ground for Atlantic Center, its long-awaited shopping center at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues in downtown Brooklyn. Caldor, Sports Authority, Marshalls, Old Navy, Pathmark, Office Max, PC Richard and several others have signed up for space. The 400,000-square-foot center, which will have only 650 parking spaces, will probably open in November of 1996.
Local retailers have snapped up many buildings on the main shopping drags and are renting excess space to national chains. Larger developers are going after abandoned factories and tracts of land. "Everyone is looking for a diamond in the rough, for that industrial building or piece of land that works for retail," said Peter Botsaris, president of the Garrick-Aug store brokerage.
Neither the flattening out of retail sales across the country, nor the recent bankruptcy filings of Bradlees and Caldor, two of the biggest players in the outer boroughs, have dampened the developers' zeal. They acknowledge that the financial problems may scuttle some chains' expansion plans, and might even force a few to close stores. But if that happens, developers say, other retailers are certain to take up the slack.
"If God forbid something really bad happened to Caldor, you could zap a supermarket into its stores and do really well," said Bruce Ratner of Forest City Ratner.
That is not bombast. Warehouse stores like BJ's and Price Club all want to open their first New York City stores. Pathmark is looking to open more supermarkets in the outer boroughs. Movie exhibitors are always looking for sites for multiplexes.
"Virtually every large tract of land or building is subject to inspection by a big box user these days," said Guy Morris, Garrick-Aug's shopping center specialist. "They'll make their geometric formulas fit into whatever space is available."
The borough newcomers are not chasing the types of shoppers that stroll up Madison Avenue or Rodeo Drive. They cater to the solid lower-middle-income crowd.
While Manhattan is riddled with Gap stores, for example, in the other boroughs that chain is opening far more Old Navy stores, which sell the Gap's lower-priced lines. For the same reason, it was Caldor and Bradlees, both discounters, that bid for the stores that the bankrupt Alexanders gave up in 1992 (Caldor won).
The chains are rapidly changing the character of the boroughs' main shopping streets. Streets like Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, 86th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, East Fordham Road in the Bronx and Hylan Boulevard in Staten Island, all once bastions of local boutiques and service shops, now are dotted with Fayva and Payless Shoe Stores, with Lechter household stores, with Old Navy and even Benetton.
"The vacancy rate on the major streets is zippo," said Michael Myers, chairman of the brokerage Corporate Realty Partners.
INDEED, the chains have driven annual rents to about $45 to $50 a square foot on Steinway Street, $80 to $100 on Fordham Road, $60 to $70 on 86th Street -- a lot more than a local shoemaker can pay. So the local stores have moved to peripheral locations, thereby expanding the shopping districts.
"The national retailers didn't push out the local bakeries or delis, they pushed them to vacant side street space," Mr. Botsaris said.
Nor is the retail boom confined to main streets. Retailers are lining up to get into old centers like Queens Plaza and Brooklyn's Kings Plaza. And new shopping centers are springing up, revolving around the so-called big box retailers whose huge stores rarely fit on crowded urban streets.
For many of these stores, New York is the last unsaturated territory. Home Depot, for example, has 393 stores across the country, yet only has two in New York City, in Ozone Park and Flushing, Queens. It bucked formidable opposition from local merchants to get the Flushing store open, and is facing local opposition to a store it wishes to build on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx. Still, it is pressing on.
'We would be remiss if we were not in New York," said Jerry Shields, a spokesman for Home Depot.
Similarly, Circuit City, the huge electronic chain, has 335 stores and a strategic plan that, by the end of 1996, will give it stores in every major market except New York. The chain is said to be ready to take a site on 14th Street in Manhattan, and is canvassing the other boroughs for sites, too. Ann M. Collier, a Circuit City assistant vice president, notes that the chain has not "announced" any expansion plans in New York, but makes it clear that, for a national chain, a move to New York is inevitable.
"We have 300 smaller markets that we could go to, but we really want to be a national retailer," she said.
The retailers who are already here say their expansion is curbed only by a shortage of sites. Toys 'R' Us, for one, has 10 toy stores and two Kids 'R' Us stores in the boroughs outside of Manhattan. It will soon open a Kids store in Long Island City, and plans to open a Toys store in College Point, Queens. And, it seeks sites for more stores.
"People read the stories about shrinkage, about rent, about taxes, and they're afraid to come to New York," said Michael P. Miller, a Toys 'R' Us senior vice president. "But once you take the plunge, you say, 'Why didn't I do this sooner?' "
The boroughs beyond Manhattan have not always been an easy sell to retailers. Even the big box users, whose size and clout usually gets them the best bargains, often have to pay annual rents of anywhere from $20 to $35 a foot for New York stores, compared to $8 to $10 anywhere else. And, like the Discovery Zone executives, many out-of-town retailers have negative perceptions of the boroughs.
Developers say attitudes started changing after Caldor and Bradlees bid for the Alexanders stores. "That was the seminal event for big box retailing in New York," Mr. Ratner said. "All the other chains wanted to know what interested those two."
Many chain executives still balk at borough rents and reputations. So some developers offer to share risks, by lowering rents in exchange for high percentages of sales.
That's how Philips International lured Walgreens to a property in Mill Basin, not far from Brooklyn's Kings Plaza mall. "I wanted $35 and they turned me down three times," said Gregg M. Saunders, a Philips partner, describing the annual rental per square foot he was seeking. So Mr. Saunders halved the rent and upped his percentage of the take. "They're doing so well, it's like they are paying me $40 a foot," he said.
Mr. Saunders cut a similar deal with T.J. Maxx, which opened about seven months ago in Staten Island. Mr. Saunders asked $20 a foot; he agreed to $12 and a high percentage. "By next year I'll benefit from this," he predicted. He says T.J. Maxx now wants sites in Brooklyn and Queens.
HIS site search will probably run him up against Forest City Ratner, which has entered the boroughs in a major way.
"About three years ago, when the office market went down, we analyzed our core skills and realized that we were good at complex urban projects," Mr. Ratner said. What clinched it was a study Mr. Ratner commissioned that showed that at least half of the $3.4 billion that New Yorkers spend elsewhere each year could be recaptured by bringing better retailing to the city.
Forest City already has built Caldor a store, with about 300 rooftop parking spaces, on the site of the old Macy's on Flatbush Avenue. The developer has four more projects in various stages of development -- two in the Bronx, one in Queens, one in Brooklyn -- and has options on an eight-acre tract on Metropolitan Avenue and Woodhaven Boulevard in Queens, where it is thinking of a 200,000-square-foot shopping center.
Landowners who either cannot or do not want to develop their land themselves are getting ample offers of assistance.
Michelangelo Real Estate, which owns a small strip center of mom-and-pop stores on Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills, recently hired Corporate Realty Partners to lease it to a credit-worthy chain.
"We figured we'd get $21 a foot," Mr. Myers said. He underestimated: A bidding war ensued. Genovese Drugs won, and is paying $24 to start, with hefty escalations.
Mr. Myers hopes to do equally well with a seven-acre site in Woodhaven, Queens, owned by the estate of Sol Goldman and housing a Coca Cola distribution center. Mr. Myers says he's had interest from Home Depot and Caldor, and from developers, all of whom agreed to triple-net leases -- leases that, in effect, make the renters responsible for taxes and maintenance.
"Everyone would like to buy it, but the Goldman estate won't sell," he said. "Why sell properties and pay half the profits in taxes when you can rent and keep 90 cents on the dollar?"
The borough's retail landlords say they are indeed reaping rich rewards. Nearly five years ago Philips International paid $17 million for a six-acre site that housed an old ink factory on Northern Boulevard and 48th Street in Queens.
"Everyone thought we were nuts to pay that much," Mr. Saunders recalled. They weren't: Philips built the 120,000-square-foot Plaza 48 shopping center, and immediately attracted Toys 'R' Us, Pergament and several smaller tenants, all of which are doing brisk business.
Their success has attracted other retailers and developers. A Tops appliance store opened in adjacent space about a year ago. A Kmart is slated for a Ronzoni Factory nearby, while Caldor -- assuming bankruptcy does not scuttle its plan -- will go into a Gallo Wine building next door. Toys 'R' Us is opening a Kids store across from Tops.
Equally popular areas are sprinkled through each borough. Philips International has a 20-acre mall off Route 440 in Staten Island that is anchored by Caldor and is "doing serious business, even though it is in the middle of nowhere, " Mr. Saunders said. The developer Charles M. Yassky is squiring a 250,000-square-foot shopping center, also off Route 440, through the city approval process. It is to be anchored by a 60,000-square-foot Pathmark.
In the Bronx, Forest City Ratner just broke ground for a 110,000-square-foot center on Bruckner Boulevard and White Plains Road, across from thriving Toys 'R' Us and Caldor stores. It will house a Pergament, a Seamans, an Old Navy and sundry other stores, and should open in 9 months. Meanwhile, Bay Plaza, a 70-acre residential and commercial center near Co-op City, keeps expanding. Last year Kmart opened there, and The Wiz just doubled its space.
For New York City, the influx is bittersweet. For decades, the city harbored a dream of restoring its once-thriving manufacturing base, and used zoning to keep retailers from bidding up industrial rents.
"The restrictions had no beneficial impact on manufacturing, but they were devastating to retailing," Mr. Rose said.
Earlier this year, the Planning Department issued a proposal to allow stores of up to 200,000 square feet to open on an as-of-right basis in areas zoned for manufacturing. It recommended lowering commercial occupancy taxes outside of Manhattan, enforcing rules against street peddlers, and otherwise enhancing the quality of life on main shopping streets. But it would remove tax incentives for stores opening in higher income areas that already have retailers clamoring to get in.
"Those incentives were there to compensate for the cost of going through the tortuous approval process that we are eliminating," explained Eric A. Kober, the department's director of housing, economic and infrastructure planning.
The city expects that community boards, the City Planning Commission and the Borough Presidents will all support the proposals. "The mayor's goal is to have all this in place by the end of 1996," Mr. Kober said.
If the Bronx's track record is any indication, the proposals should sail through. In that borough, local community development corporations, most of which started as housing groups, have been actively pursuing retailers, particularly supermarkets.
"Their goal is to stabilize neighborhoods, improve quality of life, create jobs and make good products available," said Bernd Zimmermann, director of planning and development for Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer.
Examples abound. The Mid Bronx Desperados -- a deceptively macho name for a 20-year-old community group that has arranged for more than 25,000 units of subsidized housing -- is trying to bring Pathmark to a 10-acre site on the border of Crotona Park East and West Farms. The group, with funding from the Surdna Foundation, is preparing an environmental impact statement for the site, which was once slated for an industrial park. In High Bridge, a community development group is wooing a supermarket to a site on E.L. Grant Highway.
All the city and community efforts may fail, of course, if retail sales do not pick up, or if more bankruptcies occur.
"Everyone is nervous," said Michael D. Bailkin, managing partner of the law firm Stadtmauer Bailkin. He says that a year ago he would have predicted 30 new big box stores in the boroughs within the next few years; now he expects maybe 15.
Still, even Mr. Bailkin is ready to rethink his estimates if even one healthy newcomer enters the fray. "If a Target or a Wal-Mart comes it, it will spur another retail boomlet," he said. "I haven't heard rumors yet, but it could happen."

An article on Oct. 1 about retail development in the boroughs beyond Manhattan misstated the source of some money for a shopping-center project sponsored by the Mid Bronx Desperados, a community group. Development money for the project has come from the Comprehensive Community Revitalization Program, not solely from the Surdna Foundation. The article also misstated the number of subsidized housing units arranged by the Desperados. It is about 2,100.

SECTION: Section 13; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly/Queens

HEADLINE: INSIDE QUEENS;
A Criss-Crossed Quest

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW

 BODY:
JEFFREY A. SAUNDERS knew that Scrabble was born on 79th Street in Jackson Heights. He knew that Alfred Mosher Butts lived there when he invented the game.
But he also knew that he was one of the few -- historians of Scrabble included -- who had uncovered the real story of the popular word game. 
 Over the years, books, articles and information from the game's manufacturer carried conflicting accounts of Scrabble. Dates of the game's invention were variously listed from 1931 to 1933.
Rarely was it true origin in Jackson Heights mentioned, and that bothered Mr. Saunders, who has lived in the neighborhood for 10 years and serves as co-chairman of the architecture department of the Jackson Heights Beautification Group.
So about a year ago, Mr. Saunders began his quest, to solve the Scrabble puzzle and write Jackson Heights back into Scrabble history.
"As I started talking to people who play Scrabble and I realized how many are devoted to it, I decided that I had to reconnect Scrabble with Jackson Heights," he said. "History is not written in just bricks and gardens. History is also written in people and what they do with their time."
As a result of what Mr. Saunders did with his time -- checking archives, interviewing some of the game's original players and enlisting the help of a relative of Mr. Butts -- the latest book about the game and its history, "Everything Scrabble" (Pocket Books, 1995), and the game's official history published by its manufacturer, Milton Bradley, will be revised.
"It is clear that the history of Scrabble definitely needs to be rewritten," said John D. Williams, the editor of "Everything Scrabble" and the executive director of the National Scrabble Association.
Mr. Saunders began his search in the archives of the Community Methodist Church on 35th Avenue in Jackson Heights, where he had heard some of the first games were played during the Depression. He found listings of reservations from the mid-1930's for Scrabble games in the church's basement social room.
He searched for friends of Mr. Butts and his wife, Nina. He began to collect eyewitness accounts from some of the original players of Scrabble, like former members of the Jackson Heights Woman's College Club, or people who knew them.
"Everyone I talked to would say, 'Oh, Alf, Alf and his crazy game,' " Mr. Saunders said.
Last spring, a woman from Savannah, Ga., saw a national broadcast of a children's Scrabble competition in Jackson Heights and wrote Mr. Saunders to tell him she played the game in Mr. Butts's kitchen in the early 1930's.
Mr. Saunders heard similar stories, and he concluded that it was in Mr. Butts's garden apartment, around his dining room and kitchen tables, that friends and family learned the game.
And it was on Sunday nights during the Depression, in the church's social room, that residents of the neighborhood practiced the game with hand-cut wooden tiles week after week until Mr. Butts was satisfied he had it right.
Through the accounts, Mr. Saunders discovered that the game Mr. Butts conceived in 1931 evolved over several years, with input from the players. They helped him decide things like how many triple-score squares to place on the board (there are eight) and how the first turn should be decided (it is the player who draws from the tile bag the letter closest to A).
Mr. Saunders then contacted Robert R. Butts, the great-nephew of the game's inventor, who began to sort through Alfred Butts's diaries and papers. In the papers was the patent application for a game called Criss-Cross Words, dated 1938. The name was changed to Scrabble in 1947.
Robert Butts had all kinds of clues, like blueprints of the original letter tiles and other Scrabble memorabilia. A clearer picture of how Alfred Butts developed the game began to emerge.
"I really wanted to find out the chronology of when and where he lived in Jackson Heights and relate it to the development of his games," said Mr. Butts, who lives in the house in Stanfordville, N.Y., where his great-uncle lived from 1978 until his death in 1993.
Alfred Butts, an architect who was born in Poughkeepsie but lived most of his life in Jackson Heights, began experimenting with word games while he was unemployed in the early 1930's. He drew letters on architects' linen, made blueprints of them and used a printers' knife to cut them from pieces of plywood.
He assigned values to each letter, based on their frequency in the language, which he determined by studying the front pages of The New York Times.
Later, when he created a board for the game, he drew the crossword pattern onto a cloth and pasted it onto a Checkers board.
Last Wednesday night, Mr. Saunders' quest came full circle. He was among 30 Scrabble players gathered in the social room of the Community Methodist Church for the first meeting of the Queens Scrabble Club.
The players sat in pairs at card tables, shaking their corduroy and velvet tile bags. They spelled out words like "racily," "boxier," "ego" and "zoo" on their boards, competing in the very room where the first players sat 60 years ago, helping Alfred Mosher Butts perfect his game.
"Mr. Butts, Mr. Williams and I will get together in the next few months and consolidate all of this information," Mr. Saunders said at the club meeting. "And we will reestablish a history that has been hazy -- until now."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Therese Romero (left) and Joan Bishop play Scrabble in the church where its inventor tested the game. Jeffrey Saunders (right) updated the game's history. (Photographs by Steve Berman for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "WORD PLAY: A Brief History of Scrabble"
 Here are highlights of recent findings by Jeffrey A. Saunders, a Jackson Heights resident, and Robert R. Butts, the great-nephew of the game's inventor.
 
Early 1930's -- Alfred M. Butts begins devising a spelling game with lettered wodden tiles, but no game board. He calls it Lexiko.
 
1938 -- Mr. Butts acquires a patent for Criss-Cross Words, a crossword board game that evolved from Lexiko.
 
1947 -- James Brunot, a Connecticut entrepreneur, agrees to produce and market the game, which is renamed Scrabble.
 
1979 -- After changing hands several times, the game is sold to Hasbro, which turns it over to its Milton Bradley division.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Thinking (Just Thinking) About the Impossible

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN

 BODY:
It's too soon to write the obituary for Yankee Stadium, but perhaps not too soon to start thinking about what the city would do with the remains.
George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, has set the middle of next year as a deadline to decide where the Yankees will play after their lease on the stadium expires in 2002. Mr. Steinbrenner complains often about the 72-year-old stadium's problems with parking, traffic congestion and crime, and says the team could make more money by leaving the Bronx. In the last year, he has rejected 13 proposals from the Giuliani administration to keep the team in the city. And last month, New Jersey officials said they would be happy to see the New Jersey Yankees at the Meadowlands Sports Complex. 
 Mr. Steinbrenner is a shrewd negotiator, and all his maneuvering could be just a ploy. But New York has lost four pro sports teams in four decades: the Dodgers (1957, to Los Angeles), the baseball Giants (1957, to San Francisco), the football Giants (1975, to the Meadowlands) and the Jets (1983, to the Meadowlands).
Just as New York sans the Yankees is unthinkable to many, so was Ebbets Field minus the Dodgers. But after they decamped for L.A., a hastily formed Ebbets Field Productions leased the stadium to various sporting events and theatrical, musical and novelty attractions. Leading off the first post-Dodger event, on Memorial Day weekend 1958, was the stunt car driver Jack Kochman and his "helldrivers."
So if the Yankees do leave, what will happen to Yankee Stadium? The Parks Department says it costs $3.5 million a year to operate, including maintenance, equipment and electricity. Without a professional sports team, the department estimates the operating cost at just over $1 million. What could attract enough people to raise that sort of money? Who would dare to tear it down?
The questions are fraught with political risk. Several public officials wanted nothing to do with thinking out loud, for public consumption, about the notion of the Bronx without the Yankees. Still, New York is New York, and plenty of people were willing to offer their two cents:
 DAVIDSON GOLDIN
 
 RON DELSENER
 Concert Promoter
 I could do concerts there, although the truth is it's not an ideal place to do concerts because there's not parking. Still, it is a prestigious thing to say, 'I played Yankee Stadium,' and some acts do it just to say they did it. We've done it before, we could do it again. I'd certainly take a shot at it, and maybe we could do it three, four times a summer. My first choice is to bring back the Brooklyn Dodgers, or bring in another team.

 EDWARD I. KOCH
 Former Mayor
 You could turn it into tennis courts -- put a bubble over it so it's open all year. Or you could turn it into a stadium that would be available to younsters who are in baseball leagues and use our parks and want the feeling of professionalism. I wouldn't knock it down. I'd find some use for it. You might want to bring in gatherings of large outside groups, like the Jehovah's Witnesses, to use it.

 WARNER LeROY
 Restaurateur
 Bring in another baseball team, or use it for concerts or build a theme park possibly, like Great Adventure. The best idea is to get another baseball team, or if you could even get soccer going. Or bull-fighting -- that would be great.

 FERNANDO FERRER
 Bronx Borough President
 We ought to put together a group of wealthy and concerned New Yorkers and buy another baseball team, bring it to New York City, and then when Steinbrenner challenges that, as he predictably will do, we should walk into Federal court and challenge baseball's antitrust exemption. We can then take the name Yankee Stadium off and put up Bomber Stadium, and call the new team the Bronx Bombers.

 GAY TALESE
 Author
 They could put a roof on it, and turn it into a good homeless shelter. Or it could be a wonderful park for the underprivileged -- kids otherwise limited to the cracked cement of housing projects. Green grass! If you wanted a commercial use, it could ba convention center, and would do a better job than the Coliseum or the Javits Center. That would resurrect some of the supposedly lost economy of the Bronx.

 PHIL RIZUTTO
 Broadcaster and ex-Yankee shortstop
 They'd probably make a fortune just breaking it into pieces and selling it as souvenirs. Unfortunately, it's too expensive to run for high school or even college baseball. Football draws enough fans, but not baseball.

 BETSY GOTBAUM
 Former Parks Commissioner
 The cost of tearing it down would be almost prohibitive, and it's a great landmark. I would turn it into a wonderful city-owned recreation center for the South Bronx. If we had the money, it would be wonderful to turn it into a giant swimming pool. To break even, you'd have to go after big concerts and big revenue -- Nelson Mandela brought in $1 million.
 
PETE HAMILL
Writer
The last thing they should do is another public housing project like at the Polo Grounds or Ebbets Field. I'd make it a Toyota plant and put blue-collar jobs in the Bronx. What the people desperately need is blue-collar jobs that create revenue. Maybe there could be an industrial plant or a big newspaper plant - if there are any newspapers seven years from now. Or perhaps it could be used as a big television and movie production center.
 
REP. CHARLES RANGEL
Congressman
It's a fantastic tourist center and we hope it's going to be a big economic hub for Manhattan and the Bronx. It's a place that could be a showcase and you have to market it that way. There are unlimited possibilities as an exciting place for economic development.
 
BELLA ABZUG
Former Congresswoman
You could have expositions and use it for community groups. It could be a major hub of the Bronx. It could be a cultural center - music groups, dance groups. The Bronx could use that, a center of activity.

LENGTH: 1707 words

HEADLINE: Towns Just Saying 'No' to Federal Funds

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
IN an era of fiscal austerity, it may seem incredible that any town in Connecticut would reject nearly $1 million in Federal and state grant money aimed at improving a local road. But last month, the town of Guilford did just that. It turned down a package of government aid and opted to fix the road with its own money. Earlier this year, the town of Redding also decided to go it alone, rejecting $347,000 in Federal and state transportation money to fix a beloved historic bridge on a scenic road. Skeptical about traditional approaches to state and Federal road design that a growing number of residents believe are excessive and tend to erode the distinct features of Connecticut's landscape, more and more towns across the state are debating whether to follow the same route.
"It's a startling change of affairs," said Laura Clarke, executive director of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation in New Haven. "People are saying no to gift horses of money and deciding it's much more important to retain the character of their towns." 
 In recent months, a number of citizens groups have formed to try to persuade Federal and state authorities to give towns more say over their streets, and to allow them to qualify for aid under less severe standards.
On Nov. 1 voters in Mansfield will decide in a referendum whether to accept $550,000 in government financing to refurbish a historic one-lane bridge, which transportation officials say must be widened to two lanes to quality for the money. In the northwestern part of the state, two regional planning agencies have joined forces to urge transportation authorities to allow Federal money for roads in that area, which currently don't qualify for such grants, and to design a separate set of standards for rural roads. The trend toward more local autonomy over road design is not limited to Connecticut. Transportation agencies in Vermont and Maine, for example, are reviewing their design criteria at the request of local communities. Veronika Thiebach, an attorney with the Conservation Law Foundation in Boston, said that the conventional attitude that residents have little control over road projects is changing.
"More and more citizens are rising up against the state," she said. "People don't want the type of megaprojects commonly proposed, because it fundamentally affects the livability of a community by turning our Main Streets into highways."
At issue are the rules governing road projects, based on a 1991 Federal law overseeing the financing of road improvement and the design guidelines established by the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials.
In the case of interstate highways and heavily traveled national and state routes, the law requires most projects to comply with association design and construction standards. Work on less traveled residential roads can be funded by Federal money, subject only to state design and construction standards. The state receives about $350 million of Federal money annually for road projects.
The highway and transportation association criteria have been criticized for creating a "one size fits all" approach to road design. While transportation officials say its purpose is to insure safety and uniformity, opponents say it encourages designs that widen and flatten roads, creating a homogeneous landscape and conditions ripe for speeding. Although many states have adopted standards separate from the association criteria, the Connecticut Department of Transportation relies on them for most road projects.
Among the concerns of local groups is the practice of clearing roadsides -- removing the older trees and stone walls that give a road character.
"I was stunned at their inflexibility," said James Portley, the engineer for the town of Guilford, who applied for the Federal aid for a $985,000 project to improve Little Meadow Road, a winding, two-lane road near the north of the town's center.
He said state transportation officials would not budge when residents requested saving the stone walls and 100-year-old trees lining the road. Accepting the financing would have allowed the state to widen the road far beyond what was necessary, he said.
"We're not Iowa, with all of this vast space," Mr. Portley said. "In New England these stone walls and trees mean a lot to people."
Henry W. Bielawa, First Selectman of Redding said he encountered a similar struggle over the rebuilding of a historic bridge on Poverty Hollow Road, a designated scenic road.
Earlier this year, the town rejected the $347,000 Federal-state package after residents objected to a plan to increase the span and height of the bridge and widen the approaching road.
In a recent letter to the Council of Small Towns in West Hartford regarding federally financed road projects, Mr. Bielawa wrote: "It's a sad commentary on our system when historic preservation, neighborhood esthetics and common sense are displaced by cookie-cutter design requirements, standardization without regard to local custom and usage and the 'bigger is better' philosophy. "The ultimate frustration," the letter continued, is that "the money we are not accepting will only be spent somehow, somewhere else rather than going to decrease taxes."
Transportation officials at both the state and Federal level say that the standards imposed on Connecticut roads and bridges do allow for some flexibility, but that Federal money under the 1991 law is targeted for major capital improvements not routine maintenance, and that towns must be aware of the requirements.
"We don't set up the regulations and laws but we have to make certain that towns abide by them," said Sebastian Sbalcio, principal engineer for the Department of Transportation. "Towns have to know that when they apply for financing it comes with strings attached."
Transportation authorities also point out that towns often try to waive aspects of a road project long after the job has been designed and is ready for construction. At that point, they said, the change requested may incur considerable costs. Citizens should get involved in the initial planning stages of any road project, they said.
"It's important for residents to organize early and give their input," said Carl Gottshall, assistant division administrator of the Federal Highway Administration. "A lot of people just think the project isn't going to happen and wait." Federal and state transportation officials in Connecticut met recently with representatives from the Litchfield Hills Council of Elected Officials, based in Goshen, and the Northwestern Connecticut Council of Governments, based in Torrington, to discuss the possibility of creating a new set of design standards for rural roads.
Representatives from the two regional planning agencies, which represent 20 towns, also said they'd like to see Federal law governing road improvement aid amended to include certain classifications of local roads. Under the current law, they said, few of the roads in the northwest part of the state qualify for Federal money.
Alan Chapin, First Selectman of Washington and chairman of a transportation committee for the regional agencies, said that apart from local budgets and a small annual state aid grant, the region has no other source of aid for rural roads. About 50 percent those roads, he said, are classified as being in poor or very poor condition. "We're just looking for flexibility in design standards and a fair share," he added.
In Guilford, a consortium of preservation and conservation groups representing 2,500 residents, has called for an ordinance regulating road and bridge improvement to help preserve its rural character. The group proposes that new roads not exceed a width of 22 feet and that existing roads be maintained at the current widths. Their proposal also recommends that old stone bridges be preserved by routine maintenance using native stone and timber, and that the town avoid building curbs.
"By saving the character of the town we're not standing in the way of economic development," said Shirley Girioni, president of the Guilford Preservation League. "The two things complement each other. People perceive a town through its roads."
Ms. Clarke, of the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, said more and more towns are moving to take responsibility for the future of their byways. "This is not just a historic preservation movement," she said. "People all over are feeling deeply cynical and suspicious about what's been done to their towns. Perhaps the time has come in which towns and the D.O.T. can work together."
An initial attempt by residents to reach a compromise with the Department of Transportation was apparent in a heated public hearing held recently in Branford. At issue was a proposal to rebuild the bridge over Interstate 95 at Exit 56. The spot contains a busy truck stop and has been the site of 21 accidents in the past couple of years, mostly related to truck traffic. The plan includes expanding the four-lane bridge to five lanes, raising it, closing an off ramp and building a new off/on ramp and widening the approaching road.
Transportation officials argued that the new construction would make the area safer and smooth traffic flow, but nearly all of the 100 residents who attended the hearing disagreed. Estimated to cost $5.4 million, the plan was called excessive and detrimental to the character of nearby Stony Creek. It would invite commercial development and increase traffic, they added. As glum-faced transportation officials looked on, other residents offered design plans, which seemed to many in the audience to make more sense. "If you're going to spend $5.4 million, why don't you just buy the truck stop and close it?" asked Herbert Camp, a resident.
One of the most contentious parts of the proposed plan is the widening of Gould Lane, a residential street near the exit. Doing so would entail taking land from some residents and cutting down older trees. In an emotional presentation, Linda Casanova, who lives on the road, called such portions of the plan overkill.
"You want to widen Gould Lane and make it more dangerous," she said. "This is ridiculous."

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Jobs Beyond Piecework for Mentally Disabled

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
SIX months ago, Ervin (Jimmy) Villa, went to work at Industrial Overall Services in New Rochelle. For Mr. Villa, 38, who has had problems in the past with substance abuse and learning disabilities, his job as a laborer in the silk-screen department of Industrial Overall represented economic opportunity, independence and the chance to "feel like somebody."
Trends in mental health are changing. People are no longer confined to sheltered workplaces, but are being trained to be as vocationally independent as possible, said Paul Levine, associate executive director of Guidance Center Industries in New Rochelle, the center that trained Mr. Villa. Guidance Center Industries, the vocational rehabilitation division of the Guidance Center, a nonprofit community psychiatric clinic licensed by the state, has reinvented itself over the last two years, Mr. Levine said. 
 "Twenty years ago, vocational programs for the disabled were largely confined to sheltered workshops," he said. "Our clients were given piecework assignments, or simple tasks such as packaging combs and assembling ballpoint pens under supervision, and those were pretty much the only job opportunities for them. Now the workshop, once a major part of our program, is just one of many of our vocational programs."
The Guidance Center served 4,101 clients last year and of those, 700 received job training at Guidance Center Industries.
Clients are referred to the Guidance Center Industries by New York State Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals With Disabilites, from hospitals, schools and doctors. Guidance Center has a budget of $7 million a year financed by the State Department of Mental Health, State Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals With Disabilites, United Way, private donors and fund-raising efforts.
Last year Guidance Center Industries, which has its headquarters at 363 Huguenot Street in New Rochelle, was named the "outstanding rehabilitation program" in New York State in recognition of its pioneering of vocational programs, which were designed for individuals with mental and physical difficulties, and its success in preparing them for jobs in outside businesses.
"The changes in our programs in two and a half years have led to 82 outside job placements in 1994, which represents an increase of 105 percent compared to 1993 and a 925 percent increase compared to 1992," Mr. Levine said. "I feel that our success in training and placing the disabled shows that given opportunities, people with mental disabilities don't have to be limited. With the proper training, encouragement and support, they can move into the competitive workplace. And it also instills a new awareness and sensitivity in the general public, when they realize that people with mental disabilities can do a real day's work."
One of the Guidance Center Industries' programs is a clerical program, run jointly with Monroe Business College. It covers word processing, office skills and office practices. Former graduates of this program have been placed at the Bank of New York, Ciba and Monroe Business College, Mr. Levine said. Another program, called LAMP (for Landscaping and Maintenance Procedures), placed 17 people in jobs last year.
Another program, sponsored by New York State Vocational and Educational Services for Individuals With Disabilites, is called Fast Pace. "It is actually a departure from the typical programming found in most agencies, and the way it works is similar to an employment agency," Mr. Levine said, adding that under the Fast Pace program Guidance Center Industries only gets a fee from an employer after a client has been on the job for 60 days. "But we offer placement assistance only to people who are disabled in the county."
Fast Pace clients represent a diverse group.
"We work with individuals who have master's degrees and with those who haven't graduated from high school," Mr. Levine said. "They have disabilities ranging from substance abuse and mental illness to physical impairments and learning disabilities. We have made placements that go from part-time assembler to a program coordinator in a community center."
Short-term and long-term community experiences in a variety of workplaces is obtained in a program called MOVE, which gives Guidance Center clients experience in fields like nursing homes, retail stores and libraries. "The goal here," Mr. Levine said, "is not only to introduce them to different fields of work but to give them the confidence to move on to the next step in their vocational development."
Another program, started in the spring last year, he said, is Project Art, meaning Advancement through Recognition of Talent. "This is an unusual project designed to develop individual and group projects that can be turned into business and job opportunities," he said. "It fosters vocational developments through use of talent. For example, when Jimmy Villa came to us, we found he had tremendous artistic talent and he was a perfect candidate for this program. The goals are empowerment, recovery and the use of talents to earn a living. Several of our participants, including Mr. Villa, have had their art exhibited at the New Rochelle Library and at First Fidelity Bank. And First Fidelity has bought two of Mr. Villa's paintings and has them on display."
Despite the gains, and the clients' vocational evaluations, the extensive occupational training, the internships and job coaching, it is still not easy, Mr. Levine said, to convince those in the business community to hire Guidance Center clients.
"Initially, they are very skeptical," he said. "The perception is that our people won't be able to carry their weight in the real world, that they will be more of a problem to them than other employees. We only ask them to try our people, to give them a chance."
The Guidance Center's 10 job developers actively seek employment for the center's clients. Many clients have successfully been placed in businesses ranging from banks to fast-food restaurants and retail stores.
Robert O'Brien, president of Industrial Overall Services, is one of the satisfied employers.
"When I was first approached about taking someone from the Guidance Center, I must admit I had some hesitation," Mr. O'Brien said. "But finally I was persuaded to give Jimmy Villa a chance at what was a low-paying job: cleaning screens in our silk-screen department. That was six months ago and what can I say? Jimmy isn't just good, he is a super employee. He hasn't missed a minute of work, and he's unbelievably quick and clever. For instance, in one month, just by watching people in the department, he figured out how to work the automated equipment. And I've taught him the rest. Now he is the manager of the silk-screen department, with people who work under him. He's a very talented artist, and he probably won't be with us forever, but he will go on to a good career."
Mr. Villa said: "I look up to Mr. O'Brien. He taught me silk-screening. Working for him has been a whole new eye-opener. I always wished I could get a job with art work, but until I went to the Guidance Center I was in bad shape. I was also dyslectic. I was always an artist, but I couldn't read or write. Now I feel like somebody. I am making money; I got a raise. I'm in charge of the equipment and of two other people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jimmy Villa, a silk-screen worker at an overalls manufacturer, got his job through Guidance Center Industries of New Rochelle. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Ways and Means Of Saving Farmland

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, Nathan R. Cushman was considering moving the family dairy operation from Lebanon to upstate New York, where it costs less to farm. But since then he's added hundreds of acres to the farm's holdings, constructed a huge barn off Route 87, and nearly doubled the size of his herd, to more than 1,200 cows.
What made the difference was the state's Farmland Preservation Program, Mr. Cushman said. The State Department of Agriculture has invested heavily in Lebanon, acquiring conservation easements for nine farms and a total of 2,433 acres in the rural eastern Connecticut town. 
 "If there's wasn't a program like that, we really would have been forced to go, because we wouldn't have been able to afford the additional land," Mr. Cushman said. "Dairy farms need a large amount of land to grow corn and hay for the cows."
So far the Farmland Preservation Program has helped 162 farms, totaling 24,650 acres. It remains popular with farmers, as evidenced by 130 applications to enter the 17-year-old program, and new ones filed at a rate of two or three a month.
As the program matures, its focus has been honed. Rather than trying to save, say, the last farm in a suburbanized area, it is concentrating on stretches where agriculture is still thriving, and can continue.
"Rather than just preserving the token farm in an area, they're looking at preserving clusters of farms," said Walter E. Welz, executive director of the Connecticut Farm Bureau. "That's the intelligent approach. Farmers cannot exist as islands."
Joseph J. Dippel, director of the program, agreed: "Farmers make their own best neighbors, as opposed to suburbs where people are more likely to complain about odors or strays." He also said that preserving clusters of agriculture preserves seed, fertilizer and equipment dealers as well.
As a result of the department's focus, most of the farms in the program are now either in Litchfield County (39 farms), the Connecticut River Valley (40 farms) or eastern Connecticut (67 farms).
The program, authorized by the legislature in 1978, does not purchase farms outright. Instead, the state acquires the development rights to the farm. So far the state has spent $76 million on the program, which works out to just under $3,000 per acre, a 20 percent savings over the average appraised value of the development rights. The farmer still holds the land title, so the state does not have to maintain it, and the farmer continues to pay local property taxes. But the land can not be sold for development. Building must be agriculture-related, such as barns or storage sheds, and cannot cover more than 5 percent of the property.
Mr. Cushman, who has applied to put another 386 acres into the preservation program, said that with support from the program farmers can put their money into more productive assets, like equipment, a larger herd or a better milking parlor.
"You can lease land to keep down your capital costs, but then you never know from year to year if you're going to have enough land to feed your herd," Mr. Cushman explained. "If the owner gets an offer to sell the land for development, it could be gone before you put in your next crop."
David T. Armstrong, who put his 225-acre nursery in Suffield into the program, said specialty agriculture can be viable in Connecticut without the program. But he says there is another reason farmers sell their development rights. Many farmers see it as the only way to make sure what they have built up will not disappear when they are gone.
"Farmers develop a certain emotional attachment to their properties," Mr. Armstrong said. "This is one way to keep it the way you like it. You might think your property is beautiful the way it is, but eventually you'll be gone and your kids might not see it that way."
For the same reason, many municipal officials support farmland preservation. Lebanon First Selectwoman Joyce R. Okonuk, a lifelong resident of that town, said when she was growing up most families had a small farm; today the bulk of active farmland in town is the 2,433 acres in the preservation program.
"If that land had become subdivisions or large developments the town would have lost its rural character," Mrs. Okonuk said. "We've seen that happen in other towns around us. Right now the community is a good blend of farming and residential properties. That's what makes the town unique."
In her opinion, "Development is good, but it has to happen at a rate that the town can control."
The encroachment of the suburbs on rural communities like Lebanon has required some adjustments by farmers and by their new neighbors, Mrs. Okonuk said. But the fact that townspeople supported construction of a regional vocational-agriculture center at its new high school is evidence that farming is still accepted.
"There have been a few folk who've had some difficulty adjusting," Mrs. Okonuk said. "But for the most part they're adapting, and they're thankful that farming is surviving in town. And I think it's important that you remember, when you're eating that ear of corn or drinking that glass of milk, how it got to the market."
The preservation program does not require that the land remain in active agricultural use, so farmers have the option, if their operations are not profitable, of letting the land go fallow.
The Farmland Preservation Program has set a goal of purchasing the development rights to 140,000 acres statewide, which Mr. Dippel, the program director, said was identified by studies at UConn as the critical mass for preserving agriculture.
While Connecticut is still far short of its goal, Robert C. Wagner, director of state and local programs for American Farmland Trust, said none of the nine states that have farmland preservation programs have reached their goal, although four states -- Maryland, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Vermont -- have put more land into their programs.
Mr. Wagner says the trust is urging the Federal Government to provide financial support to states with Purchase of Development Rights programs, because the states are losing farmland at rates far beyond what they are saving.
In Connecticut, for instance, 1,500 acres a year on average were preserved in the period 1980 to 1994. But according to the Federal Department of Agriculture, during that same period the average loss of prime farmland to residential or commercial development approached 8,500 acres a year. "These programs have become a race against development," Mr. Wagner said.
Mr. Welz of the state chapter of the Farm Bureau said the limited financial resources of the state has traditionally hampered the program. In years when the economy is booming and the state has money available, land prices skyrocket; when the economy goes into a downturn, the state has no money for the program even though prices slide.
"Relatively speaking, you can get some much better buys today than you could five or six years ago," Mr. Welz said. "You get much better bang for your buck today -- but because times are hard the state doesn't have as many bucks. It's kind of a vicious cycle."
Dr. Emilio Pagoulatos, head of the Department of Agriculture and Resource Economics at the University of Connecticut, said the state should not consider the program just as preservation of agriculture, but as preservation of the rural way of life.
"The demand for open space would justify significant investment," Dr. Pagoulatos said. "There will come a time when we'll miss the Connecticut countryside, and then it will be too late for preservation."
For the 1996 fiscal year the state has allocated $3 million for farmland preservation, less than the $5 million for the 1995 fiscal year, and far below the $10 million a year peak in the 1980's. Still, it's a substantial amount given cuts to other programs, the program's advocates note.
"If I were to assign the Connecticut program a single characteristic, it would be endurance," said Mr. Wagner. "They never get a huge appropriation, but each year they get something. That keeps it moving forward."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nathan R. Cushman's dairy farm in Lebanon once was in danger of relocating to New York State. That was before the Farmland Preservation Program stepped in, allowing him to add hundreds of acres to the land that feeds his herd. (Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1677 words

HEADLINE: Anti-Smoking Law Moves On Over Objections

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AFTER an abortive effort in the late 1980's, Westchester is again preparing an anti-smoking law -- this time, one that would be the strictest of its kind in the state. The county's tough regulation would ban smoking in all eating areas of restaurants by next year, in restaurant bars by 1998 and in taverns by 2000.
The proposed changes to the county's health code are expected to pass over the objections of restaurateurs and bar owners who claim that their rights are being denied and that their businesses are sure to suffer. 
 "Westchester is pushing the envelope," said Tom Scaramellino, president of the 200-member Westchester-Rockland chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association. "They are putting restaurants here at an unfair advantage."
Mr. Scaramellino, who owns Crystal Bay Dining and Catering in Peekskill, predicted that if the code changes are enforced, many diners will go to restaurants in nearby counties in New York and Connecticut, where smoking laws are less strict.
"We won't be on a level playing field in Westchester," he said.
But county officials explained that arguments citing economics, personal rights or equality with other restaurants have little to do with the issue. They said that even when smokers are separated, a restaurant's employees and its nonsmoking diners are still being exposed to second-hand smoke.
"It's a matter of life and death, and we can't fool ourselves any more," said Dr. Mark Rapoport, the county's Health Commissioner.
The Federal Food and Drug Administration has labeled tobacco a Class A carcinogen, equal to asbestos and radon. And the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that 418,690 American smokers a year die from tobacco-related causes; another 53,000 nonsmokers die because they have been exposed to others' smoke.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also says that tobacco kills more Americans each year than alcohol, cocaine, crack, heroin, car accidents, homicide, suicide, fires and AIDS combined -- a fact that Westchester officials and anti-smoking groups often use in their campaign to pass the new law.
But as Michael Denslow, the owner of Hoppfields, a restaurant in Bedford, discovered, even when restaurateurs prefer a no-smoking policy, the public may not be ready. When he opened his 125-seat restaurant 15 months ago, it was strictly a no-smoking establishment. All did not go as planned, however, and "there were arguments night after night," Mr. Denslow said, because smokers insisted on having seats set aside for them. "So I gave in," Mr. Denslow said. "I let them have their way, because I have to run a business. I thought the public would welcome the policy, but I was wrong."
At Azuma, a Japanese restaurant with 30 seats in Hartsdale, however, the owner, Anthony Saegusa, said that even though state law requires no separation of smokers in restaurants of his size, he banned smoking, and customers went along with it.
But Mr. Scaramellino, in Peekskill, said the job of a restaurateur "is to please customers, not to say no to them."
At the Broadway Grille in Irvington, the proprietor, Gregory Nilsson, is also worrying about what he will tell his customers, although it will be business as usual for him and other tavern owners for the next five years. Mr. Nilsson said: "But what do I say to my customers then? Do I tell them to get out if they are going to smoke? That's crazy. It would be like chasing business away."
Restaurateurs like Mr. Scaramellino and Mr. Nilsson plan to protest the proposed health code changes at a public hearing next month.
But Mr. Denslow said he "would embrace the new law."
Proponents of the changes cite studies showing that businesses do not suffer when smoking regulations go into effect.
A study by the University of California published in 1992 in the American Journal of Public Health looked at taxable sales in 15 California and Colorado cities with smoking bans and 15 cities without them and found "no significant effect" on sales in cities with the ordinances. "The presence of a 100 percent smoke-free ordinance had no significant effect on total restaurant sales in any community," the study said. Surprisingly, the study also said that restaurant sales increased about 14 percent in some cases when a smoke-free ordinance was in effect.
Douglas Martin, president of the American Lung Association of Hudson Valley, recalled that similar arguments about business and personal rights were heard in the late 1980's when the county passed smoking restrictions and in 1990 when the state's Clean Indoor Air Act took effect.
The county's anti-smoking law, passed by the Board of Legislators, never garnered the support of anti-smoking coalitions because it was considered too weak, Mr. Martin said. It was later rescinded when the state passed its law.
New York's Clean Indoor Air Act limits smoking in most public places, including stores, schools, taxis, work sites and most restaurants. Smoking is allowed only in private homes, bars, some hotel rooms, tobacco businesses, limousines under private hire, some boxes in indoor arenas, restaurants with 51 or fewer seats and at private social functions.
"We have come a long way," Mr. Martin said. "It was controversial to think of separating diners then. The restaurant owners were very upset."
This time, the county's smoking law would be enacted not by the Board of Legislators but by the 12-member Board of Health, an appointed panel represented by doctors, municipal leaders, a county legislator, a restaurateur and others.
Dr. Douglas G. Aspros, president of the Board of Health, said the code changes under consideration in Westchester reflected a changing climate.
"It is one thing for people to choose to smoke themselves," he said. "It's quite another to expose others unwillingly. We are looking at this strictly as a health issue."
Lillian R. Jones, co-chairwoman of Communities for a Smoke-Free New York, said, "Given the fact that tobacco is considered a Class A carcinogen, how many people would be willing to sit next to a pile of asbestos?" The organization represents local chapters of the American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association and the American Heart Association and the League of Women Voters of Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Putnam Counties.
The Board of Health expects to complete the wording of the code changes later this month, hold a public hearing in November and begin enforcing the new law by Jan. 1.
Contrary to New York City's anti-smoking law, which exempts restaurants with 35 or fewer seats, Westchester's ordinance would make no such distinction. As proposed, it would ban smoking in all eating establishments, regardless of size, Dr. Aspros said. Also, New York City allows smoking in some bar sections of restaurants, provided they are separated from the dining room.
Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, called the proposed code changes in Westchester "even more onerous than New York's." He added, "We're concerned."
He said that the hospitality industry, which has shown steady growth in the county, could suffer if meeting and convention planners, many representing foreign groups, which are used to being able to smoke, take their business elsewhere.
The cigarette manufacturer Philip Morris Companies, which has offices in Rye Brook, is also opposing the code changes in Westchester. The company threatened to move its corporate offices from New York City if a tough smoking ban was passed there. But Mary Coughlin, a spokeswoman, said the company has no plans to leave New York City now.Its policy in Westchester is that restaurateurs here should determine smoking policies, not the government.
She also cited studies on the impact of smoking bans on restaurants that contradict aspects of the University of California research. A survey commissioned by the New York Tavern and Restaurant Association showed that nearly 6 in 10 New York City restaurants near suburban county borders lost customers because of New York's smoking restrictions. In an April 1994 Charlton Research Poll of restaurant owners in localities with smoking bans, 32 percent reported a loss of business.
Meanwhile, efforts to prevent teen-agers from smoking are growing, especially since President Clinton has given the fight the full backing of the White House. In August, the Food and Drug Administration proposed banning cigarette vending machines and self-service racks of cigarettes. It also recommended that stores be required to see proof of age before selling cigarettes. Manufacturers, distributors and retailers would be held responsible for sales of cigarettes to minors. And the sale of single cigarettes or "kiddie packs" of cigarettes would be banned.
In Westchester, the Health Department reported that during a sting operation in August, 41 of 55 establishments sold cigarettes to under-18-year-olds, in violation of the State Adolescent Tobacco Use Prevention Act. The minimum fine for violating the law is $100, with subsequent fines as much as $1,000. Repeat offenders risk losing their license to sell cigarettes.
Surveys in the Hudson Valley region last year by anti-tobacco coalitions revealed that about 4,700 packs of cigarettes were illegally being sold to minors each day.
In Hastings-on-Hudson last week, two teen-age smokers reported that they traveled to Yonkers, where they could easily buy cigarettes. "Lots of stores sell to us," said Richard Mullin, 15, a half-a-pack-a-day smoker. "It's easy for minors to get them."
Commissioner Rapoport at the county's Health Department has said that 60 percent of all smokers start by the age of 14 and 75 percent by 18. Fred Kelly, 14, who started smoking when he was 10, said last week that even though there was an all-out effort to stop teen-agers from smoking: "It won't do any good. Kids are aware of the problems, but they don't care. They figure they will quit later, before it becomes a health hazard."
