HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Thinking (Just Thinking) About the Impossible

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

 BODY:
It's too soon to write the obituary for Yankee Stadium, but perhaps not too soon to start thinking about what the city would do with the remains.
George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, has set the middle of next year as a deadline to decide where the Yankees will play after their lease on the stadium expires in 2002. Mr. Steinbrenner complains often about the 72-year-old stadium's problems with parking, traffic congestion and crime, and says the team could make more money by leaving the Bronx. In the last year, he has rejected 13 proposals from the Giuliani administration to keep the team in the city. And last month, New Jersey officials said they would be happy to see the New Jersey Yankees at the Meadowlands Sports Complex. 
 Mr. Steinbrenner is a shrewd negotiator, and all his maneuvering could be just a ploy. But New York has lost four pro sports teams in four decades: the Dodgers (1957, to Los Angeles), the baseball Giants (1957, to San Francisco), the football Giants (1975, to the Meadowlands) and the Jets (1983, to the Meadowlands).
Just as New York sans the Yankees is unthinkable to many, so was Ebbets Field minus the Dodgers. But after they decamped for L.A., a hastily formed Ebbets Field Productions leased the stadium to various sporting events and theatrical, musical and novelty attractions. Leading off the first post-Dodger event, on Memorial Day weekend 1958, was the stunt car driver Jack Kochman and his "helldrivers."
So if the Yankees do leave, what will happen to Yankee Stadium? The Parks Department says it costs $3.5 million a year to operate, including maintenance, equipment and electricity. Without a professional sports team, the department estimates the operating cost at just over $1 million. What could attract enough people to raise that sort of money? Who would dare to tear it down?
The questions are fraught with political risk. Several public officials wanted nothing to do with thinking out loud, for public consumption, about the notion of the Bronx without the Yankees. Still, New York is New York, and plenty of people were willing to offer their two cents:
 DAVIDSON GOLDIN
 
 RON DELSENER
 Concert Promoter
 I could do concerts there, although the truth is it's not an ideal place to do concerts because there's not parking. Still, it is a prestigious thing to say, 'I played Yankee Stadium,' and some acts do it just to say they did it. We've done it before, we could do it again. I'd certainly take a shot at it, and maybe we could do it three, four times a summer. My first choice is to bring back the Brooklyn Dodgers, or bring in another team.

 EDWARD I. KOCH
 Former Mayor
 You could turn it into tennis courts -- put a bubble over it so it's open all year. Or you could turn it into a stadium that would be available to younsters who are in baseball leagues and use our parks and want the feeling of professionalism. I wouldn't knock it down. I'd find some use for it. You might want to bring in gatherings of large outside groups, like the Jehovah's Witnesses, to use it.

 WARNER LeROY
 Restaurateur
 Bring in another baseball team, or use it for concerts or build a theme park possibly, like Great Adventure. The best idea is to get another baseball team, or if you could even get soccer going. Or bull-fighting -- that would be great.

 RICHARD A. KAHAN
 Developer and president, Urban Assembly
 There are a lot of exciting possibilities -- everything from restaurants to education to entertainment. We started thinking about it a year ago, but then decided to wait until the Yankees decided what they were doing. We could do a theme high school, which would encourage people looking at careers in sports management, sports recreation and sports medicine.

 FERNANDO FERRER
 Bronx Borough President
 We ought to put together a group of wealthy and concerned New Yorkers and buy another baseball team, bring it to New York City, and then when Steinbrenner challenges that, as he predictably will do, we should walk into Federal court and challenge baseball's antitrust exemption. We can then take the name Yankee Stadium off and put up Bomber Stadium, and call the new team the Bronx Bombers.

 GAY TALESE
 Author
 They could put a roof on it, and turn it into a good homeless shelter. Or it could be a wonderful park for the underprivileged -- kids otherwise limited to the cracked cement of housing projects. Green grass! If you wanted a commercial use, it could ba convention center, and would do a better job than the Coliseum or the Javits Center. That would resurrect some of the supposedly lost economy of the Bronx.

 PHIL RIZUTTO
 Broadcaster and ex-Yankee shortstop
 They'd probably make a fortune just breaking it into pieces and selling it as souvenirs. Unfortunately, it's too expensive to run for high school or even college baseball. Football draws enough fans, but not baseball.

 STAN MARTUCCI
 Owner, Stan's Sports Bar and Sports World, opposite the Stadium
 What we're dealing with here is a big white elephant. It's very depressing to me. What do I do with my business? I rely on the Yankees. How about getting another team in here? I saw what they did to Ebbets Field when the Brooklyn Dodgers left; they put up apartment complexes. How do you just tear down Yankee Stadium? It's kind of sacred.

 BETSY GOTBAUM
 Former Parks Commissioner
 The cost of tearing it down would be almost prohibitive, and it's a great landmark. I would turn it into a wonderful city-owned recreation center for the South Bronx. If we had the money, it would be wonderful to turn it into a giant swimming pool. To break even, you'd have to go after big concerts and big revenue -- Nelson Mandela brought in $1 million.

 JOE BAUM
 Chairman, Rainbow Room
 It would make a heck of a supervised all-sports park -- tying it in with the park that already exists across the road -- that would be used for spectator as well as participatory sports. That seems like a logical, fresh air kind of thing for the Bronx.

HEADLINE: A Theory of Almost Everything

BYLINE: By John Horgan; John Horgan is a senior writer for Scientific American. His book "The End of Science" will be published next year.

 BODY:

HIDDEN ORDER
How Adaptation Builds Complexity.
By John H. Holland.
Illustrated. 185 pp. Reading, Mass.:
Helix Books/Addison-Wesley
Publishing Company. $24.
 
AT HOME IN THE UNIVERSE
The Search for Laws of Self-Organization and Complexity.
By Stuart Kauffman.
Illustrated. 321 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $25.
 
ARE WE ALONE?
Philosophical Implications of the Discovery of Extraterrestrial Life.
By Paul Davies.
Illustrated. 160 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $20.
 
FRONTIERS OF COMPLEXITY
The Search for Order in a Chaotic World.
By Peter Coveney and Roger Highfield.
Illustrated. 462 pp. New York:
Fawcett Columbine. $27.50. 
IN 1993, Gottfried Mayer-Kress, a physicist at the University of Illinois, offered advice, in a press release, to American officials agonizing over the conflicts in Somalia and Bosnia: stop viewing the Somalian and Serbian warlords as "bad guys" and think of them instead as "parameters" within a "self-organizing complex adaptive system." In this way, Mr. Mayer-Kress suggested, the officials might come up with solutions to the crisis.
Mr. Mayer-Kress is no crackpot. He is a respected member of a scientific discipline that studies something called complexity. What is complexity? Good question. One practitioner has counted at least 31 different definitions, each of which has its adherents. These often involve other protean buzzwords like "chaos," "information," "self-organization" and "emergence." One common, and revealing, synonym for "complex" is "interesting." Complexity, it seems, is in the eye of the beholder.
Investigators of complexity -- let's call them complexologists -- may not agree on what they are studying, but they share a dissatisfaction with the "reductionist" science of the past. They are also imbued with an almost religious belief in the power of mathematics and computers -- or "macro scopes" as they are called by some complex ologists -- to transcend the limits of conventional science and reveal the order underlying the messiness of nature -- and even of human affairs.
This faith stems from a seductive syllogism: Computers, by following very simple rules, can generate astonishingly complicated patterns. Nature also generates astonishingly complicated patterns. Therefore, simple rules must underlie the patterns of nature, and, with the help of computers, scientists can root out those rules. Of course, simple rules do underlie nature. They are embodied in quantum mechanics, the theory of natural selection, molecular genetics. But complexologists insist that much more powerful rules remain to be discovered.
Scientists and journalists have been churning out books on complexity for almost a decade or so now. (My favorite is still "The Dreams of Reason," by the physicist Heinz Pagels, published in 1988.) Although complexologists have not really accomplished much yet, at least relative to their ambitions, the books have maintained their exuberantly optimistic tone.
The batch considered here is no exception. Perhaps the most modest is by John H. Holland, a computer scientist with joint appointments at the University of Michigan and the Santa Fe Institute, the self-anointed headquarters of complexity. More than 20 years ago, Mr. Holland invented genetic algorithms, which are pieces of computer code that can "evolve," that is, rearrange themselves at random in order to become more efficient at solving a problem.
Genetic algorithms, Mr. Holland has proposed, might lead to a general, mathematical theory that can illuminate a wide range of "complex adaptive systems," from immune systems to human brains to entire economies. In "Hidden Order: How Adaptation Builds Complexity," he moves briskly past the obligatory grand rhetoric and plunges with gusto into nuts-and-bolts descriptions -- complete with equations and flow charts and diagrams -- of how such a theory might work.
He has the heart of an engineer. He wants to solve complexity-related problems, and not just any problems but big ones: AIDS, mental illness, inner-city decay. He envisions computer-based "flight simulators" that would allow officials to foresee, for instance, how a low-income housing project might affect an inner-city neighborhood.
He only briefly considers whether a simulation of downtown Detroit would also apply to Los Angeles. But that is the crux of the problem. Would any official really trust a model general enough to apply to both cities, or to all cities and to human immune systems? Another question: Is a cure for AIDS more likely to emerge from mathematics and computer science than from the same kind of gritty, bench-top work that led to the discovery of the AIDS virus?
Mr. Holland's ambitions pale beside those of his colleague Stuart Kauffman, a full-time resident of the Santa Fe Institute and one of the most charismatic of the complexologists. "At Home in the Universe" is a condensed, passionately written version of Mr. Kauff man's 709-page magnum opus, "The Origins of Order" (1993). For decades, Mr. Kauffman has been performing computer simulations of abstract, interacting "agents," which can represent everything from molecules and genes to whole organisms and companies.
He also foresees practical consequences stemming from his work. His simulations, he suggests, may serve as a guide for managers of large, complicated systems, like the United States. He also devotes a chapter to the burgeoning field of directed evolution, in which chemists generate new enzymes, genes and other useful molecules by inducing them to "compete" among themselves.
BUT Mr. Kauffman once considered a career as a philosopher, and his hunger for deep truths has persisted. He believes his models have revealed "laws of complexity" at play in the universe that counter the inexorable drift toward heat death -- toward universal sameness -- decreed by the second law of thermodynamics. In his view, these laws of complexity, more than the random siftings of natural selection, made the appearance of life on earth and its subsequent evolution not only possible but probable. The refrain "we the expected" runs through Mr. Kauffman's book like a mantra.
This same idea enlivens a new book by the Australian physicist Paul Davies. In "Are We Alone?" Mr. Davies considers not complexity per se but the likelihood that there are other conscious beings in the universe. He warns at one point that we cannot assume life like ours is probable simply because we exist; he compares such reasoning with that of the lottery winner who thinks winning is easy.
But then Mr. Davies indulges in this very fallacy. Pointing to the work of Mr. Kauff man and others, he bravely declares that not only life but also intelligence -- intelligence capable of discovering mathematical laws -- is inevitable. There must be other conscious beings in the universe. He reiterates the message of his previous books, notably "The Mind of God" (1992): the fact that we can discern highly mathematical laws ruling the cosmos suggests that it has a purpose or plan, one in which we play a role.
Mr. Davies is a writer of great charm and lucidity, and his message has been well received. Earlier this year he won the million-dollar Templeton Prize, which is bestowed annually on someone who has "advanced public understanding of God or spirituality." But one wishes he would take up the only theological question that really matters: if there is a plan to the universe, why does it require so much human suffering? Even if there are laws of complexity that made us inevitable, how is that fact supposed to comfort a Bosnian woman who has seen her daughter raped and slaughtered?
Given the extraordinary claims, both worldly and spiritual, being made for complexity, one yearns for a hard-nosed appraisal of the field. "Frontiers of Complexity" is hardly that. Peter Coveney, a physicist, and Roger Highfield, a journalist, both British, echo and even amplify the claims of Mr. Holland, Mr. Kauffman and Mr. Davies. In the view of Mr. Coveney and Mr. Highfield, complexity may lead to the creation of artificial brains and ecosystems, to the elimination of disease and warfare and pollution, and to the building of "a bridge between science and the human condition."
But they are good reporters. Buried in the hype are nuggets of important criticism. They point out, for example, that a concept called the "edge of chaos," which Mr. Kauffman and others have adopted as their definition of complexity, has been studied and rejected as flawed by several of Mr. Kauffman's own colleagues at the Santa Fe Institute.
The British authors note that John Holland's genetic algorithms are not as clever in practice as they are in theory; so far, the algorithms have proved useful only for limited applications. One catch is that the programmer must intercede to insure that they evolve in the right direction; the "watchmaker" (to borrow Richard Dawkins's phrase) is hardly blind. Moreover, because it is usually impossible to trace the steps that lead genetic algorithms to a solution, programmers may not entrust them with important problems.
Mr. Coveney and Mr. Highfield also provide overdue criticism of a popular candidate for a theory of complexity: self-organized criticality. The theory's paradigmatic system is a sand pile; as one drops sand on a pile, it "organizes" itself into a "critical" state, in which each additional grain of sand is increasingly likely to trigger an avalanche down the sides of the pile. In the same way, say adherents of self-organized criticality, many systems -- brains, economies and so on -- tend to approach a state in which a small disruption can alter the entire system.
STUART KAUFFMAN has become a proselytizer for self-organized criticality, as has Vice President Al Gore. In "Earth in the Balance," Mr. Gore wrote that self-organized criticality had helped him understand not only the sensitivity of the environment to potential disruptions but also "change in my own life." But experiments done at the University of Chicago and elsewhere have shown that self-organized criticality does not even provide very good descriptions of sand piles.
Finally, Mr. Coveney and Mr. Highfield review developments in the theory of mathematics and computation that cast doubt on the very notion that there is a general theory of complexity. The mathematician Gregory Chaitin, for example, has suggested that as science seeks to provide mathematical descriptions of increasingly complex phenomena, it must keep expanding its base of axioms; to know more, in other words, we must assume more. "Our efforts to create a grand theory of complexity may be built on sand," Mr. Coveney and Mr. Highfield comment.
In fact, this is one of the most peculiar aspects of complexity: according to its own tenets, its lofty goals may be unreachable. As most complexologists freely acknowledge, their mathematical models offer only probabilistic descriptions of nature. "We must give up the pretense of long-term prediction," Mr. Kauffman writes in one of his rare lapses into humility. "We cannot know the true consequences of our own best actions." But as the philosopher of science Karl Popper pointed out, prediction is our best means of distinguishing science from pseudo-science.
The history of 20th-century science should also give complexologists pause. Complexity is simply the latest in a long line of highly mathematical "theories of almost everything" that have gripped the imaginations of scientists in this century. Previous candidates included cybernetics, information theory, catastrophe theory and, of course, chaos. All have gone through a boom-bust cycle, in which great expectations were inevitably followed by only limited applications and hence disappointment.
It is hard not to empathize with the dissatisfaction that underlies complexity. Modern science, for all its power, is still pitifully inadequate when confronted with the problems that really matter, such as poverty, racism or conflict between states. Nor has science answered the deepest of philosophical questions, namely: Were we inevitable, or just a fluke? Complexity enthusiasts think they can find the answers that have eluded their "reductionist" predecessors. Maybe they will. But their own work, and the record of their predecessors, raises another possibility: maybe these answers are beyond the reach of science.

HEADLINE: Cost of Taxi Medallions Must Come Down

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Consider the Cabbies" (editorial, Sept. 24): The way to give cabbies a better life and for riders to obtain better service isn't to raise rates. As long as drivers compete for jobs, their net pay can't increase, so any revenue from a meter-rate increase would go to medallion owners. 
 By limiting the number of medallions, New York City creates an artificial shortage of taxis at public expense. A $200,000 medallion equivalent to the same value in stocks or bonds yields $20,000 to $40,000 a year. This is a gift from the public to medallion owners.
We must enable professional cabbies to buy their own medallions. That can happen only if medallions cost something within reach of a small entrepreneur: $10,000 or less.
To bring down the cost, the city can issue more medallions, impose a property tax on the market value of medallions, and even reduce fares.
Cabbies who own medallions will provide polite, competent service in cleaner, more comfortable cabs. They will earn a decent living, rather than meager wages working for someone else.
 
MARY M. CLEVELAND
New York, Sept. 24, 1995
 
The writer is an economist.

HEADLINE: New Word of Advice for the Graduate: Software

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
A few years ago, Orion Letizi, an English major who graduated from the University of California at Berkeley, would probably have become a teacher, journalist or graduate student. But just three months after leaving behind Milton and the metaphysical poets, Mr. Letizi is up to his ears in computer software.
He has a job offering technical advice to customers of a company that sells access to the Internet. On his own time, he is learning computer programming. And with six other people, he is starting a service to distribute music on the Internet. 
 "Previous to my current experience I really was at sea when it comes to computers," said Mr. Letizi, who is 23 and lives in San Francisco. "I just walked into it."
Across the country, a generation of college graduates with no technical training is streaming into the software business, drawn by the industry's image as a generator of personal fortunes and cultural excitement.
"There's no doubt that being a computer software company -- people see that as the place to work right now," said Lisa Mars, the vice president of human resources at Computer Associates in Islandia, L.I., the nation's second largest software company. Last spring, recruiters from Computer Associates, who visited more than 75 campuses nationwide, were besieged by applicants with majors ranging from economics to music composition to philosophy.
Call it the Netscape effect, after the company that this summer came up with one of the biggest opening days in Wall Street history when it offered shares to the public, making Marc L. Andreessen, its 24-year-old co-founder, worth $58 million overnight. Or perhaps the phenomenon can be credited to popular culture, which has glamorized computer programmers recently in movies ("The Net," starring Sandra Bullock), in novels ("Microserfs" by Douglas Coupland) and on television ("Dweebs," a new sitcom on CBS).
All this is a reminder that fads in careers are spurred not only by economic opportunity but also by deeper social and cultural currents. In the 1970's, many bright and ambitious graduates went into journalism, inspired by the Watergate reporting of Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein of The Washington Post. In the 1980's, an era marked by preoccupation with wealth, many of the brightest graduates joined Wall Street.
The popularity of software in the mid-90's "is an interesting coming-together of a business that's on the covers of all the business magazines and that's extremely hip and sexy," said Jeremy Ross, an executive at Byron Preiss Multimedia in New York.
"You have kids coming out of school who see it as not only a hip thing to do, but also getting reinforcement from their parents that it's a smart business move," Mr. Ross said.
Many are lured by the prospect of jobs in multimedia, that burgeoning market for on-line services, CD-ROM's and video games that has given a digital flavor to whole neighborhoods in San Francisco and New York.
Creating multimedia products, including displays on the highly popular World Wide Web, the graphical portion of the Internet, requires less programming skill than sheer creativity. Demand is rising for digitally savvy graphic artists, sound engineers, film makers, producers and journalists. The trend reflects a fundamental shift in the computer industry: what was primarily a business tool a few years ago is rapidly becoming a central technology for information and entertainment.
At New York University, applications for the Interactive Telecommunications Program -- a kind of computers-for-poets master's degree -- increased by a "phenomenal" amount for this fall's class of 85 students, said Red Burns, the director. "We had many hundreds of applicants."
Damion Clayton, 25, who left a career as a stockbroker to learn programming in the N.Y.U. program, said: "This is a huge opportunity; it's the dawning of a new era. If you're losing money in this business, you're an idiot."
Few smitten with software's Klondike Fever will ever get rich. Although tales of overnight fortunes like those made at Netscape become legend, computer technology evolves rapidly, leaving many start-up companies out of business.
Salaries in the industry are rising, but they are not comparable with those of corporate lawyers or investment bankers. The median base salary for an entry-level programmer is $31,000, according to a survey by the Software Publishers Association, an industry trade group.
But many drawn to the field distinguish their motives from those of 80's-era graduates who went to Wall Street to make big money fast. Echoing the utopianism of the 1960's that has long been intertwined with the ideology of the personal computer, they talk of software as a cultural revolution, akin to rock-and-roll or mind-expanding drugs.
Troy Whitlock, 25, who studied political science as an undergraduate and is now learning programming at the University of Texas at Austin, said with light self-mockery: "My goals are the same idealistic goals you find in every graduate student: To change the world, to explore the multiple realities that are out there, and to facilitate a resistance to a hierarchical order, which is what the Web is all about."
The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that demand for computer systems analysts, engineers and scientists will grow faster than almost any other job category in the next 10 years. By 2005, there will be 737,000 more openings than the 663,000 jobs that existed in 1992, the most recent year for which data are available.
Paradoxically, the number of university degrees awarded in computer and information sciences has been falling since the mid-80's. In 1985-86, according to the Department of Education, 41,889 bachelor's degrees were awarded, compared with 24,200 in 1992-93, the most recent year surveyed.
Experts cite several reasons for the drop-off, including weaker math and science preparation by high school students.
Another explanation is that software designers need not have computer science degrees, thanks to advances in programming languages that allow people without technical experience to write software code. Also, the nature of the software industry, which is driven by small companies started by self-taught enthusiasts, tends to attract students who do not have special training.
"A computer science degree is really not that important," said Ms. Mars of Computer Associates, which hires liberal arts majors and others for entry-level jobs advising clients on how to use its business software. "As they learn more and more about the product, they start to get involved in the code and then move into development, where they write code. The type of people we hire have such initiative that they learn on their own."
To be sure, not all software companies are so hospitable to English majors. Human resource officials at Adobe Systems and Lotus Development, two large and prestigious companies, said that nearly all of those hired into the development department have computer science degrees.
But at small Athena Design in Boston, of five developers responsible for writing code, only two were computer science majors. "Two of the others were economics majors, and the third, I don't even know if he graduated from college," said David Pollack, 31, a former lawyer who founded the company. In 1993 Athena brought out a spreadsheet program called Mesa that Mr. Pollack, who has been passionate about computers since he was a teen-ager, designed primarily by himself.
"The nice thing about the software industry is your barriers to entry are very low," he said. "What does it cost to develop the technology? A couple of thousand dollars for the hardware and to feed yourself for a year."
Increasingly, college students in all majors are leaving school far more steeped in computers than their older brothers and sisters. Ninety percent of undergraduates at the University of California at Berkeley take at least one computer course, said Richard Fateman, a professor in the computer science department. At Dartmouth College the campus E-mail system, Blitzmail, is more popular than the telephone, and students can submit homework electronically.
The explosive growth of the World Wide Web and the ease with which original content can be created for it seem to have prompted legions of young people to open the hoods of their computers to discover how they work.
"It is pretty remarkable, the number of 15-year-olds out there suddenly offering their services to write Web pages," said Ken Wasch, president of the Software Publishers Association. "The Web has captured the imagination of technically proficient teen-agers in much the same way that rock-and-roll captured the imagination of my generation."
The job growth in the field of Web design and other multimedia fields can be gauged from last month' edition of the Multimedia Directory, an industry guide, which lists 1,150 software producers, publishers, tool developers and telemedia firms. Many were founded within the last three years. The market for consumer CD-ROM titles is expected to reach $1 billion by the end of 1996.
Regina Joseph, 29, a former music editor of Spin magazine who left print to found a CD-ROM magazine called Blender, said, "I do lectures all the time, and I get so many kids who come up to me and say: 'I really want to do this. Can you point me in a direction?' "
But many in multimedia suspect that the field has overheated. They worry about false expectations for its products and an overly glamorous image of the work involved. A recent survey sponsored by O'Reilly & Associates found that only 5.8 million adults have a direct connection to the Internet, and another 3.9 million consumers use commercial on-line services such as Compuserve and America Online. The numbers were lower than many previous estimates.
Justin Firestone, who graduated from Dartmouth with a degree in art history and archeology in 1992, landed a job in New York a year later helping to create a CD-ROM about Frank Lloyd Wright. With Byron Preiss Multimedia and Microsoft as co-publishers, the well-reviewed title earned him a better job at another multimedia shop, Future Vision.
But recently he left the business, turned off, he said, by the pressure to rapidly pump out titles at the expense of quality. He foresees a brutal industry shakeout after the Christmas sales season, an opinion shared by some analysts. "I keep in touch with friends in many shops," he said, "and the tone is one of tremendous stress."
In the span of two years, Mr. Firestone, 25, has gone from ignorance of software design to expertise to disillusion. "Ultimately, things virtual become unsatisfying," he said.
He wants to return to graduate school, probably to become an archeologist.

He is part of a generation of graduates with no technical training streaming into the business. (John Popplewell for The New York Times) (pg. A11)

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: DOLE HINTS SWITCH ON TAX CUT PLAN BY SENATE G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, raised the prospect today that Senate Republicans might not go along with the entire $245 billion in tax cuts that they had agreed to with their House counterparts. But Speaker Newt Gingrich immediately took issue with the idea, vowing that he and the House were inexorably committed to the full reduction.
"There will be tax cuts," Mr. Dole said on the CBS News program "Face The Nation." But he went on: "There will be credits, child credits for families with children. Will it be $245 billion? I'm not certain at this point." 
Mr. Dole's pronouncement was the first time he had spoken so pessimistically in public about the tax cut, and it came at a time when opinion polls showed that the Democratic strategy of linking budget cuts and planned reductions in Medicare and Medicaid with "a tax cut for the wealthy" was starting to take hold with the public.
Mr. Gingrich, appearing on the ABC program "This Week," said it would be "virtually impossible" to win approval in the House for a smaller tax cut.
"I don't think that the House Republicans who were elected on the Contract With America," Mr. Gingrich said, "are going to walk away from family tax credits for children, or walk off from an economic growth -- tax cut -- in the capital gains, and just say, 'Gee, we now give up.' I think that the Senate voted for $245 billion in tax cuts, and I think the Senate, frankly, is honor-bound to deliver on that."
By publicly wiggling on the tax issue, Mr. Dole raises the prospect of a rift between Senate and House Republicans at a time when the two chambers are already at odds over budget issues.
On Friday, House Republicans revolted against their leadership and joined with Democrats to defeat compromise legislation on spending bills for the Defense Department and the Interior Department because they were angry about Senate-dictated changes.
But Mr. Dole, a candidate for his party's Presidential nomination, finds himself caught between a Democratic attempt to paint the tax cut as a boon to the rich and rank-and-file Senate Republicans who have always been less than enthusiastic about the tax cut and have grown even more wary in recent weeks about delivering on a $245 billion cut.
"I'm hearing from a lot of sources on the Republican side, and not those who've said from the start that they thought that it was too much, but others who are frankly a little surprised by the past couple days," Mr. Dole said.
"There's been some indication, even from conservative Republicans' so-called steering committee, which meets weekly, that maybe we shouldn't try to go all the way to $245 billion," Mr. Dole said.
Three Republican members of the Senate Finance Committee -- Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming and Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York -- have expressed skepticism in recent weeks over the idea of cutting taxes so deeply while at the same time trying to balance the budget by 2002.
Mr. Hatch has predicted the tax cut will never pass, and Mr. D'Amato has said he would rather concentrate on reforming Medicare and Medicaid without "this business of tax cuts."
Mr. Gingrich turned up the political heat on wavering Senate Republicans -- singling out Mr. Dole and the Budget Committee chairman, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, who is the Senate's point man in the tax fight.
"Senator Dole and Senator Domenici and the Senate Republicans crafted a budget resolution with us that said $245 billion in tax cuts," he said. "The Senate Republicans voted for that resolution. Now, I think that it would be fairly unlikely that they would expect to be able to walk off from that and be able to pass anything in the House."
Mr. Dole said the primary goal of the Senate would be to pass the family tax credit of $500 per child, a capital gains rate reduction and to look at some kind of estate tax relief.
"We'll see what happens," he said.
From the outset, the Senate and the House have been at odds over the tax cut.
The tax cut was one of the pillars of the Contract With America, the campaign manifesto that helped Republicans win control of the House last year but was largely ignored and even derided by some Senate Republicans.
House Republicans originally proposed a $350 billion tax cut over the seven years in which they intend to balance the Federal budget. The Senate Finance Committee responded with a figure of $170 billion, and even then only after it was guaranteed that the money would not be needed to help balance the budget.
Negotiators from both chambers compromised on the $245 billion.
While Mr. Gingrich is not in the political fix in which Mr. Dole finds himself, the tax issue is just as much trouble for the Speaker, who would face a revolt if he tried to reduce the size of the budget cut. Conservative Republicans in the House, and especially its 73-member-strong freshman class that wears fiscal conservatism like a badge of honor, are unyielding in their support of the tax cut..
"I cannot participate in and will strongly oppose a betrayal of our solemn pledge to provide tax relief for all Americans," Representative David M. McIntosh, a freshman Republican from Indiana, said in an interview today with The Associated Press.
President Clinton, too, is part of the tax-cutting frenzy. But his proposed $105 billion tax cut has been a legislative nonstarter in the Republican-controlled Congress.
That has opened the way for Democrats in Congress to beat down the Republican plan and try to turn it into a political hammer.
"In a Congress dominated by a Republican majority, we've got a $270 billion cut in Medicare on the table, a $245 billion cut in taxes for those who don't need it on the table, a shift from the cuts in Medicare to cuts in taxes," Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."
"To pay for a tax cut for the wealthy out of a pool of resources for Medicare is wrong," he said.

HEADLINE: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: THE FUTURE;
Vatican Is Holding Talks About Papal Visit to Cuba

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 1

 BODY:
Even as Pope John Paul II prepares for a visit to the United States this week, the Vatican is quietly pursuing a diplomatic dialogue with Washington's oldest enemy, Fidel Castro, and has reopened talks with the Cuban Government about the possibility of visiting the Communist-ruled island.
Despite his apprehensions about the pontiff, who played a central role in the collapse of Communism in his native land, Poland, Mr. Castro has proven receptive to those initiatives, according to diplomats and church officials in the United States and Cuba. They predicted that contacts would intensify between the Vatican and Cuba, the only Latin American country that John Paul II has not visited.
The reopening of the talks was reported today in The Miami Herald and on a new Internet report on the Pope's visit produced by The New York Times on the World Wide Web. Quoting unidentified Vatican officials, the report said that the pontiff was expected to raise the issue of Cuba when he meets with President Clinton in Newark on Wednesday.
The report also said that as a result of recent discussions between the Holy See and the Cuban Government there was a "50-50 chance" that the Pope would meet with Mr. Castro in Havana early next year.
Nearly five years ago, Cuba and the Vatican agreed that the Pope would visit Havana, and the Holy See went so far as to announce the trip. No specific date was set, however, and the matter appeared to have a low priority as economic troubles and then political unrest grew in Cuba, while the church there began speaking out with growing frankness on the country's problems.
In a telephone interview this morning, Archbishop Benjamino Stella, the Papal Nuncio in Cuba, declined either to confirm or deny the possibility that John Paul II might visit Cuba soon, or to discuss any other aspect of recent communications between the Vatican and the Cuban Government.
"I know the subject of Cuba is very much in evidence this weekend," he said, referring to speculative reports in Spanish and Italian newspapers recently about prospects for a papal visit to the island, "but I do not want to comment. I ask your forgiveness, but I prefer not to do it."
On Friday, however, a Vatican spokesman in Rome denied reports that the Pope intended to include Cuba on his Latin American trip, saying, "Nothing is planned." On that visit, set for February, the pontiff's itinerary calls for him to make stops in El Salvador, Nicaragua, Guatemala and Venezuela, all of which are two hours or less from Cuba by plane.
In an interview in Havana last December, Mr. Castro expressed reservations about receiving the pontiff in Cuba. "There are people who are interested in politicizing a visit of the Pope," he said. "We do not agree with that kind of politicization."
Mr. Castro also made it clear that he viewed John Paul II as reflexively anti-Communist and the Catholic Church in Cuba as excessively conservative. He said he sympathized with the theology of liberation, a blend of Marxist analysis and Catholic doctrine that the Pope has sharply discouraged, and complained that "the church here, the upper ranks of the hierarchy, has been closer to the church in Miami than the theology of liberation."
As Cuba's economic and political difficulties have deepened, the Catholic Church there has become increasingly active. The Catholic charity Caritas now distributes medicine and food in Cuba, the formation of a Justice and Peace Commission by the Archdiocese of Havana to investigate human rights abuses was announced last year, and the Archdiocese of Havana publishes a newsletter that is one of the few publications not controlled by the Government.
Like Mr. Castro, the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Cuba has opposed the 34-year-old American economic embargo, saying that it inflicts unnecessary hardships on the Cuban population. But the Cuban Conference of Bishops has also criticized what it calls "the exclusionary and omnipresent character of the official ideology" and the "excessive control of state security organs." Despite his ideological differences with the Vatican, Mr. Castro has never broken diplomatic relations.
This summer, Mr. Castro met at the Nunciatura in Havana with a special envoy sent by the Pope, Cardinal Bernardin Gantin, according to diplomats and church officials in the United States and Cuba. Mr. Castro also conferred with Archbishop Jaime Lucas Ortega y Alamino, who last October became the first Cuban to be named Cardinal since Mr. Castro seized power in 1959.
"This has been going on for a long time, at least five years," a European diplomat who is based in Havana said today about the contacts between the Cuban Government and the Vatican. "But the pace seems to have picked up lately, and there appears to be some momentum building."

HEADLINE: Newsday Tests Just How Deep Cuts Can Go

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
For Newsday, the worst was supposed to be over by now.
Instead, it is becoming clear that the Long Island newspaper, often described as one of the best regional newspapers in the country, is struggling to move beyond the trauma that began with the closing of its New York City edition this summer. 
 The paper is completing a painful cost-cutting program, including voluntary buyouts, that led to the departure in recent weeks of more journalists than the paper's executives had predicted. Threatened layoffs were avoided, but the paper's total news staff is shrinking to 484 people from 724. That represents a cut of about 50 more jobs than Newsday expected when it closed the New York edition.
Those departing through the buyout program include top-level newsroom managers, like the foreign editor; columnists and senior reporters, like the chief White House correspondent, and some of the paper's most promising young writers.
"Psychologically, it's very debilitating" for Newsday, said one longtime manager who insisted on not being identified. "It causes people to question: 'What is the vision for the journalistic mission?' "
John McDonald, a former bureau chief for the East End of Long Island and the vice president of the paper's union, said, "It's got a long way to go to come back."
Newsday has become a highly visible test of the theory taking hold in newspapers nationally that sharp staff cutbacks will not affect readers. Mark H. Willes, chief executive of Newsday's parent, the Times Mirror Company, became the best- known advocate of that theory when, after he closed New York Newsday in July, he ordered cuts of about 800 of Newsday's total staff of 3,200 and oversaw sharp reductions at other papers owned by the company.
The cuts at Newsday and other Times Mirror papers, including The Los Angeles Times and The Hartford Courant, have put Times Mirror in the spotlight, because of its papers' reputation for quality, at a time the newspaper industry is under intense pressure to improve financial performance.
Everette E. Dennis, executive director of the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center in New York, said Mr. Willes's efforts to wring savings out of his newspapers were being watched carefully.
"You simply can't produce the same thing with fewer and perhaps less talented people," Mr. Dennis said.
"A newspaper is a living organism," he said, adding that once "living tissue" is cut off, "the organism will go on, but it will be scarred."
After Newsday spent what executives said was more than $60 million for the cost-cutting moves, so many journalists decided to take buyouts that Newsday's managers began furiously negotiating to keep some senior staff. The editors now plan to hire new journalists to fill some of the slots left empty.
At the same time, Newsday executives said, the paper's business managers have been under orders to get the annual profit margin up to about 17 percent, the average profit margin of several large newspaper companies, from about 7 percent. Newsday's annual profits have suffered in recent years because of weakness in the Long Island economy and multimillion-dollar annual losses at New York Newsday. The publisher of Newsday, Raymond A. Jansen, declined to be interviewed.
All of Times Mirror's big newspapers have been adapting to changes since Mr. Willes became chief executive on June 1. David S. Barrett, editor of The Hartford Courant, said his staff was skeptical about whether his paper was still committed to serious, in-depth journalism after a buyout program reduced his news staff from 342 to 294 people. The Courant lost some of its best-known columnists and prize-winning reporters.
In Washington, Jim Mann, a foreign affairs reporter for The Los Angeles Times, said he had an unsettling experience this summer, when his paper discontinued its Washington edition, which its editors had said was critical to keeping the West Coast paper visible among policy makers.
Mr. Mann received a call from an aide to Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who wanted to know how to get daily copies of the paper for Mr. Christopher. Mr. Mann had been under the impression that the paper planned to deliver its regular edition to Washington the same day as its publication -- in time to help set Washington's agenda. But after he checked with his paper, Mr. Mann had to tell the aide that The Los Angeles Times was no longer available on the East Coast on the day of publication -- even for the Secretary of State.
A spokeswoman for the paper said shipping expenses made same-day delivery impossible.
But perhaps because of all the attention given to the shutdown of New York Newsday, the stresses felt at Newsday on Long Island may be the clearest barometer of the changes in the newspaper industry. Editors at the paper's headquarters in Melville said recent events had been so painful that there had been a kind of group grieving process.
"Sure, a lot of people are sad, upset, frustrated about what's happened," said Anthony Marro, the editor since 1987. "I've spent the past month watching talented people go off to do journalism somewhere else and I can't imagine anybody being happy about that. At the same time, I'm very excited about the staff that's still here."
People at Newsday said Mr. Marro and Mr. Jansen were clearly unprepared for Mr. Willes's demand for sharp cuts. The result, they said, was that an effort to try to avoid layoffs ended up hurting the paper.
Early this summer, the journalists at the paper said, the executives were so obviously worried about the prospect of layoffs that they suggested that Newsday staffers who could get a job elsewhere should do so and take the buyout. Only in September, toward the end of the eight-week buyout offer, did managers appear to realize that many of the paper's best journalists were fleeing.
In interviews, some of those who have left said they had lost interest in what they feared would become a parochial suburban paper. Some said that they were confident Newsday would recover journalistically but that they were too wrung out emotionally by recent events to stay. Others said they doubted that Mr. Willes would be satisfied with any attainable profit at the paper. Still others said they felt certain he would eventually sell the paper, creating a new crisis.
Mr. Willes has said Times Mirror will not sell its newspapers. A corporate spokeswoman, Martha Goldstein, said last week that Newsday's managers, not Mr. Willes, had set the paper's financial goals. Asked if there was a likelihood of new cutbacks in the future, the spokeswoman would say only, "We have no reason to believe that Newsday won't make their performance standard."
Some former staffers said even the paper's top executives seem dispirited by demands for higher profits, possibly at the cost of Newsday's broader ambitions. "He took away their dream that someday they were going to be a major paper," said one journalist who echoed the words of many of his colleagues. "Now, it's going to be The Nassau County Daily Bugle."
Mr. Marro was told about such comments in an interview. Although he told his employees that he disagreed with Mr. Willes's decision to close New York Newsday, Mr. Marro said no one could know what his journalistic dreams were.
"My resolve," Mr. Marro added, "is to keep this a first-rate paper. And to make it a place where journalists do their best work."

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Nuclear Power

 BODY:
New Jersey and Connecticut are both greatly dependent on nuclear power to generate electricity. Changing economics, especially high maintenance and capital costs for nuclear power plants and decreasing oil and natural gas prices, have made the electricity produced by nuclear energy more expensive than power from other sources. One plant, Shoreham, closed before it began producing electricity. No new reactors have been ordered for 20 years in the United States. Some nuclear plants in the region are also notoriously unreliable. Many have capacity factors, the measure of a plant's reliability, well below the national average.

HEADLINE: Still 'Forever Wild'?

BYLINE: By Bill McKibben; Bill McKibben is the author of "Hope, Human and Wild," about the history of the Adirondacks.

DATELINE: JOHNSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
The Empire State can boast of many things but none grander than the vast Adirondack Park, which occupies the northern quarter of the state. It's the world's largest- scale, longest-running experiment in ecological restoration, and it's under siege this fall as never before.
I live in the central Adirondacks, and when a windstorm blew through here in mid-July it knocked down millions of trees. But it left a lot more than that standing. 
 The Adirondack Park, a unique patchwork of state and private land, is bigger than the Glacier, Grand Canyon, Yellowstone and Yosemite national parks combined, so the wind affected most of the park about as much as a water-main break on Canal Street in Manhattan bothers Far Rockaway, Queens.
Yet some state officials want to use the storm as an excuse to override the state's protection of the Adirondack wilderness -- the guarantee in the state constitution that it will remain "forever wild."
They are talking about "salvage" operations on this public land, and they're planning to allow private owners with windblown stretches of land to clear-cut large holdings -- damaged and healthy trees alike -- with no direct oversight.
Much worse for the future of the park, Gov. George Pataki's administration seems bent on easing the way for developers, whose new subdivisions would do far more damage than the 80-mile-an-hour winds that toppled the pines and hemlocks in July.
The park's regional planning agency faces crippling staff cuts, and the state has stopped spending money that had been reserved for the acquisition of new public land. New state appointees have even proposed changing park rules to allow outside trash to be put in local landfills.
All of this has come as a stunning disappointment to people who care about these glorious mountains, lakes and woods. Many of us had hoped that Mr. Pataki would turn out to be a protector of the park, for we badly need a return to the bipartisan consensus that has for more than a century protected the Adirondack wilderness.
The Adirondacks won their special designation more than a century ago after a manmade disaster -- unrestrained logging -- caused whole mountainsides to erode into the headwaters of the Hudson. Early photographs of the now densely forested land around my house show mile upon mile with hardly a tree in sight.
Generations before the rest of the world had even heard of ecology, New York began a classic experiment in restoration. With more and more land purchased by the state and protected by the constitution's guarantee that timber could not be "sold, removed, or destroyed," trees began to grow again.
With them came the wildlife. There are old men and women in my town who can remember when the first bear returned here, an object of great wonder. Now bears are common, and we are celebrating the slow return of moose.
Moderate Republicans have been at least as important in protecting the Adirondacks as Democratic liberals. Nelson Rockefeller extended important zoning regulations to the half of the park that remains in private hands, preventing the construction of large-scale vacation resorts in the back country.
New York's partnership between public and private interests is a successful example of the federalism now in vogue in Washington: the state's public lands are in far better shape than the overgrazed and overcut national forests. Conservationists trying to create biosphere reserves in tropical rain forests and the African savanna have begun to study the Adirondacks.
But there's still much work to do. As the Residents Committee to Protect the Adirondacks points out, though the Adirondacks lie in the poorest corner of the state, this area is not as poor as comparable areas of the rural Northeast -- and we have a wild forest that could serve as the base of our economic future, both in wilderness tourism and small-scale timber harvesting.
Mr. Pataki, who was an environmentalist in the Legislature and as Governor signed the visionary law protecting Long Island's Pine Barrens, still has time to champion the Adirondacks. The Governor should watch his polls. Recent surveys show his approval rating dipping below 40 percent, and most New Yorkers say he's more conservative than they are.
If in a few years he could say that he brought all sides together -- if he could point to new shoreline protection for Adirondack lakes, to the acquisition of a few key parcels of land that Gov. Mario Cuomo could never buy and to economic progress tied to the land's continuing integrity -- that would be a signal accomplishment, a powerful claim to long-lasting gratitude. It would be an accomplishment on an Adirondack scale.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 3, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A new book by Bill McKibben, the author of an article published yesterday on the Adirondacks, was described incorrectly. The book, "Hope, Human and Wild," examines local efforts around the world to reduce environmental damage.

HEADLINE: Noncandidate Powell Stirs Waves on Republican Right

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Without running for President, without even disclosing a party affiliation, Gen. Colin L. Powell has caused more commotion on the Republican right than any of the declared candidates.
Last week Gary L. Bauer, a former Bush Administration aide who heads the Family Research Council and American Renewal, both conservative groups, sent a fax to 5,000 conservative opinion leaders, warning that "the current flirtation with Colin Powell as the 1996 G.O.P. Presidential nominee has gone far enough" and urging his friends to cut it out. 
 For many of Mr. Bauer's allies, it has been a heavy flirtation -- and an unlikely one, given General Powell's emerging reputation as the political heir of Nelson A. Rockefeller, who earned the enmity of conservatives as the rival of their hero, Barry Goldwater, for the 1964 Republican Presidential nomination.
Many right-wing Republicans had hoped to support William J. Bennett, the author and former Cabinet member, or former Vice President Dan Quayle, or Jack F. Kemp, another former Cabinet member. All three withdrew from the race before it had started, and conservatives have lacked a champion since. A few have settled on Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, but he has not caught fire. So prominent conservatives, like many others, have been pouring their hopes into General Powell.
The pro-Powell conservatives find appeal in the general's military background, his devotion to traditional values like discipline and family solidarity and patriotism, and his economic conservatism. They overlook, to the astonishment of people like Mr. Bauer, his backing for abortion rights and gun control.
In the first issue of The Weekly Standard, a new conservative magazine, Bill Kristol, who was Mr. Quayle's chief of staff, said this: "Can a moderate win the nomination of a conservative, newly energized, Reagan-Gingrich Republican Party? Yes -- especially if Powell throws a few bones to conservatives by saying the right things about personal responsibility, no new taxes and limited government."
"He is a leader," Mr. Kemp said. "He transcends the parties. He is a Republican on almost every issue."
Mr. Bennett said on television that General Powell was "a sensitive, thoughtful and nuanced man," and suggested that he could run for President on a platform of "duty, honor, country." Ralph Reed, head of the Christian Coalition, noted that the general had said "he agreed with many of the things we were promoting -- traditional family values, school choice and things of that nature."
The conservative pollster Richard Wirthlin has also made positive noises about a Powell candidacy as a Republican. He argued that the general's positions on the economy and on controlling crime, "as well as providing a moral standard for the country, put him in a very good position of bringing in a majority of the conservative vote if he should run."
It is all too much for Mr. Bauer, who objects to General Powell's support for abortion rights and for gun controls, his criticism of the Republican "Contract With America," his qualified backing for affirmative action and his lukewarm attitude toward overhauling the welfare system.
"Republicans should quickly right themselves and ask the good general to match his rare charisma with rock-solid conservatism," Mr. Bauer wrote in his fax memorandum. "As things stand now, that appears to be a long-term project."
Since sending it, he said in an interview, he has been swamped by messages of support from rank-and-file conservatives. But "there has been no rush to the microphones on Capitol Hill," he added ruefully, and "people at the grass roots see a sellout by their leaders."
"It's part of a pattern," Mr. Bauer said. "There is much more passion for change outside Washington than inside. The Congressional freshmen sense that, which is why they are pressing Gingrich so hard. But there are always tensions between governing conservatives and citizen conservatives. Same with liberals."
Most Republican officeholders have been careful not to say anything harsh about General Powell, although Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the front-runner for the 1996 Republican nomination, has been considerably more complimentary than Senator Gramm.
Of the well-known conservative activists, only Paul Weyrich of the Free Congress Foundation has spoken out in support of Mr. Bauer's position. On CNN's "Inside Politics" program on Thursday, he said of General Powell, "If he should get the Republican nomination, it would be as if Ronald Reagan never lived and Nelson Rockefeller never died."
But Mr. Kristol, of The Weekly Standard, may be having second thoughts. He said last week that "there's a case to be made that Powell would do to the Gingrich revolution what Bush did to the Reagan revolution -- stall it."
In addition, an anti-Powell note was sounded last week by Lawrence Eagleburger, the former Secretary of State, who said in an interview with the journal International Economy: "I don't know where he is on any issue other than some security issues. I don't know why he should be President. I know personally that if Colin had had his druthers, we would not have fought the Iraq War. President Bush and Brent Scowcroft pushed him into it."
Tony Dolan, who was Ronald Reagan's chief speechwriter, sees the tumult as the inevitable result of the growth of the conservative movement.
"Doctrinal unity is not a problem when you're small," he said. "But you grow, you gain power and factions develop. Now there is no longer an approved vision of conservatism. We don't know which is the official Vatican newspaper. Is it The Standard? Is it The National Review? Is it Human Events?"
Mr. Dolan does not think General Powell will run, but the possibility of a candidacy, he said, is splitting conservatives between those who look back to the battles of the 1960's and 1970's, when Republican moderates remained a powerful force, and those whose outlook was shaped by the triumphs of the Reagan era.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

HEADLINE: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: THE FAITHFUL;
Vibrant Parishes Find Strength in Diversity

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
The parish demographics have changed wildly, even weekly, in the nine decades since German immigrants built St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Queens. Last Sunday, a young Filipino woman's voice rang out from the Ridgewood church's choir loft, while down below a Vietnamese grandmother rocked her infant grandchild. Hispanic and Indian schoolchildren stood together, and older Polish and Italian men knelt with their thick arms and rosary beads hanging before them.
"Mass here can feel like Sociology 101," Msgr. Eugene McGovern, the pastor at St. Aloysius, said. 
 While St. Aloysius has multilingual priests, there are so many immigrant groups at the working-class church that it is not possible to create separate masses for each. The celebration and instruction that takes place at the parish's main Sunday Mass, then, is done in only one language -- English.
"I often wonder how much they are taking in," Monsignor McGovern said of the single language for his great variety of parishioners. "My hope is that each person takes a bit. But there is such diversity that we can't offer that complete kind of parish life."
It was Pope John Paul II who once said that "culture must become faith, and faith must become culture," and as he travels through the New York City region this week, the Pope will see many churches like St. Aloysius that are living through all the joys and travails of carrying out his dictum. For the Catholic Church in the city, the latest, spectacularly varied surge of immigrants has at once reinvigorated and enriched parishes while straining the church and its resources to their limits.
Immigrants, with each group harboring its own special notions of the spiritual, political and economic role of the Catholic Church, have turned to parishes across the city looking for help and healing, security and education. And that does not even include salvation.
That kind of searching by Catholic immigrants -- a good number of them undocumented -- has become more urgent in light of what many of them perceive as a nasty turn in the country's political climate, one they say they think has turned them into targets.
"In the Catholic Church, there is no need to have a visa or a passport," said the Rev. Ronald Marino, who runs the Catholic Migration Office in Brooklyn. "You are not asked where you came from or if you are legal."
Even in New York City, the Diocese of Brooklyn, which includes Queens, stands out, with the largest immigrant membership among its 1.6 million parishioners.
"In Brooklyn and Queens, we have a microcosm of the whole world and thus a microcosm of the universal church," Father Marino said. "It goes beyond language and whether or not you can do Spanish bingo. And so with that kind of pressure, the challenge to minister is great. We do some things well, and some things need a lot of work."
The impact of immigrants on the church in the city, and the simultaneous effect of the church on the immigrants, can be measured in all sorts of ways, straightforward and subtle. To make the best use of its priests with foreign-language skills and immigrant backgrounds, the diocese has created 18 separate apostolates in the two boroughs to be spiritual and practical outposts for specific ethnic groups, from Haitians to Pakistanis. At the Most Precious Blood Church in Astoria, Queens, the special-language Mass schedule for Sunday reads: 10:45 Croatian; 12:30 Italian; 5:00 Filipino; 6:30 Brazilian.
In upper Manhattan, more than 20,000 Catholics, almost all of them Hispanic, fill churches that had been imperiled by the flight of European Catholics from the city. "Our 10 churches here, without the Dominicans, would be empty," said Msgr. Joaquin Beaumont, pastor of St. Elizabeth, where 3,700 people turn out for Sunday Mass. In Flushing, Queens, Korean immigrants raised $5 million to build their own church, St. Paul Chong Ha Sang. The 4,000 people who attend Mass every Sunday make up the largest Korean Catholic community outside of Korea.
This Catholic migration in the city at times takes surprising turns. For instance, St. Frances de Chantal, a traditionally Italian parish that had seen its numbers dwindle and its school shut, faced possible closing several years ago as the Borough Park section of Brooklyn became populated almost exclusively by Orthodox Jews.
But many of the Jews hired Catholic Polish women to be their house cleaners, and those women began attending Saturday evening Mass at St. Frances. Other Poles followed. Now, 3,000 Polish immigrants go to Mass every weekend. Last Saturday, as the moon appeared in the night sky and the Orthodox walked by with their children, light and music poured out of St. Frances and onto the streets of Borough Park.
Inside, the air was thick with perfume, and there were two weddings and a pair of baptisms taking place in addition to Mass. The faces in the pews, encompassing every generation, were out of some old Solidarity poster. The collection baskets contained only single bills, but they were filled to the top.
With the Pope's Mass before thousands of the city's immigrants at Aqueduct Racetrack on Friday, only days away, a group of St. Frances parishioners spoke of the mixed blessings of the Catholic Church in America. Halina Nowakowicz, 52, said that "after six days of work, I couldn't imagine not hearing a Polish homily." Jacek Kaczocha, a 19-year-old theology student, said that "everywhere you look in New York are people who have abandoned the church," and that he believed the Catholics back in Poland were "closer to God."
But the power of the weekly experience at St. Frances meant everything to Kazimierz Nojewodka, 42. "I am only a handyman, and I hear bad words spoken at me, words that humiliate me," he said. "Here, I get my identity back. I am a child of God again."
That redemptive sense of identity suffused the basement church at St. Jerome's on Newkirk Avenue in Brooklyn last Sunday. More than 600 Haitian immigrants had emerged from subways and car-service vehicles to be a part of the 7:45 A.M. Creole Mass. There were horns and drums in the church, and the elderly and the 8-year-olds didn't mind kneeling on the hard floor.
The Haitians, who fight the hardships of immigration politics and racial prejudice, sang strenuously and laughed frequently. The Catholic Church -- a complicated institution in Haiti that has served both as an ally of dictatorships and a champion of the poor -- seemed on this Brooklyn morning a place of unity.
"My faith was strong in Haiti, but it got stronger here," Gertrude Crevecoeur, an office administrator, said. "Haitian people believe."
Of course, the dynamics and phenomena produced by immigrants and the church in the city are often complex, the successes shaded. After 26 consecutive years of declining enrollment at Catholic elementary schools in the Brooklyn and Queens diocese, there have been three straight years of increases. But in many instances, only a fraction of the children attending the schools are Catholics.
And in the case of Catholics who have come to the city from India, many of whom get together for Mass once a month at Holy Family Church in Brooklyn or Our Lady of the Snows in Floral Park, there has been a more muted sense of vitality and shared experience. "The numbers are increasing, but I think most are disappointed," the Rev. Paul Vazhapilly said. "The knowledge of the faith, the practice of the faith, seems to be less for everybody here."
In certain instances, the experiences for immigrant Catholics in the city have been rich but isolated from the larger church. For other immigrants, the experiences have been troubled by the political tensions carried here from their native countries.
The Koreans in Flushing have set up what amounts to an old-style national parish -- St. Paul Chong Ha Sang -- serving exclusively immigrants from Korea. Because traditional church life in Korea was built on the strength and involvement of lay people, the parishioners in Flushing have managed well despite the shortage of diocesan priests and the near absence of priests who speak their language. The parish boasts 27 prayer groups and a credit union with $20 million in assets.
At the Church of the Transfiguration in Chinatown, recent immigrants from the Chinese countryside, people who belonged to the "underground" Catholic Church in China, have brought life and numbers and energy. But they have also found themselves wary of other parishioners and priests they believe belonged to the government-sanctioned "patriotic" Catholic Church in China. So great is their suspicion of native Chinese priests that it is not uncommon for the new immigrants to go to the Rev. Raymond Nobiletti, the American-born pastor, and ask him to rehear confessions that have been heard by Chinese priests.
"We run an obstacle course here," said Father Nobiletti, "and every couple of months I have to get up and remind everyone that this is the United States, and that we don't discriminate."
Church officials say they believe that the multiple challenges are going to be more daunting in the future. Immigrants will keep coming, and they will always be mostly poor.
"We don't pretend to meet all their demands, but we do what we can," said Bishop Joseph Sullivan, executive vice president of Catholic Charities for Brooklyn and Queens. "What we must try and do is create a human environment for them to pursue their destiny."
Many Hispanic Catholics, who have been arriving in New York for decades, adapting themselves and changing the church in the city as well, think they have part of the answer to the task ahead.
"The nature of the Catholic parish in America is changing," said Antonio Stevens-Arroyo, a scholar and the director of the Program for Analysis of Religion Among Latinos. "The clergy can't run everything. There are not enough of them. A home-based spiritual life built around the family and a dedication to the community is the parish of the future. And Puerto Ricans and Dominicans and others have been doing it for decades."

Companies Propose Plan
To Settle Implant Suits
Three major manufacturers of silicone breast implants, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Baxter Healthcare and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, proposed a new settlement that would both reduce a previous offer to thousands of women and make it harder for them to collect awards. 
 Under the plan, the companies' contribu tions could rise sharply from their share of the original $4.25 billion deal, which had collapsed, but would reduce individual awards. Women who chose not to accept the plan could still sue the manufacturers. [Page A14.]
 
Restrictions Placed on Daiwa
State and Federal regulators charged Daiwa Bank with unsound banking practices and imposed tough restrictions on the bank in reaction to its admission last week that a trader in its New York branch had lost $1.1 billion over the last 11 years. [D6.]
 
Deal Reached on Canary Wharf Sale
An investor group led by the Canadian developer Paul Reichmann and Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia will buy Canary Wharf, according to Lloyds Bank, which leads the group that owns the London complex. [D8.]
 
Auto Sales Hurt by Strike
General Motors and Chrys ler reported disappointing September sales, as an eight-week strike by car haulers began to take its toll. G.M.'s sales rose one-half of 1 percent, to 401,463 units, and Chrysler's sales fell 6.6 percent, to 157,004 units. [D9.]
 
British Utilities in $4.4 Billion Deal
Southern Electric P.L.C., Britain's second-largest regional power distribution company, agreed to be acquired by National Power P.L.C., the nation's largest generator of electricity, for $4.4 billion. [D8.]
 
Cigna to Take $750 Million Charge
Cigna became the latest insurance company to announce it would increase the amount of money it has set aside to pay insurance claims arising from environmental cleanups and asbestos, saying it would take a $750 million charge against third-quarter earnings. [D24.]
 
S.E.C. Sends Signal to Advisers
In three recent cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission has put the nation's investment advisers on notice that they have an extra responsibility to put the interests of clients before their own -- and to alert clients to conflicts of interest, even potential ones. Market Place. [D12.]
 
Nextel Chief Executive to Resign
Nextel Communications' chief executive, Wayland R. Hicks, will resign, and the company said it would move its headquarters to Seattle. Analysts said the moves signaled the increasing influence Craig O. McCaw has on the company. [D6.]
 
David Rockefeller Quits Board
David Rockefeller resigned from the board of Rockefeller Group, saying his role as a director might conflict with his role in an investor group bidding to buy Rockefeller Center Properties, which holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center. [D10.]
 
Consumer Spending Rises 1%
Consumer spending rose a strong 1 percent in August, lifted by a surge in purchases of new cars. In a separate report, a survey by the National Association of Purchas ing Management showed that manufacturing activity remained weak in September, pointing to continued slow economic growth. [D6.]
 
The purchasing management report sent stocks down sharply over concerns about corporate profits. The Dow industrials fell 27.82 points, to 4,761.26, and the Nasdaq composite sank 15.97 points, to 1,027.57. [D12.]
 
License Pacts for Lotus Notes
Lotus Development is expected today to announce license agreements with 11 telecommunications companies around the world that will make its Notes software available on their public networks. [D2.]
 
Lucas Industries Settles Dispute
Lucas Industries said it would pay $88 million to settle a two-year legal dispute with the Department of Defense. The settlement will result in a charge to earnings of $87 million for the 1995 fiscal year. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Even Its Allies Castigate U.S. Over Failure to Pay U.N. Dues

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 2

 BODY:
Britain's Foreign Secretary called it "representation without taxation." Australia's Foreign Minister suggested Washington could lose its United Nations voting rights. The Nordic countries as much as said that American deadbeats were setting a "deplorable" example for the world.
Day after day for more than a week, friends of the United States in Europe and nearly every other region have lined up in the 50th General Assembly to castigate those whose failure to pay United Nations dues is leading the organization to the point of bankruptcy. Since Washington owes more than any other nation -- about $1.4 billion by its own account -- the criticism is pointed. 
 "The severest financial crisis in the history of the United Nations casts a dark shadow over the 50th anniversary," Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, said in a speech today. "The failure of particularly one major member state to meet its obligations by withholding legally obligated contributions is not only contrary to Article 17 of the Charter, but has also driven the organization to the very brink of insolvency."
A few hours later, Gareth Evans, the Australian Foreign Minister, delivered a stinging retort to charges of organizational bloat, in which he noted that the New York City police department had an annual budget $600 million higher than the $1.2 billion needed to run all United Nations offices in New York, Geneva, Vienna, Nairobi and five regional commissions combined.
Warming to the subject, he added that the whole United Nations -- including the World Health Organization, the International Atomic Energy Agency, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund -- employed 61,400 people, nearly 4,000 fewer than the number who work in three Disney amusement parks.
"Three times as many people, 183,000," he said, "sell McDonald's hamburgers around the world."
American officials have been struck by the particular bitterness of important European allies and others reflected in speeches and meetings in recent weeks, an American diplomat said today. "We got the message," he added.
Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, is in Washington today consulting with officials and members of Congress about ways to begin meeting the overdue payments of Washington's normal assessments.
Last week, when Congress approved a resolution allowing the Government to operate until a budget formula could be found, $120 million for payments to the regular United Nations budget and $50 million for peacekeeping operations were set aside. American diplomats hope to make those payments within six weeks. In addition, $26 million was paid last week toward the costs of peacekeeping in Macedonia, where American troops are stationed.
An American official said today that the Administration hoped to persuade Congress to approve as much as $500 million to $600 million in allocations to pay late United Nations bills by the end of the year. Some members of Congress have said that will not happen without restrictions or conditions.
Officials are already facing a potential legal problem with the United Nations over a decision by Congress to unilaterally cut the United States assessment for peacekeeping operations from 31 percent to 25 percent. Washington pays 25 percent of the organization's regular budget, a figure chosen by Americans when assessments were apportioned.
