HEADLINE: NOT GUILTY: THE RACIAL PRISM;
Racial Split at the End, as at the Start

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB 

 BODY:
The seven workers at the Pasqua Coffee Bar in lower Manhattan like to joke around with one another, to trade stories about family and regular customers, and to help one another out in jams.
But until the astonishingly abrupt culmination of the O. J. Simpson murder trial yesterday, they never seemed to get around to discussing what, for much of America, has been a prickly and divisive topic. 
 Then, as the voice of the court clerk intoning "not guilty" came over the restaurant's radio, Charmon Savage, a black man who works in the kitchen, jumped up, punched the air with both fists and exclaimed, "Yes! Yes! Yes!"
Geraldine Foney, the restaurant manager, who is white, lowered her head with disgust in her eyes. "I thought he should have rotted in hell," she said.
And several other women on the staff, including Debi Diaz, a counterwoman, grumbled in disbelief after hearing the verdict of the jurors, nine of whom are black. "They have to retry him," she said. "It's ridiculous, you know."
The scene at the Pasqua Bar was repeated in thousands of different settings across the country yesterday, with reactions that seemed often to be shaped by race -- especially by race -- sometimes by the person's sex and frequently by a jaded belief that personal wealth can triumph over just about anything.
At the Texas Bar-B-Q in downtown Dallas, a black-owned restaurant, a couple of black men greeted the verdict with eruptions of elation. Several white customers quietly left shortly afterward.
At Jocks n Jills Sports Bar at the CNN Center in Atlanta, the reaction was much the same as the verdict came over a bank of wall-to-wall television sets -- black customers often embraced and cheered; whites sat in stony silence.
Over the Internet, the comments were often starkly racial.
Since it first began to transfix the country in June 1994, the Simpson murder case has been a combination soap opera, passion play and national Rorschach test laden with sex, celebrity, wealth, violence and, perhaps most sensitively, race.
The reactions to the verdict parallel the racial divide in every opinion poll taken since the trial began. Separated by a constant gap of about 40 percentage points, many whites seemed to hold fast to the belief that Mr. Simpson was guilty, while blacks believed as adamantly in his innocence. Several polls indicate that behind the response of many blacks is a deep suspicion of the police and the criminal justice system.
A poll taken by CBS News immediately after the verdict found that about 6 in 10 whites believed the wrong verdict was reached, while 9 in 10 blacks said the jury had come to the right conclusion. Both blacks and whites said Mr. Simpson was given a fair trial.
While a majority of whites had said the trial was fair in last weekend's CBS News poll, that number rose after the verdict. And among blacks it nearly doubled, to about 8 in 10 from about 4 in 10.
At a time of wide uncertainty over any number of issues in the United States, the disparate reactions may reflect more than black wariness with the police.
Russell Adams, chairman of the department of Afro-American studies at Howard University, said, "We have been for the last 10 or 15 years in a racial polarization posture, part of it caused by vagueness on the part of the economy, part caused by the sense of the center not having held, of a moral disarray and, let me use this phrase, of an ethnic disarray -- the expected roles that had worked for people in the past are no longer predictable."
For all this, there were more than a few black people who said yesterday that they thought Mr. Simpson was guilty, and a larger number of whites who said they believed there was a reasonable doubt.
At the Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta, where the reading of the verdicts led to delays on several Delta Air Lines flights, the overwhelmingly white crowd in Concourse A greeted the news quietly, but two or three white women applauded and a white man thrust his arms aloft and cheered.
In Washington, James Fisher, a black 23-year-old clerical worker at the Department of Agriculture, said, as some other blacks did: "I feel he did the murders. I expected the verdict. I figured his lawyers were good."
For the most part, though, the sentiments ran passionately in the opposite direction.
"It's about racism," said John Thomas, 27, who is black, as he sat in the emergency room of Kings County Hospital in heavily black central Brooklyn. "Today, racism took a solid blow."
But in Chicago, Katherine Long, 36, an arts administrator who is white, said Mr. Simpson's acquittal would increase racial problems more than if he had been convicted. "They're opening a very big can of worms with this," she said, "and people are going to think that black jurors always acquit black men.
"It sets a precedent, which will hearten racists who think that they should stick with their own, like a Jewish juror should find a Jew innocent," Ms. Long added. "It will perpetuate myths."
At the Connecticut Street projects in San Francisco, where Mr. Simpson grew up, the sounds of celebration shook the sidewalk. Rap music poured from an open van. Cars slowed and honked. People danced in their doorways.
"This has been going on for years in our country to the black people," said Bonnie Beasley, 55, who lives a few blocks away in a house next to the one where Mr. Simpson's mother lives. "What happened with Mike Tyson?"
"In every city there is a Fuhrman," she added, referring to Mark Fuhrman, the racist former detective whose role in the case was emphasized by Mr. Simpson's lawyers. "That's America, but this verdict shows the black race has hope."
Stephen Bowers, an investor who is white and was having lunch at the Jocks n Jills Sports Bar in Atlanta, saw race as an undermining influence in the trial.
"The case turned when the black jurors pivoted from looking at the murder to looking at the police," he said. "O. J. should have burned and the cops should have lost their jobs. Instead, O. J. does no time and the cops go on being cops."
In a sentiment expressed by numerous people around the country, David Epps, 26, who is white and was also at the restaurant, said: "If you've got enough money to hire Johnnie Cochran and Robert Shapiro, you get off. If it was you or me we'd go to jail."
Around the country, too, many women also said they were hit hard by the verdict because of an empathy for Mr. Simpson's former wife, Nicole, who, according to testimony, endured years of abuse.
"He should have gone to jail for all those years of beating her," Rosalind Alvarez, 28, said, as she shopped at a neighborhood market in Buffalo, where Mr. Simpson starred as a running back for the Buffalo Bills football team. "Imagine, a man can kill his wife and walk away. What kind of justice do we have here?"
That was a question that John Zelenka, a white technician from Rockland County, N.Y., had as he walked away from Times Square, where a crowd of black men erupted in cheers as they saw the verdict reported on a large high-tech screen on the old Times Tower.
Mr. Zelenka, his head held low, said, "I'm certain the guy did it." More disturbing, he said, was the reaction. "That disappointed me," he said. "You could see it in the crowd -- it was along race lines."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Passers-by watched the verdict with shock through the windows of the "Today" show studios at Rockefeller Center, left (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times); at her restaurant in Harlem, Sylvia Woods cheered as she hugged her daughter and a waitress. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)(pg. A1)

HEADLINE: A VISIT FROM THE POPE: PREPARATIONS;
From Newark to New York, An Elaborate Choreography

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
From Interstate 280 and the New Jersey Turnpike in Newark, which will be closed while his motorcade whizzes by, to a town house on East 72d Street in Manhattan, where he will spend the next four nights, the preparations drew to a well-organized conclusion yesterday on the eve of Pope John Paul II's first visit to the New York area since 1979.
The Pope is to arrive in Newark this afternoon for a visit that will include a meeting with President Clinton, prayers in John Cardinal O'Connor's official residence at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan and a speech to the United Nations General Assembly. 
 As construction workers in hard hats lumbered past joggers in bandanas and park rangers in Smokey Bear-style hats, Cardinal O'Connor went on an inspection tour of Central Park. The Great Lawn looked much as it would before a rock concert, with bulldozers that went beep-beep-beep as they shifted into reverse to smooth the dirt in front of the portable stage.
But this time, it will support an altar instead of musicians and their instruments, and the amplification system will carry words of inspiration to worshipers up to a quarter-mile away.
The arrangements are no less elaborate in Newark, where more than 700 police officers and hundreds of F.B.I. and Secret Service agents will be on duty today when the Pontiff lands at Newark International Airport. He is to be greeted by President Clinton before leaving for Sacred Heart Cathedral, which is at the center of a two-mile square that will be closed to traffic from about 11 A.M. until dark. The police will start ticketing and towing cars inside a smaller, 32-block zone at 7 A.M.
"A full-court press is on," the police director of Newark, William R. Celester, said. "We are pressing into service everything that we have."
The heaviest traffic delays in Newark will be between 3 P.M., when the Pope's plane is due to land, and 7 P.M., when he is expected to leave for Manhattan. Traffic will be stopped on Interstate 280 and the New Jersey Turnpike while the Pope and the President are on the way from the airport to the cathedral.
In New York, city officials issued a four-day gridlock alert for Manhattan. To encourage motorists not to drive into Manhattan while the Pope is in town, street cleaning rules will be suspended in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx today through Sunday in the hope of freeing up parking spaces. The Transportation Department urged motorists who live outside the city to park in those three boroughs and take subways or buses to Manhattan, where, it said, several areas had "particular potential for congestion," including the East Side, from the Battery to 125th Street. The Pope will be staying at the residence of the Vatican's representative to the United Nations, on East 72d Street.
Transportation officials warned that traffic congestion may spill over to the West Side tomorrow and Saturday. For Friday, when the Pope is scheduled to say Mass at Aqueduct Race Track, the Transportation Department advised drivers to avoid the Belt Parkway, the Van Wyck Expressway, the Nassau Expressway and Rockaway Boulevard.
Preparing for and protecting the Pope is expected to cost New York City $5 million to $7 million in police overtime and another $1 million in what Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called "incremental costs." Newark has set aside $300,000 for police overtime and $2.3 million for equipment, including boats that will patrol the Passaic River during the Mass at Sacred Heart.
But officials in the two cities said there would be a payoff from the Pontiff's trip. Mr. Giuliani and city economic development officials have estimated that the visit will generate about $65 million in direct and secondary spending in the city, including hotels, souvenirs, food and transportation. That would produce about $2.13 million in city tax revenues, the city's Economic Development Corporation estimated. City Hall officials also noted that the Federal Government reimburses the city for most of the costs of protecting foreign dignitaries, including the Pope.
The police command and control center, at Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan, will coordinate 18 city agencies and 17 police units. How many officers will be involved is a closely held secret: the chief of department, Louis R. Anemone, would say only that "thousands" of officers will be on duty.
"I'm looking for that balance between access and the Pope's safety," Chief Anemone said. "It's a fine line we're walking."
Chief Anemone said that the police had received "a couple" of "off the wall calls to 911," but that there had been no serious threats.
Referring to the last papal visit in 1979, Chief Anemone said security this time would be tighter. The Pope will not ride in an open-air limousine, and the public will be kept farther away. "The world is different," he said. "He himself has been a target already."
This time, the authorities will have have high-technology help: a police helicopter with a video camera will hover above all events, feeding live video to the command center. But they will also be in constant touch with police officers on the street, including the contingent assigned to one particular street -- East 72d, between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue.
At least one officer has been stationed on the block for the last six weeks, residents said. Yesterday, officers took up posts at the entrance of each building on the block after removing the mailbox at the corner of 72d Street and Madison Avenue. (The police told residents they will bring it back after the Pope leaves.)
Parking was prohibited on both sides of the street, and by nightfall barricades had been put up to block traffic. Neighbors have been notified that once the Pope arrives, they will have to be escorted by the police. But they will not be asked for identification; people who say they are going to an address not on that block will be asked to take another route. Two groups of about 50 police officers each were briefed yesterday on who lives where on the block.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was working to accommodate hundreds of reporters who will want to record the Pope's every action -- and who will undoubtedly have questions about his papacy past and present. The Quinn Library at Fordham University was put on alert to provide answers. "I told everyone, 'Brush up on your encyclicals,' " said Linda LoSchiavo, the director.
But despite the anticipation, the preparations and the publicity, not everyone was aware that the Pope was coming to New York.
"What's going on?" asked Helena Vrinera as she walked on a path around the Great Lawn yesterday with a camera dangling from her neck. "I don't know. I'm a tourist from Argentina."

HEADLINE: U.N. Fiscal Woes Are Said to Threaten War Crime Tribunals

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The work of international tribunals established to prosecute charges of genocide and war crimes in Rwanda and in the Balkans is being seriously impaired by United Nations spending restrictions, the chief prosecutor of the tribunals and Washington's senior human rights officer said today.
In interviews in Warsaw, where they are attending a human rights conference organized by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Justice Richard Goldstone, the chief prosecutor for both tribunals, and John Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, discussed their fears about the fate of the tribunals. 
 The tribunals are prevented from spending the money to send investigators into the field, recruit lawyers and other personnel or renew contracts of current personnel as a result of restrictions on United Nations agencies imposed by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali last month in the face of a fiscal crisis.
If these restrictions continued, they "would shut down the Rwanda tribunal and render unconscious the Yugoslav tribunal," said Mr. Goldstone, a South African jurist.
As a result of the cuts, the Yugoslav tribunal will have to curtail its investigation into reports that Serbian forces killed up to 8,000 men after they seized the United Nations-designated "safe haven" of Srebrenica in July, and another report that Croatian forces committed war crimes when they invaded the Serbian-held region of Croatia in August.
So far, the Yugoslav tribunal has indicted 43 people, including Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, their military commander. More indictments are expected next week, said Mr. Goldstone.
"It is unacceptable, if not immoral," for these charges to have been made, and so publicly, if there will be no money for trials at which the accused have an opportunity to defend themselves, he said. He added that it would also be a violation of judicial fairness to take defendants into custody if a lack of resources will deny them a speedy trial.
"The criminal justice system cannot conduct itself if resources are turned on and off," said Mr. Goldstone.
Similar fears about the fate of the tribunals in light of the fiscal crunch were expressed by Mr. Shattuck.
"This is the moment of truth for the tribunals," said Mr. Shattuck. "They must not be stopped by a lack of funding."
Mr. Shattuck said that one reason the Clinton Administration put $3 million into separate funds for each tribunal was to insulate them from the vagaries of United Nations financing. But those funds have also been effectively frozen by the United Nations measures.
At the same time, however, a major reason that the United Nations is facing an economic crunch is because the United States is at least $1.2 billion in arrears in its dues to the organization.
Asked whether the current negotiations among the warring parties in the Balkans might result in some of the accused leaders being spared prosecution in exchange for signing a peace plan, Mr. Shattuck replied, "The war crimes tribunal is non-negotiable."
The first trial, concerning war crimes charges in the Balkans, is scheduled to begin in November, and there are no plans to postpone or cancel it because of the United Nations spending restrictions.
Fears about future financing of the tribunals come at a time when a major legal obstacle to the proceeding has been cleared. On Monday, the appeals chamber of the tribunal, which sits in The Hague, unanimously rejected an appeal from one of the Balkan defendants, thus upholding the tribunal's jurisdiction.
The appeals court described its decision as "an important and historic moment in development of international law," noting that it was the first time since the trials at Nuremberg and Tokyo after World War II that an international appellate court had ruled on the status of international criminal and humanitarian law.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Wall Street lands a new retail business, a men's-wear chain called Rochester Big and Tall

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
A SAN FRANCISCO-BASED men's-wear chain, Rochester Big and Tall, has signed a 20-year, $7 million lease for 15,000 square feet of retail space on two levels at 67 Wall Street.
The company is taking over a site, at the corner of Pearl Street, previously occupied by the Bank of Nova Scotia. "They could have located anywhere in Manhattan," said Faith H. Consolo, senior managing director of the Garrick-Aug store leasing brokerage, who negotiated the deal along with her associate, Ferne Glanzrock. "They could have chosen Madison Avenue, near Paul Stuart. But they chose Wall Street." 
 Bob Sockolov, chief executive of Rochester Big and Tall, said the financial district was "the logical place for us to be, because we have so many customers in the investment and banking businesses."
The company has 20 stores in major markets, including Chicago, Beverly Hills, Atlanta, Dallas, Boston, Washington and London. It also has another store in Manhattan, at 1301 Avenue of the Americas, at 52d Street.
"We've been successful on Sixth Avenue, and New York is a big enough city for us to have another store in another district," Mr. Sockolov said. "We're going where a lot of customers asked us to be. Not everybody comes up to midtown. We also get a lot of tourists, and a lot of tourists go to see Wall Street."
The deal is a little bit of good news for the Alliance for Downtown New York, the local business improvement district. The alliance, with the help of proposed tax abatements from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan, is hoping to turn the financial district and its surrounding area into a 24-hour village.
Under the plan, the area, which has never fully recovered from the late 1980's economic and real estate slump, would be revitalized by converting underused office buildings into residential space, spurring additional residential development and attracting more retail outlets.
Sixty-seven Wall, a 303,000-square-foot office building, dates to 1920, when it was built for the Munson Steamship Lines. The building's exterior is decorated with classical and nautical ornamental motifs in terra cotta, cast iron, copper and limestone. It is undergoing an exterior renovation to restore it essentially to the way it looked 75 years ago.
The work includes replacing the Spanish tile roof to match the 1920 design and replacing more than 2,000 pieces of damaged decorative terra cotta on the upper floors with precast concrete replicas of the original.
Rochester Big and Tall's customers include Rush Limbaugh, John Goodman, Luciano Pavarotti, George Foreman, Hakeem Olajuwon, Patrick Ewing and many members of the San Francisco 49ers.
 
A French Accent on Park
 For more than three years, the former site of the Banque Nationale de Paris, in the elegant I. M. Pei-designed building at 499 Park Avenue on the southeast corner of 59th Street, sat empty, its 26 windows darkened.
Jayne Sacks Rosenhaus, director of leasing for the landlord, Park Tower Realty, had said the landlord was looking for "an elegant retailer with high-end prices."
One has finally been found -- and it is a tenant that will allow the store to retain its French accent.
Bernardaud, a 132-year-old porcelain house from Limoges, France, is moving its Manhattan store early next year from 783 Madison Avenue, between 66th and 67th Streets, to the 3,200-square-foot site, which has 135 feet of street frontage and the 26 windows on both Park and 59th.
Stuart S. Ellman and Helene Wall of Judson Realty were the agents for Bernardaud, whose porcelains are sold in specialty stores but which has only one other boutique, on the Rue Royale in Paris. The lease is for 15 years. Michel Bernardaud, head of the company, said the main reason for choosing 499 Park was the space, which is three times larger than the current site, "so we can display our products the way we want to."
Then there's the location. "There is a lot of consumer traffic between Bloomingdale's and all the stores that have opened on Madison Avenue around 59th Street," he said.
And there are the windows. "The 26 windows are a bonus," he said. "We're going to have a lot of work to do in terms of display."
 
666 Fifth Leases
 The National Tourist Office of Spain and three textile companies have leased a total of nearly 28,000 square feet of office space at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street.
The tourist office, relocating from retail space across the street at 665 Fifth Avenue, took 8,000 square feet on the 35th floor. Windsor Textile signed up for 4,000 square feet; 18 International Ltd., for 10,000 square feet, and Cleyn & Tinker Inc., for 5,600 square feet. All three are moving from 1290 Avenue of the Americas. The four leases total about $11 million, said Arthur L. Bocchi, vice president and director of leasing for Sumitomo Realty and Development, owner of the building.

HEADLINE: Chrysler's Chief Strongly Attacks Kerkorian

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
In a strong personal attack, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation denounced Kirk Kerkorian yesterday as an uninformed troublemaker whose pursuit of profit was harming other stockholders.
The unusually strong criticism by Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of the No. 3 auto maker, was the first time that he had formally -- and publicly -- attacked Mr. Kerkorian by name as well as the motives and impact of his long-running attempt to assert greater control over the direction of the company. 
 Mr. Kerkorian's battle with Chrysler was joined last spring when he started a takeover attempt that failed for lack of financing. He has since increased his Chrysler stake to nearly 15 percent of the shares outstanding, and has indicated he may pursue a proxy fight for representation on the board of directors.
In a speech yesterday to a group of institutional investors in New York, Mr. Eaton likened Jerome B. York, Mr. Kerkorian's newly hired chief lieutenant to a hired gun who is harassing Chrysler through the news media by passing false information. Mr. York left as Chrysler's chief financial officer in 1993, jumped to I.B.M. and signed on with Mr. Kerkorian last month.
"We know that Kerkorian has no real knowledge about these issues and no real basis for complaint," Mr. Eaton said. "His objective is personal gain, no matter how it is dressed up or who he has out front."
While he offered no details, Mr. Eaton accused Mr. Kerkorian of trying to "drive a wedge" between him and Robert Lutz, Chrysler's president. And he also implied that Mr. Kerkorian's threat of a proxy fight was merely an effort to create "fractional constituencies" on the board that would represent his interests at the expense of other shareholders.
Mr. Eaton's attacks touched not only Mr. York but also other senior advisers to Mr. Kerkorian, including Lee A. Iacocca, the former Chrysler chairman, and Bruce Wasserstein, the investment banker whose firm has been hired by Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation to advise on its investment in Chrysler. He labeled the men the "Kerkorian, Iacocca, York and Wasserstein team."
The focus of his criticism centered on what Mr. Eaton called the Kerkorian camp's "directed attack" against the company, its management and its products, which he said had cost Chrysler investors.
"You cannot trash a company without hurting its shareholders," he said. "We don't know how many car and truck sales we may have lost from this negative campaign already. And the mudslinging has just started."
Mr. Eaton added, "This doesn't generate shareholder value; it destroys it."
In a statement, Mr. York disputed the assertion that the actions of Tracinda had harmed any shareholders. "Our long-term objective is to enhance value for all Chrysler's shareholders -- and our actions to date have helped increase the value of Chrysler's over 380 million shares by billions of dollars."
At times, Mr. Eaton's attack accused his adversary of seeking benefits that Mr. Kerkorian has denied wanting. For example, Mr. Eaton said that Chrysler would not pay Mr. Kerkorian a premium for his stock through so-called greenmail or approve any deals that benefited Mr. Kerkorian at the expense of other investors.
Through his aides, Mr. Kerkorian has said he will never accept either proposal. In the statement yesterday, Mr. York reiterated that position, saying, "Tracinda has repeatedly stated that its shares are not for sale and that we will not accept any benefit that is not equally available to all shareholders."
Mr. Eaton's speech was delivered to the Council of Institutional Investors, a group of pension funds that collectively own more than 25 percent of Chrysler's stock. Their support could well prove to be critical in Chrysler's battle against Mr. Kerkorian.
After Mr. Eaton concluded his presentation, some of the institutional fund managers took to the microphone to pronounce their support for Chrysler and its management team.
Speaking to reporters after his speech, Mr. Eaton was asked why his tone against Mr. Kerkorian had become so hostile. "We have to start speaking out a little bit," he said. "It's hurting the company. It's hurting the shareholders. We have to continue to defend ourselves."
At the heart of the dispute between Chrysler and Mr. Kerkorian is a huge cash kitty that the company has built up in a healthy auto sales market. The cash, which Chrysler hopes to build to $7.5 billion, is intended to help the company continue to invest in new products and equipment and meet its obligations during the next economic downturn.
But Mr. Kerkorian and his aides contend that Chrysler is being "ulta-conservative" in its calculation of how much cash the company would need in a downturn. Instead, the Kerkorian camp has said that the company should turn some of that cash over to shareholders.
"When you live in a monsoon climate like the auto industry, you don't just put a little cash away on the off-chance that someday it might rain," Mr. Eaton said. "It will rain. You plan for it or you drown."
Mr. Eaton added: "Managing a company always involves compromises between the short term and the long term. We are fortunate at Chrysler because the company has never been in a better position to handle both."

Eaton, chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, answering questions after his speech in New York yesterday, in which he assailed Kirk Kerkorian, the auto maker's largest shareholder, for his attempt to gain greater control over the company. "His objective is personal gain, no matter how it is dressed up," Mr. Eaton said of Mr. Kerkorian. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Erosion in Japan's Foundation

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: KITAMOTO, Japan

 BODY:
In a land where house rents can reach $25,000 a month, perhaps the biggest surprise is not how expensive real estate is, but how far prices have fallen.
Real estate values in general have plummeted in Japan by two-thirds to three-fourths from their peak five years ago, making sorry tales of the property slump in most of America seem almost sweet by comparison. And the collapse here is threatening the financial system of the world's second-biggest economy after the United States. 
 Fortunes are being lost, companies are going bankrupt, homeowners are suffering from diminishing wealth, and the nation's banks, saddled with at least $500 billion in ailing real estate loans, are reluctant to lend a helping hand. Yet Tokyo is still one of the world's most expensive real estate markets. One Japanese Government study found some residential land in Tokyo still selling for 30 times as much as land in New York.
The story of Japan's boom-to-bust property market is particularly sobering for Japan's nervous Asian neighbors, like Hong Kong, India, Singapore, China, Taiwan and South Korea, where go-go growth has sent property prices spinning out of control. A Japanese Government study shows that the world's seven most expensive cities for commercial land values are in Asia.
Some analysts fear that Japan's real estate woes could decimate the nation's banking industry, sending destructive ripples through the global economy. Just this week, Japanese officials said seven giant housing-loan concerns, together saddled with $63 billion in losses, would be closed.
To be sure, the real estate deflation is good news to some people. It has made housing more affordable for Japanese consumers. And it has created a golden opportunity for American businesses. Previously, astronomical real estate costs ranked with Japanese protectionism as a major impediment to foreign penetration of the Japanese market. With prices falling, it is much easier for American companies, from retailers to auto makers, to expand their presences here.
But for the economy as a whole, the real estate crash has been a disaster. And in one of its most striking manifestations, ghost towns are emerging in commercial and residential districts.
Even in Tokyo, a city where crowds swell so thickly that rush-hour pedestrian traffic moves like molasses and professional pushers pack commuters onto trains, empty office buildings and darkened windows are becoming a common sight. And while would-be homeowners salivate at lower housing prices, they also remain jittery at paying prices that remain exorbitant by the standards of most countries, and that still have plenty of room to tumble.
Yoshikazu Itobashi, a computer engineer, knows plenty about ghost towns. Not only does he live in one, he works in one.
Ten months after Mr. Itobashi paid $330,000 for an apartment in an isolated new housing development in the Tokyo suburb of Kitamoto, the tower is only 20 percent occupied, and his children do not have to fight for the swings in the playground, because they have not materialized.
And Mr. Itobashi's new offices, nearly two hours by train from his home, make New York City's troubled Rockefeller Center look like a money machine. The development, called Tennozu Isle, is led by the Mitsubishi Corporation, the umbrella company for the Mitsubishi Estate Company, which is pulling out of Rockefeller Center.
A few years ago, Tennozu Isle was billed as Japan's biggest commercial community, with parks, shopping malls and office towers near a waterfront. Now, elevators glide past empty floors in some of the 11 office buildings, stores are going out of business and the complex has the feel of an isolated outpost, its workday population linked to the city only by a single, congested monorail.
"I usually can't get a seat on the train from Kitamoto," Mr. Itobashi said. "If the apartment wasn't so nice, I would be in real trouble."
A brief economic rebound last year led by housing activity buoyed hopes briefly before fizzling out. And the continuing fall in property prices has fueled a startling round of deflation for a wide range of goods and services. While lower prices might cheer consumers, they hurt producers, and some financial experts worry that a deflationary spiral could ultimately lead to a shrinking economy.
Without a recovery in the real estate market, which helped power Japan's phenomenal growth in the 1980's, the economy will probably not rebound strongly, analysts say. Although the economy grew modestly in the second quarter of this year, analysts doubt that the rate can be sustained.
"There is no simple answer to all this, and people are looking for simple answers," said David Atkinson, a financial analyst who once followed the real estate industry at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd. "Much of the problems are structural."
The bubble has burst with all the impact of America's savings and loan crisis of the 1980's. Thousands of businesses are saddled with debt on property that is worth a fraction of the purchase price, crimping their ability to borrow and grow. One financial company that purchased a tract of prime land at the peak for about $430 million sold it recently for about $60 million, or one-seventh the original price, according to a real estate executive who insisted on anonymity.
That the transaction went through at all was an encouraging sign, for commercial activity has been scarce, partly because of high property taxes and other regulations. The authorities hoped that historically low interest rates -- the discount rate is now 0.5 percent, compared with 5.25 percent in the United States -- would entice people to borrow and buy real estate, but that has not happened.
Instead, vacancy rates in office space in Tokyo are running at about 10 percent, and property values continue to fall. In the last year, prices for commercial land in Tokyo have declined nearly 20 percent.
A decade ago, no one in Japan could have imagined a property bust of this severity. The Japanese had always believed that investment in land was safe, even in hard times. So, when interest rates slid and credit became easy in the mid-1980's, millions of individuals and thousands of companies raced to buy houses and buildings, driving up land prices to unheard-of heights.
When prices peaked five years ago, the real estate in Tokyo alone was worth three times more on paper than all of the land and buildings in America, according to estimates by the Japan Real Estate Institute. Other comparisons pegged the dollar value of the Imperial Palace, where the Japanese Emperor lives, as greater than the worth of all of California.
In 1989, the Bank of Japan began raising interest rates and tightening credit, which led to the bursting of the speculative bubble. Since then, property magnates and ordinary homeowners have watched in growing horror as their net worth has tanked.
"The decline of prices is going to be a catharsis for a new order," said Osamu Aoi, a director at the Eiwa Real Estate Company. "Real estate properties priced themselves out of the market."
The result is that some new buildings have been boarded up for years because of battles over ownership and mortgage payments, while elsewhere, "work-in-progress" signs adorn idled construction sites. Buildings that used to hum with activity now stand empty, their dark windows retreating into the night.
"Buildings are like human bodies, so that if you stay in bed, your muscles get flabby and won't function as well," said Katsuhiro Tairodate, a manager at the Japan Real Estate Institute. "If the windows are kept shut and there is no air flowing in and out, the place may start rotting and fungus may grow."
Prices remain excruciatingly high. Commercial rents in Tokyo are still three times higher than in New York. And families living in central Tokyo pay an average of 13 times their annual income for a home, compared with about three times household income for their counterparts in New York, according to a Japanese Government study.
Rents are sky-high as well, and with the rise in the value of the yen over the last decade, which has made apartments more expensive in dollar terms, a lavish four-bedroom house can still cost a rich foreigner about $25,000 a month in an expensive area of Tokyo. More typically, though, a one-bedroom apartment in central Tokyo can cost $2,000 to $4,000 a month, down from more than $6,000 at the peak, and a four-bedroom suburban-style home can run $6,000 to $7,000, down from $10,000.
Commercial rents have fallen by more than 40 percent in prime Tokyo locations, and in some cases by 60 percent or more. A 6,000-square-foot office floor can cost $820,000 in annual rent, down from $2.3 million.
To get tenants, some real-estate companies are apparently turning to bare-knuckles tactics. Mitsubishi strong-armed its affiliate companies to move into its Tennozu complex, suggesting it would send business their way, people in the real estate industry said. Mitsubishi declined to comment.
Mr. Itobashi, the commuter between ghost towns, said he felt a bit cheated by his real estate company, which, he said, told him and his new neighbors that the apartments were selling like hotcakes and might be gone if he did not grab one.
"When the economy goes down, real estate companies use these methods," said Masahiro Imaizumi, who runs the Recruit Corporation, which analyzes residential real estate. "We're in a time when there is an oversupply in the market and consumers know that, so they may be pressured into signing contracts. But the shrewd customer can see through these techniques."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rubin Says World Economy Is in a Pause

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3

 BODY:
The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said today that the world economy was in "a pause," but forecast stronger global growth next year and reaffirmed the Clinton Administration's commitment to a stronger dollar.
On the eve of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Mr. Rubin also said there had been progress toward constructing a new "financial safety net" to prevent future Mexican-style financial disasters. 
 But in a luncheon meeting with reporters, he refused to comment on the outlook for the dollar and other currencies despite today's rally by the dollar. On speculation that the United States and its allies may agree during the World Bank and I.M.F. meetings -- which begin Wednesday -- to act to bolster the value of the American currency, the dollar jumped against the German mark and Japanese yen, closing today in New York at 1.4385 marks and 101.41 yen.
Acknowledging the world economic pause, the Treasury Secretary cited economists' forecast of a return to "solid growth" next year of around 2.4 percent in Europe, North America and Japan combined. "There has been a pause but it's getting better," he said.
Mr. Rubin said it was in all countries' interest to cooperate with the proposed new financial safety net if they wanted to escape the risk of a catastrophic Mexican-style currency outflow and maintain access to capital markets.
This means agreeing to timely disclosure of important financial information to the market and accepting tighter I.M.F. surveillance of their economic policies, he said.
Richer countries with an interest in stable markets, he continued, should subscribe to the proposed $50 billion emergency fund that the I.M.F. will use to bail out emerging economies in difficulties. Mr. Rubin predicted the new fund would be in place sometime next year.
While currency traders are waiting to see whether the United States and its allies make make another call Saturday for a stronger dollar and follow it with central bank intervention in the currency markets, the World Bank is pursuing its campaign to encourage private investment in developing countries.
Since taking over six months ago, James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank's new chief, has been urging the institution to reduce its penchant for building dams and other mega-projects and become a catalyst for promoting private investment.
As aid diminishes, he sees private investment as the best hope for poorer nations. And he is concerned that while private lending has soared in recent years, it may now be turning down.
So at its annual meeting, which runs for nine days, Mr. Wolfensohn is inviting the thousands of bankers and private business executives who attend to a program of seminars and lectures explaining why it is to their advantage to invest in developing countries
Finance ministers from seven developing countries where the World Bank thinks opportunities are particularly attractive -- Botswana, Kazakhstan, Morocco, Bangldesh, Peru, Moldova and the Philippines -- will also meet with them and explain what they have to offer.
Mr. Wolfensohn is also mending fences with the World Bank's critics. A year ago an angry coalition of environmental activists, convinced the World Bank's development projects did more harm than good, disrupted its 50th birthday celebrations with cries of "50 years is enough."
Mr. Wolfensohn, who recently canceled a $1 billion dam in Nepal, will try to convince these critics that the World Bank is becoming more responsible: there will be three days of discussion at the meetings on making development environmentally sustainable. Vice President Al Gore, a strong environmentalist, will address the conference.
The World Bank is courting investment for poor countries at a time when governments around the world are seizing any excuse to cut development assistance, and when a wave of foreign investment in just a few developing countries is propelling them into the industrial era.
In Washington, Congress appears to be ready to make a big cut in the Clinton Administration's request of $1.3 billion for the International Development Association, the World Bank arm that helps basket-case economies with injections of nearly free money.
After peaking at $61.9 billion in 1991, worldwide official development aid slumped to $54.5 billion last year. Over the same period, private capital flows to the developing world soared to $172.9 billion from $62.9 billion, according to the World Bank's calculations.
But private capital, too, seems set to diminish without new stimulus. The Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based association of more than 190 financial institutions, predicts a $40 billion decline this year, to around $ $130 billion.
These flows remain highly concentrated, with a dozen mainly Asian nations receiving 80 percent of the total and with Africa getting barely 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Plans to Fly Blind on the Economy

 BODY:
The Republicans' budget plans in Congress will severely limit the collection of data vital to tracking what the economy is doing, and will weaken agencies like the Securities and Exchange Commission that enforce rules of economic fair play.
The consequences could be damaging. Capital markets in the United States are the envy of the world because investors, big and small, feel confident that they can buy and sell stocks, bonds and other securities at a fair price. That confidence flows directly from tight supervision over brokers and dealers by the S.E.C. 
 Under its current chairman, Arthur Levitt, oversight has been exercised with a light touch. Mr. Levitt has stripped away needless rules governing how corporations raise money from the public and, where possible, has sought voluntary agreements rather than imposing edicts. Where Mr. Levitt has exercised regulatory powers has been on behalf of small investors, requiring that dealers offer them the best price available in the market. Mr. Levitt's reward for this: The Senate is now debating whether to cut his budget by between 10 and 20 percent.
The Republicans are also going after data collection and information-gathering. The theory seems to be that if the Government does not know what it is doing it will be tempted to meddle less with private industry.
Thus, at a time when the Bureau of Labor Statistics is designing an expensive fix of the Consumer Price Index, which controls the inflation adjustment to Federal spending and tax revenues, the G.O.P. is debating whether to cut its budget by 10 percent. At a time when the Census Bureau is preparing for the next census and designing procedures to correct the undercount of minorities, the Republicans propose whacking millions of dollars out of its budget. At a time when everything Congress does depends on an accurate picture of the economy, the G.O.P. proposes cutting the Bureau of Economic Analysis.
Flying blind, Congress might, as the G.O.P. hopes, meddle less. More likely it will still meddle, only less wisely.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Higher as Traders Await Meeting of the Group of 7

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday as traders sought to protect themselves ahead of a meeting of industrial powers that could lead to a move to bolster the dollar.
The dollar's rise was helped by comments from a Portuguese central banker. 
 The governor of the Bank of Portugal, Antonio de Sousa, said yesterday that there was a strong chance that concerted intervention on behalf of the dollar could follow this weekend's meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven nations in Washington.
"People were woken up by that statement and remembered that the usual trading strategy ahead of the G-7 meeting is squaring positions or buying" dollars, said Callum Henderson, a senior analyst at MMS International.
In April, officials of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- announced their support of the dollar and said they would take appropriate actions to defend it. The dollar then had tumbled to its lowest levels since World War II against the Japanese yen and the German mark.
Since then, the Group of Seven nations, and in particular Germany, the United States and Japan, have worked to bolster the dollar by buying the currency.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 101.41 Japanese yen from 100.35 yen on Monday. The dollar rose to 1.4385 marks from 1.4277 marks and to 1.1584 Swiss francs from 1.1504 Swiss francs. The British pound fell to $1.5838 from $1.5901.
Trading was thin yesterday, with markets in Germany closed for a national holiday commemorating the nation's unification. With German dealers absent to defend the mark, the German currency lost ground against other European currencies and that also weakened the mark against the dollar.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar surged to a 20-month high of 75.34 United States cents after polls indicated that voters in Quebec would reject secession from Canada in an Oct. 30 referendum. Earlier polls had shown voters divided over secession.
In New York trading, the Canadian dollar settled at 75.26 United States cents, up from 74.73 on Monday. The Canadian dollar has risen 2.2 percent in the last two weeks.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The French Ostrich

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A few weeks ago I attended question hour at the Australian Parliament, a raucous weekly event when the opposition questions the Prime Minister, Paul Keating. Mr. Keating was asked about France's claims that it was entitled to test its nuclear weapons in Polynesia because these colonies were actually part of France. His voice dripping with contempt, Mr. Keating said: "Oh, yes. There are Polynesians all the way down from Aix-en-Provence. They pop out of the woodwork. They are doing Polynesian dances in the back end of the Loire Valley, in the walled city of Carcassone, in the lovely humidity of Aix-en-Provence. There are Polynesians everywhere."
As Mr. Keating was doing this little hula, the Australian lawmakers were falling out of their seats with laughter. They were laughing at France -- and with good reason. President Jacques Chirac's arrogant decision to defy the world and go ahead with two nuclear bomb tests in Polynesia deserves contempt. It is a sign of a country whose leadership is seriously out of touch with the main currents of the post-cold-war world. President Chirac is known as "Le Bulldozer" for the way he plows ahead, undeterred by critics. "L'ostrich" would be more appropriate. 
 It isn't just Greenpeace and a few environmental radicals eating seaweed and wearing sandals who are protesting France's explosions at the Mururoa and Fangataufa atolls. Japan and Sweden each sent ministers to Tahiti to express their opposition, Australia and New Zealand boycotted French products, while 9 out of the 12 members of the European Union spoke out against the tests. What Mr. Chirac has totally missed is that the anti-nuclear movement has gone Main Street. The nuclear debate is no longer between leaders who want to test and environmentalists who don't. Now the debate is between nations that are thinking environmentally and those, like France, that are not.
During the cold war the fear of being obliterated by the Soviet Union overrode the fear of testing nuclear weapgger threat is the bomb itself. The world isn't afraid of Chernomyrdin, the Russian Prime Minister, it's afraid of Chernobyl, the Russian meltdown. The bomb was designed to prevent another Pearl Harbor, but what people are really worried about is another Three Mile Island. As the French writer Dominique Moisi puts it: "Now that the threat against which we need nuclear weapons is no longer clear, all that is clear is the threat of the nuclear weapons themselves -- to the environment and to the human race."
The reason Mr. Chirac doesn't understand this is because he is a Gaullist politician who, like any good Gaullist, has a vision that is dominated by the exalted role it seeks for France on the world stage. Pursuing the grandeur of France is his obsession -- an obsession that is becoming increasingly unsustainable.
Consider the following: France has been a leader in the effort to form a united Europe with a single currency. A united Europe, led by France, appeals to Mr. Chirac because it would enhance France's global stature and help keep Germany under control. But to have a united Europe and a single European currency, France needs to get its budget deficit down from 6 percent of G.D.P. to 2.5 percent, where the Germans have it. The Germans said there can be no common currency without a common fiscal policy.
But when France's Finance Minister, Alain Madelin, tried to cut the budget, slim down France's bloated welfare state (the most bloated in Europe) and reform the Government to make France more competitive for the 21st century, the French public and labor unions howled -- because it meant trimming benefits to workers, businessmen and civil servants. Mr. Madelin got fired. It was the French public saying that nuclear grandeur is fine as long as the Polynesians are the ones who pay, but an exalted role for France in Europe is not fine if we have to pay. (That's why there is never going to be any European monetary union. Forget it. Buy German marks. They're all you'll ever need.)
Mr. Chirac wants grandeur on the cheap, but there's no such thing. And that's why Gaullism is dead. The world won't sacrifice for Mr. Chirac's nuclear ambitions and his people won't sacrifice for his European ambitions. If Mr. Chirac doesn't grasp that soon they won't be laughing at him just in Australia.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: You Can't Starve the U.N. Into Reforming Itself

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Reform of the U.N. Is Overdue" (editorial, Sept. 28): You give the impression that all that is required for United Nations reform is decisive measures by the Secretariat, but it is not that simple. Effective reform cannot take place without concerted action by member states, and that is hard to achieve. 
 I was co-author of a comprehensive proposal for the reform of the United Nations Development System in 1969 -- the Capacity Study led by Sir Robert Jackson. By the time governments reviewed and authorized its application, so many compromises had been introduced that the internal logic of the scheme was fatally watered down.
 In 1986-87 I was given the role of coordinating implementation of the reform proposals of the Group of 18, endorsed by the General Assembly. These were less logical, but even so, when we tried to put them into effect, some of the very governments that had urged reform raised objections.
Moreover, even though the reforms in the budget process demanded by the United States were effected, this did not result in prompter payment of United States assessed contributions.
At a Ditchley Foundation conference in March this year, senior representatives of the United States and European countries responsible for United Nations affairs agreed that reform was essential, but in two days of intensive debate were unable to agree on what should be done.
The only way forward is by taking some individual measures that will have a multiplier effect, such as restricting the tenure of all executive heads of United Nations institutions and agencies, including the Secretary General, to one (possibly longer) period; introducing arrangements that will insure their election on a rational and merit basis, rather than through the horse-trading process that prevails at present; and developing a consolidated budget for the United Nations system that would resolve many of the problems of coordination and duplication on which much money is vainly spent.
As to "how," withholding contributions is no way to bring about change. In the present acute financial crisis caused by member states not paying their assessed dues, chief among them the United States, harassed senior United Nations officials who might otherwise concentrate on improved management and reform must instead wrestle every day with the problem of how to meet the bills and juggling funds from one pocket to another.
 
MARGARET ANSTEE
London, Sept. 30, 1995
 
The writer was United Nations Under Secretary General, 1987-93.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Seizing the Moment To Reach for the Vine

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

DATELINE: MARGAUX, France

 BODY:
DAVID FINLAYSON stood in the doorway of the immense vat room at Chateau Margaux one day in mid-September looking out at the rain that would fall intermittently over most of the Medoc, the wine area north of the city of Bordeaux, during the two weeks or so it would take to harvest the grapes.
Not a lot of rain to be sure, but enough to turn what might have been a spectacular vintage into one the experts were calling, guardedly, very good but not outstanding. 
 Mr. Finlayson, 23, was getting his first taste of Bordeaux's notoriously uncooperative fall weather. The son and nephew of South African wine makers, he was spending a privileged month at Chateau Margaux, one of the region's most famous properties, on an apprenticeship that began in August.
"I've learned more in a few weeks here than I had in the previous 10 years," Mr. Finlayson said, forgetting that 10 years earlier he was 13.
A few months hence, with the 1995 Margaux safely stored for its two years of barrel aging, Mr. Finlayson will be back at work in his father's winery, Glencarlou, in Stellenbosch, in the South African summer.
"I'm going to California next year," he said. "If I ever make my own wine, something of Margaux will be in it."
While Mr. Finlayson was asked to work in the cellar, some 200 people in Bordeaux, mostly students, got letters from Chateau Margaux on Sept. 15, inviting them to help in the harvest. They would pick grapes under the hot sun -- or in the rain -- for about $8 an hour, plus breakfast, lunch and transportation to and from Bordeaux. For his work, Mr. Finlayson got only room and board.
"If you want to work," the letter said in effect, "show up tomorrow." Few failed to.
"It says something about the economy," said Paul Pontallier, the manager of the chateau. "Or perhaps something about Margaux."
Margaux is one of the five first growths -- the others are Chateaux Haut-Brion, Lafite-Rothschild, Latour and Mouton-Rothschild -- that sit at the very pinnacle of prestige among Bordeaux's more than 3,000 wine producers. Margaux is the only famous chateau to bear the name of the town where it is situated.
Grape picking in the Bordeaux region has become a sought-after job. "Ten years ago, the chateaus were desperate for pickers," Mr. Pontallier said. Now, there is a waiting list of people who want to pick, perhaps because there are fewer jobs: more than 50 percent of all the grapes in Bordeaux are now brought in by mechanical harvester.
Picking at Chateau Margaux began on Sept. 16, a Saturday. Spirits were high. It had been a spectacular summer for grapes in Bordeaux, hot and dry. If the rain held off, it could be a very fine year, even spectacular. Bordeaux was ready for a great vintage; its last great was in 1990.
The decision to pick on the 16th was made on the night of the 13th, and the letters were dispatched on the 14th. But the decision to begin was not lightly made.
"Deciding on the harvest date is a long process," Mr. Pontallier said. "We start at the time of the flowering of the vines, which in 1995 was on June 1. On average, the harvest starts 110 days later. Two weeks before the 110 days are up, we begin sampling the berries. We test for sugar and acid content, but mostly we taste. And when we think the time is ripe, we go."
In fact, the harvest at Chateau Margaux, or a small part of it, begins earlier. Alone among the first-growth chateaus, Margaux makes a rare and expensive white wine called Pavillon Blanc. Its sauvignon blanc grapes mature before the merlot, cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc and petit verdot that go into the chateau's even more famous red.
Pavillon Blanc grapes are harvested by a team of Margaux employees and people from villages in the Margaux area, many of whom have picked for the chateau for generations. This team also works the red grape harvest, bringing the number of pickers in 1995 to about 170.
After working through Saturday the 16th, the pickers were told to take Sunday off and be back on Monday. Many of the merlot grapes needed to mature a bit more. The pickers, divided into four teams, worked Monday and Tuesday. Then the rains came. No grapes were picked on Wednesday or Thursday, the 20th and 21st, but by then all the merlot had been harvested, most of it in very fine condition.
On Friday and Saturday, the teams were out again, moving into the cabernet sauvignon and cabernet franc plots. After a Sunday off, they worked three days before the rain returned. Friday the 29th dawned warm and sunny, and the good weather held through Oct. 2, when the few remaining plots were picked.
The pickers then left, but the fermentation vats were full and the serious work of making one of the world's most-sought-after wines was beginning.
By law, Margaux may make as much as 5,700 liters of wine, or about 1,500 gallons, from every hectare of grapes. (A hectare is about two and a half acres.) The chateau makes 4,800 liters per hectare on average, and only 3,500 to 4,000 for the best plots. Grapes from the various vineyard plots, from the greatest to the least, are fermented separately. Almost from the time the grapes are picked, Mr. Pontallier and his team have some idea of which vats will go into the first wine, Chateau Margaux, and which into the second wine, Pavillon Rouge. But nothing is certain.
"We taste," he said. "We taste, we taste, we taste."
The new wine will go into 225-gallon barrels in October or early November. When the final selection and blending are done early in 1996, the cut will be severe. As much as 50 percent of each vintage goes into Pavillon Rouge. Under previous owners, only about 15 percent was held out for the second wine.
The 1995 harvest produced 1,600 barrels of wine, which translates to 435,000 bottles, or 40,000 cases. "Because we haven't made our final selection, we don't know how much will go into the first wine, and how much into the second," Mr. Pontallier said, "but it will be around 20,000 cases of each."
In 1977, Andre Mentzelopoulos, a Paris financier born in Greece, bought Chateau Margaux from an old Bordeaux wine family, the Ginestets, for $15 million and began a program of renovation still under way. He died in 1980, and ownership passed to his wife and daughter and then to an Agnelli family trust called the Exor Group. Corinne Mentzelopoulos, Andre's daughter, is on the Exor board and is managing partner of Chateau Margaux.
The Margaux pickers' party, the gerbaude, which celebrates the end of the harvest with food, wine and song, was held on Oct. 3. "The name predates French," Mr. Pontallier said. "It goes back to a time when people were happy that the harvest, which meant their food -- not just wine -- was safely stored for the winter months ahead."
 
TASTINGS
Chateau St.-Georges 1990, St.-Georges-St.-Emilion. About $15.
 
This big property in the satellite appellation of St.-Georges-St.-Emilion would almost certainly be rated as a classified growth if it were in St.-Emilion proper. Classified or not, the wine is immensely popular in France and Belgium, where it is sold mostly by mail order. The chateau itself is one of the glories of the St.-Emilion region and one of the most imposing chateaus in Bordeaux. The wine, usually about 50 percent merlot and 30 percent cabernet sauvignon, is elegant and intense, and in this vintage it displays the structure that should enable it to enjoy a long life. Because of the lesser appellation, St.-Georges is invariably underpriced.

HEADLINE: '95 PLAYOFFS;
A.L.'s Angry Man May Be Its M.V.P.

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
The man in the batter's box in Jacobs Field took a swing at the baseball with an economy of motion and a power of execution that was nearly startling. The ball rocketed over the left-field fence virtually before the outfielder had a chance to blink, let alone take a step. This was Albert Belle, the sometime enfant terrible, whacking his 50th home run of the season, his 17th of September, tying Babe Ruth's record for the month, and his 31st in the last two months, also a major league record.
Albert Belle, at 6 feet 2 inches, 210 pounds, hits the way Joe Louis punched. His short, swift stroke is like a blow that starts at the shoulder and ends by flattening the object of choice. 
 When Belle hit No. 50 on Saturday -- becoming the 12th player in history to do so -- the sellout crowd of 41,578 stood and cheered as he rounded the bases with the solo, game-tying shot, chanting, "M-V-P! M-V-P!" accompanied by a tintinnabulation of cowbells.
His teammates piled out of the dugout to congratulate and pummel him, and not necessarily in that order. The fans, sublimely unconcerned with Belle's reputation for a hot temper and a coldness to the news media, continued their show of appreciation for so long that he was forced to take two curtain calls and Manny Ramirez, the next batter, had to step out of the box several times before the fans got under control.
The Indians went on to win by 3-2, nothing special since they had the best record in baseball, ending the strike-abbreviated 144-game season with 100 victories, 56 games over .500 and 30 games ahead of their nearest Central Division rival, Kansas City.
And while this is a team brimming with talent, Belle, pardon the expression, is the bellwether.
"Anybody who doesn't vote for Albert has his own agenda," said the Indians' manager, Mike Hargrove, when asked about the league's most valuable player candidates. Belle, the Indians' left fielder, and Mo Vaughn, Boston's first baseman, are the two leading candidates for the award -- Frank Thomas is also in contention, but his White Sox, unlike Cleveland and Boston, are not. Belle, meanwhile, has hit more home runs than Vaughn (50-39) has a higher batting average (.317 to .300) and tied him for the league lead in runs batted in with 126.
And the two began competing on the same field last night when the Red Sox met Cleveland here in the first game of their American League playoff series.
Hargrove's comment about those with their "own agenda" was a less-than-veiled reference to the news media, from which voters for the m.v.p. award are drawn.
About his chances, Belle said in a formal interview Saturday, "It will be tough." And then, with a touch of irony, he added, "I'm not really considered a media darling."
Belle, who is 29, is noted for being abrupt and abusive to reporters and others. When he was a star at Louisiana State University he was suspended from the team for temper outbursts. When he was called up to the Indians in 1990, he played only nine games before going into rehabilitation for an alcohol-abuse problem for the rest of the season.
In 1991, he started the season with the Indians, but was sent down to the minors for 16 games because of what the club called an attitude problem, which included an inclination to not run out batted balls. He also was famous for tearing up the dugout, the clubhouse and fixtures such as toilets and sinks when miffed at something or someone, including himself for, say, striking out.
He was suspended by the league four times, twice for charging the mound when hit by a pitch, once for throwing a baseball as hard as he could into the chest of a fan who, he said, was peppering him with racial epithets, and once for having a corked bat, though he contended that someone had "messed" with his bats without his knowledge.
"In the last few years, Albert and I have had a number of soul-searching talks," said John Hart, the Indians' general manager. "And Albert has matured." When asked for an example, Hart noted that Belle hasn't thrown a ball at a fan in several years.
What is unquestioned about Belle is his ability to hit a baseball, and his work ethic in this area. The Indians must be satisfied that they are getting their money's worth from him, which is $4.2 million this year, with an option of $5 million on his services for next season.
Belle always seems to be at the batting cage on the field or at the one under the stands, or watching videotapes of his hitting or of pitchers he will face, or going over the copious notes he takes on the pitchers, and what they threw him.
"I've never seen anyone work so hard on hitting," said Belle's friend and teammate, the All-Star second baseman Carlos Baerga, "except maybe Tony Gwynn. He even hits into a net behind the dugout during innings. I call him 'The Animal' because I tell him he's not human. I said to him, 'You have to take a day off.' He said, 'No, no, I have to keep working. If you want to be a good hitter you have to work hard.' "
Although friends like Baerga and center fielder Kenny Lofton find Belle a good, chatty and humorous companion, he still has his periodic tantrums around the baseball field, which confuses them. "Nobody understands why he gets so mad," Baerga said.
Also confused are most of the pitchers who face Belle, the would-be m.v.p. They have not figured out how to keep his bat under control.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Rockefeller Center Trust Delays Deal with Zell Group
Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that is scheduled to take ownership of Rockefeller Center, delayed its deal with an investor group led by Sam Zell, the Chicago financier, while it considered two other offers made in the last week.
The trust said it would not exercise its option to require the Zell group to buy a 9.7 percent stake for $10 million. The decision signals an effort to mend fences with shareholders and creditors. Market Place. [Page D6.]
 
British Air to Evaluate Alliances
British Airways said it was evaluating its alliances in North America after the announcement by the USAir Group that it was involved in talks with the parent companies of American and United Airlines on a possible takeover. British Airways owns 24.6 percent of USAir and depends on the carrier to feed passengers to its trans-Atlantic routes. Some analysts said British Airways would begin talks with other domestic carriers. [D4.]

Acquittals in Growth Hormone Case
A Minneapolis judge acquitted a Genentech sales manager and three Caremark International employees accused of paying kickbacks to a doctor for prescribing a synthetic human growth hormone. [D6.]
 
Amended Offer for Publisher
The Western Publishing Group said that Richard E. Snyder and Warburg Pincus Ventures had renegotiated their offer to buy nearly a one-third interest in Western. The amended offer appears to be for less money than the deal that was originally announced early last month. [D2.]
 
U.S. Moves on Russian Oil Deals
The Clinton Administration, citing protection of American interests, has sought to counter Russian influence in the Caspian Sea oil region by fighting two projects that are being promoted by Moscow. [D2.]
 
Rubin Predicts Global Growth
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the world economy was in "a pause," but forecast global growth of about 2.6 percent next year and reaffirmed the Clinton Administration's commitment to a stronger dollar. On the eve of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, Mr. Rubin also said there had been progress toward constructing a new "financial safety net" to prevent future Mexican-style financial disasters. [D3.]
 
Questions Over Wireless Systems
As the telecommunications industry gathers in Geneva for its quadrennial trade show, two troubled debt offerings have raised questions about the viability of so-called global wireless personal communications. [D4.]
 
A New Kind of Personal Computer
Jean-Louis Gassee, the founder of Be Inc. and the former engineering head of Apple Computer, demonstrated a new personal computer with its own operating system software. [D6.]
 
A Premium for Simpson Case Ads
Media directors and other agency media executives said they were being asked by the broadcast networks to pay $200,000 to $300,000 yesterday for a 30-second daytime commercial placed around the O. J. Simpson verdict. Ads during that time period would regularly cost from $30,000 to $35,000. But some advertisers shied away from placing ads. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D2.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain For 3d Day; 30-Year Yield Dips to 6.45%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were higher yesterday for the third consecutive session.
But trading was light and largely affected by technical factors, with traders squaring positions and setting strategies ahead of Friday's report on employment in September. The light volume magnified price moves. 
 Prices continued to be supported by recent sluggish economic data, suggesting that the Federal Reserve would have room to cut short-term interest rates once more this year. And the gains yesterday were supported by strength in the dollar in world currency trading.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 105 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.45 percent, from 6.47 percent on Monday.
In bond futures trading, which typically affects prices in the cash market, the December bond contract backed off from an important resistance level of 115 4/32, which was the peak on Monday. At the same time, the cash market hit its high of the session, 105 24/32. The December contract closed at 114 26/32.
Robin Mesch, the chief fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research in Boston, said that even though prices in futures trading did not go higher, sentiment remained bullish.
With the reports on leading economic indicators and August factory orders scheduled today, the Monday peak could again be retested in the futures market, she said.
Traders said a move above 115 would probably generate buy orders. Many buyers would be likely to place stop orders, which can be used to either protect an existing profit or limit the potential loss on securities that have been sold short. Short-selling involves the sale of borrowed securities in the hope that the price will decline and the securities can be bought back at a profit.
"Other than the overall bullish structure of the market, there were no fundamental factors driving the rally today," Ms. Mesch said, "and the move up occurred on thin air. And so that is why the rally ran out of breath up there and maybe ran out of breath for the week.
"The current technical factors would support a pullback in the market at this point, but nothing we think is going to do real damage to the overall bullish structure."
She said the market would be seeking its lows for the week, which she put at about 113 23/32. "The long-term trader should still view these dips as an opportunity to get on board the buy side this quarter," she said.
P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager for SunAmerica Asset Management, agreed that the underlying tone of the market was strong. "Today, for example, when there was no real data out, no one was willing to short the market," he said. Investors who short the market are betting that prices will fall.
Two pieces of data released yesterday effectively canceled each other out. A weekly report on chain-store sales from the Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and Schroder Wertheim & Company showed a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts said it was another sign that the economy was not growing at a pace fast enough to cause inflation to accelerate, preventing the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates again.
But another report released later in the day, the Johnson Redbook Service, indicated strength in retailing. The report showed a 1.4 percent rise in retail sales for the week.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 5, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's trading in the credit markets misstated the high for the December bond futures contract on Monday. It was 114 30/32, not 115 4/32.
