HEADLINE: THE POPE'S VISIT: NEWARK;
In Fleeting Moments, Pope Vitalizes Streets of Newark

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 4

 BODY:
He passed by them first as a vague, white-robed blur behind the darkly tinted rear window of an indistinct black limousine, and later as a cloudy figure beneath the thick, bulletproof shroud over his special Popemobile. Each time, he came and went in a matter of seconds.
But to many of the people who waited long hours here on the sidewalks outside Sacred Heart Cathedral, that fleeting moment of communion with Pope John Paul II was enough. With just a wave and a smile, he gave them the heady, exalted feeling of being at the center of something holy and historic. 
 "I'm totally satisfied," said Lydia Masi, 69, of Newark, who spent more than 10 hours in the intermittent drizzle for her short-lived glimpse of the man she believes speaks for God on earth.
"Bravo Il Papa!" Mrs. Masi had shouted, as loudly as her lungs would let her, when the Pope neared her patch of sidewalk. Afterward, she said, "I got the chills."
In Mrs. Masi and the several thousand other people who gathered here today for the beginning of the Pope's brief American tour, the currents of emotion ran strong and deep. Their revelry and ardor transformed an inner-city neighborhood that is usually somewhat desolate into a crowded open-air arena of song and celebration as pride and jubilation swept through a city more accustomed to insult and injury.
Lisa Mendez, 35, said that usually when she tells people that she is from Newark, "they look at me funny." On this special day, their reaction was kinder. "They say, 'Oh, you're so lucky,' " Ms. Mendez said.
These were people whose paths do not typically cross. Spanning the economic extremes of the Archdiocese of Newark, in which the many pockets of urban poverty mean that roughly 40 percent of the 238 Catholic parishes operate at a deficit, they converged on the cathedral, both from tranquil suburbs an hour's drive away and city blocks within walking distance.
But on this day, in the presence of the Pope, they cut often identical figures: eager, jostling witnesses to a charmed occasion.
The Pope came to the cathedral from Newark International Airport for a 5 P.M. prayer service. The streets outside the majestic French Gothic structure, which crowns Newark's highest hill, were billed as the only place in the New York metropolitan region where people without tickets to specific events could hope to see the Pontiff up close.
Although the overall turnout fell far short of the crowd of 100,000 people for which the authorities had braced, there were still enough people -- 15,000, by one police estimate that seemed generous -- to fill nearly a half-mile stretch of the sidewalk along Clifton Avenue, the main street beside the cathedral.
They laughed, cheered and even wept during the anticipation-filled hours leading to the Pope's arrival. And when his seemingly infinite motorcade suddenly pulled into view shortly after 4:30 P.M., they roared.
When the Pope later circled the cathedral in his Popemobile, Carrie Figueroa, 19, gushed: "Oh, my God, here he comes. He's so cute!"
But the reception accorded the Pope transcended mere celebrity worship. People talked of being profoundly, indescribably moved.
"He really didn't seem real," said Bertha Adams, 43, of Newark. "Other celebrities I've seen seem like ordinary people when you see them. But the Pope was different, like a godsend." Ms. Adams is Baptist, and while it seemed that the majority of the crowd around the cathedral was Catholic, there was a significant minority from different faiths.
No two people brought precisely the same sense of formal ceremony to the occasion. Some dressed up while others dressed down; some toted video cameras and portable televisions while others carried nothing heavier than a simple rosary; some cheered while others bowed their heads silently in prayer.
At one house along Clifton Avenue, Doris Estela tied dozens of yellow and white plastic flowers, one by one, to the black wrought-iron railing on her front porch. She also hung a banner -- "Welcome to Newark, Holy Father" -- that had been colored by her 10-year-old daughter, Angela, who dressed in in beige linen pants and a lacy white blouse for the occasion.
"My mom said no jeans today," Angela said. "She said I should look pretty for the Pope."
Several dozen feet away on the sidewalk, Johann Suarez, 20, of Newark cradled a 2-month-old baby boy whom she had named Johnny Pasqual, in honor of the Pope. Maria Veiga, 36, stood on tired feet that had carried her six miles from an adjacent suburb through crime-ridden areas of the city.
"My husband said I was crazy," Mrs. Veiga said. "I said God was going to protect me."
The first people to line Clifton Avenue were Sylvia Esteves and her aunt, Elisa Nicoletti, who were not taking any chances when it came to getting a good view of the Pope.
With sleeping bags at the ready, they toured the streets around the cathedral at 11 Tuesday night to make sure there were not any overzealous people pitching tents in coveted spots.
Reassured that there were not, Mrs. Esteves, who lives in Newark near the cathedral, and Mrs. Nicoletti nonetheless proceeded to conduct a strategic canvass of the area with a special eye toward where street cleaners looked busiest -- a clue, they decided, to the precise route of the papal motorcade.
The two women fixed on a section of sidewalk kitty-corner from the cathedral entrance, then went back to Mrs. Esteves's house and set their alarm for 3:50 A.M. They got to their chosen ground at 5 A.M.
For these two, the Pope's visit had special personal meaning because the cathedral is a place where their family has marked many important milestones: baptisms and weddings, funerals and first communions.
It took a while for the excitement on the street to build. Up until about 10 A.M., there were fewer than 100 spectators outside the cathedral, and their numbers did not exceed those of the roughly 500 police officers until noon.
Lieut. Henry Gajda of the Newark police said he kept waiting in vain for an overwhelming deluge of people. "We thought we spotted a crowd over on Park Avenue a while ago," Lieutenant Gajda said, referring to a nearby intersection, "but it turned out to be two busloads of senior citizens headed to Atlantic City."
The police presence provided a grave counterpoint to everything else. While people waved to the Pope, police officers in a line between them and the street kept their backs to the Pontiff and their eyes on the crowd.
Those officers did not relax until the Pope left at around 7 P.M. The 1,800 people who had attended the prayer service spilled out of the cathedral with wide eyes and wider smiles.
Sister Clara Marie, who received dispensation to leave her cloister in Newark to attend the service, spoke of shaking the Pope's hand. "It's like holding the hand of your father," she said. "There's a gentleness and fatherly affection."
One priest broke into song. "Fly Me to the Moon," he crooned as he walked off into what for him had clearly become an enchanted evening.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Selloff in Technology Issues Pulls Stock Market Down
Technology stocks were battered, leading the stock market to its third straight loss, as Wall Street continued to brace for possible disappointments in third-quarter earnings. The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, dropped 18.18 points, to 1,002.27. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 9.03 points, to 4,740.67.
Technology stocks dropped after an analyst at Soundview Financial Group downgraded five semiconductor makers for the first time in three years, citing rising supplies of computer chips. [Page D12.]
 
Leading Indicators Up 0.2%
The index of leading economic indicators increased for only the second time this year, rising two-tenths of 1 percent in August, indicating moderate expansion in the months ahead. In a separate Government report, factory orders rose 2.6 percent in August on strong demand for cars and trucks. [D4.]
 
The reports helped Treasury prices extend their rally through a fourth consecutive session as expectations continued for another cut in interest rates. [D19.]
 
The dollar fell against most leading currencies as traders took profits. The dollar fell to 100.94 Japanese yen from 101.42 yen and to 1.4349 German marks from 1.4385 marks. [D10.]
 
Ford Sales Fell 9% in September
Following soft September sales reports from its rivals, Ford said its overall vehicle sales for the month fell 9 percent, more than what analysts had expected. The decline was Ford's first monthly sales drop this year. [D2.]
 
Court Orders Extradition of Leeson
A German court ordered that Nicholas W. Leeson, the trader whose $1.35 billion in losses brought down Barings P.L.C., be extradited to Singapore to face 11 charges of fraud, forgery and breach of trust. [D6.]
 
South American Beef Gaining Favor
After decades of being shut out of the world's largest meat markets because of an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease, Argentina and Uruguay have contained the disease among their cattle and are expected to begin shipping fresh and frozen beef to the United States and other countries in the next six months. [D6.]
 
New Club Shakes Up Golf Stocks
The willingness of many golfers to pay $300 for the newest innovation in equipment, a long-shot driver called the Burner Bubble, is unexpectedly putting pressure on the stocks of the industry leaders, the Callaway Golf Company and Cobra Golf. But analysts are unsure how to play this fight for dominance of the $1.5 billion premium club market. Market Place. [D12.]
 
Peddling the New AT&T
Richard A. McGinn, the chief executive of AT&T's giant equipment-manufacturing division, met with senior executives from nine telephone companies at the Telecom '95 trade show in Geneva this week to promote his soon-to-be-independent company and found unanimous support for AT&T's breakup. [D4.]
 
Tough Sell for Simpson TV Special
A number of the larger companies that stage pay-per-view television events have been approached about offering a pay-per-view interview with O. J. Simpson, but the companies have reservations about such an event. "It may have some attraction to people who were voyeurs to this circus, but my reaction is that it would be in extremely bad taste," one executive said. [B18.]
 
Putting Whimsy in the Air
Two new airlines are taking their promotional cue from Southwest Airlines, which has had its flight attendants singing to the tune of the Flintstones and other familiar melodies since its inception in 1971. Valujet has adopted a cartoon of a smiling Boeing 747 as its logo, and Western Pacific has four planes painted with TV's "Simpsons." Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Ford Had 9% Sales Decline For September

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Following soft September sales reports from its rivals, the Ford Motor Company said today that its sales for the month fell 9 percent, more than what analysts had expected.
The decline was Ford's first monthly sales drop this year and was worse than results at the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation, which reported sales figures on Monday. 
 "The market is a little softer than they expected," said Carnie Colliver, manager of market analysis for Auto Pacific, a consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif.
Ford and other auto makers have been hurt by a strike by 5,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters at Ryder System Inc.'s car hauling unit. More than 500,000 cars and trucks have piled up at plants, rail yards and ports around the country during the 28-day strike. Paul Ballew, an economist and sales manager for J. D. Power and Associates in Troy, Mich., estimated that the strike cost American auto makers about 100,000 vehicle sales last month.
Ford has also been hurt by factory changeovers for production of new Taurus and F series trucks.
The company said car sales fell 16.8 percent, to 136,689, while truck sales declined seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 152,743. The decline ends an eight-month string of sales increases, including large sales to its rental fleets. The surge enabled Ford to steal market share from General Motors and Chrysler.
Ford said it was not concerned by the decline. "There's been no fundamental shift in the market climate," Robert L. Rewey, group vice president of marketing and sales, said in a statement.
Industrywide, cars and trucks sold at an annualized pace of 14.82 million in September, below the year-ago pace of 15 million, according to Luckey Consulting Group. In August, the best month so far this year, vehicles sold at an annual rate of 15.7 million.
On Monday, Chrysler reported a 7 percent decline in sales. G.M. eked out an increase of half of 1 percent over September 1994.
Most Japanese auto makers also said sales in the United States were down or little changed last month. The Toyota Motor Corporation said its sales volume was down 7.5 percent, to 77,635 cars and trucks. The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said sales fell 18.2 percent.
The Nissan Motor Company was the big exception, posting a 21.8 percent increase in sales from September 1994.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Ryder Strike Talks Seen
 CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- Ryder Systems Inc. said today that it would resume negotiations on Thursday with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in an attempt to end a four-week-old strike at its car-hauling company.
Ryder, the nation's largest car hauler, said the strike was costing the company as much as $1 million a day in revenue.
"There is no doubt the strike's had a dramatic impact and played a critical role in getting Ryder back to the negotiating table," a union spokesman, Jeff Cappella, said.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Vision Tests May Reduce Auto Accidents of Elderly

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 4

 BODY:
Efforts in many states to make it easier to renew driver's licenses may be misguided, according to a study that shows screening programs help reduce fatal crashes among the elderly.
The study's lead researcher, David T. Levy, an economics professor at the University of Baltimore, said, "This study shows that license screening, particularly vision testing, is effective at reducing fatal crashes involving senior drivers." 
 The eight states that did not require vision testing in the study period of 1985 to 1989 had 7 percent more traffic fatalities each year among elderly drivers than the 42 states with mandatory vision screening, the researchers said in a report published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
The researchers said that testing motorists' road knowledge also had an effect on the rate of fatal crashes involving elderly motorists. The researchers adjusted their findings to account for the differences in the states that could skew the results, such as how much people drove on average, how fast they drove, the number of people living in urban areas and the availability of hospitals.
In the five years studied, an average of 17,294 drivers older than 70 were involved in fatal crashes each year.
"We estimate that 282 lives would be saved with universal vision testing compared with no states having vision tests," the researchers said. That figure is only for fatal crashes involving senior drivers.
"There might be additional lives saved among younger drivers," Mr. Levy said in an interview, "because some of the younger drivers also have vision problems and are still driving."
With some highly publicized fatal traffic accidents involving elderly drivers, officials have been wrestling with how to get hazardous older drivers off the roads without penalizing able ones.
Although drivers from 16 to 24 are the most likely to have automobile accidents, those older than 65 have the second-highest crash rate per vehicle mile traveled, according to previous studies. Any driving problems of the elderly can be expected to grow as baby boomers age.
"Now there's 13 million drivers age 70 or older," Mr. Levy said. "By the year 2020, it's going to be 30 million."
In 1989, the states that required no vision testing for license renewal were New Jersey, Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Vermont and West Virginia. Mr. Levy said he did not know whether any states have dropped testing or added it since then.
Alan Hoskin, statistics manager for the National Safety Council, said the study relied on sound methods and reached justifiable conclusions.
"There really is no basis for restricting driving on the basis of age alone," he said, "but it should be on the abilities of the driver."

HEADLINE: AT&T's 3-Way Split Is Playing Well in Europe

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 4

 BODY:
For Richard A. McGinn, Telecom '95 has been a grand coming-out party.
Mr. McGinn, the chief executive of AT&T's giant equipment-manufacturing division, met with senior executives from nine telephone companies at the big telecommunications trade show here this week to promote his soon-to-be-independent company. 
 The AT&T Corporation announced last month that it would split itself into three separate, publicly traded companies. One of the company's primary goals is to unshackle its equipment division, which has been hampered by its ties to the long-distance division. Mr. McGinn said today that the telephone executives he spoke to were unanimously in favor of AT&T's drastic move.
"The head of one European phone company told me, 'This has changed everything for us and how we look at you,' " Mr. McGinn said. He declined to identify the executive because he said he did not want to risk upsetting him.
Prior to the announcement of the breakup, AT&T's Networks System Group was losing customers because regional Bell operating companies in the United States and state-owned monopolies in Europe were reluctant to buy equipment from the same company that was beginning to compete with them in their home markets.
Now, analysts and potential customers said, AT&T has a fighting chance to win lucrative contracts from both the Baby Bells and European telecommunications giants to supply them with everything from cellular telephones to digital networking equipment.
AT&T introduced a new product today that would enable companies to offer local telephone service without laying miles of copper wire. Combining digital technology with a traditional fixed-wireless network, the company said it had developed an economical way for telephone operators to offer phone service in less-developed markets.
Industry executives said the new product would appeal to telephone companies in Asia and the Middle East, and could help increase AT&T's overseas sales, which are currently 25 percent of the division's total revenue of more than $20 billion.
In Europe, industry executives said, the state-owned telephone monopolies would still be more likely to buy the majority of their gear from home-grown equipment companies like Alcatel Alsthom of France and Siemens of Germany.
But at least one European telephone company said it would cast a kinder eye on AT&T. John J. Goossens, the chief executive of Belgacom, the state telephone company of Belgium, said he had warned AT&T in February that his company would not buy equipment from AT&T because it was trying to compete for customers in Belgium's long-distance market. "That's no longer a problem," he said.
The good news for AT&T is bad news for beleaguered European equipment companies. Alcatel and Siemens have both built lavish booths at the Telecom '95 trade show and are putting up a brave front for its 130,000 visitors. But they are under pressure from their biggest customers -- France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom -- which are themselves facing new competition and want to pay sharply lower prices for equipment.
"We can no longer play the Good Samaritan to local suppliers in the name of the Government," said Mr. Goossens, who was the chief executive of Alcatel's Belgian operations prior to joining Belgacom in February.
Alcatel announced last week that it had lost $240 million in the first half of 1995. The company also said it would take a charge of $2 billion to $2.4 billion to pay for a major restructuring of its operations. Alcatel is expected to disclose further details of its planned overhaul at a news conference here on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Index of Leading Indicators Rose in August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators rose in August, the Commerce Department said today, indicating moderate expansion in the months ahead.
The index, which is intended to project economic growth over the next six months, increased two-tenths of 1 percent in August, in contrast to a decline of the same amount in July. The increase in August was only the second this year. 
 Factory orders for consumer goods led the advance. A separate Government report issued today showed that strong consumer demand for cars and trucks contributed to a gain of 2.6 percent in factory orders during August. Auto manufacturers returned to regular production schedules in the month, after having closed plants during July to retool for the next model season, helping lift orders over all.
Today's economic reports were in line with expectations.
Recent ups and downs in the leading index point to "at best modest expansion in the months ahead," said William Sullivan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York.
Eight of the 11 components of the leading index contributed to August's increase. They were factory orders for consumer goods, which rose; weekly jobless claims, which declined to a monthly average of 339,000 in August from 367,000 in July; the money supply, which increased; the average workweek, which grew to 41.5 hours in August from 41.3 hours during July; capital spending, which rose; permits for new home construction, whose number grew; stock prices, which were higher in the month, and unfilled factory orders, viewed as a measure of whether plants can keep up with demand, which fell.
The three other components held the index back. Prices for sensitive materials declined, suggesting that demand for raw materials will slow; the delivery time for goods decreased, also a sign of slower demand, and the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment fell to 86.1 in August from 87.4 in July.
The index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity, increased three-tenths of 1 percent in August after showing no change in July. The index of lagging indicators, including labor market conditions, which generally improve after other parts of the economy have strengthened, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in August after having fallen by the same amount in July.
The separate factory orders report showed that inventories have stopped accumulating at factories, an indication that manufacturers have succeeded in trimming production to keep it in line with demand.
"Manufacturing has ceased to be a drag on the economy, but it hasn't turned into a plus," said Robert Dederick, an economic consultant at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "It's still rounding the corner."
Factory shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose 3 percent in August, the report showed, while unfilled factory orders declined two-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department reported last Friday that the economy grew at an annual rate of 1.3 percent in the second quarter, the slowest pace since the first three months of 1993. Analysts believe the growth rate improved in the third quarter to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent as consumer spending accelerated. Growth in the fourth quarter will probably run at a similar pace, analysts said.
The Government will publish only one more leading index, for September. The Conference Board, a New York business research organization, is taking over compilation of the index in a money-saving move by the Government. No major changes are planned in the report's contents.

HEADLINE: Texts of Speeches at the Airport and Sacred Heart Cathedral

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the addresses by Pope John Paul II at Newark International Airport and at Sacred Heart Cathedral in Newark yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: 

 
AT THE AIRPORT
 Mr. President, dear friends, dear people of America, it is a great joy for me to return to the United States as I had hoped to do last year. Thank you all for receiving me so warmly. This is a land of much generosity and its people have always been quick to extend their hands in friendship and to offer hospitality. Thank you especially, President Clinton and the First Lady, for coming here today in that same spirit.
For my part I greet you and all the representatives of the Federal, state and local governments. I greet the Bishops' Conference of the United States and the individual bishops who have invited me to their dioceses and have worked so hard, with countless co-workers, to prepare for this visit. I look forward to meeting the Catholic communities of Newark, Brooklyn, New York and Baltimore, as well as our brothers and sisters of other Christian churches and ecclesial communities. To the members of the Jewish faith I extend a very cordial greeting and my respectful best wishes on this day of special significance for them.
I greet all the people of this great nation of every race, color, creed, social condition. I pray for you all and assure you of my profound esteem.
Exactly 30 years ago today my predecessor, Pope Paul VI, spoke to the United Nations General Assembly and delivered a message that still resounds in many hearts: "No more war, war never again!" He went on to appeal: "Peace, it is peace which must guide the destinies of people."
I, too, come as a pilgrim of peace and understanding among peoples. Tomorrow, in observance of the United Nations' 50th anniversary, I shall return there to express my deep conviction that the ideals and intentions which gave origin to that worldwide organization half a century ago are more indispensable than ever in a world searching for purpose.
The world, in fact, is undergoing a profound transformation. Opportunities for justice, reconciliation and development are visible in parts of the world where they were hardly discernible even a few years ago -- almost within our reach, it seems, but still so difficult to grasp. Ancient rivalries and suspicions still compromise the cause of peace. We must find ways to set them aside. If we do not, history and the Lord of History will judge us harshly.
Especially since the events of 1989, the role of the United States in the world has taken on a new prominence. Your widespread influence is at once political, economic, military and, due to your communications media, cultural. It is vital for the human family that in continuing to seek advancement in many different fields -- science, business, education, art and wherever else your creativity leads you -- America keeps compassion, generosity and concern for others at the very heart of its efforts.
In particular, for nations and peoples emerging from a long period of trial, your country stands upon the world scene as a model of a democratic society at the advanced stage of development. Your power of example carries with it heavy responsibilities. Use it well, America! Be an example of justice and civic virtues, freedom fulfilled in goodness, at home and abroad.
From its beginning until now, the United States has been a haven for generation after generation of new arrivals. Men, women and children have streamed here from every corner of the globe, building new lives and forming a society of rich ethnic and racial diversity based on commitment to a shared vision of human dignity and freedom. Of the United States we can truly say, "e pluribus unum."
It is my prayerful hope that America will persevere in its own best traditions of openness and opportunity. It would indeed be sad if the United States were to turn away from that enterprising spirit which has always sought the most practical and responsible ways of continuing to share with others the blessings God has richly bestowed here.
The same spirit of creative generosity will help you to meet the needs of your own poor and disadvantaged. They too have a role to play in building a society truly worthy of the human person -- a society in which none are so poor that they have nothing to give and none are so rich that they have nothing to receive. The poor have needs which are not only material and economic but also involve liberating their potential to work out their own destiny and to provide for the well-being of their families and communities. America will continue to be a land of promise as long as it remains a land of freedom and justice for all.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen: I come as one who has an abiding hope in America's noble destiny. I thank God for allowing me to return to you again. Thank you and God and God bless you, bless you all. Thank you very much.
Pope is bringing you the rain. Very important event. Thank you very much.
 
AT THE CATHEDRAL
 Dear Archbishop McCarrick and my brother cardinals and bishops, dear brother priests, dear seminarians, men and women religious and lay faithful of the family of God which is the church in Newark:
We are gathered in this cathedral dedicated to the Sacred Heart of Jesus in order to give thanks to the Most Blessed Trinity for the bonds of faith and love which unite us in the One, Holy, Catholic and Apostolic Church.
The presence of the President of the United States at this evening prayer helps us call to mind that it is precisely our service of God which inspires and motivates the healthy pride which we all feel in our native land. This evening, let us thank God for the extraordinary human epic that is the United States of America.
This magnificent building stands in the heart of Newark as a powerful reminder of God's steadfast love for his people and a sign of faith in Christ, our hope of glory. The cathedral made of stone is a symbol of the living church, God's household, which is open to everyone without exception, to men and women of every race and tongue, of every people and nation.
You -- the people of God in Newark and throughout New Jersey -- are the living stones which make up the Body of Christ in the midst of your city and state. Wherever you are -- in your families, neighborhoods, places of work or recreation -- you are called to build up the church in faith, hope and love.
The stirring challenge of the new evangelization -- the aim of which is to proclaim that Jesus Christ is the center of history, the hope of humanity and the joy of every heart -- was faced by the last year's Archdiocesan Synod. I greet with affection all of you who so zealously took part as delegates in that important assembly.
The Synod wisely called for a great mobilization of resources so that all Catholics would receive the solid spiritual and doctrinal formation needed in order to bear convincing witness to their faith and assume their full role in the church's mission. I pray that, as a result of the Synod, the Archdiocese of Newark will become ever more of one heart and one mind -- a community joyously united with its bishops and priests in attentively listening to the word of God, devoutly celebrating the sacraments and generously meeting the needs of others.
With special affection, I greet my brothers in the priesthood and thank each one of you for your dedicated service of the Gospel! The Lord has chosen you to be in the forefront in bringing souls to him. Like Christ, the Head and Shepherd of the church, you must know, tend and offer your life for your flock.
Ordination configures you to Christ the Servant -- to Him who humbly washed His apostles' feet because He came among us not to be served but to serve. Such selfless service is the model of all ministry in the church. As you return to your parishes or to the various apostolates in which you are engaged, I pray that -- in the words of Saint Paul -- God will make you worthy of his call, and fulfill by his power every honest intention and work of faith.
To the seminarians -- and how heartening it is to know that your number is increasing! -- I offer a special word of encouragement. The new evangelization of America calls for a great spiritual maturity on your part. The gift of the priesthood demands that you follow Christ even unto death on a cross.
Without the virtues of self-discipline, diligent contemplation of the truth, simplicity of life and joyful dedication to others, you will not have the inner strength to combat the culture of death which is threatening the modern world. I urge you to pray each day: "O good Jesus, make a priest like unto your own heart." Christ himself is your inheritance. He will never abandon you or disappoint you!
With profound gratitude for your immense contribution to the church's life, I embrace all the men and women religious. Whether your life is hidden with Christ in God in solitude, penance and contemplation, or whether you are actively engaged in the world, the whole ecclesial community looks to you to see what it means to love the Lord with an undivided heart.
The recognition of the genius of woman and of the specifically feminine charisms which women religious bring to the church's life and mission is a providential sign of our times. If in the past these gifts were sometimes insufficiently esteemed or thwarted in their legitimate expression, now is the time for all of us to work together to follow where the Lord leads, in love and fidelity. May the Holy Spirit strengthen your hearts, making them blameless and holy before our God and Father, so that you may serve his people with ever greater joy!
To the whole church in Newark and New Jersey I repeat the words of encouragement found in the First Letter of Peter: "There is cause for rejoicing here . . . because you are achieving faith's goal, your salvation."
Dear friends in Christ, the First Letter of Peter exhorts us to be clothed with humility in our dealings with one another; we read: "Bow humbly under God's mighty hand, so that in due time he may lift you high." This lowliness and humility is explained as abandoning ourselves into the hands of God: "Cast all your cares on him because he cares for you." Yes, God holds humanity in the highest esteem! God reveres everything that is authentically human -- everything that affects individuals and societies, nations and states!
As you well know, I have come to the United States in connection with the 50th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. That organization exists to serve the common good of the human family, and therefore it is fitting that the Pope speak there as a witness to the hope of the Gospel.
The United Nations is an instrument of dialogue and peace. The criteria of its actions ought always to be the integral well-being of people. The challenge which is permanently before its member states, agencies and personnel is similar to the challenge which confronts every individual: In your relations with one another, clothe yourselves with humility.
In particular, the powerful and the mighty ought to show meekness in their dealings with the weak. The powerful always need to remember that they owe their position to God -- to the One who is stern with the arrogant but who shows kindness to the humble. Nations and governments -- like individuals -- need to acknowledge that the Lord rules the world with justice; with fairness He rules the peoples and guides the nations.
The First Letter of Peter also recalls the need for watchfulness: "Stay sober and alert." Fifty years ago, after the end of the incredible destruction caused by the Second World War, the United Nations organization was established as an international forum of vigilance at the service of peace and justice in the world.
The United Nations has a necessary role to play in preventing and relieving the enormous sufferings which the world's peoples and nations inflict on each other, sufferings which in the 20th century have reached unprecedented proportions in wars and conflicts and in political and ideological oppression caused by the greed and arrogance of those who plot evil in their hearts.
The history of the world in the last 50 years cannot be written without reference to the United Nations. Is it not still needed, to watch and warn and exhort when conflict and injustice threaten the tranquillity of order? Should it not be strengthened as the guarantor of peace, justice and humanitarian concern -- whether in the Balkans, in Africa, or in any place where these values are threatened? Should it not be reformed to insure that it will be guided by an objective assessment of the international situation in order to be a credible forum in which to address issues of fundamental importance for the building of a more human and just world?
Our prayer for peace is therefore also a prayer for the United Nations organization. Saint Francis of Assisi, whose feast we celebrate today, shines forth as a great lover and artisan of peace. Let us invoke his intercession upon the United Nations' work for justice and peace throughout the world.
May the God of all grace, who has called us to everlasting glory in Christ, confirm and strengthen all who work and suffer for the peace and well-being of the human family.
To Him we commend the church in the United States and the local church of Newark and the surrounding dioceses. To Him be honor, glory and praise forever! Amen.

HEADLINE: State and City Sweeten Offer To 2 Commodities Exchanges

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
The governing boards of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange are considering a new package of incentives from New York City and the State of New York intended to keep them from leaving Manhattan.
But directors of the two exchanges would not comment on whether the sweetened incentives, worth as much as $80 million -- more than double an earlier incentive package -- would be enough to prevent them from going ahead with plans to move to Jersey City. A spokeswoman for the Coffee Exchange said the offer was under review, but refused to comment further. 
 Since July, when the two exchanges signed a letter of intent to move to the site of Jersey City's old Colgate factory, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki have worked to prevent the exodus. The loss of the exchanges would cost New York 5,000 jobs and split commodities trading activity between Jersey City and lower Manhattan, where other exchanges that trade commodities are.
One of those other exchanges, the New York Mercantile Exchange, cited the large overlap in membership among the exchanges when it proposed in August to merge with the Coffee and Cotton exchanges, in hope of keeping the commodities activity centrally located. The Mercantile, which combined with the Commodity Exchange last year, is staying in New York City and has already received $200 million in tax breaks to move to Battery Park City.
In late August, the city and state offered the Coffee and Cotton exchanges a $36.8 million package of tax and economic development incentives to move to the site of the Mercantile project. But people involved in the talks said it wasn't enough to match Jersey City's incentives.
So on Tuesday, the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Economic Development Corporation agreed to put up an additional $30 million, or $15 million each, in cash for the exchanges, and $50.5 million in non-cash tax and economic development incentives.
Under the terms of their latest offer, the cash would be provided as long as the Coffee and Cotton exchanges stay in New York, whatever happens with the proposed merger with the Mercantile. The amount of the non-cash incentives would depend on whether the exchanges move to the new Mercantile facility or to another site, or develop a new headquarters at 4 World Trade Center, their current home.
"We're trying to match what Jersey City is offering," said Charles A. Gargano, chairman of New York's Empire State Development Corporation. "These 5,000 jobs are important and downtown is the financial center of Manhattan."
Coffee and Cotton exchange members are expected to meet today with their outside financial advisers to discuss the Jersey City offer, and are scheduled to vote on the Jersey City relocation plan on Monday.

HEADLINE: Flu Shot Found to Reduce Lost Work Days and Doctor Visits

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
A person need not be over 65 or chronically ill to benefit both medically and financially from flu vaccine, according to a new study of healthy, working adults.
The study, conducted last fall and winter among 849 employed men and women from 18 to 64, showed that immunizing such people against influenza reduced the number of upper respiratory illnesses, days lost from work and visits to a doctor, for an estimated net savings of nearly $47 a person. 
 Many employers are already providing free or low-cost flu shots for their workers. The new findings, by a team headed by Dr. Kristin L. Nichol of the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Minneapolis, are expected to prompt even more companies to do it.
Dr. Nichol's report is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine, just a week or so before the vaccine for the 1995-96 flu season reaches doctors.
In an editorial in the journal, Federal vaccine experts challenged the Minnesota team's conclusions. Citing other studies that had failed to show an economic advantage to immunizing healthy, working adults, Dr. Peter A. Patriarca of the Food and Drug Administration and Dr. Raymond A. Strikas of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggested that an unusually high rate of flu in the season under study inflated the benefits observed.
In a more typical season, they predicted, vaccinating healthy working adults would certainly prevent many from becoming ill but might not result in any economic advantage.
Nonetheless, Dr. Patriarca and Dr. Strikas concluded, "When a patient, for whatever reason, wishes to reduce or eliminate the risk of influenza infection, there is no reason to withhold or discourage the use of the vaccine unless the patient has medical contraindications to its use."
The vaccine is 70 percent to 90 percent effective in preventing flu in adults under 65. Conditions that make its use inadvisable are a severe allergy to eggs (the vaccine virus is grown in chick embryos) and the presence of a fever-causing illness.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has generally recommended flu vaccine for people over 65 and those of any age who suffer from chronic illnesses, including cancer and immune-suppressing diseases, because the elderly and chronically ill face an unusually high risk of developing serious or life-threatening complications from the flu.
The vaccine has also been advised for individuals who live or work with high-risk people, residents of nursing homes and chronic care institutions, children and teen-agers on long-term aspirin therapy and, unofficially, for workers who provide essential community services.
The typical charge for a flu shot at a workplace or in a community setting is $10, but charges can range from $20 to $80 when the shot is provided by a private doctor. Medicare, the Federal health care program for the elderly, reimburses doctors who administer flu shots to people covered by the program.
The potential benefits of expanding the use of flu vaccine are great. Dr. Patriarca and Dr. Strikas pointed out that influenza costs American consumers "at least $12 billion annually in direct and indirect expenses" and is associated with 10,000 to 40,000 deaths above the number normally expected and more than 150,000 such hospitalizations each year.
In the new study, half the subjects received a flu shot and the other half received a dummy injection in the fall of 1994. Neither the person administering the shots nor those receiving them knew who got which injection. The participants were then queried by telephone each month about occurrences of upper respiratory illness and visits to a doctor or absence from work because of such an illness.
Dr. Nichol and her colleagues reported that from December to May, those who received the real vaccine had 25 percent fewer episodes of upper respiratory illness, took 43 percent fewer sick days from work and made 44 percent fewer visits to doctors for upper respiratory illnesses.
In trying to explain the benefits, Dr. Nichol said, "Flu predisposes people to developing secondary infections, and the vaccine might prevent both, resulting in a ripple effect of benefits."
The researchers suggested that since their analysis did not include savings associated with a decrease in nonrespiratory illness, hospitalizations or deaths resulting from the flu and its complications, their finding of a $46.85 cost savings per immunized adult might underestimate the potential savings.
"We also did not assess a misery index," Dr. Nichol said in an interview. "Just decreasing the suffering associated with the flu is a significant benefit, even if it were not cost-saving."

HEADLINE: Macedonia Names Fill-In for Wounded Leader

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Oct. 4

 BODY:
The Macedonian Parliament named an interim President today after determining that President Kiro Gligorov, who received serious head injuries in a car-bomb attack on Tuesday, was incapable of performing his functions.
The transfer of power to the Speaker of Parliament, Stojan Andov, was in accordance with the Constitution and for that reason was heralded by Western diplomats and Macedonians, mindful of the region's stormy history. 
 At the same time, they expressed concern about the country's future without Mr. Gligorov, 78, a former Communist official who became President of this former Yugoslav republic in 1991 and led it to independence that year as Yugoslavia began to splinter.
A good friend of Washington and a reliable ally of the West, he has managed to keep the country's volatile ethnic mix from exploding and has prevented the war among former Yugoslavian republics from spreading south. The United States has some 500 troops here as part of the United Nations peacekeeping mission, the only place in the Balkans it has troops.
Internal tensions exist between the Macedonian majority and the one-fifth of the population composed of ethnic Albanians, who are demanding more cultural and political autonomy. Relations with Serbia to the north and Greece to the south have also been strained.
Last month, Mr. Gligorov earned Washington's gratitude by signing an agreement that settled a bitter and destabilizing feud between Greece and Macedonia over the latter's name and flag.
Police officials said they did not know who was responsible for the car bomb that exploded at the side of the road as Mr. Gligorov's armored Mercedes drove toward his office in central Skopje. His driver was killed, several bystanders were wounded and Mr. Gligorov was struck in the head by shrapnel.
Diplomats said today that it was unlikely that Mr. Gligorov, who has serious brain injuries, would ever work again.
A team of American investigators, including agents from the F.B.I. and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, are expected to arrive here on Thursday to help in the investigation of the bombing. Scotland Yard is also planning to send a team.
Though Mr. Andov's Liberal Party has been part of the governing coalition, and diplomats and Macedonian political observers said they did not expect any radical changes, they nevertheless expressed some anxiety.
"I am very worried," said a prominent Macedonian intellectual. Speaking on the condition of anonymity, he said that Mr. Andov lacked Mr. Gligorov's political wisdom, flexibility and popularity.
In the past, Mr. Andov has taken a hard line toward the country's minority Albanians.
The senior American diplomat here, Victor Comras, said that Mr. Andov was "pro-American and pro-Western" and that he was committed to a market economy. Mr. Andov and his party have also campaigned against government corruption, which is pervasive here. But diplomats and some Macedonians here say that in his business dealings, Mr. Andov, who has grown quite wealthy since the collapse of Communism, does not always follow Western standards.
Though no group has taken responsibility for, or been accused of, the attack that nearly killed Mr. Gligorov, a European diplomat described the assassination attempt as "very professional" and said that it was likely that the bombers had been trained outside of Macedonia.
The owner of the car used in the bombing has been identified, the police said, and two men who were seen near the site of the blast have been arrested. No information about their identities or nationalities has been released.
While making it clear he had no hard evidence, one diplomat said he suspected Bulgarian extremists. Though Bulgaria has recognized Macedonia's independence, it has not recognized that Macedonians are a separate ethnic group, asserting that they are really Bulgarians.
Some people speculated that the bombing could have been the work of extreme Macedonian nationalists, angry because President Gligorov agreed to change the country's flag and provisions in the Constitution to settle a feud with Greece. Greece contended the flag and name -- Macedonia -- had been usurped from Greek history, going back to Alexander the Great. It was a contention many Macedonians bitterly disputed, noting that Alexander the Great was a Macedonian.
Suspicion was also directed at extremist Albanians living in western Macedonia. In general, ethnic Albanians, who make up 23 percent of the population, have been campaigning for more cultural autonomy, like the right to their own university, greater economic opportunities and an end to discrimination against them in the police and armed forces. But some Albanians would like to secede.
Whoever was responsible, one diplomat here said, the attack was another reminder that "this is the Balkans." The violence came at a moment when things were beginning to look up for Macedonia, what with the signing of the Greek accord and less bellicose sounds coming from Serbia.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Forecasts a Lag for Japan, Then Recovery

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4

 BODY:
While sharply reducing its growth estimate for Japan this year, the International Monetary Fund today forecast a recovery for the Japanese economy in 1996 that it said would help the United States and six other industrial powers maintain their current rates of growth.
The I.M.F., in its semiannual assessment of the world economy, reduced its growth estimates for all seven of the leading industrial nations. It cut Japan's the sharpest, to one-half of 1 percent, from 1.8 percent in May. 
 But the fund said that the recent fall in the exchange value of the yen, combined with lower interest rates and a new Government spending package, should increase growth to at least 2.2 percent in 1996.
"I think we could be looking at even higher numbers for Japan once the recovery gets going and confidence is restored," the monetary fund's chief economist, Michael Mussa, told a news conference today.
But the I.M.F. warned that Japan must act to resolve the problems of its troubled financial and banking industries if it was to attain a recovery.
In particular, it said that many smaller insolvent financial institutions, particularly in mortgage finance, must be merged or shut down. Japan's 21 major banks as well as its regional banks, though solvent, should start working off bad loans and widen the spreads between what they pay lenders and charge borrowers in order to rebuild their balance sheets.
Worldwide, the I.M.F. forecast economic growth of 3.7 percent to 4.1 percent in 1996, despite the slowing economies of many of the industrial nations. Recoveries in Latin America and Russia, as well as Japan, and high growth rates in Asia, are expected to bolster overall world growth.
For the seven economic powers that make up the Group of Seven industrial nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- the I.M.F. expects aggregate growth of 2.3 percent in 1996, compared with 2.4 percent this year.
The fund reduced its growth forecast for the United States this year to 2.9 percent from 3.2 percent. It predicted a further slowing to 2 percent in 1996.
For the United States to achieve even these rates, the I.M.F. warned against any premature relaxation in monetary policy that could reignite inflation. And it called for a "front loaded" attack on the Federal budget deficit, including the postponement of "the introduction of significant tax cuts until substantial progress toward a balanced budget has been achieved."
The German growth forecast was cut from to 2.6 percent this year from 3.2 percent, but was expected to rise to 2.9 percent next year. The I.M.F. chopped its forecasts for France by to 2.9 percent this year.
Britain is now expected to grow by 2.7 percent this year and 2.9 percent next year; Italy, 3 percent and 2.8 percent, and Canada, 2.2 percent and 2.7 percent.
Also helping sustain global recovery, in the I.M.F.'s view, is an expected upturn in Latin America as it shakes off the effects of the Mexican peso crisis, with overall growth in the Western Hemisphere forecast to more than double, to 4 percent next year from 1.8 percent.
"The worst of the Mexican crisis is past, and we expect significant recovery in the months ahead," Mr. Mussa said.
And a sharp turnaround was forecast for Russia and Central Asia, where the 4.6 percent rate of economic contraction expected this year, would be transformed into economic growth of 2.4 percent in 1996. The I.M.F. revised upward its Asian forecasts, to 8.7 percent this year and to 7.9 percent in 1996.
Some private economists found the I.M.F.'s latest picture of the world economy too optimistic, saying that the agency has underestimated the importance of the slowdown in major economies this year as a result of weakening consumer demand and a depletion in the stocks of unsold goods.
"They are on the optimistic side," said C. Fred Bergsten, a former United States Treasury Under Secretary, who runs the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
"The I.M.F. is basically relying on a big improvement in Japan, Latin America and Russia, and continued growth in Germany to sustain the world," Mr. Bergsten said. "If anything goes wrong in any of those engines, it will have to downgrade its projections again."

HEADLINE: Limelight Goes Dark as Crackdown on Drugs Reaches Major Clubs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
For more than a decade, the Limelight has been an enduring fixture on the fickle night life landscape, a place where rockers, ravers and drag queens mingled to techno or whatever the latest musical trend. This week, it has been dark and eerily quiet.
After a drug raid early Saturday, the police padlocked the Chelsea club, one of Manhattan's longest-running dance spots. But today, its lawyers are headed for court in an attempt to reopen it. 
 "We're hopeful that we will be able to reopen very soon," said Alan M. Klinger of Stroock Stroock & Lavan, which represents Peter Gatien, the owner of the Limelight as well as two other trendy nightspots, the Tunnel and Palladium. Mr. Klinger said there had been meetings with city officials in the last several days to reach an agreement before a hearing this afternoon before Justice Fern Fisher-Brandveen of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
On Friday, undercover officers, some in suits, mixed with the crowd looking for drug sales. By closing time, about 5 A.M. Saturday, as the last patrons drifted out into the morning chill, officers had arrested three people, including an employee, and charged them with selling marijuana. City lawyers then obtained a court order closing the Limelight, where they said drugs were "rampant" and sold in an "open and notorious manner."
The Limelight was the first major nightclub to be shut down under the Police Department's Civil Enforcement Initiative, which began as part of a community policing effort in 1991 and uses department lawyers to close drug dens, problem bars, brothels and other locations under the nuisance abatement section of the city administrative code.
The program was also used to close 122 nuisance locations in 1994 and is expected to be enlisted to close another 150 by the end of the year.
At the Limelight, a cavernous, mazelike club in a deconsecrated church at the Avenue of the Americas and West 20th Street, undercover police officers reported making 17 drug buys involving 23 people on five occasions since early August and seeing cocaine and other drugs being sold, sometimes in full view of employees, sometimes by employees themselves.
Mr. Klinger said Mr. Gatien, who opened the Limelight 13 years ago, has never condoned drug use or been cited for drug violations in any of his clubs. He said Mr. Gatien had believed "effective internal procedures" were in place at the Limelight to deter the use or sale of illegal drugs there.
But, court papers filed by the city said, "Despite the open and notorious sale, possession and use of cocaine and other illegal controlled substances inside the premises, it is apparent that the owner and operators of the subject premises have made no effort to stop or even curtail the rampant illegal drug activity taking place."
Law enforcement officials said the raid on the Limelight was only the beginning of a crackdown.
"This is not the only club where this kind of activity is rampant," said Arlette Hernes, an executive in the office of Robert Silberling, a special narcotics prosecutor. "The investigation into the whole subculture is one that will continue."
Some 20,000 patrons parade each week through the 140-year-old landmark building, once the Episcopalian Church of the Holy Communion. This summer the Limelight and Palladium were the first New York clubs to introduce "foam" parties, in which patrons dance in waist-high foam. Some have said they take LSD, Ecstasy and marijuana to enhance the experience.
Robert F. Messner, managing attorney of the Police Department's civil enforcement initiative, said the strategy is to use civil law to close down a business, exerting economic pressure so the owner changes conditions in order to reopen for business.
"Our goal is not to close the Limelight forever," Mr. Messner said. "It's a feature of New York City and it is a positive thing for a community to have night life. What we want is to change it from a place that has rampant drug use to one that has no active drug life."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain for Fourth Day; 30-Year Yield at 6.43%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices extended their rally through a fourth consecutive session yesterday as reports showing subdued economic growth failed to change expectations of another cut in interest rates.
"We're priced for the Fed to lower rates sometime later this year," said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston. 
 Market participants, however, remain focused on the September employment report, which will be released tomorrow. And many traders were absent yesterday because of Yom Kippur.
The light volume exaggerated price swings, as the 30-year Treasury bond rose 10/32 , to 10528/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.43 percent, from 6.45 percent on Tuesday.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that its index of leading economic indicators in August showed an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent, in line with economists' expectations and reversing a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in July. And a separate Government report showed factory orders climbing 2.6 percent in August, more than offsetting the revised 1 percent decline in the previous month.
Eight of the 11 components in the leading indicators index contributed to August's increase. But analysts noted that the component that measures the change in prices for raw materials declined, holding down the rise in the overall index.
"The movement of the leading indicators component series indicates that the economy is growing, but not fast enough to generate any inflationary pressures," said Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a New York research and analysis firm.
Still, Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, said the broad gain in the index prompted some hesitation in the bond market, even though the numbers came within expectations. The raw materials component, he noted, is often volatile.
The factory orders report for August encouraged the bulls, Mr. Chan said, because orders for nondurable goods rose only two-tenths of 1 percent, just below expectations. He noted, however, that credit markets failed to surge because the factory-orders report also pointed toward moderate growth in the future. For example, the report showed that the ratio of inventory to shipments narrowed, suggesting "that the manufacturing sector may soon start igniting some of its engines as it moves beyond its inventory overhang problems," Mr. Chan said.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the long bond's recent move to lower yields "supports my belief that the positive fundamental backdrop of low inflation will continue and ultimately bring those yields down to 5.75 to 6 percent level."
Mr. Dwyer said he saw the market staying within its current trading range, with an upward trend in prices, in advance of the September employment report.
In bond futures trading yesterday, the December bond contract closed just off its day's high of 1159/32 , at 1158/32 . Mr. Alexy of CS First Boston said that "most people are looking for the market to sell off ahead of employment number."
"The fact of the matter," he added, "is we go into most of these big numbers either pinned up against resistance levels or pressing support. The market is not given much breathing room, and it is forced to make big bets."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Higher New York fares won't help cabbies or improve service.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THIS is one of those only-in-New York stories that holds wider lessons for all of us. Yellow cab fares in the city have not changed in almost six years. Over the same period, the cost of living has crept up by more than 20 percent. And while hard data on cabbies' incomes do not exist, few apparently take home more than $7 an hour after expenses.
Time for a rate increase, right? It's only a matter of common sense, argues the licensed cab owners trade association, which is gunning for a 27 percent increase. 
 But common sense is not always good economics. If the taxi business is in financial straits, asks Edward Rogoff, a professor of management at Baruch College, why do licenses to operate them trade freely for record amounts -- upward of $170,000? And if adequate numbers of drivers are available at current compensation, is there any reason to believe the proposed fare increase will end up in their pockets rather than in those who control the limited supply of licenses?
"This is the most unjustified rate request in memory," Mr. Rogoff concludes .
New York City has 50,000-plus cars with drivers for hire. However, just 12,000 of them are "medallion" yellow taxis with the legal right to pick up passengers on the street. That's the same number as in 1937. Some taxis are driven by the owners of the medallions. But most taxis most of the time are under lease for a flat fee, about $85 for a 12-hour shift. Owners maintain the vehicles, but drivers pay for gas. To break even, a driver must earn roughly $100 a shift. And to net a mere $7 an hour, his revenues must approach $200.
Figure that the owner of a medallion keeps a taxi leased an average of 50 half-day shifts a month, or roughly 600 shifts a year. Lease revenues thus exceed $50,000 annually or, conservatively, $35,000 after repairs, depreciation, fleet management and inspection costs. It is thus no real shock that medallions trade for the price of a Rolls-Royce.
But why haven't rising ownership costs and growing indirect competition from radio-dispatched livery services and illegal "gypsy" cabs lowered the price?
Two factors continue to work in the medallion owners' favor: strong demand for street-hail taxis in Manhattan, and a seemingly bottomless supply of drivers willing to work long hours in difficult conditions for peanuts.
Christopher Lynn, the new chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, sees the drivers' wretched pay as potential justification for a fare increase. However, since the market for drivers is competitive and medallion owners are not saints, it is hard to see why any portion of the new revenues would go to the drivers.
If nothing changes but the fares, the profits will be reflected in medallion values, much the way changes in property taxes are reflected in land values rather than rent. Moreover, there is widespread agreement that the level of service has deteriorated.
What, then, are the plausible choices for the commission? Mr. Rogoff suggests that the taxi regulators could upgrade the minimal level of service by insisting on better-maintained cars and more competent drivers. Owners would have to pay higher wages to accomplish those goals. But taxi commissioners have been promising such changes for decades. While fare increases have been nominally tied to service improvements, plenty of clunkers still cruise the mean streets. No mayor, it seems, has ever been willing to pay the political price in challenging the power of organized medallion owners.
Another option would be to increase the number of medallion taxis, making it easier to find a cab at rush hour and inducing some cabs to cruise the outer boroughs, where they are rarely found today. Politically unrealistic as it may be in a city where rent control and other gross market restrictions are considered untouchable, Mr. Rogoff suggests "a long-term commitment to getting out of the medallion system entirely." He proposes a gradual increase in the number of medallions that would allow owners who have recently invested in medallions enough time to recoup much of their cost.
Absent that possibility, what's left? Benign neglect. The commission need not reward medallion owners with higher fares. Nor should city officials, hard pressed to provide basic services such as schools and parks, continue to enforce the yellow cabs' monopoly on cruising for passengers.
Such an approach is hardly ideal by anybody's reckoning. Medallion owners would still reap rich rewards from their monopoly until inflation eventually eats away their surplus. Taxi riders would have to endure inferior medallion service, or take their chances in hailing nonlicensed cabs.
But, then, "ideal" has never really been part of the New York City political vocabulary.

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: Italy Faces Itself

 BODY:
A remarkable criminal trial now under way in Palermo has riveted an Italian public already shaken by a procession of corruption scandals. In the dock is Giulio Andreotti, a seven-time Prime Minister who has been at the center of power in Italy since 1947. Prosecutors charge that Mr. Andreotti was for decades the covert ally and protector of the Sicilian Mafia. Others assert that he may even have connived in political murders.
All charges in the 2,000-page indictment are denied by the 76-year-old Christian Democrat, whose supporters insist he is in fact being framed by the Mafia, in reprisal for his role in promoting mass trials of its thugs a decade ago. Determining the truth may take years of testimony from more than 500 prospective witnesses, among them two former U.S. Ambassadors to Italy, two onetime Foreign Ministers and the past Secretary General of the United Nations. 
 Yet the case involves far more than the reputation of a master politician. What is truly being tried is the entire political order in postwar Italy that Mr. Andreotti personified. As the chief cobbler of successive coalition cabinets, he ranged the political spectrum, working first in the 1950's with the right, then with Socialists and more recently even with the long-despised Communists until the old system (and his party) sank terminally in scandal.
Did Mr. Andreotti also broker a deal with Salvatore Lima, the late Mayor of Palermo, to obtain Mafia votes for Christian Democrats? As some assert, did he kiss the cheeks of a fugitive Mafia boss in Sicily in a telltale gesture of collaboration? Did he acquiesce in the killing of a too-inquisitive journalist in Rome and fail to take actions that might have prevented terrorists from killing Aldo Moro, a political rival?
Some of these accusations may spring from the fevered backwaters of a conspiratorial political culture. It is to the great credit of Italy's judicial system that all charges are to be ventilated in an open courtroom, and apparently broadcast by radio from the same maximum-security bunker in which Palermo's Mafia trials were conducted in the 1980's.
A certain worldly cynicism has long been Mr. Andreotti's political hallmark. "Power is a disease one has no desire to be cured of" is one of his maxims. "See all, tolerate much, correct one thing at a time" is another. He attained the pinnacle in an era when Washington urgently sought to keep the Italian Communist Party, Western Europe's largest, from sharing national power. This gave Mr. Andreotti extra leverage, which he astutely exploited.
So it happened that for most of the postwar years, a single unwieldy party has dominated Italian politics, arguably providing a stable framework for real economic growth. But permanent power also led to corruption, profligacy and credible charges of criminal complicity with the Sicilian underworld. Mr. Andreotti deserves his day in court, but few will mourn the demise of the system that he came to embody.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Uncool in School: Dress Code Debate

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 4

 BODY:
Marc Peyser tries not to be too uncool about the way teen-agers dress. Hey, when he was in high school he was suspended for wearing shorts. He lets his son wear oversized, baggy pants, the kind that make some nervous adults cross the street and others want to grab the waistband and pull up.
"They don't look good, but I've learned to live with them," he said of his son's baggies. "You don't want him to have to look different from his friends." 
 But Mr. Peyser, a member of the Board of Education in this city of corporate headquarters, has had it with baseball caps. Kids have this hat thing, but he and some other school board members have a respect thing, and hats in class, they say, do not show respect. So Stamford has joined a growing debate over school dress codes across the country that asks, in the era of grunge, whose schools are these, anyway?
No hats, no bare midriffs, no see-through clothing, no underwear showing, no vulgar T-shirts, no sunglasses, no beepers, no cellular phones, no oversized jewelry that can be used as weapons: the more or less standard list of prohibitions that Stamford is considering for its high schools is a world away from dress codes in the 60's, when blue jeans were banned and skirts had to reach the knee.
But those who are unhappy about the new dress codes -- including principals and teachers, as well as students and civil-liberties lawyers -- ask whether they are really necessary, or whether they reflect the general unease of adults about the state of education, society and teen-agers.
In Stamford, for example, the proposed dress code is supported by adults like a group of executives who visited one of the two public high schools and later complained to the district superintendent about students dressed more for the street corner than the office.
"If you haven't been part of big groups of teen-agers, it can be very overwhelming to walk into a high school," said Anthony Markosky, the principal of Stamford High School. "And I've got 1,900 teen-agers."
In meetings with school board members, students complained that the board was concerned about image instead of education. The image Stamford wants to avoid, in big high schools where wealthy students from suburban neighborhoods mix with teen-agers from housing projects and immigrants from dozens of countries, is that of the inner city.
"People don't understand what happens when you have a corporate culture," said Robert King, a board member. "It's not enough any more that downtown Stamford looks good. We want everything to look good, and that includes the schools. We know some people put their children in other schools because Stamford schools are supposed to be unsafe." In Stamford High's cafeteria on a recent day, however, almost no one was wearing anything except caps that would violate the proposed dress code. The Board of Education had just backed away from banning hats, leaving it to teachers to allow hats in their classrooms or not, a practice that has been in effect for years.
Most of the dress code, in fact, does not address the dominant fashion, which progresses from casual to grunge to hip-hop: loose-fitting to baggy jeans and pants, covered to the knees by T-shirts, sweatshirts or flannel shirts. One boy, perhaps five feet tall, swaggered in pants so baggy the crotch was at his knees. Another wore a bandanna: forbidden by the new code, forbidden by the old code. For there has always been a dress code.
"We've had one all along but it was never published," Mr. Markosky said as he patrolled the corridors. "If you're conspicuous by your dress, you can be referred to the office.
"I tell the kids, when you get up in the morning and look in the mirror, ask yourself, 'If I'm walking down the hall and Mr. Markosky sees me, what's he going to do?' If you think he's going to send you home, change your clothes."
So far this year, under the old, informal dress code, Mr. Markosky has sent six students home, all girls, for wearing tank tops and revealing shirts. "I've got eight million things I should be dealing with, and dress codes are about 84th on my list," he said. "It's never been a problem."
He stopped to look in on an economics class taught by Joe Carpentieri, who wore a ponytail, a Harley-Davidson T-shirt, denim shorts to his knees and deck shoes without socks.
"He's one of my best teachers," Mr. Markosky said. "Would he be a different teacher in long pants? I'd take a whole school full of people like him."
One problem with setting standards is that the Supreme Court has ruled that students have rights of free expression. Fashion, in most cases, can be regulated only if it disrupts education or poses a safety or health issue. So distractingly short skirts can be banned, earrings ordered off in gym class, gang colors prohibited.
In the last few years, school districts in Connecticut, Virginia, Texas and California have also acted to ban hats and offensive T-shirts, citing a 1986 Supreme Court decision that acknowledges the right of schools to teach citizenship.
"It used to be that you had to show disruption," said Thomas B. Mooney, a Hartford lawyer who represents school boards and teaches a course on law and public education at the University of Connecticut Law School. "Now you have this additional idea that we have the right to create a school environment free of vulgarity."
A problem with setting standards, however, is enforcing them. Outside Fort Worth, teachers in the Birdville School District began the year measuring girls' skirts to enforce a four-inch-above-the-knee rule. Four hundred students were told to change their clothes on opening day, and mothers of tall girls complained that stores did not sell skirts long enough for their daughters to comply.
In Connecticut, one principal encountered an angry mother when he sent her daughter home for wearing an obscene T-shirt, but not for the reason he expected: the girl had stolen her mother's shirt.
Students are quick to seize on these inconsistencies.
"If you say we can't wear something because parents don't like it, well, they're not all your parents," Mike Pietrantuono, a Stamford High School sophomore, said at a meeting of the school board's student liaison committee. "If your parents don't care if you wear a Budweiser T-shirt, that's it."
In fact, the student committee supported nearly all of the proposed dress code, objecting mainly to the hat ban, and pointing out that a ban on wearing outside coats in school would not work because lockers were not secure. The school board, which will vote on the code on Tuesday, has amended it to address their concerns.
Most of the students on the committee, like most of their classmates, were not wearing caps. It was the principle they defended, though one not easily enunciated. The question of why caps are so important usually evokes a blank look.
"Just everyone throws them on," said Brad Tippett, a senior with a Notre Dame cap on backward. "Maybe they don't want to comb their hair."
Mr. Peyser knows the "bad hair day" excuse, as he calls it. But he cannot believe that a majority of the board has accepted it, backing away from what he considers the most important part of the proposed code, the ban on caps. "We had a fine opportunity to create a positive image by doing something not very complicated, and we blew it by caving in to a few people," he said.
Others, however, suggest that what prevailed was common sense.
"It's just another fad," said William C. Newman, a lawyer with the Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts. "It's really a generational problem, because some people see it as a sign of disrespect, when I think many kids would be surprised to be told they were being disrespectful."
"It's part of the youth uniform," he said. "It's not disrespectful. It's not anything. It just is."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Joe Carpentieri, making his fashion statement in shorts and ponytail, teaching economics at Stamford High School. (pg. B7); Anthony Markosky, the principal at Stamford High School, observing a student meeting on the dress code. (Angel Franco/The New York Times) (pg. B12)
 
"It's Image and Education in Stamford."
 Under a proposed dress code at Stamford High School, 17-year-old Brad Tippett would be in compliance, with the possible exception of his baseball cap. The code would give teachers the option to ban caps in their classrooms. The fashion debate is a far cry from the 1950's and 60's, when blue jeans were banned and skirts had to reach the knee. Other things illegal under the code: cellular phones, sunglasses, underwear showing.
