HEADLINE: In Vermont Fashioning Furniture And Lives

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

DATELINE: THETFORD CENTER Vt.

 BODY:
DOWN dirt roads that go nowhere, past fields of goldenrod and trees brushed with the fiery palette of autumn, the sound of Garrett Hack's wood saw is the only sign that one of Vermont's talented furniture makers is nearby, eking out a living.
There is little about Mr. Hack's operation that he doesn't do himself, from air drying his own wood to building his own workshop. But he's one of a new breed of furniture maker, not a colonial craftsman who learned his skill in his father's workshop. Despite the promises of his Princeton University degrees in civil engineering and architecture, Mr. Hack prefers farming, tending a milk cow, calves, horses, chickens, a big garden -- and his sawdusty business. He and his wife, Hope Haviland, a weaver who just gave birth to their fourth child, also teach their children at their home here in eastern Vermont. 
 "I love working the land," Mr. Hack said. "It's a satisfying counterpoint to working with wood -- the macro versus the micro. It gives me balance in my day."
A state that is home to the laid-back, nature-loving Ben & Jerry's and whose only Representative, Bernard Sanders, is known to all simply as Bernie, is hospitable to those seeking alternative ways of life. These furniture craftsmen -- there seem to be no women -- say that they are more interested in the quality of their lives than in money. It's a good thing, too, since most of them are forced to stitch together livelihoods using other skills in order to stick with their first love -- making furniture.
Vermont's young furniture makers are one example of the current resurgence in American crafts, as well as of the industrialized world's ever-increasing appreciation for the handmade. Unfortunately, the prices for their work seem high, particularly to many consumers whose notions of furniture manufacture are based on instant delivery and factory-direct savings. And despite the satisfaction of the work, the income can be meager.
It took Mr. Hack's parents, who live in Greenwich, Conn., 10 years before they approved of his way of life. Last year, they finally bought a piece of furniture from him. Today his orders are steady enough so he doesn't have to worry. His "effective income," Mr. Hack said, exceeds $30,000, because he provides his own food and heating.
Most craftsmen would be happy with $20,000 to $30,000 a year. And they would like it if their business were steady. Craftsmen find it harder and harder to charge by the hour: prices are generally by the piece. Rick Schneider, whose degree in physics plays an important role in his work, produced a soaring circular wooden staircase for a new house in New York. It cost the owners $46,000, but if it had been priced by the hour, it would have been more than $50,000, he said.
So, this new breed of furniture maker is often forced to moonlight. Robert Chambers, a furniture maker who lives in Corinth, is famous among Windsor chair aficionados for the quality of chair he makes. But he teaches to make ends meet. Others build houses, restore antiques, refinish furniture. One works as a forest ranger; another is a writer. Most grow their own food. Their wives work, some as potters and weavers, others in the business, as finishers or bookkeepers.
There are between 75 and 80 furniture workshops in Vermont with three to four employees, said Kari Berg, a former natural resources marketing specialist with the Vermont Department of Economic Development. Half of them are one-person operations. The larger shops gross between $100,000 and $300,000 a year; one-person shops gross less than $100,000 -- often much less.
Making furniture was not the first career choice for most. Among those wielding planes and sandpaper are a former film editor and a former copy-machine salesman. Mr. Chambers, for instance, has a master's degree in mechanical engineering and worked in the aerospace industry for 11 years. "The idea of making weapons of destruction caught up with me," Mr. Chambers said.
Robert Gasperetti, who lives and works in Danby Village, has three people working for him now making Shaker and Craftsman-inspired furniture. But when he began, it was in a girlfriend's garage, handcutting dovetails with gloves on, warmed by a kerosene heater.
"It's difficult to make a living doing this, and after I had a fire, in 1991, I had to decide whether I wanted to continue the struggle," he said. "But I need the satisfaction of creating things. I could not don a tie and go to work for someone else."
Neither could his furniture-making peers. They greet visitors and customers in cutoff jeans with sandals, boots or running shoes, an occasional gold earring and a fair number of ponytails. Most are in their 40's. A few of the men were born in Vermont, but most have come because they like the social climate.
"This is a place where you can be who you are," said Bruce Pyle, a maker of exquisite Shaker chairs and boxes who lives in Pittsford. "It's a great place to raise children -- it's safe. We know everyone in town. People help each other out when they are in trouble."
Kate Carmel, the senior curator at the American Craft Museum in New York, describes this as a "post-60's community, a kinder, gentler place." "The politics are liberal," she said. "It's the story of the craft world throughout the 20th century -- setting limits on urbanization and mechanization, the elevation of human skill as opposed to mechanized and undifferentiated. Most of the craft people need space. They use the local woods. They love being outside of the pressure of big business. There are many sons and daughters of middle-class professionals."
Ms. Carmel says that in order to sustain a couple, the furniture maker must have two or three people working for him. Some do; some have even more, but many work alone. Solo woodworking is, as Ms. Carmel notes, "a very hard business."
And just what constitutes "handmade" is a matter of opinion. There is no agreement about the point at which it becomes production furniture. Some say the cutoff point comes when a shop has more than five people and produces multiples.
For Mr. Chambers, who works alone, the difference between what he makes and what a production shop with several people turns out is the difference between a hand-knitted sweater and one made in a factory. "The machine-made is perfectly stitched," he said. "The handmade has subtle irregularities that add up to a more interesting unity."
Yet, the individual craftsmen have a grudging admiration for those who are able to make more than one piece of furniture at a time. "People don't understand the price or skill difference between what we do and production pieces," said Chris Bretschneider, who did graduate work in physics and who now works with three other furniture makers in Shoreham. One of Mr. Bretschnei der's associates, Ellen Markel, was the only woman furniture maker in Vermont. Last month, she moved to California.
"I think some of the resentment comes because places that sell the furniture and take a commission take the same percentage whether we make it or it comes out of a production factory," Mr. Bretschnei der said. "But the production people are probably making more money."
What Mr. Pyle resents is the implication that production furniture is handmade. "It's not," he said, citing a shop with nine workers. "The production worker signs his name when it comes off the assembly line. They suggest they are like us. I don't mind their making furniture. I resent the marketing."
Dan Mosheim, who has two employees (one is his wife) works alongside them in his shop in Arlington in order to preserve the integrity of the pieces that bear his name. "So much is lost in the drive to reduce the price," he said.
There is also a certain defensiveness among those who make more than one piece at a time. Matthew Burak, who has a showroom in Danville, took great pains to explain that the power tools used in his shop were made to his specifications and based on the hand tools he had been using. "At first we cut every mortise and tenon by hand," he said. "As we've grown we've copied equipment, high-tech equipment that copies the handwork. I've done what I can to streamline."
For a while his business had a dozen wholesale accounts, but Mr. Burak decided against developing a large production company. "The quality of the furniture would absolutely suffer," he said.
Jack McGuire, who owns McGuire Family furniture in Isle La Motte with his wife and two of his children, doesn't make furniture anymore. "I have gone beyond the point of wood and furniture," he said. "The challenge of the business has taken over."
Linda McGuire said, "it's stupid to spend an hour cutting a mortise by hand with a chisel when you can do it with a router."
"One hour versus three or four minutes," she said. "You are adding cost to the product that doesn't need to be there."
There are certainly other luxuries that individual craftsmen can enjoy that are not available to a production workshop. They can be very selective about the wood they purchase. Mr. Chambers, for example, prefers to work with unseasoned green wood because it produces tighter joints as it dries and expands. Mr. Hack air-dries his because it makes the colors sparkle.
Many of Vermont's furniture makers excel at reproductions, but those who try to step free of the past have a much harder time. No independent-minded design stars have yet emerged -- no Wendell Castles, no George Nakashimas.
Which hardly surprises Ms. Carmel. "The reproductions of Shaker, Craftsman and American 18th-century furniture, in modernized form, is what New England is all about," she said.
"There's room for self-expression within traditional craft," Mr. Pyle said. "Just because I am working in traditional style doesn't mean I'm duplicating what was done before. I've updated it to make it more contemporary, to make it more for the way we live today but still maintain the esthetic that made it appealing." In the end, it's the sheer joy of creation and the promise of the materials that count. "Absolutely iridescent," Mr. Gasperetti said as he ran his hand lovingly over pieces of unfinished curly maple.
"When this is polished up," he said, "it dances. Gosh -- it's surreal."

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
Russian Makes Met Debut In Season's First 'Aida'

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
However one may feel about Sonja Frisell's monumental seven-year-old production of Verdi's "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera, the company's biggest problem with the work of late has been at the center, casting the title role. Indeed, in some seasons, Dolora Zajick has so far outshone her partners that the opera might well have been renamed "Amneris."
Ms. Zajick returned to the production in her usual good form on the second evening of the Met's season on Tuesday. But this time she faced a worthy adversary as Aida, Nina Rautio, a Russian soprano heard in New York four years ago as Tatyana in the Bolshoi Opera production of Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin." 
 Ms. Rautio was preceded by a considerable reputation in the role, and she in no way disappointed, pouring out a rich, lustrous tone. She produced strength and vulnerability in equal measure and in quick succession, pulling back smoothly on the fiendishly difficult top notes in the Nile scene. When her voice caught slightly on one of them, a listener was inclined to blame her partner, Kristjan Johannsson, singing Radames.
Once focused on a note, Mr. Johannsson can fill the house with a bright, clarion call. But focus does not come easily or quickly, and anything below a full shout tends to become woolly.
In his company, it would seem, any singer might force, and Ms. Rautio fell into the trap at moments. Still, her grasp of the role and her ability to project it placed it commandingly at the center of a gaudy production that was inclined to distract.
Two other singers made promising Met debuts: Carlo Colombara, strong except at the bottom of his range as Ramfis, and the economically named Deng, stentorian but a bit stiff as the Messenger.
Ms. Zajick supplied her expected sturdy Amneris, with wonderfully full tone at the bottom, though through the early going much of her work in the low register was lost in the orchestral ruckus stirred up by Christian Badea. Her last act was a superbly calculated tour de force.
The rest of the cast was adequate or better: Stefano Palatchi regal as the King, Timothy Noble properly gruff as Amonasro and Christine Goerke ethereal as a priestess.
But when it came to sheer understated beauty, a rare treasure in this opera, nothing could touch the exquisitely balanced pianissimo work of the male chorus in the second scene of Act I. True, the playing of the woodwind choir in the ensuing dance music came close.
The Met Titles did their work unobtrusively and seemingly without hitch on their second night out. But perhaps a way can be found to make use of their downtime, to instruct listeners in the fine points of audience response. One should not, for example, applaud at the crucial break on an unstable, unresolved chord (a dominant seventh in third inversion, if you must know) before Amneris inaugurates the cry "Ritorna vincitor!" The disruption takes all the starch out of the combative revelry.

HEADLINE: Futures Trades Could Explain Daiwa Mystery

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
To futures traders at Lehman Brothers, there was something about Toshihide Iguchi -- they called him "Toshi" -- that just didn't make sense.
At the end of a hectic day, Mr. Iguchi, a bond trader at the New York branch of Daiwa Bank Ltd., would often execute a complex maneuver used mainly by those specialized traders who seek to exploit small mathematical discrepancies in the market. But these moves did not seem to fit with Mr. Iguchi's other trading. Although he certainly made large bets, he was ostensibly a straightforward short-term investor betting on the direction of interest rates. 
 Last week, the motive for the strange trades suddenly became clear, when Daiwa announced that Mr. Iguchi had racked up $1.1 billion in losses over the last 11 years.
"When I saw in the paper what he did, I finally understood what happened," said one trader who had done business with Mr. Iguchi at Lehman.
The effect of those unusual trades, known as basis trades, was actually to help him hide losses in the futures market, say three traders who worked at Lehman in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
This is a new twist. In fact, Mr. Iguchi appears to have covered his tracks so well that in its initial statements, Daiwa and the United States Attorney's office, which has brought fraud charges against Mr. Iguchi, said he had only traded United States Treasury bonds and had done no trading in futures or any other financial instruments known as derivatives.
Derivatives are fast and easy ways to make big bets on financial markets and have been involved in some of the biggest financial disasters of recent years. Indeed, futures contracts were behind the downfall of Britain's Barings P.L.C. when a trader in Singapore lost $1.3 billion trading futures on the Japanese stock market.
What's more, according to these traders, who spoke on condition of anonymity, those complex trading maneuvers by Mr. Iguchi could well explain a central mystery: how he was able to tap into the bank's long-term bond holdings, and its holdings of customers' bonds, to cover his mounting losses.
One key point is that Mr. Iguchi was in charge of both bond trading and some record-keeping. That dual position -- which was specifically criticized as unsound by the Federal Reserve in 1992 and 1993 -- appears to have allowed him to hide even more of his trading tracks. The basis trades apparently permitted Mr. Iguchi to move the futures losses into bond accounts, which he controlled more directly, these traders said.
In its fraud charges against Mr. Iguchi, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said he had forged a statement from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation showing $4.5 billion of bonds held in Daiwa's account, when the account contained only $3.4 billion. It is that $1.1 billion gap that is said to represent Mr. Iguchi's trading losses.
But it is still unclear how much of Daiwa's problem came from any futures trading by Mr. Iguchi. While traders at Lehman said he traded both bonds and futures there, traders at other firms remember him mainly for bond trading.
Daiwa, based in Osaka, Japan, has already been harshly sanctioned by Federal and New York State regulators, who have virtually closed down its trading activities in New York.
And it faces further investigation in Japan. Bloomberg Business News reported today that Japanese financial authorities had begun an on-site investigation of Daiwa offices. The Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, began searching Daiwa headquarters in Osaka and the Ministry of Finance its Tokyo branch, Keizo Tsujiyama, manager of corporate communications at Daiwa, was quoted as saying. Bloomberg also said Sumio Abekawa, Daiwa's chairman, had quit as head of the Kansai International Airport Company to focus his energy on the bank's review.
Representatives of Daiwa, Lehman and the United States Attorney's office declined to comment on any futures trades by Daiwa.
The root of Daiwa's problem may lie in Japan's rush to get a financial foothold abroad. In the mid-1980's, at the peak of Japan's financial rise, Japanese banks and brokerage firms were eager to establish themselves among the leading players in New York and London financial markets. Mr. Iguchi was one of a handful of traders who burst on New York's bond market, buying and selling in huge quantities. Even at the time, this appeared to be more bravado than skill; most successful traders are as discreet as possible.
Still, Mr. Iguchi was one of the most active and profitable customers for Lehman's futures desk, Lehman traders said. "It was a hot, hot account and was handled with kid gloves," one trader said.
On the phone, another trader said, Mr. Iguchi was arrogant and abrupt, but no more so than many others on Wall Street, generally not considered the most polite of places. Those who met him, though, described a shy, reticent man with a slight build, who often talked about his personal problems -- like an unpleasant divorce.
What Mr. Iguchi did not talk about, but what appears to have been eating away at him, was a disastrous record as a trader.
In a rambling 30-page letter that Mr. Iguchi sent to the president of Daiwa in late July admitting the losses, he described a tale of woe.
"He must be the worst trader in the world," said someone who has read the letter. "Every time the market moved, he was on the wrong side. He said he saw people making big-time money at other banks and he wanted to trade big as well."
In the letter, filled with guilt and self-criticism, Mr. Iguchi blames his worry about his trading losses for the end of his marriage, said the person who read the letter, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He said he was ready to confess at least four times, but then he didn't," this person said.
Lehman traders said that they could not tell whether Daiwa was making or losing money over all on its trading, but the that unusual basis trades appeared to be a way to cover up his losses in futures.
"We would say, 'Is Toshi making or losing money?' " one trader recalled. "If he was losing money, he would do a basis trade."
Because of the peculiarities of accounting for basis trades, such a maneuver could make it look as if he had lost no money on futures.
In a basis trade, someone sells futures and receives the actual commodity -- in this case bonds -- on which the futures contract is based (hence the name "basis"). The trade could also work in reverse: trading bonds for futures.
Because they involve a swap of things of theoretically identical value, basis trades do not have to be sent to the brawling floor of the Chicago Board of Trade to be executed at the current market price. Instead, a dealer like Lehman can merely set the price anywhere between the day's high and low.
This flexibility appears to have allowed Lehman -- legally -- to get Mr. Iguchi out of some jams. On days when Mr. Iguchi bought futures that subsequently fell in price, he would call Lehman and do a basis trade, selling futures and receiving bonds. And he would ask that the price be set at the day's high.
That way his futures account would look as if it had broken even or even made a small profit. Of course, these moves did not erase Daiwa's losses; they merely moved the losses from the futures account to the bond account. That is because the cost of creating the appearance of selling futures at a good price was that Mr. Iguchi had to buy bonds at the same inflated price.
And this could have helped Mr. Iguchi avoid having his losses detected. In futures trading, traders must cover losing positions every day with cash margin payments.
In bond accounts, by contrast, cash moves only when bonds are bought and sold. Moreover, Daiwa said Mr. Iguchi had forged not only account statements but also trade confirmations and other records in the bond account that hid his actions.
For a dealer like Lehman, swapping bonds and futures is not improper. This tactic is used, say, to move profits to the following year to delay taxes, or to postpone embarrassing losses.
Traders familiar with Mr. Iguchi's futures activity also suggested that his unusual basis trades could also clear up another mystery: how he was able to tap into the bonds that Daiwa kept at Bankers Trust.
Under normal circumstances, a custodian like Bankers Trust releases such bonds only when it is notified that cash has been received for them. These payments have to be accounted for on the books of the institution, creating various auditable paper trails.
But with basis trades, the custodian transfers the bonds to a futures firm and receives a notice that they were part of an exchange for futures.
Traders who did business with Mr. Iguchi suggest that by using bonds in the custody account to cover losses from futures trading, Mr. Iguchi could well have found an easy way to keep his activity undetected. Other futures-trading experts say that while this is plausible, Mr. Iguchi could have found other ways to tap into the bonds in the custody account.

HEADLINE: Ready for a New Direction

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
Having experienced a similar situation, I wholeheartedly agree with the comments and conclusions in "Lost Jobs, Found Directions" (Sept. 7). In 1992, I was laid off from a financial-management position at age 55 after 23 years with the company. Fortunately, I had expanded my skills beyond that corporate job over those years, teaching part time. 
 After one year of unemployment, I was able to secure a full-time teaching position at Reading Area Community College in Reading, Pa. While this required a change in our family's life style -- i.e., an apartment in Reading for myself during the school year, and approximately half of my former salary -- I would not change my present situation for double my former corporate salary. There is much more to life than trying to impress most corporate bosses.
 
RICHARD M.RISINIT
Rye, N.Y.

HEADLINE: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE OVERVIEW;
Confront Crises, Pope Urges Nations

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
Speaking to the world from the rostrum of the United Nations and to America from the goal line of Giants Stadium, Pope John Paul II yesterday called on the nations -- and the United States in particular -- to live up to their moral responsibilities and confront the crises of faith that cloud this century's last decade.
"It is one of the great paradoxes of our time that man, who began the period we call modernity with a self-confident assertion of his coming of age and autonomy, approaches the end of the 20th century fearful of himself, fearful of what he might be capable of, fearful of the future," the Pope told the United Nations General Assembly. 
 The Pope's first full day in the United States, marked by gray skies and intermittent rain, began with the central purpose of his visit, a speech at the United Nations on the banks of the East River, and ended on the other side of the Hudson, before a wet but jubilant crowd of 83,000 people at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands.
There, the Pope intensified his call to America to preserve its openness to immigrants and its social support of the poor.
On past trips to the United States, he has focused on calls to resist liberalizing trends on abortion and sexual mores. And though he passionately championed the rights of the "unborn child" last night at Giants Stadium, his most striking statements to Americans over the last two days have been warnings against what he perceives as a rising movement to limit immigration, reduce subsidies for the poor and the weak, and retreat to an isolationist position.
"Is present-day America becoming less sensitive, less caring toward the poor, the weak, the stranger, the needy?" the Pope said at the stadium in his most strongly worded challenge of the trip so far. "It must not!
"Today, as before, the United States is called to be a hospitable society, a welcoming culture. If America were to turn in on itself, would this not be the beginning of the end of what constitutes the very essence of the American experience?" [Excerpts, page B10.]
For the first time on this trip, the Pope returned to his condemnation of abortion -- an issue that has been one of the fixed points of his Papacy -- calling on Americans, and Roman Catholics especially, to defend the "unborn child" as they have defended the rights of other defenseless groups in the past. A failure to do so, he said, casts a "moral blight" on society, and marks a break in the American civil rights tradition.
The rain did little to dampen the pageantry at the Mass at Giants Stadium, where the Pope, riding in his bulletproof Popemobile, made a slow tour of the crowd before returning in a triumphal procession to take his place at the red-carpeted altar, decorated with banks of yellow chrysanthemums.
On the field level, soaked spectators leaned over fences, and from the upper decks, there were cheers of "John Paul II, We Love You." Some spectators performed the wave, a cheer common at athletic events.
The service was itself a celebration of America's ethnic diversity, with choirs singing in Spanish, English and Polish, and the Pope himself switching at one point from English into Spanish.
The theme of the Pope's homily was the inclusion of those he said are sometimes shunned by society, and it was reflected at the Mass. The Most Rev. Theodore E. McCarrick, the Archbishop of Newark, said, "We are an immigrant church and still receive newcomers from all over the world."
The Mass was the last event of the day in a papal schedule that began at 9 A.M. with a four-hour visit to the United Nations. He met with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, with the United Nations General Assembly president, Diego Freitas do Amiral, gave two speeches, including one to the staff of the United Nations, and listened to a multinational choir of young children as they sang, "Let There Be Peace on Earth."
Throughout the day, the Pope's travels brought pockets of gridlock to various parts of New York City as the police closed streets to allow his motorcade pass. The Pope had been scheduled to take a helicopter from Manhattan to Giants Stadium, but the rain and low cloud cover forced him to travel through midtown and the Lincoln Tunnel during the evening rush to reach New Jersey, backing up traffic for 20 minutes or more.
After the Mass, he returned to Manhattan through the tunnel.
At the stadium in New Jersey, security appeared to be tight, though somewhat inconsistent. People sitting on the field and in the lower tier seats had to pass through metal detectors and be subjected to hand-held scanners and drug-sniffing dogs. Those destined for the upper level seats, however, faced less scrutiny.
The high point of his visit, timed for the eve of the United Nations' 50th anniversary celebration, was his address to the General Assembly, his second in 16 years and the third by a leader of the Roman Catholic Church.
The Pope stressed that he came not as the leader of a temporal power "nor as a religious leader seeking special privileges for his community," apparently in response to critics who have questioned his ceremonious reception by a s;ecular organization.
The Pontiff's speech was largely an appeal to the organization to live up to its own potential, to "rise more and more above the cold status of an administrative institution, and to become a moral center where all the nations of the world feel at home."
The Pope presented the United Nations with the new challenge, calling on it not only to defend universal human rights but also what he called the "rights of nations."
He defined these as the rights of national or ethnic groups to defend their culture, language and traditions, not necessarily as separate sovereign states but as part of an identity which should be held to be inviolable.
"A study of these rights is not easy, if we consider the difficulty of defining the very concept of 'nation,' which cannot be identified a priori and necessarily with the state," he said.
But in protecting these rights, the Pope argued, the international community -- through the United Nations -- might succeed in stemming the tide of nationalism and tribalism that has recently erupted into war in the Balkans and Central Africa.
"A presupposition of a nation's rights is certainly its right to exist: therefore no one -- neither a state nor another nation nor an international organization -- is ever justified in asserting that an individual nation is not worthy of existence," the Pope said.
Autonomy for ethnic groups, whether political or cultural, has been a central issue for much of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union in the period since the collapse of Communism. Pope John Paul, a native Pole, has followed the rise of nationalism in the region closely, particularly after it exploded into war in the former Yugoslavia.
"Unhappily, the world has yet to learn now to live with diversity," he said
Despite the globalization of the world economy and culture, the Pope said there had been a "powerful re-emergence of certain ethnic and cultural consciousness, as it were, an explosive need for identity and survival, a sort of counterweight to the tendency toward uniformity."
"This is a phenomenon," he said, "which must not be underestimated or regarded as a simple leftover of the past."
Only by recognizing and even protecting ethnic diversity can harmony be found among nations, he said. And the United Nations, he added, could serve as the model "family of nations," with rich, strong countries looking after the interests of weaker, more vulnerable ones.
The twin theme of diversity and unity seemed to blend together yesterday as the Pope switched from the halls of the United Nations to the mix of cultures and languages on display at Giants Stadium. For many people there, the near-deafening cheers that greeted him reflected the hope that he would leave unity in his wake.
"He came at the right time," said Jennie Koziol of Beach Haven, N.J.
"There is so much division. He brought all of the people together."

HEADLINE: THE POPE'S VISIT: THE REIDYS;
For Some Students, Internalized Excitement

SERIES: One Catholic Family: A Day in School

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
The traffic was already snarled and the police were out in force when Owen Reidy walked into Regis High School on the Upper East Side yesterday morning. But Owen was thinking about his Latin test, his math test and his economics test and not the hoopla surrounding the arrival of Pope John Paul II at the United Nations.
"Maybe someone will pray that I get a good grade on my Latin test," he muttered, as he shuffled into school early for the 8:50 examination. The 14-year-old freshman, who travels to school by express bus from the Riverdale section of the Bronx, has a hard time waking up in the morning, and this rainy day was no exception. He was looking forward to the long weekend ahead. 
 The Pope's visit means a shortened school week for Owen, his Regis classmates and students at many other Catholic schools. They have today off to prepare for an early start tomorrow morning, when many will go to Central Park for a 9:30 A.M. Mass to be celebrated by the Pope.
But inside Owen's school yesterday, it was business as usual, with no palpable sense of excitement. Regis, a competitive school named for a 17th-century Jesuit priest, encourages its students to internalize their faith.
So instead of wearing Pope buttons or waving banners, the 523 young men at Regis went routinely to classes and the library, shot hoops in the gym and played Frisbee in the lunchroom .
"It's more of a personal thing," Owen said of the Pope's visit. "People don't really talk about it, except to find out who's going to Central Park."
But although few wear their religion on their sleeves, they revealed a genuine excitement about the Pope's visit, when pressed.
"It's getting like more exciting that he's actually here," Owen said yesterday morning. "I can feel his presence."
Rodnev Lapommeray, a freshman like Owen, said he was going to the Central Park Mass with the fervent hope that the Pope would say something about Haiti, the native land of his parents. Mike Moro, a senior, received good-luck wishes all day because he is reading a petition in Japanese at the Mass tomorrow.
The Rev. Kenneth J. Gavin, the president of the school, said the relative absence of Pope mania represented a conscious effort.
"You cannot be a Catholic in New York without the Pope's visit affecting you," he said, "but the Pope is part and parcel of our whole life. The very things the Pope talks about -- being a pilgrim of peace or issues of poverty -- are issues that are shot through our curriculum all the time. To do it any other way would be grandstanding."
Owen had another explanation for the calm: "It's only been on TV since yesterday and we had three tests today and had to study. This is a hard school."
He and his two sisters -- Anne, 17, and Marcia, 16 -- will be among the tens of thousands at the Central Park Mass. About 80 of his fellow students will be there, too. He is an altar boy at St. Gabriel Church, where he went to elementary school, and he will go to Mass with the youth group from the church.
At 14, with his black shirt hanging down over his khaki pants, he has a flippant manner, complaining that his sisters still try to boss him around even though he is now the oldest boy at home in a family of nine children. His brothers Tim and Bill are away at school.
They are a close family, though, these nine children in seven different schools, all of the older ones thrilled that the man who embodies their faith is in New York.
Owen, who comes from a comfortable family and attends school in an affluent area, said he hoped the Pope would talk about homeless people. He said he felt bad about the people he saw on the streets of the city and hoped that maybe the Pope could help.
"Maybe he could get a more conscious effort on that," he said. "It's getting colder. There are soup kitchens but they're two miles away. It's hard, two miles away. It's not like the people around here, living in their big two- and three-story apartments."
He then switched into his comic-relief mode, insisting that some of the upperclassmen were making comments about the Pope's "$700 shoes" and his extensive security.
"I guess it doesn't matter what you say but what you do," he said a few minutes later. He went to the lunchroom to throw a Frisbee, then ran to catch the bus home.

TOMORROW: With the Reidys at the Pope's evening prayer service at St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers.

HEADLINE: Clinton Signs Order Easing Travel, Aid and Money Transfers Between U.S. and Cuba

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton has signed an executive order that would ease restrictions on travel to Cuba by Cuban-Americans, academics, artists and members of the clergy, and allow American relief agencies and human rights groups to greatly expand their work in Cuba, Administration officials said today.
In a speech on Friday, Mr. Clinton also plans to announce measures that would allow American and Cuban undergraduates to study in each others' countries and American news organizations to open bureaus in Cuba, the officials said. Mr. Clinton signed an executive order instituting the changes on Tuesday as part of a broad new effort to increase the flow of democratic ideas into Cuba, they added. 
 The order calls for the removal of travel restrictions for Cuban-Americans who want to visit seriously ill relatives in Cuba. The President also will allow Western Union to set up offices in Cuba to help Cuban-Americans send money to their relatives for travel to the United States once they obtain visas.
In August 1994, when thousands of Cubans attempted to sail to the United States, President Clinton ordered sanctions against Cuba to punish Mr. Castro for allowing the migration. He restricted travel by academics and barred Cuban-Americans from sending money to relatives. Now these restrictions are being relaxed.
Several officials suggested the new policy might be the first step toward a further opening toward the island, although they insisted Mr. Clinton would not only uphold the 33-year-old trade embargo on Cuba but strengthen it. The executive order also calls for the hiring of more officials to enforce the embargo, the officials said.
Several American officials, citing Fidel Castro's past ambivalence toward increased contacts between Cubans and Americans, suggested that the Cuban President might block many of Mr. Clinton's new initiatives from taking effect.
Mr. Castro, upon learning of the plan several weeks ago, pre-emptively denounced the Administration's moves as efforts to subvert socialism in Cuba.
Several conservative Cuban-American groups were quick to attack the changes, saying they could help prop up Mr. Castro and create warmer ties between the United States and Cuba.
Ramon Cernuda, the Miami representative of several Cuban dissident groups, said of the executive order: "On the one hand it will be applauded for humanitarian and family reasons by many in the Cuban-American community. The criticisms will come from those who want to maintain a climate of isolation and deprivation in Cuba."
Andres Nazario Sargen, leader of Alpha 66, which has long sought to overthrow Mr. Castro, attacked the new policy. "I'm not surprised," he said. "They've been planning this all along. They are pacifists and they're seeking an understanding with Fidel but he cedes only those things that do not damage him, and this will not damage him."
A senior American policymaker rejected such criticisms. "This policy will not sustain Castro unless you think more independence, more political activity, more Cubans having the ability to feed themselves and create jobs for themselves outside of the Government system helps Castro," the official said.
And Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, founder of Cambio Cubano, an exile group that favors negotiations with Mr. Castro, described Mr. Clinton's action as "very positive." Cuba, he said, "has taken steps forward, mostly in the economic realm but also in the political, and this is the required calibrated response. It undoes the president's error in making a deal with the far right."
In defense of lifting the restrictions, Administration officials said the freer atmosphere is intended to nurture independent thinking and activities outside the Communist system to help prepare Cuba for the eventual arrival of democracy there.
"We're trying to get more channels of communication open," said a senior State Department official. "We believe from what we saw in Eastern Europe that it helps to aerate the society. We're trying to help the Cuban people prepare for the inevitable transition."
The Administraton insisted that it was not changing its policy, but merely following the dictates of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992, which calls for more people-to-people contacts with Cuba as well as tightening the economic noose around Cuba.
Several Cuban-American lawmakers complained that the Administration failed to consult them on the changes. But Administration officials said they discussed the policy beforehand with several members of Congress, with Florida officials and with a few Cuban-American leaders.
In the past, Cuba has refused to let American news organizations open offices on the grounds that successive Administrations would not allow Prensa Latina, the Cuban news agency, or other Cuban news groups to open bureaus in the United States.
Adminstration officials indicated that once several American news organizations won permission from Mr. Castro, then the United States would give the green light for Cuban news organizations to open bureaus.
A spokeswoman for The New York Times said it was "highly interested" in opening a bureau in Cuba. But the spokeswoman, Nancy Nielsen, added that The Times "would need to learn as much as we could about the working conditions that would be made available to us."
CNN, The Miami Herald and more than a dozen other American news organizations have asked permission from Cuba to set up bureaus.
Mr. Clinton's new policy will allow American relief organizations to do far more for Cuba than what they are allowed to do now: provide food and medicine. These groups will be allowed to work with independent Cuban organizations to build housing, set up businesses and conduct job training.
Jose Cardenas, the Washington representative of the Cuban-American National Foundation, said his organization was studying the order, but that Mr. Clinton appeared to be reacting to a recent House vote to further tighten the embargo on Cuba.
Administration officials said that under the new policy, Cuban-Americans could apply to send up to $300 every three months to relatives who are suffering from disasters.

HEADLINE: MEXICO PAYS BACK PART OF U.S. LOAN

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Mexico announced today that it had recovered enough from its crippling economic crisis to repay, a few weeks ahead of schedule, $700 million of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from the United States this year, a gesture that represents as much a political payback as an economic one.
The offer comes just days before President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico is scheduled to fly to Washington and New York for a series of meetings, including one with President Clinton next Tuesday. Mr. Zedillo will use the trip to argue that the American-led rescue was a success even though Mexico remains mired in a punishing recession that is severely restricting the sale of American goods here. 
 The early repayment of a portion of the $12.5 billion that Mexico has borrowed from the United States, and the payment of more than $400 million so far in interest on the loans without missing an installment, also provides Mr. Clinton with ammunition to silence critics who had warned that Washington would never recover the money.
In an impressive show of spin control, officials on both sides of the border portrayed the early repayment as proof that Mr. Clinton had been right when he stood by Mexico after Mr. Zedillo, in office for just weeks, was forced to devalue the peso abruptly, setting off Mexico's worst financial crisis in a decade.
In February Mr. Clinton served as the broker for $50 billion in international economic first aid for Mexico, including $20 billion in loans from the United States. He did so after the United States Congress refused to go along with a plan to give Mexico $40 billion in loan guarantees.
"Today's decision sends a positive signal to the financial markets that the tough financial measures Mexico has taken are succeeding and the American taxpayer is being paid ahead of schedule," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued in Washington.
In an interview today at Los Pinos, the Mexican equivalent of the White House, Mr. Zedillo said, "This is a proof that the money lent was put to good use, that it was not a giveaway -- it was an investment made by the U.S Government." He said that the United States was getting a return on its investment in the form of $468 million in interest that Mexico had already paid.
Mr. Zedillo said the timely American helping hand also prevented "a major crisis in international financial systems."
Looking relaxed and speaking in English, Mr. Zedillo stressed that the short-term American loans had helped Mexico withstand a savage run on Mexican finances staged by international investors after the peso devaluation. He also placed blame for the crisis squarely on previous Mexican administrations.
"Many of the problems that Mexico has had in the past regarding inflation, unemployment and financial collapse have to do in their origin with irresponsible fiscal policies," Mr. Zedillo said.
To obtain the $700 million, Mexico sold five-year bonds worth the same amount in German marks in European markets today. Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said this morning that Mexico was trying to replace the short-term United States debt with longer-term bonds at more favorable rates. The refinancing transaction would be similar to those undetaken by homeowners to lower their mortgage payments and to spread them out over a longer time.
The Mexican Government's austere recovery plan of higher taxes, lower spending and strict controls on credit has restored some degree of investor confidence.
The Mexican stock exchange responded enthusiastically to the early repayment announcement today, surging more than 3.5 percent, and the exchange rate remained steady at about 6.5 pesos to the dollar.
The payment announced today is a first installment on $2 billion in short-term United States debt that comes due on Oct. 31. In effect, Mexico is repaying part of the 90-day loan three weeks ahead of schedule. The United States will renew the remaining $1.3 billion in loans for another three months, American officials said.
The $700 million will be used to repay $350 million that Mexico borrowed from the United States Treasury and $350 million from the Federal Reserve, American officials said. Mexico has made it clear that it does not plan to request any American money beyond the $12.5 billion it has already borrowed.
The bonds sold today are the third major international debt issue that Mexico has made since July, representing the country's return to the international credit market far sooner after the crisis than most economic analysts had expected.
Mr. Ortiz said Mexico planned to offer more bonds on the international market in order to make other repayments to the United States.
The American rescue package has set off intense debate in the United States and Mexico about the relationship between the two countries. Even as the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement has brought the two economies closer together, fears of illegal immigration and huge job losses have at times seemed to make the two countries strangers living in the same house.
"I think one has to distinguish all the fog that is used periodically in political fights both in Mexico and the United States from the long vision that has been shared by the two Governments over the last few years," Mr. Zedillo said.
He said he expected the Mexican economy to grow between 3 percent and 4 percent in 1996, after shrinking this year.
The Goverment's own economic recovery medicine has been effective but harsh. About a million Mexicans have lost their jobs this year because of sharply higher inflation and sky-high interest rates. Taxes have increased too, eating away the buying power of already-low Mexican salaries, which have reached their lowest level of buying power in history, according to Mexican university studies.
But Mr. Zedillo gave no indication of letting up on the controls. "Some people believe there is a tradeoff between the state of people's well-being and the state of public finances, but they're wrong," Mr. Zedillo said. "If we want economic growth and if we want to create jobs and improve the well-being of our people, we have at all times to conduct a responsible fiscal policy."
Mexican officials said Mr. Zedillo and Mr. Clinton would discuss issues like immigration, drug control and the extradition treaty between the two countries, but that no important announcements were expected to be made.

HEADLINE: Sluggish Income Figures Show Gains for Some

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Many of the Americans who suffered most in the economic downturn of the early 1990's -- black households, single mothers and young adults -- saw their incomes grow the fastest as the economy expanded briskly last year, the Census Bureau announced today. But overall, middle-class incomes continued to show virtually no gains, and the earnings of full-time workers dropped slightly.
The most striking gains were made by black households, which saw a 5 percent rise in median income after adjusting for inflation. 
 At the same time, the number of Americans living in poverty dropped by 1.2 million last year, to 38.1 million, the first decrease in five years, the Census Bureau reported.
Economists said poor Americans had benefited as unemployment fell and companies paid part-time and full-time workers alike to work longer hours. "This is the economy doing, finally, what it ought to do," said Douglas Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research group.
Yet middle-class incomes showed little recovery from the drop that began with the recession of 1990-1991. In 1992 and 1993, many economists referred to the recovery as a recovery without jobs, as companies expanded their output by working their employees harder rather than expanding their payrolls. More recently, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has warned of a recovery without raises because steady growth has not found its way into many middle-class pocketbooks.
The poor and the rich made the biggest gains last year, with average incomes going up by slightly more than 2 percent, while the middle class saw its average income go up by a little less than 1 percent.
Census officials refused to speculate on the reasons for the income changes, other than to note the strength of the economy. Mr. Reich said today that many families appeared to be working longer hours. Hourly wages stayed about the same.
The inflation-adjusted median income for American households edged up to $32,264 last year, from $32,041 in 1993, but the Census Bureau said that change was not large enough to be statistically significant. Half of American households earn more than the median, and half earn less.
While black households, single mothers and young adults fared best last year, their incomes still remained lower, after adjusting for inflation, than they were in 1989, the end of the last economic expansion. The most affluent fifth of the population has become more prosperous since then, while the other four-fifths of the population has lost ground, said Robert Greenstein, the executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group here.
In recent years, the Census Bureau's annual release of income and poverty figures has become the basis for an increasingly vituperative debate in Washington over whether welfare programs should be cut and whether the rich are getting an excessively large share of the nation's prosperity. The debate has continued despite warnings by Census Bureau officials that their income statistics may not be the best basis for it because those figures do not take into account taxes, many forms of Government assistance and regional differences in the cost of living. The poverty line, $15,141 for a family of four last year, has faced similar criticism.
Democrats and Republicans alike seized on today's figures to buttress their positions. Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, said that the Clinton Administration's economic policies had helped economic growth and had contributed to a reduction in the percentage of Americans in poverty, to 14.5 percent last year from 15.1 percent in 1993.
But Senator Connie Mack of Florida, the Republican chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said that Government policies were to blame for the general stagnation of middle-class incomes.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Says Investing Cash Will Pay Off

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 5

 BODY:
To defend itself against Kirk Kerkorian, the Chrysler Corporation is preparing to argue to its big investors that it can create better returns by spending some of its cash reserve on new products and new strategies rather than on a special dividend or share repurchase, a company executive said today.
Chrysler is girding to counter proposals by Jerome B. York, Mr. Kerkorian's chief strategist and a former chief financial officer at Chrysler, for the company to share more of its cash with stockholders. Mr. York plans to present his ideas to the company in about two weeks. 
 But Chrysler believes it can make a strong case to investors not to tinker with its financial plan, which calls for a cash cushion of $7.5 billion to take advantage of opportunities that arise and to see it through the next downturn. Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, is preparing to meet with big investors this month, perhaps before Mr. York makes his proposals.
Chrysler executives have already met with the company's institutional investors three times since November, said the executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Eaton is expected to tell the investors, as he suggested in a speech in New York on Tuesday, that Chrysler has plans that will do more to enhance shareholder value than simply handing out cash.
For example, Mr. York has said that by increasing the leverage of Chrysler's financial subsidiary, the company could free up $500 million for investors. But Chrysler executives said the company was looking at using that money -- which they say is closer to $300 million -- to support more leasing. That would not provide a one-time jolt to the share price, they said, but would generate a better return for years to come.
Chrysler might also use some of the cash to finance a new car or truck not already accounted for in its capital budget, or to pursue a joint venture abroad.
 Chrysler said it would be considering these moves regardless of Mr. Kerkorian's goading. But people in Mr. Kerkorian's camp scoffed at the company's assertion.
Mr. Kerkorian, who holds more than 14 pecent of Chrysler's stock, failed last spring in a bid to buy the company. Since then, he has been cagey about his intentions, saying only that he thinks Chrysler has hoarded too much cash.
Some Chrysler executives still appear to believe that Mr. Kerkorian's true goal is to force the company to buy him out at a premium. Mr. Eaton suggested in his speech that was the case, and he declared that Chrysler would "not entertain" paying greenmail.
In a "Dear Bob" letter to Mr. Eaton today, Mr. Kerkorian said, as he has before, that he would not accept greenmail. He requested that Chrysler's board amend the company's bylaws "to insure that no shareholder receives any benefit for its shares that is not equally available to all shareholders."
 In a statement, Chrysler said, "Mr. Kerkorian's suggestion is unnecessary, since the board's position is clear: we have no intention of paying him or anyone else greenmail."
Chrysler, which had $6.9 billion on hand at the end of the second quarter, wants to preserve a substantial cash cushion because auto makers can burn through enormous amounts of money -- not only in bad times but even in fair to middling times.
As the economy softened between last December and July, for example, Chrysler used about $3 billion of cash, officials said. The introduction of a new line of mini-vans, increased rebates and other incentives, and a cut in production reduced Chrysler's cash on hand to less than $5 billion at one point in July.
Mr. York says he thinks Chrysler needs only a $5 billion reserve, the target he set before departing as the company's chief financial officer in 1993. Although Chrysler has grown since then, it has also become more efficient, has developed more popular products and has bolstered its credit rating, he points out.
His record as a finance officer at I.B.M. after he left Chrysler suggests that Mr. York is more likely to urge the auto maker to buy back a large amount of stock than to call for higher dividends. While he was at I.B.M., the company did not raise its dividend, but announced two stock buybacks of $2.5 billion apiece.
Stock buybacks tend to be more popular among pension funds and other big institutional investors -- whose proxy votes Mr. York may need -- because dividends are taxable.
Chrysler's stock slipped 25 cents a share today on the New York Stock Exchange, to $51, while the shares of Ford and General Motors rose.

HEADLINE: Sales Rise at Discounters And Department Stores

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Retailers in September managed to shake off the worst of the summer doldrums, which had been widely attributed to the oppressive heat in August.
Department stores and discount stores showed modest increases in sales, but the results were not shared by retailers in the hard-hit specialty apparel and specialty hard goods sectors, in which some stores suffered their worst month of the year. 
 The mixed results, analysts said, do not presage a spending spree any time soon.
"We think consumer spending will be constrained the rest of the year," said Richard N. Baum, vice president of investment research at Goldman, Sachs. The level of current installment credit is up year over year, Mr. Baum said, but not at the rate that it rose last year. "Since consumer spending is in large part driven by levels of installment credit, it means our spending power is less than it was a year ago."
Jeffrey M. Feiner, the senior retailing analyst for Salomon Brothers, said: "Consumers remain quite cautious. However, we expect a favorable Christmas, particularly for stores catering to upper-income consumers whose net worth has significantly benefited from the rise in the stock market."
Other analysts have estimated that Christmas sales will rise 3 to 5 percent from last year's lackluster performance.
The Salomon Brothers index of same-store sales rose 3.3 percent in September, following a 1.5 percent gain in August and a 3.9 percent gain in September 1994. The Bloomberg composite same-store index for September rose 3.2 percent from the previous year, following a 1.3 percent increase in August. The index rose 3.7 percent last September. Same-store sales, regarded as the most reliable measurement, are those at stores open at least a year.
At the Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target discount stores, same-store sales were up 9.1 percent from the corresponding period last year. Sales at Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Kmart Corporation, the nation's biggest and second-biggest retailers, were up 4.2 percent and 4.1 percent, respectively. Nevertheless, Kmart said it expected earnings in the third quarter to be "well below" last year's 4 cents a share.
The Kohl's Corporation led the mini-resurgence among department stores, with same-store sales up 14.2 percent. Federated Department Stores Inc. posted a 4.9 percent gain, while Sears, Roebuck & Company's sales were up 4.5. But sales at Broadway Stores Inc., formerly Carter Hawley Hale, plummeted 17.4 percent, and those at the J. C. Penney Company fell 0.9 percent, the second consecutive monthly drop.
By contrast, in the specialty apparel sector, same-store sales fell 21 percent at Charming Shoppes Inc.; 10 percent at the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation; 5 percent at Lane Bryant, a unit of Limited Inc., and 3.3 percent at Talbots Inc., a subsidiary of the Aeon Group. But even in that vulnerable category, all was not gloom and doom. Sales at Ambercrombie & Fitch, also a unit of Limited, rose 15 percent. At Eddie Bauer, a unit of Spiegel Inc., they gained 5 percent, and at Gap Inc. they rose 3 percent, the company's biggest increase in four months.
"Retailing is still marked by essentially the same trend evident in most of 1995," said Mr. Feiner of Salomon Brothers. "Consumers are going to department stores, given their broader merchandise mix."
Sales at Neiman Marcus, the upscale retailer owned by Harcourt General Inc., gained 5.5 percent last month. "While people today, and especially women, are in a spending downturn for fashion apparel," said Kurt Barnard, who publishes Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, "sales are excellent at the very, very upscale stores, where the wealthy sector shops."
In the specialty hard goods sector, same-store sales fell 13 percent at the Hechinger Company, 10.1 percent at Builder's Square and 7 percent at the Bombay Company last month.
The striking exception in that sector was stores that sell computers, audio equipment and electronics. Sales at the Audio King Corporation were up 19 percent, and they rose 8 percent at both the Tandy Corporation and Circuit City Stores Inc.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gained for the fifth consecutive session yesterday, as investors continue to believe that slow economic growth and low inflation will give the Federal Reserve the leeway it needs to cut short-term interest rates in the near term.
Prices were given a lift by the release of reports on jobless claims and housing completions. For the week ended Sept. 30, the number of first-time benefit claims climbed 6,000, to 341,000, up from the prior week, but slightly less than the 345,000 that had been expected. And August housing completions fell 7.9 percent, to a 1.2 million unit annual rate, the lowest level since September 1993. 
 The 30-year bond rose 6/32 , to a price of 1062/32 to yield 6.42 percent, down from 6.43 percent on Wednesday and the lowest since Feb 11, 1994, when it was 6.40 percent.
Traders speculate that the Commerce Department's August report on housing completions may also have brought investors back into the market to cover short positions, which would partly explain the momentum in the early session. The market firmed after the release of the report.
But the bulk of the day's gains, traders said, were tied to technical trading and follow-through buying after the December futures contract peaked above key resistance levels on Wednesday. The December bond contract ranged as high as 11522/32 yesterday and as low as 1152/32 before settling at 11511/32 .
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, saw yesterday's bond market as preparing itself for today's deluge of monthly labor statistics. "While the rise in initial claims for unemployment insurance was less than expected today," he said, "the differential was meaningless because it was so small.
"Tomorrow's payroll number will certainly go a long way toward determining the near-term direction of the market," he added.
Mr. Fine said expectations center on a rise of 150,000 in the nonfarm payroll number, with expectations extending from a rise of 75,000 to a rise of 225,000.
"My own feeling is that some of the August gain seen last month captured jobs that ordinarily would show up in September, which is why my forecast of plus 125,000 is toward the lower end of the range," he said.
But in a broader sense, Mr. Fine said, the decline in bond yields over the last week is primarily the result of two factors. "First, the continued mixed nature of economic releases suggest an economy that is growing only moderately on a trend basis," he said, "and as a result is not likely to engender any increasing inflationary pressures."
"Second," he said, "there is growing belief that Congress, at some point, will enact legislation that will noticeably reduce the budget deficit. Both of these forces in concert will likely result in another Fed easing of 25 basis points before year-end, although the timing of the next Federal Open Market Committee action could well be influenced by potential debt ceiling snafus."
The committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, next meets on Nov. 15. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, a New York money-management firm, said that there was great anticipation today's employment number would be soft, with a gain of less than 100,000. "It's important to note that expectation has been coming down for the past several weeks," he said. "So the weaker the economy, so goes the bond market in the other direction."
Mr. Battipaglia thought yesterday's housing completions report may have had more impact than the jobless claims, suggesting that the housing sector was still uneven. "Although mortgage rates are at 25-year lows, it has not sparked a breakout for the housing industry," he noted.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Sunglasses are in fashion, and so is the stock of Sunglass Hut.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne 

 BODY:
WHEN Andre Agassi showed up at the United States Open tennis tournament in his spiffy clothes and Oakley goggle-style sunglasses, he exemplifed a trend that has turned Sunglass Hut International, a retailer of fancy sunglasses, into a stock market darling.
Cool and hip are words generally used to describe Sunglass Hut's products -- Revo, Armani, Oakley and other top-of-the line sunglasses that are sold through more than 1,400 locations, from shopping malls to airport kiosks. With an average ticket of $80 for sunglasses, the company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., is being regarded by analysts as the next retail "category killer," a type of store, like Home Depot, Barnes & Noble and Staples, that sells one category of products and wipes most competitors off the map. 
 Sunglass Hut, however, has almost no competition. What is distinctive about the company is that it has taken an ordinary commodity -- sunglasses -- and forged a new distribution network and, in doing so, promoted the sales and design of new high-end products. Sunglasses, it turns out, are turning into a fashion statement not unlike sports footwear, in which popular sports and entertainment celebrities take something mundane and functional and turn it into a high-margin, sought-after and pricey status symbol.
"Sunglass Hut is perhaps the most interesting company I cover," said David A. Buchsbaum, an analyst with Southeastern Research Partners in Charlotte, N.C. "They have no significant competition, they have an extremely talented managment, and consumers are responding to their offerings. I originally recommended the stock at $17 and change and it's a long way up since then."
Sunglass Hut, which trades on Nasdaq, has been selling between $45 and $50 a share recently and closed yesterday at $46.625, unchanged. Just five months ago, it was hovering in the mid-$20 range, which means it doubled in value during the summer sunshine. Some of the company's numbers are eye popping. Most analysts estimate a growth rate of 35 percent a year; since going public in June 1993, the stock has appreciated 300 percent, compared with the return on the Russell 2000 index of small companies of 33 percent. Merchandise margins are an extremely high 60 percent because so little real estate is needed to sell so expensive a product.
Despite this stellar performance, many analysts say the company is only beginning to realize its potential and say there is more upside left -- although not perhaps in the immediate future given the run-up in price to date. They praise Sunglass Hut's recent strategic moves, which include merging with Sunsations, its closest rival, and entering the prescription eyeglass market with a new line of Sunscriptions sunglasses and new Eyex stores, which will sell high-end regular prescription eye glasses. Sunglass Hut is also setting up shop in Federated and Sears department stores and has been a hit overseas, from sports-minded Australia to cloudy England. Because Sunglass Hut buys in such volume, it can offer its Ray-Bans and Seregenti glasses at prices more attractive than other eyeglass chains, which tend to sell cheaper styles anyway, or than mom-and-pop operations.
An aging population plus the sunglasses-as-fashion trend will provide the underpinnings of future growth, analysts say. "The technology of sunglasses is really changing," said Thomas Filandro, an retailing analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, a research firm. "Look at all those baseball players, sitting in the dugout, wearing Oakleys. They are not going to allow their batting average to go down or their fielding to become poor just to sponsor an item. And how many young boys watching baseball now want Oakleys?"
Analysts are hard pressed to come up with shadows on this bright long-term outlook. Overexpansion, a lessening of interest in expensive sunglasses, an economic downturn, or a dark and miserable winter could all be bad for the company. But sunny weather willing, the company so far has been able to avoid missteps in its expansion strategy -- just yesterday, in fact, Sunglass Hut reported strong third-quarter same-store sales gains, with a 13 percent rise.
Most analysts expect that the company's high price-earnings multiple of 70 will fall in the next year to a more earthbound 35 or so. But they say a rise in earnings will keep the stock in the $50 range in the near term and even higher for the long run. A planned offering of 1.5 million new shares from the Sunsations merger is considered too small to hurt the current stock price.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Daiwa Officials Said to Consider Quitting

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 5

 BODY:
As Japan's regulators opened their investigation of the Daiwa Bank, the institution's top two executives were reported today to have suggested that they would resign to take responsibility for $1.1 billion in losses incurred by a Japanese-born trader in the New York office.
The disclosure last week that Toshihide Iguchi, a top bond trader, had secretly incurred such huge losses over 11 years at one of Japan's large commercial banks has increased worldwide anxiety over Japan's banking troubles. Confidence in the banking system has been undermined by the fact that Mr. Iguchi was able to avoid detection for so long, although the markets initially shrugged off the incident because the losses would not severely impair Daiwa's capital base. 
 "We have to worry because the scandal was disclosed at a very bad time," Japanese news reports quoted the Vice Finance Minister, Kyosuke Shinozawa, as saying.
Japanese authorities are likely to feel particularly embarrassed by Daiwa's disclosure when they meet Saturday in Washington with finance ministers and central bankers of the Group of Seven industrial nations, which includes the United States and Japan.
The United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, has reportedly indicated that Japan's economic woes and its banking system, hobbled by at least $500 billion in bad real estate loans, will be an important topic.
Japanese news reports said that Daiwa's president, Akira Fujita, and its chairman, Sumio Abekawa, were to step down, though no specific dates were given. A Daiwa spokesman refused to comment on the reports.
In its initial disclosure, Daiwa portrayed the losses as the unfortunate consequence of Mr. Iguchi's behavior, saying he falsified records of his trading activities and fooled his bosses and auditors. Critics say the Ministry of Finance and other banking regulators did not adequately inspect Daiwa's banking activities.
Some Japanese press reports have said that another trader and other Daiwa employees were either involved or aware of the mounting losses. Other reports have said that between the time Daiwa apparently learned of the possible misconduct and the time it publicly disclosed it, the bank was able to sell part of its stock holdings -- at a nice profit -- to help cover the $1.1 billion loss.
Officials at Daiwa and the Ministry of Finance refused to comment on any of these reports.

HEADLINE: New York City's Capital Needs

 BODY:
With its crumbling bridges, collapsing schools, crowded prisons and deteriorating public buildings, New York City faces major infrastructure investments in the next several years. The resources available for the task are shrinking, however, because of the city's budget problems. Two decades ago New York's last fiscal crisis led to a long and disastrous period of low public investment. To avoid a recurrence, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani must find other ways to meet the city's needs.
Mr. Giuliani has twice announced cutbacks on capital spending. Part of the reason is that the city is approaching the constitutional ceiling on the amount of bonds it may issue in relation to the value of its real estate, which is declining. Another factor is the challenge by City Comptroller Alan Hevesi to Mr. Giuliani's proposal to raise capital funds by selling New York City's water system. 
 The Mayor has made one promising suggestion, about to be adopted by the City Council, to meet the problem. That is to create a new Department of Design and Construction to save money by completing capital projects more rapidly. The Mayor's office estimates that perhaps 15 percent of the cost of each project can be squeezed out if the current multi-agency bureaucracy is consolidated. City Hall also believes that further money can be saved from standardized practices, new technology and better coordination of building projects.
The Mayor should then redouble his effort to repeal the Wicks Law, which requires the letting of many small construction contracts instead of one big overall contract. Mr. Giuliani estimates that this change alone could save $1.4 billion in construction costs over the next 10 years. Additional savings might be achieved if the city took a tougher bargaining position with construction unions, demanding concessions in much the way it has demanded savings from the municipal labor force.
The current capital plan calls for investing $40 billion over the next decade. It is an enormous sum that is still probably inadequate to the city's needs. In the last several months, the capital budget of the city received far less publicity and scrutiny from the City Council than the budget for day-to-day spending on welfare, health programs and other city services. The Mayor and Council need to address the issue in public so that New Yorkers can be told about the choices involved.
For example, many of the city's construction projects could be scaled back or stretched out. Mr. Hevesi has suggested that $1 billion for housing programs in the next five years be distributed over a longer period of time. Similar stretchouts might make sense for port renovations and other economic development projects that, however worthy, should be of lower priority than renovating schools and basic infrastructure like roads and bridges.
The temptation to let these problems slip is great, since politicians would rather maintain services that people depend on now than spend money that will not be appreciated for years. But a fiscal crisis is no time to jeopardize the safety and well-being of the next generation of New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Takes a Dive on Doubts About Central Bank Intervention

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday as doubts grew that central bankers would intervene in foreign-exchange markets to support the dollar.
Currency traders squared their positions and sold dollars as they awaited United States economic data on employment today and the end of a meeting of ministers and officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations in Washington. 
 "It was a rout," said Kevin Lawrie, a vice president at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "Maybe some of the expectations from earlier in the week have dissipated."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 98.58 Japanese yen from 100.94 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also fell to 1.4205 German marks from 1.4349 marks and to 1.1389 Swiss francs from 1.1531 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5854 from $1.5821.
Despite the broad selloff, traders remained wary of the possibility that central banks could come into the markets to buy dollars if the Group of Seven reaffirmed a commitment to the dollar this weekend.
But such intervention is unlikely early next week because of the Columbus Day holiday in the United States on Monday and a national holiday in Japan on Tuesday.
The dollar rose earlier this week as traders tried to protect themselves from intervention after the Group of Seven meeting this weekend. On Wednesday and yesterday, traders changed their minds.
The dollar dropped on profit taking and doubts that the United States would bother to intervene unless the Japanese addressed their banking troubles.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said this week that the United States hoped the Japanese would put together a plan to strengthen its banking system, which faces $400 billion in bad loans.
Without steps by Japan to act on its flagging economy by bolstering the banks, the United States might drop its efforts to weaken the yen. A weaker yen would help Japanese exporters and the economy as a whole.
"We are putting another demand on the Japanese, and maybe the market is perceiving that they are not going to be able to do it," said Peggy Reed, a currency vice president at Credit Agricole.
