HEADLINE: It's Not News to Experts That Consumer Price Index Is Inflated

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Not So Quick on This Budget Elixir" (editorial, Sept. 30) states that I believe I've "uncovered a politician's dream: huge spending cuts and tax hikes that are too technical to understand or much notice." 
 The issue here is the Government's use of changes in the Consumer Price Index as a proxy for changes in the cost of living. You describe me as in a "rush" to alter present practice. I respectfully demur. Thirty-three years ago I became Assistant Secretary of Labor for Policy Planning and Research. I was nominally in charge of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which computes the C.P.I. The statisticians were tolerant and friendly. They undertook to teach me to the extent I was teachable. They even shared professional confidences.
One of these was that the Consumer Price Index overstates the cost of living. I have kept a watching brief on this matter ever since.
There are a range of reasons, the simplest being the "substitution bias." The index prices a fixed market basket. If the price of meat goes up, the cost of the basket goes up. But if consumers switch to poultry, the change in the basket cost does not accurately measure the change in the cost of living. I will omit the "hedonic regression method" for estimating the value of quality change as somewhat too sensational. Suffice that there are many upward biases (some downward), and they are no mystery.
You state the Bureau of Labor Statistics "already knows about the potential biases and is updating its procedures." No, no, no. About every 10 years it reconstructs the basket, and this usually lowers the trend line.
In 1998, the C.P.I. will incorporate new expenditure weights from the 1993-95 expenditure survey. This will give us an up-to-date C.P.I. It will not give us a cost of living index. Nor in my view ought we to ask the Bureau of Labor Statistics to convert the one to the other. This is a task for Congress and the President.
A panel of economists has proposed reducing adjustments based on the C.P.I. by one percentage point to reflect cost of living changes accurately. In 12 years that would bring in $1 trillion. Alternately, we would lose $1 trillion. In the process we will lose Social Security, or so I believe.
 
DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN
U.S. Senator from New York
Washington, Oct. 5, 1995

HEADLINE: First-Time Jobless Claims Rise by 6,000

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits rose by 6,000 last week, the biggest increase in three weeks, but remained at a level analysts said reflected modest job growth.
The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 341,000, up from 335,000 in the week that ended on Sept. 23. 
 It was the highest level since 366,000 initial claims were filed in the week ended Sept. 16.
The claims figures were released on the eve of the monthly employment report, which analysts said would probably confirm moderate job growth.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims dropped by 250, to 351,500 from 351,750. It was the lowest since Sept. 9.

HEADLINE: Assembly Speaker Offers Plan to Stop Subway Fare Rise

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
With just four weeks until subway, bus and commuter rail fares are scheduled to rise, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, has proposed a $410 million package, including up to $200 million in state and city aid, to keep fares at their current level through the end of 1996.
Yesterday's proposal by Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, would require Gov. George E. Pataki and possibly Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to do an about-face in a year when both had cut support for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. But Mr. Silver suggested that the Governor, the Mayor and the Republican leaders of the State Senate might find the fiscal sacrifices politically preferable to a 25-cent increase, to $1.50, in the city's transit fare and a 9 percent increase in commuter rail fares. 
 "It makes sense for everybody," he said. "We're developing a reasonable plan that everybody contributes to. Both the city and the state have a lot at stake economically."
Mr. Silver's call for $110 million from the state got a cold reception from the Governor, who said, "We are not in a position to spend that type of additional state money in this year's budget or in next year's budget."
But Senator Norman J. Levy, a Merrick, L.I., Republican who is chairman of the Transportation Committee, called the Silver plan "a significant, positive step forward." He noted that the Speaker's proposal was in some ways identical to one Mr. Levy himself made last month.
And John McArdle, a spokesman for Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said, "I would refer you to Senator Levy for a read on how the proposal would fare in the Senate."
Deirdra Picou, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, said, "We have to study the plan before we respond to it."
The first element of Mr. Silver's three-part plan would have the state give back $110 million of the $220 million it took this year from a metropolitan-area mass transit fund to balance the state's budget. The budget had cast that transfer of funds as a loan, though it did not specify when it would be paid back.
"It's a legitimate obligation of the State of New York," Mr. Silver said. He said he had not discussed the issue with the Governor or his aides, or with Republican legislators, but he added, "I would think that they would go along with it."
The second element of Mr. Silver's proposal would prevent the M.T.A. from siphoning $210 million a year from its operating budget to pay for capital projects. Changing that pay-as-you-go approach, advocated by the M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, would make that money available to keep the fares down.
This part of the Speaker's plan might be the easiest to carry out. The $11.9 billion, five-year M.T.A. capital plan requires the approval of a four-member review board, which includes two critics of the plan, Mr. Levy and Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan, a Queens Democrat.
But John Cunningham, an M.T.A. spokesman, said Mr. Silver's idea "would sacrifice the capital program in order to save the fare."
"That's the way we used to do business in the 60's and 70's," he continued, "and we thought we had gotten away from that."
As the third part of his plan, Mr. Silver suggested that the city give the M.T.A. $85 million, another element that mirrors Mr. Levy's proposals. The city formerly reimbursed the M.T.A. for the cost of operating the transit police force, which was merged this year with the city's Police Department. The M.T.A. has asserted that the city underpaid over several years and owes the authority $88 million, which the city denies.
Mr. Levy has said the city should pay the M.T.A. the money. Mr. Silver said the city could contribute $85 million and view it as either a payment of that debt or simply a way to help keep the fare down.
Mr. Silver said the city could take the money from a special tax passed four years ago by the Legislature for the Safe Streets, Safe City program. The money was supposed to increase the size of the police force, but Mr. Silver said the tax had generated far more than was needed to meet Safe Streets, Safe City staffing targets.
As an alternative to the city contribution, Mr. Silver proposed a package of measures that would raise the same amount of money, including allowing increased vending in the subways, consolidation of some departments and a limited hiring freeze at the M.T.A.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Political Insider With Bush Tells of the Outside

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

THE POLITICS OF DIPLOMACY
Revolution, War and Peace, 1989-1992
By James A. Baker 3d with Thomas M. DeFrank
Illustrated. 687 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $32.50. 
 James A. Baker 3d never hid his distaste at having to leave his post as Secretary of State to bail out President George Bush's floundering 1992 re-election campaign. Mr. Baker even points out in his new memoir that "in 14 years of public service, I've only lost my composure once -- on Aug. 13, 1992, the day I announced I was leaving the State Department to become President Bush's chief of staff."
It was widely reported at the time that Mr. Baker had been disappointed at having to forfeit his image as a statesman and return to the grungy world of partisan politics, where he had won a reputation, in Time magazine's words, as "The Velvet Hammer," the master of those Washington black arts of handling, leaking and spin control.
The reluctant campaign manager did not pull out the election for President Bush, and since returning to private life, he has devoted himself to writing these memoirs, memoirs that assiduously avoid dealing with Mr. Baker's roles as a campaign manager and White House chief of staff for Presidents Reagan and Bush. Like many political memoirs, "The Politics of Diplomacy,' which was written with Thomas M. DeFrank of Newsweek magazine, is more interesting for what it leaves out than for what it discloses.
Not only does Mr. Baker decline to give the reader an insider's tour of the Ford, Reagan or Bush administrations, in which he served, but he also seems unwilling to reveal much about his four-decades-long friendship with George Bush, his political mentor and protege. Instead, Mr. Baker dwells almost exclusively on the foreign policy issues he grappled with during the 43 months he served as President Bush's Secretary of State, a momentous period that witnessed the breakup of the Soviet Union, the fall of the Berlin wall, the end of apartheid in South Africa and the gulf war.
Although there are a couple of displays of Mr. Baker's down-home, Texas-style taste for ribald expression -- he calls Gen. Manuel Noriega of Panama a case of "bad chili" and refers to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria's penchant for marathon meetings as "bladder diplomacy" -- most of this book is written in a hard-working student's careful, dessicated prose. Mr. Baker, a precise man who was famous for always keeping his jacket buttoned over his monogrammed shirts, is equally buttoned-up about his feelings in this book. He reveals almost nothing about himself, save the fact that he likes to play tennis and hunt, and just as little about the world leaders he routinely dealt with. He describes Mikhail Gorbachev as "invariably positive" and Boris Yeltsin as "physically intimidating," and uses the word "stalwart" to describe the British so many times that it begins to feel like a Homeric epithet.
In his first meeting with Yitzhak Shamir in 1989, Mr. Baker says, he tried to break the ice by suggesting some improbable common ground. "We both know that the media like to pigeonhole people with catch phrases," he told Mr. Shamir, who was then Israel's Prime Minister. "You've been described to me as a man of principle who is incapable of being practical. I've probably been described to you as a man totally lacking in principle who cares only about being practical."
This image of Mr. Baker as a wily pragmatist who worked to implement a foreign policy that was essentially ad hoc and reactive frequently surfaced in the press during his tenure in the State Department. And this book, despite its efforts to confer diplomatic immortality upon its author, only reinforces that perception.
In these pages, Mr. Baker repeatedly argues that politics and policy "are inextricably linked" and that "politics drives diplomacy, not vice versa." He found, he writes, that "common sense was an effective guide to action"; he says he would call himself "a realist" who believes in solving "the problems of the present before tackling the problems of the future."
A few pages later he adds that he approached "the world of 1989 from the 'inside out,' much the way I had approached politics and government."
"I started with an overall notion of where we wanted to go," he writes, "and worked backward from that goal, beginning with those institutions that we had to control or influence the most in order to achieve our objective: first, the immediate bureacracy; second, the Congress; and third, the press. Once we had done what we could in this regard, we would work on insuring our 'continental base' (relations with Canada, Mexico, and Central America), then strengthening and, where necessary, expanding our alliances across the Atlantic and Pacific."
Given this workmanlike outlook, it's little wonder that neither the Bush Administration nor Mr. Baker's new book has done much to articulate a vision of foreign policy. While Mr. Baker frequently emphasizes the importance of "new thinking" in coping with a rapidly changing world, there is no discussion in these pages of broader moral or ideological issues, no overview of how America should cope with a post-cold-war world. Instead, Mr. Baker's narrative moves ploddingly from incident to incident, crisis to crisis, issue to issue.
His efforts to help President Bush put together an international coalition for the Persian Gulf War tend to read like a candidate's hunt for crucial delegates at a convention, while his drive to bring about the first full-scale peace talks between Israel and her Arab neighbors often sounds like a political strategist's attempts to exchange favors and compromises for votes on a big Congressional bill.
Because these negotiations in the Middle East eventually led to the 1991 peace conference in Madrid (which in turn opened the way for advances under the Clinton Administration), because the gulf war wrought changes in the region that the Bush Administration was able (and willing) to exploit in the pursuit of a goal, the chapters devoted to these negotiations are by far the most interesting -- and vivid -- part of the book.
On other matters, Mr. Baker tends to offer predictable responses. He defends the Bush Administration's muted response to the crackdown in Tiananmen Square, arguing "we had to strike a delicate balance between the need for decisive steps and the need to safeguard the underlying strategic relationship to the extent possible." He rationalizes the Bush Administration's support of Saddam Hussein before the gulf war by arguing that "at the time, we saw Iraq as a potentially helpful Arab ally in moving the moribund Middle East peace process forward." And he argues that the war in Bosnia could not "have been prevented by any combination of political, diplomatic, and economic measures."
Although Mr. Baker tries to suggest that the Bush Administration played a crucial role in ending the cold war, his account underscores the fact that it was a role largely confined to responding constructively to developments within the Soviet Union and to initiatives on the part of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin.
For all his success in politics, Mr. Baker seems to have never been able to forget his grandfather's admonition to "work hard, study and keep out of politics." And with this book he reveals that "the Velvet Hammer" would rather be remembered as a Warren Christopher or George Shultz.
With "Diplomacy," the man who became famous for handling scattered politicians and malleable reporters has turned his attention to the reader; the man famous for spinning the message of the week is now spinning his own image for history. And yet, readers, like voters in the last Presidential election, are unlikely to buy his message. In this case, it's clear the diplomat is still a politician.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James A. Baker 3d (G. P. Putnam's Sons)

A Loss of $1.8 Billion Seen From Hurricane
Hurricane Opal will cost insurance companies about $1.8 billion, enough to make it the fourth most expensive disaster to American insurers, and the third most costly hurricane. 
 Although the losses will be small compared with the $15.5 billion caused by Hurricane Andrew in 1992, they are enough that analysts expect renewed efforts by insurers to limit the amount of business they do in coastal areas exposed to hurricanes. [Page A25.]
Retail Sales Mixed in September
 
Retail sales in September managed to shake off the worst of the summer doldrums, with department stores and discount stores showing modest improvement. But some specialty-apparel and specialty-hard-goods stores suffered their worst month of the year. [D4.]

The dollar fell sharply as doubts grew that central bankers would intervene in foreign-exchange markets to support the dollar. The dollar fell to 98.58 Japanese yen from 100.94 yen on Wednesday and to 1.4205 German marks from 1.4349 marks. [D7.]

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Balkan Peace at Hand? 4-Year Path to a Truce

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Croats have what they want. The Serbs are exhausted. The Muslims see no better option. That, four years after the wars of Yugoslavia's destruction began, is the basis on which the United States was able today to announce the outlines of a road to Balkan peace.
It is a grim, and perhaps fragile, basis for a settlement. America only took the lead in pushing for peace after about 3 million people had lost their homes and more than 200,000 had been killed. The result is a deep reservoir of bitterness, particularly among Bosnian Muslims, that could easily trigger renewed fighting. 
 This legacy, replete with hordes of refugees, may weigh on the area for years to come, just as the Middle East was destabilized for decades by the 1948 war and its harvest of Palestinian refugees. But for now, it is clear that exhaustion and a rough balance of power in the area, combined with the bullying ingenuity of Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator, made peace this year a real possibility.
There is still a long way to go. A cease-fire agreement worked out late last year by former President Jimmy Carter looked just as promising as the one announced today, but was never fully carried out.
Moreover, the central issue that has defeated all previous attempts at mediation -- the division of territory -- remains unresolved. Over the last four years, negotiation has never caused a single square foot of Bosnian land to change hands: that has been done by force alone.
"I don't think it's in the bag," said a senior State Department official. "There are very tough issues to deal with on the map, especially the fate of Sarajevo. But there's never been an opportunity like this one."
Radical changes on the ground over the last three years have created that opportunity. The Croats are now largely satisfied. They have recovered all but 3 percent of their territory within Croatia and grabbed perhaps one-fifth of Bosnia. Greater Croatia exists. This is almost certainly enough to insure the re-election of President Franjo Tudjman later this month.
The Serbs, meanwhile, have suffered serious military setbacks, losing the Krajina area of Croatia and seeing their share of Bosnia dwindle to about 49 percent from close to 70 percent. With the losses, the ability they long enjoyed to dictate terms has also evaporated.
This reverse has been rooted in the decision of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to lend only limited support to his brothers west of the Drina River in Croatia and Bosnia.
As a result, while the Muslim-Croat Federation has been fighting with the decisive support of the Croatian Army, the Bosnian Serbs have been relatively beleaguered. In effect, after a protracted struggle, Mr. Milosevic has brought the Bosnian Serbs to heel.
He is to be rewarded later this month with a visit to the United States, when talks between the Presidents of Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia will begin at a secluded, as yet undetermined, site.
Such a visit amounts to the culmination of a long-sought rehabilitation for Mr. Milosevic, who has long wanted to overcome his image in America as the man who destroyed Yugoslavia, and countless lives, by unleashing Serbian nationalism across the Balkans.
"There will always be a certain queasiness in dealing with the man," said a senior Administration official. "But in recent months Mr. Milosevic has proved himself a viable interlocutor. Even Arafat came to the White House in the end."
The fact remains, however, that the peace now taking form is one based on the acceptance of widespread destruction and enormous shifts in population.
For the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, the agreement on the cease-fire and further peace talks was an extremely difficult one, reached only after bitter internal debate, American officials said.
In the end it appears that only promises of large amounts of Western economic aid and military assistance in the event of a peace, as well as a sense that no more military gains were imminent, convinced the Government to sign.
The official singled out Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic of Bosnia as the most resistant to the current peace plan because he is concerned that it would ultimately cause the partition of Bosnia, with roughly 50 percent of the country going to the Serbs.
His position reflects that of many officials within the Bosnian Government and the army who are deeply skeptical of American assurances that Bosnia will remain a single state -- albeit one split down the middle -- with some real authority still vested in its central Government.
These officials contend that the only way to preserve a single Bosnian state may ultimately be to fight on and to defeat the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. This long-term objective is certain to persist for some time and is likely to be a source of tension if a settlement is reached and as many as 20,000 American troops lead a NATO force into the area to police the peace.
Administration officials insisted today that everything possible would be done to insure that Bosnia is not partitioned. Economic aid will be fashioned in such a way as to discourage the splitting of the country, and efforts will be made to insure that the final constitution will give the central Government of Bosnia real power.
However, the fact remains that, in any settlement, Bosnia is to be a state with three armies -- the loosely tied, but mutually suspicious, Croat and Bosnian Government forces on one side, and the Serbs on the other. If the NATO force only consolidates the lines between these armies, the ultimate death of Bosnia may become inevitable.
What hope there is for the country may now lie in the radically changed attitude of the Clinton Administration. President Clinton has already begun a drive to convince Congress that American troops must go to Bosnia in the event of a peace because American leadership of the NATO alliance is at stake and because only the United States can make a peace hold in the Balkans.
Four years ago, when Yugoslavia fell apart, America's position was the opposite: it tried to portray the conflict as a European problem and to leave it to Europeans to solve.
That policy persisted from the Bush Administration into the Clinton Administration. Its fruit was a long war. If the emergent peace is to hold, it seems clear that it must be led and guaranteed by the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard C. Holbrooke, the American peace negotiator, in Croatia yesterday after arriving from Bosnia with a cease-fire agreement. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Storm Transforms Florida Beach Town Into a Scene of Ruins

BYLINE: By New York Times Regional Newspapers 

DATELINE: NAVARRE BEACH, Fla., Oct. 6

 BODY:
Before Hurricane Opal, this tiny beach town on a barrier island near Pensacola was covered by majestic sand dunes, sea oats and sun-loving tourists. Today, two days after the storm crashed ashore with 125-mile-an-hour winds and 20-foot waves, Navarre Beach is a desolate landscape.
The dunes, some 20 to 30 feet high, have been washed out to sea, along with the only road that ran through this town and the rest of Santa Rosa Island. Vegetation is gone. House after house along the water was battered, buckled or blown away. And the town's 300 permanent residents were being kept away from their property by several dozen National Guard troops. 
 All along a 100-mile stretch of the Florida Panhandle coastline, residents sought to return to their homes. In some areas, because roads and power were out and because of fear of looting, the authorities said it was still too dangerous to allow homeowners to inspect their property. Okaloosa County officials planned to allow residents to visit their damaged homes on Saturday, but only to collect personal items. Several other beach-front communities, which have been under 24-hour curfew, were opened briefly to residents today. .
Many people who did get to see or return to their property reached two conclusions: that despite the estimated $1.8 billion damage in Florida and the loss of life -- 18 deaths have now been recorded in four states -- the destruction could have been much worse if the storm had struck an urban area; and, second, that it would take weeks, if not months, for life in quiet coastal communities like this to return to normal.
"It really can't be the same," said Tom Chapman of Montgomery, Ala., whose 60-year-old waterfront vacation home in Santa Rosa Beach vanished during the storm. "There are too many memories and too much we put into that house."
Elsewhere in the Panhandle, about half a million people remained without electric power, and many towns lacked safe drinking water. It may take several more days to restore utility service.
Several roads and bridges remained impassable, and the authorities said it could take six months to rebuild parts of U.S. 98, the area's main coastal thoroughfare.
"This is a long-term emergency," said Jo Miglino, a spokeswoman for the state Division of Emergency Management in Tallahassee. "We're going to be in this for the long haul. There's no two ways about it."
In Navarre Beach, near where the hurricane's eye made landfall on Wednesday, it was hard to picture any recovery at all. A tour of the town today with a National Guard escort showed that every structure had suffered wind and water damage, some reduced to rubble and others left with gaping holes in walls and roofs. A few houses were swept into nearby Santa Rosa Sound, and pieces landed half a mile away on the mainland.
Sand coated the entire barrier island, obscuring the few parts of the roadway that were not washed out Wednesday. Debris of all sorts -- pieces of sailboats, abandoned cars, household appliances and, at one spot, a single water ski -- littered the waterfront. A sign outside the town's Holiday Inn, now standing in a newly formed tidal pool, stated the obvious: "CLOSED."
Some residents said they planned to rebuild, despite the continued risk of hurricanes.
"I don't want to lose the view," said Mr. Chapman, the Alabama man who lost his vacation home. "It's fabulous. You can't describe it. We had picture of it. But those albums are gone now."
Farther east, along Panama City Beach, where two-story homes, motels and souvenir shops along Highway 98 were sacked by the hurricane blasts, residents were shocked to find miles of beach swept away.
"I had a garden here -- now I've got a cliff outside," said Betty Dyer, a 10-year seasonal resident. "I don't know if Panama City Beach will ever be the way it was. At the least, it's going to take years and years of repairs. And after that happens, there'll be another reality. We don't have much of a beach left anymore."
C. F. Whatley, who has lived on the beach since 1984, predicted long-lasting economic woes from Opal.
"We'll have to do one heck of a sales pitch to get the Canadians and snowbirds to ever come back here again," he said. "We can only hope for what happens by next summer."
Other coastal residents found that perhaps the only thing worse than surveying damaged homes was not being allowed to return there.
In the luxury resort community of Destin, tensions were high as barricades and police officers kept elderly residents away from their beachside apartments.
"I thought surely they'd have to let us in," said Bob Pittman, a retiree who drove from Atlanta to check on his waterfront condominium. "They don't care if you own these places or not."
Many residents wanted just to retrieve photograph albums and other mementos -- "the things you have that reflect on your life," as Virginia Smithey, a retiree, put it.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1571 words

HEADLINE: For Legal Aid, Tough Times Get Tougher

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga.

 BODY:
Martha Bramblett, a slight 33-year-old mother of two, visited this city's office of Georgia Legal Services not long ago to get help with her marital problems.
Her husband, a mechanic, often turned violent after finishing his daily six-pack, she told Wanda Andrews, a lawyer there. In July, after a quarrel, Ms. Bramblett said, he stormed out of their trailer home outside town. Last month he hired a lawyer, served divorce papers on her and demanded custody of their children, ages 5 and 3. Ms. Bramblett told Ms. Andrews that she wanted the divorce. "But I'm not going to let him have custody of the kids," she said. 
 Legal Services lawyers who represent clients like Ms. Bramblett may soon be faced with turning away increasing numbers of them: Congress is preparing to enact legislation that would add heavily to deep budget cuts imposed on the lawyers in the Reagan Administration and restrict the nature of the cases they take.
The lawyers here, and in 1,200 other offices around the country, work for the Legal Services Corporation, created by the Government during the Nixon Administration more than two decades ago to help people in the economy's cellar fight the civil-law indignities and entanglements of everyday life. Legal Services lawyers take on spats with merchants, landlords, welfare officials and spouses, and problems of garnished paychecks and lost credit.
Now a bill approved by the House would chop the corporation's annual budget by one-third, to $278 million from the $415 million appropriated for the last fiscal year; a Senate version would cut it to $340 million. Because of budget cuts in earlier years, the corporation says, it already turns away about half the people whose below-poverty-line incomes qualify them for help.
The House bill would also dismantle the corporation, converting its financing into block grants to the states, which would have no obligation to allocate them to the existing Legal Services offices.
Both houses, which are expected to begin working out the differences between their bills during the week of Oct. 8, would prohibit Legal Services lawyers from lobbying on behalf of the poor before legislatures and government agencies, and from bringing class-action suits against public agencies. Both would also forbid the lawyers to take cases from prisoners, illegal immigrants or women seeking abortions.
In part, Legal Services has been swept into the budget-slimming tide rolling through Congress and the Republican conviction that the states can manage Federal money more efficiently than Washington can.
But it has also become a special target of conservative lobbies like the Christian Coalition that deem it meddlesome, liberal, anti-family and, in promoting the welfare rights of the poor, an obstacle to overhauling the welfare system.
"What I hear is they are going to emasculate us," said William K. Broker, managing lawyer of the Savannah office. "They take away half your money and restrict what you do."
Mike Hancock, executive director of the Farm Workers Justice Fund, an advocacy group for migrant laborers, said of the legislation, "They're horrible, terrible, restrictive bills that destroy the ability of Legal Services to represent poor people."
The corporation's opponents say it has far overstepped its mandate to help the poor. "It was almost as though in creating Legal Services we had asked bureaucrats to design a program to benefit liberal Democratic activists all over America," said Larry Neal, press secretary to Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is the author of some of the legislation's tougher restrictions.
"Some of them are angry about losing their jobs," Mr. Neal said of Legal Services officials, "so I'm sure they are going to feel emasculated."
While Legal Services may be a symbol of liberalism or a line in the budget to lobbyists and lawmakers in Washington, to many of its clients it is simply a way to get help with some of the tedious but pressing problems of daily life. Nearly 1,000 of the 2,500 cases that the Savannah office closed last year involved housing disputes, and nearly 800 others involved family issues like protecting women from abuse and arranging custody of children.
Across the nation, the corporation says, 33 percent of all cases involve family law, 22 percent housing, 16 percent helping people collect benefits like welfare and Social Security, and 10 percent consumer disputes stemming from matters like personal bankruptcy or business fraud.
Lawyers in the Savannah office helped Yvette McGee, a 20-year-old mother of three, get her landlord to patch "a big picture-frame-size hole in the wall to the outside." He had refused to repair the hole, Ms. McGee said, until the lawyers wrote a letter for her, outlining her rights. She gave the landlord the letter, and soon he "patched up the hole and fixed some other things, too," she said.
Her mother, Frazier McGee, 43, said: "Business people don't hear your voice. They talk to you like you are dumb. The legal aid lawyer comes in and tells you, 'That's not the way it's supposed to be.' " Yvette McGee added, "When you have a lawyer, they talk to you like you are a person."
Mr. Broker, the managing lawyer in the Savannah office, said the legislation in Congress would force him to drop from one to three of the seven full-time lawyers there, an effect that would leave people like the McGees with that much less of a chance in trying to find someone to take their case.
Fourteen years ago, at the dawn of the Reagan Administration, Congress chopped financing for Legal Services by 25 percent. That cut alone, despite some small increases in the Legal Services budget later, has already taken a heavy toll. William Lutz, a spokesman for the corporation, said the legal staff had shrunk to one lawyer for every 8,000 people with incomes below the poverty line, from two for every 10,000.
This time, on top of the new budget cuts, Legal Services lawyers would encounter restrictions on the cases they could take. In addition to the ban on working on behalf of the poor before legislatures and regulators, they would be barred from taking on a client whose welfare or Social Security office had inexplicably cut benefits. And they would be forbidden to use contributions from private sources, like churches and charities, to take on cases that they would otherwise be barred from handling -- action on behalf of prisoners, for instance.
Then there is the proposed ban on class actions against government agencies. Although class actions account for only about 2 percent of the corporation's caseload, by their nature they can have a large impact. And under either Congressional bill, the Savannah office would have had to decline a case like one it has filed on behalf of 450 people, nearly all women who are, or recently have been, on welfare.
In that case, whose defendants include the United States Education Secretary and the State of Georgia, the office is asking the court to order forgiveness of the women's Government-guaranteed student loans. The lawyer handling the case, Murphy A. Cooper 3d, said that from 1988 to 1992, the women enrolled in an accredited private job-training schoolto learn nursing and office skills. Mr. Cooper said the school had promised to place them in jobs upon completion of the courses.
The women got help from the school in obtaining Government-guaranteed student loans of $2,000 to $4,000, money that was then paid to the school as tuition. "The school basically ran on student-loan money," Mr. Cooper said.
But the women say the school did not deliver what it promised. Most never found jobs and, without work, defaulted on the loans and lost access to credit. Until Legal Services interceded, the Government garnished the tax-refund checks of those who did find work.
"The question," Mr. Cooper said, "is who is going to be left holding the bag, the students or the lenders?"
The Savannah office's seven full-time lawyers, average age 42, earn $24,250 to $52,000 a year. But it is Albert Mazo, one of two full-time volunteers, who is perhaps the most passionate about his job. Now a little stooped and nearly bald at the age of 80, Mr. Mazo started a paint-manufacturing company in town after earning a law degree from the University of Georgia as a young man. When his wife died seven years ago, he sold his business and began practicing family law for Legal Services.
He describes the cases he has handled as eye-poppers. Right now he is enmeshed in a dispute over a 14-year-old girl whose father now has custody of her but who has confessed to having sexual relations with her. The girl's mother has a history of instability, Mr. Mazo said, but has now righted herself. "I'm going to try to get that child back for the mother," he said.
"I don't think of helping children as being liberal or conservative," Mr. Mazo said. "I just think of it as being right."
Only one significant lobby has emerged to defend the corporation: the nation's private lawyers, whose pro bono work could not begin to scratch the corporation's annual load of 1.5 million clients.
Dolly Chisholm, head of the Savannah Bar Association's pro bono committee, said that without the Legal Services office here, "a lot of these people would be out of luck."
"The office here runs just beautifully," she added. "Their motive is just to help serve the public."

HEADLINE: Technology Shares Up a Bit But Other Issues Are Mixed

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, while some technology issues made a modest recovery.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.50 points, to 4,769.21. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.14 point, to 582.49, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 2.16 points, to 1,012.04. 
 "The stock market was directionless, motionless, trendless and friendless," said Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. "It clearly reflected the employment data."
The Labor Department reported yesterday that employers added 121,000 jobs in September, much fewer than expected. The August employment figure was revised upward by 13,000 jobs, to 262,000.
"The bottom line is that the economy continues to limp along at a no-boom, no-bust pace," Mr. Johnson said. "The earnings season is fast approaching and most investors are very edgy." The initial batch of third-quarter earnings reports -- including some from big corporations like Chrysler, Motorola and Texas Instruments -- is scheduled to be released week.
A number of technology stocks, which had been pushed down recently, managed to achieve modest gains, despite afternoon profit taking. Intel jumped 1 1/8, to 62, after being upgraded by Merrill Lynch. Other technology gainers included Computer Associates, up 1, to 40, and Cyrix, up 2 3/4, to 42 1/2. The initial public offering of ESS Technology ended the session at 16, up 1.
But shares of DSC Communications, a maker of telephone and cable television equipment, fell sharply after the company said third-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. The stock fell 8, to 44 3/8, in very heavy trading.
Banking issues benefited from the belief by traders that interest rates would continue their decline. Citicorp advanced 1/8, to 72 7/8; J. P. Morgan increased 3/8, to 78 1/4; Mellon Bank gained 1, to 47 5/8, and Wells Fargo rose 1 7/8, to 199 5/8.
Big name household-products companies also finished on the upside. Procter & Gamble climbed 1 1/8, to 80 1/8, a record, and Johnson & Johnson rose 1 3/4, to 77 1/4.
The Dow Jones utility index slumped 1.25 points, to 215.07, after one of its components, Niagara Mohawk Power, announced plans to split itself into two companies. Niagara Mohawk shares fell 1 1/4, to 11 5/8. Consolidated Edison closed at 30 1/8, down 1/2; Commonwealth Energy closed at 41 3/4, down 5/8, and New York State Electric and Gas closed at 25 7/8, down 1/4.
Oil stocks were lower as concerns grew about various downward pressures on energy prices. ARCO declined 7/8, to 105 3/4; Texaco fell 1/8, to 66 3/8; Mobil dropped 1/4, to 101 7/8, and Chevron slipped 1/4, to 49 1/8.
Alcoa, which said that third-quarter profits more than tripled from the corresponding period last year, rose 1 1/2, to 53 1/8. Iomega, which projected a doubling of its third-quarter revenues, increased 3/4, to 19 3/4. And Sybase, which was upgraded by Soundview Financial, advanced 2 1/4,to 33 7/8.
Wal-Mart Stores traded down 1/8, to 23 3/4, after being downgraded by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Advances topped declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,197 to 993. Turnover on the Big Board dropped to 313.7 million shares, from 367.5 million on Thursday; the average daily volume this year has been slightly less than 338 million shares.
Earlier yesterday, stocks in Tokyo ended sharply higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 285.87 points, or 1.57 percent, at 18,506.28, after hitting a high of 18,547.43.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Jumped in August

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Consumers borrowed heavily in August, running up their installment debts by another $9.1 billion after an $8.8 billion increase in July, the Federal Reserve said today.
Outstanding consumer installment credit was expanding at an 11.1 percent annual rate in August, up from the 10.9 percent rate seen in July.
Much of the increase came from greater use by consumers of their credit cards.
Revolving or credit-card debt ballooned upward by $4.33 billion in August, for an annual rate of 13.8 percent, compared with a $3.25 billion expansion in July.
"We think consumers are getting pretty deeply in hock," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass.
Borrowing to buy new cars slowed sharply in August, as auto loans expanded by $1.46 billion for an annual rate of 5.2 percent. That was down from the $4.42 billion in car loans posted in July.
Before seasonal adjustment, total outstanding consumer installment credit in August was $987.87 billion, up from $971.58 billion in July and up from $863.05 billion a year ago.
There were other signs this week that American consumers' ability to keep spending, and thus keep fueling the country's economic growth, could be pinched.
The Commerce Department said on Monday that personal incomes from wages, salaries and all other sources were flat in August.

HEADLINE: Little Change In New Jersey And New York

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Employment levels in New York City, New York State and New Jersey were nearly unchanged in September, with the region continuing a sluggish pattern of economic expansion that is lagging behind that of most of the nation, Government reports showed yesterday.
"The region is on a slow and uneven growth path as we enter the fourth quarter," said John L. Weiting, the New York regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The economy just doesn't have sufficient strength to make much of a dent in the ranks of the unemployed." 
 The Labor Department's monthly data for the nation's 11 largest industrial states showed that the unemployment rate fell slightly in New York State, to 6.8 percent in September from 7.1 percent in August. In New York City, it fell to 8 percent from 8.3 percent.
The unemployment decline was sharper in New Jersey, to 5.7 percent in September from 6.6 percent in August.
But Mr. Weiting said the apparent improvement in New Jersey was "not as good as it first appears" because it partly reflected a decline in the number of people looking for work, including young people who returned to school.
The unemployment rate is based on the number of people who are actively looking for jobs; thus, it does not count those who have withdrawn from the labor market.
The number of people employed in the region -- regarded by many experts as a better gauge of economic performance than the unemployment rate -- rose by less than 1 percent last month.
Employment was virtually unchanged in New York State, at 8 million jobs, and in New Jersey, at 3.8 million jobs. It rose in New York City to 3 million jobs in September from 2.9 million jobs in August.
Connecticut is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

POPE URGES NEW YORK TO BE KINDER
Echoing the moral challenge he has posed several times since his arrival Wednesday, Pope John Paul II called on New York City to pay more attention to hardship and poverty in its midst. "Have the people living in this huge metropolis lost sight of the blessings which belong to the poor in spirit?" the Pope said at a morning Mass for about 75,000 people at Aqueduct Race Track in Queens. [Page 1.]
Nationally, the number of Roman Catholic seminarians has fallen precipitously in recent years, and the Pope came to St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers to offer them encouragement, saying those who would be priests must be tough-minded in a materialistic culture, yet spiritually alive and compassionate. [1.]
 
JOB OFFER EXPECTED IN SCHOOLS SEARCH
With the blessing of Mayor Giuliani, the Board of Education has decided to offer the job of schools chancellor to Rudolph F. Crew, the Superintendent in Tacoma, Wash., even though he has not yet said whether he would take the job, officials said. [1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
BOMBING SUSPECT ORDERED TESTED
A Federal judge ordered a defendant in the third trial stemming from the World Trade Center bombing to undergo psychiatric tests after the man tried to stab himself in prison and threatened to kill his court-appointed lawyer. He has been demanding a Muslim lawyer. [22.]
 
LIMELIGHT CLUB IS ALLOWED TO REOPEN
A week after police staged a drug raid there, the Limelight was allowed to reopen under an agreement with the city that calls for more rigorous security to deter drug use and sales. The club is to hire more bouncers and retain security consultants to create a more comprehensive anti-drug program. [22.]
 
ARREST IN SNACKING BURGLAR CASE
In a world plagued by bank robbers, carjackers, kidnappers and tax cheats, detectives in Queens say they have captured a man who developed a voracious new type of robbery: the snacking bandit. The suspect, a Queens man, was arraigned on charges that he sneaked into the homes of elderly East Elmhurst residents, stole cash and other valuables, then raided their refrigerators on his way out. [22.]
 
CHESS GAME ENDS IN ANOTHER DRAW
Viswanathan Anand agreed to a uninspired draw in Game 16 of his world championship chess match with Gary Kasparov, making it look as though he has reconciled himself to bowing out of contention with respectable draws. The score is now 9 1/2 to 6 1/2 with four games to be contested. Another draw will give Mr. Kasparov at least a tie match and thus enable him to retain his title. [28.]
 
REGION
 
UTILITY ASKS TO RESTRUCTURE
Threatening to throw itself into bankruptcy unless it wins relief, Niagara Mohawk Power, the utility that serves much of upstate New York, has proposed forming a separate company to free itself from state regulation. The company said its sweeping plan was necessary to avoid sharp increases in the cost of electricity for millions of New Yorkers. [Business Day, 35.]
 
REGIONAL EMPLOYMENT REMAINS STAGNANT
Employment levels in New York City, New York State and New Jersey were nearly unchanged in September, with the region continuing a sluggish pattern of economic expansion that lags behind that of most of the nation, Government reports showed. [Business Day, 36.]

HEADLINE: Payrolls Rose By 121,000 In September

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6

 BODY:
Factory employment resumed its decline in September, but the economy generated enough service jobs to swell overall payrolls by 121,000, Labor Department figures showed today.
The unemployment rate, meanwhile, remained at 5.6 percent, about where it has hovered for a year. 
 Today's report, the first broad gauge of economic performance for September, provided additional evidence that growth picked up a bit over the summer but that conditions were still soft enough to dispel fears of revived inflation.
"It looks like almost the perfect soft landing," said Frank McCormick, senior economist at the Bank of America, referring to the Federal Reserve's effort to restrain an economy that was expanding at an unsustainably rapid pace in late 1994. "The Fed should be quite pleased."
New Jersey and California posted sizable declines in their jobless rates during September while Pennsylvania and Florida had increases. New York State recorded a slight decline, although employment levels in the region were nearly unchanged. [Page 36.]
The nationwide increase in payroll jobs was about at the pace needed to keep up with population growth and was a bit below expectations. At the same time, the Labor Department raised its estimates for July and August by a total of 35,000 and the Clinton Administration and most private analysts continued to regard the job market as satisfactory, although not robust.
"These numbers are further evidence that we are likely to see continuing economic growth with low inflation in the second half of this year," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
After some early swings, market reaction to the employment report was subdued, with analysts finding little to inspire thoughts of change in monetary policy. Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation, called the results "plain vanilla" and "very close to neutral" for the Fed's policy makers.
Still, the drop of 32,000 factory jobs following a flat August was an unsettling development and brought the total decline since March to 200,000. The declines last month were widespread, with the biggest ones in motor vehicles and in apparel and textiles, where the department noted that losses have accelerated of late.
On the other hand, the factory workweek lengthened by 6 minutes last month and factory overtime rose 12 minutes. When uncertain about the economic outlook, companies tend to squeeze more production from existing workers rather than hiring new ones.
Temporary-help and other business services added 59,000 jobs last month, while social services and health services spurted 58,000 and retail trade jobs climbed 48,000. Finance, insurance and real estate, all of which have been moving slowly higher for several months, added 8,000 in September. Government jobs fell 30,000 after a huge August jump, a gyration the department attributed to the trend toward an earlier opening of the school year, a change that has not yet been fully reflected in the seasonal adjustment process.
Construction was reported up 16,000 but this was significantly overstated, the agency said, because sluggish hiring during the spring and summer left fewer workers than usual to be laid off in September.
Average hourly earnings, the report also showed, rose 4 cents after easing 2 cents in August. Average weekly earnings rose six-tenths of 1 percent, nearly offsetting August's decline.
The department's survey of households found 361,000 more people with jobs. This nearly matched the expansion of 380,000 in the labor force, leaving the unemployment rate unchanged.
But Merrill Lynch & Company pointed to the likelihood of more "slack" in the labor market than suggested by a jobless rate of 5.6 percent. It cited the fact that the proportion of adult men who are employed, 72.8 percent, is some two percentage points below the levels of the late 1980's. This probably reflects "reserves of potential workers who are not reporting themselves" part of the labor force, the brokerage firm's economists said.
Geographically, there was unusual regional disparity last month. Unemployment fell five-tenths of a percentage point in the West, to 6.4 percent, while it rose three-tenths of a point in the South, to 5.8 percent. The Northeast and Midwest were essentially unchanged, at 6.1 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively.
New Jersey's rate eased to 5.7 percent from 6.6 and California's declined to 7.2 from 7.8. By contrast, the rate for Pennsylvania rose to 6.4 from 5.5, while Florida's rose a full point, to 5.6 percent. New York's rate was 6.8 percent, compared with 7.1 percent last month.
If threatened budget cuts are carried out, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said it would have to reduce the number of households surveyed each month to 50,000 from 56,000 and would thus be unable to provide the early data on 11 large states.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Labor Picture in September" shows employment and unemployment statistics for September. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)(pg. 36)
 
Graph: "Consumer Borrowing" shows net change in consumer installment credit outstanding from May 1994 to Aug. 1995. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)(pg. 36)

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Dole Dive

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
After a solid month of Powellmania, I am certain of only two things:
1. Anyone who counts "The Producers" among his favorite movies -- see "My American Journey," page 593 -- can't be all bad. 
 2. Bob Dole's campaign for the Presidency is kaput.
Since only the second of these two assertions is debatable, please forgive me for dwelling on it to the exclusion of an extended exegesis of the cultural overlap of Colin Powell and Mel Brooks.
Mr. Powell remains an enigma in any case -- a Rorschach test, as prognosticators are fond of prognosticating, whose nearly papal popularity is more revealing about the rudderless populace that cheers him than it is about the man himself. And now that the Rorschach test has been taken by the political party to which Mr. Powell claims affinity, the preliminary results are easy to read: The Contract-era Republican establishment doesn't want Mr. Dole, whether Mr. Powell runs or not.
"It has grown harder and harder to fake any enthusiasm for G.O.P. front-runner Bob Dole," wrote Arianna Huffington last week in the lead essay on the most influential conservative editorial page in the country, The Wall Street Journal's. Mrs. Huffington -- whose latest cultist calling is as what Vanity Fair calls a "ubiquitous" and "self-appointed guardian" to Newt Gingrich -- is hardly speaking just for herself.
She is in fact merely stating in blunt language the message other leading Republican conservatives have been tiptoeing around since the Powell boom began in earnest after Labor Day. When William Kristol and William Bennett talk up a Powell candidacy, as Mrs. Huffington also is, they never endorse the retired general's few known specific views -- which are patently opposed to the Gingrich revolution they stand for and the religious right they are in bed with -- but instead use his glowing presence to beat up implicitly on Mr. Dole, for whom they can't muster even fake enthusiasm.
None of this has stopped the press from referring reflexively to Mr. Dole as the "G.O.P. front-runner" -- describing his candidacy much as Theodore H. White once described another front-runner in "The Making of the President 1972." Mr. White wrote that Edmund Muskie's campaign that year "seemed irresistible" because "he had solid financial backing, a large and experienced staff, the endorsement of the party's leading figures, the advice of the party sages, the affirmation of the nation's pollsters."
Mr. Dole, too, leads the existing G.O.P. field by far in cash, polls, staff and endorsements, but who believes this emperor has clothes? "Man Without a Message," declared a recent anti-Dole editorial in The Manchester (N.H.) Union Leader, the conservative primary-state rag that could yet bring Mr. Dole to grief as it reduced Mr. Muskie to tears.
As mushy in his views as was Mr. Muskie -- whose campaign slogan, "Trusty Muskie," emphasized the ur-Dole virtues of moderation and tried-and-true Washington experience -- Mr. Dole stands in relation to the true Gingrichian heart of his party's right-wing leadership as his Democratic antecedent did to his party's McGovernite left. As Arthur Miller wrote of Willy Loman, he is liked but not well liked. On a recent "Crossfire," Mr. Kristol foresaw a Dole nosedive as soon as Nov. 17, when he is "likely" to do "badly" in a debate on "Larry King Live."
The front-runner has no one but himself to blame for his stumble. As the Powell book was published, the Senator was already taking heat for reversing his principled, lifelong record on affirmative action and even changing the church where he worships to pander to the Christian Coalition. But he kept on flip-flopping -- whether by trying to stall Bob Packwood's departure, embracing the supply-side economics he once ridiculed or returning a contribution from the gay Log Cabin Republicans, whose support his campaign had solicited.
So universal has been the condemnation of Mr. Dole for such hypocrisies that no one bothers to talk about the age issue anymore -- as if the unlikelihood of a Dole Presidency has rendered it moot. Last weekend "Saturday Night Live" revealingly focused on the Dole character issue instead, depicting him as eager to score political points by implying Colin Powell was gay. The sketch would have been far funnier if its Bob Dole had not so sourly evoked the real thing.

HEADLINE: Talks in Rome Look to Helping Balkans Recover From War

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: ROME, Oct. 6

 BODY:
With the ink barely dry on a Bosnian cease-fire agreement, representatives of governments in the United States, Europe, Japan and the Middle East met in Rome today to begin thinking about ways to promote the financial and economic recovery of the war-torn Balkan region.
The American negotiator, Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke, said efforts were partly directed toward meeting immediate concerns. 
 These included the restoration of gas and electric service to Sarajevo, which the Bosnian Government has made a condition for carrying out the truce that Mr. Holbrooke brokered on Thursday and which is to take effect on Tuesday. Sarajevo's bedraggled population of 300,000 is facing its fourth consecutive winter without regular energy supplies.
Russia has announced that it would reopen a pipeline delivering gas to Sarajevo, but Mr. Holbrooke said restoration of electric service was proving to be a "technical problem," with access to some power pylons and generating stations hampered by land mines. He said delays in restoring power could lead to a postponement of the cease-fire, but he said he hoped any delay would be "exceedingly short."
The discussions were also directed toward lining up commitments for financial aid to promote economic reconstruction of the region.
Mr. Holbrooke, speaking at a news conference after the talks, stressed that economic assistance involved the entire Balkan region, including countries not involved in the fighting, like Albania.
The meeting came as large amounts of investment money are being sought to support the Middle East peace process. There was no talk of specific financial commitments, and while some diplomats attending the discussions said estimates of the required financial assistance went as high as $4 billion, others stressed that it was too early for precise figures.
The meeting was attended by representatives of the countries that have long been seeking to broker a Balkan peace, including the United States, Russia, Britain, France and Germany, as well as by the foreign ministers of Yugoslavia and Bosnia and the deputy foreign minister of Croatia.
Reflecting the need to drum up enough money to bolster the peace effort, the group also invited for the first time representatives of the Arab League and Japan.
Japan's Ambassador to Austria, Tsuyoshi Kurokawa, said that the Balkan war was "primarily a European problem, and maybe also of the United States," but that Tokyo was prepared to "cooperate closely."
Officials emphasized that Bosnia and Croatia faced not only the cost of reconstructing factories, roads, rail lines and power systems, but also a lag in opening up their economies to the kind of foreign investment that has surged into the other countries of Central and Eastern Europe since the collapse of Communism.
Carl Bildt, the European Union's mediator for the Balkans, said Bosnia was expected to send representatives as early as next week to European Union economic planning sessions in Luxembourg.
"This is the first of our meetings not focused on problems of war, but on problems of peace," he said.

HEADLINE: THE POPE'S VISIT;
A Homily Links Human Progress and Salvation

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the homily by Pope John Paul II at Aqueduct Race Track yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
Dear Brothers and Sisters in Christ, 
 Jesus' words in today's Gospel bring me back to my youth and remind me of a song we used to sing in my home parish at Wadowice. The words of that song are very simple, but at the same time very profound:
"Come, Holy Spirit, we stand in need of your grace.
Spoken in Polish and then in English: "Make us grow in the heavenly knowledge you have revealed. Make it easy for us to understand it, and by our perseverance may it remain in us. Enlightened by that truth, we shall be confirmed in goodness."
Spoken in English: These words express well the theology of the Holy Spirit, through whom the Father reveals what is "hidden from the learned and the clever," and through whom the Son reveals the Father. The Spirit, in fact, is the active agent of the Church's evangelizing mission. For this reason, the Church constantly invokes the Holy Spirit, invokes the Holy Spirit, upon individual communities, and today we are doing the same, we renew that same invocation here, at the Aqueduct Race Track in Queens, in Brooklyn.
I am happy to see such a representative gathering of the faithful of this local church. I greet all of you with warm affection: your stalwart pastor, Bishop Thomas Daily; my brothers, cardinals and bishops, religious women and men from the Diocese of Brooklyn and many other dioceses. At the same time my greetings go to the leaders of the various religious denominations and the civil authorities from both local and state government. . . .
Spoken in Spanish: I know that there are many Spanish-speaking people, families and communities present at this Mass. In the heart of the Pope, you have a special place. To each one I express my sincere love and affection in the Lord.
 
'Progress of Peoples'
 Spoken in English: The theme of this morning's Mass is "Progress of Peoples." The progress of peoples is closely connected with the proclamation of Christ's message of salvation and hope. Of this salvation Isaiah speaks in the first reading: "The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light. Upon those who dwelt in the land of gloom a light has shone." This darkness stands for the spiritual darkness which sometimes envelops people, nations and history itself, in its desolate mantle. Certainly the 20th century has witnessed such periods of gloom. The two World Wars were times of great darkness which plunged peoples and nations into immense suffering. For many people, the 20th century continues to be a time of terrible anguish and torture. From the depths of such sad experiences the human family searches for a path of justice and peace.
Spoken in Spanish: Isaiah goes on to suggest that genuine justice and peace, the authentic progress of peoples, is centered on God's plan to send a Savior. For he writes: "A child is born to us, a son is given us. . . . His dominion is vast and forever peaceful. . . . He confirms and sustains by judgment and justice, both now and forever." Here the prophet is speaking of the Messiah whose arrival Israel so eagerly awaited. This is the Messiah so anxiously looked to by modern men and women, especially when they have been immersed in the devastating experiences of war, of concentration camps, of brutality and contempt for human dignity.
It is here that the words of Jesus, He who is our salvation and our hope, take on a special meaning: "Come to me, all you who are weary and find life burdensome, and I will refresh." Christ Himself carried a burden, and His burden -- the cross -- was made heavier by the sins of us all. But Christ did not avoid the cross; He accepted it and carried it willingly. Moreover, He now stands beside those weighed down by trials and persecutions, remaining beside them to the end. It is for all people and with all people that He carries the cross to Calvary, and it is there that for all of us He is nailed to his cross. He dies the death of a criminal, the most humiliating death known to the world at that time. That is why to those in our own century who carry terrible burdens He is able to say: Come to me! I am your brother in suffering. There is no humiliation or bitterness which I do not know.
 
God's Kingdom on Earth
 Spoken in English: It is precisely through the Gospel of the cross and through His Resurrection that Christ lays the foundations for advancement of God's kingdom in the world. The presence of this kingdom opens to us the dimension of eternity in God, and discloses the deepest meaning of our efforts to improve life here on earth.
What kind of society is worthy of the human person? The Church responds with the unique perspective of salvation history. She proclaims the truth that the Word of God, through whom all things were made, was Himself made flesh and dwelt among us. He entered the world's history -- our history -- as a man; a human person, a divine person. He took on our history and made it complete. By His Resurrection He became Lord and was given full power in heaven and on earth. Thus through the power of His spirit, Christ is now at work in our hearts and in our world. The Spirit instills in us a desire for the world to come, but He also inspires, purifies and strengthens those noble longings by which we strive to make earthly life more human.
Dear friends, we are gathered together in this enormous metropolis of New York, considered by many to be the zenith of modern civilization and progress, a symbol of America and American life. For more than 200 years people of different nations, languages and cultures have come here, bringing memories and traditions of the "old country," while at the same time becoming part of a new nation. America has a reputation the world over, a reputation of power, prestige and wealth, richness. But not everyone here is powerful; not everyone here is rich. In fact, America's sometimes extravagant affluence often conceals much hardship and poverty.
From the viewpoint of the kingdom of God we must therefore ask a very basic question: Have the people living in this huge metropolis lost sight of the blessings which belong to the poor in spirit? In the midst of the magnificent scientific and technological civilization of which America is proud, and especially here in Queens, in Brooklyn, in New York, is there room for the mystery of God? That mystery which is "revealed to the merest children," the mystery of the Father and the Son in the unity of the Holy Spirit; the mystery of divine love which is the source of everything? Is there room for the mystery of God? Is there room for the revelation of life -- that transcendent life which Christ brings us at the price of his Cross and through the victory of His Resurrection? . . .
The Gospel of the kingdom of God is open to every aspect of earthly progress which helps people to discover and enter the space of divine life, the space of eternal salvation. This is the work of the Church; this is the work which the Holy Spirit will accomplish through all of us, if only we will heed the truth he reveals and be confirmed in goodness.
 
Honoring Marriage and Family
 In practical terms, this truth tells us that there can be no life worthy of the human person without a culture -- and a legal system -- that honors and defends marriage and the family.
Society must strongly reaffirm the right of the child to grow up in a family in which, as far as possible, both parents are present. Fathers of families must accept their full share of responsibility for the lives and upbringing of their children. Both parents must spend time with their children, and be personally interested in their moral and religious education. Children need not only material support from their parents, but more importantly a secure, affectionate and morally correct family environment.
Catholic parents must learn to form their family as a "domestic church," a church in the home as it were, where God is honored, His law is respected, prayer is a normal event, virtue is transmitted by word and example, and everyone shares the hopes, the problems and sufferings of everyone else. All this is not to advocate a return to some outdated style of living. It is to return to the roots of human development and human happiness.
The truth which Christ reveals tells us that we must support one another and work together with others, despite cultural, social or religious differences. It challenges us to be involved. It gives us the courage to see Christ in our neighbor and to serve Him there. And, in imitation of our Divine Master who said, "Come to me, all you who are weary and find life burdensome," we ought to invite others to come to us by stretching out a helping hand to those in need, by welcoming the newcomer, by speaking words of comfort to the afflicted. This is the goodness in which the Holy Spirit confirms us! This is how you -- women and men; young people and old; married couples and singles; parents, children and families; students and teachers; professional people, those who work and those who are suffering the terrible burden of unemployment -- this is how everyone can make a positive contribution to America and help to transform your culture into a vibrant culture of life.
This, dear brothers and sisters, is what it means to work for the kingdom of God in America today. This is the way which leads to the true progress of nations and peoples; it is the path of justice and peace, the light which shines in the darkness, the yoke which is easy and the burden which is light. This is where our souls will find rest. . . .

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Paul II in the Popemobile with John Cardinal O'Connor at St. Joseph's Seminary. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises as Traders Try To Second-Guess the Group of 7

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Cautious currency traders, still trying to second-guess what steps the Group of Seven industrial powers may take this weekend, drove the dollar higher yesterday.
The dollar held its ground even as the German mark drew strength from political uncertainty in France. 
 The dollar rose early in the week on expectations that the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- would reaffirm a commitment to keeping the dollar strong at the weekend meeting in Washington. On Wednesday and Thursday, the dollar fell on profit taking and on doubts that the leading central banks would back up a Group of Seven commitment with rounds of dollar-buying.
But yesterday, traders were not taking any chances.
"There are expectations that they will talk about the dollar during the G-7 meeting," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit. "But many traders are still being careful about their moves ahead of the meeting."
The dollar was also supported late in the day by comments by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who said he welcomed the dollar's rise since the Group of Seven's pledge in April to continue economic cooperation efforts that would stabilize currency markets.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 100.54 Japanese yen from 99.58 yen. The dollar rose to 1.4220 marks from 1.4205 marks and to 1.1449 Swiss francs from 1.1389. The British pound fell to $1.5833 from $1.5854.
The mark surged against other European currencies after Prime Minister Alain Juppe of France was accused of misusing his office when he was deputy mayor of Paris by obtaining cheap housing for his son. The allegations in French newspapers fed speculation that Mr. Juppe might be forced to resign.
The French franc fell as low as 3.5191 francs to the mark, its weakest since June 28, when it was quoted as low as 3.5306. The mark settled at 3.5125 francs, up from 3.4710 francs on Thursday. The mark typically benefits from political uncertainty in Europe.
In other currency trading, the Canadian dollar rose on continued expectations that Quebec voters would reject secession in a referendum at the end of the month. The Canadian dollar rose to 75.11 United States cents, from 74.85 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Treasuries End the Day Mainly Flat

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices barely moved yesterday as the report on September employment did little to change the market's outlook on the economy and interest rates.
The Labor Department reported that 121,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month, while the unemployment rate remained at 5.6 percent. Economists had expected payrolls to gain 161,000 for the month. 
 "If you had a bullish or a bearish view, you can still defend it within the framework of the data we've had," said Matthew Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston in New York.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 of a percentage point, to 105 29/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 6.42 percent. Trading volume was lighter than usual, with many traders preparing for a long holiday weekend. The Public Securities Association, a trade group, has recommended that the cash market in Treasury securities be closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day.
Trading was volatile in the morning. Prices first rose, then fell sharply as some traders concluded that elements of the Labor Department's report could portend a return to brisk economic growth.
"The component that spooked the market was a larger-than- expected increase in average hourly earnings," said Steven Saslow, an executive managing director at HSBC Securities in New York.
The Labor Department said average hourly earnings jumped 4 cents, to $11.52. Higher wages can help accelerate inflation. "Had it not been for that, the market would be trading better," Mr. Saslow said.
But investors later saw new reasons to believe inflation was not about to pick up speed. The Center for International Business Cycle Research at Columbia University said its preliminary leading inflation index fell to 106.2 last month from an unrevised 106.5 in August.
"You've got the best of all possible worlds: low inflation and moderate economic growth that leaves the Fed room to ease" interest rates, said Frank Rachwalski, who manages $12 billion of fixed-income securities at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
In the corporate market, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Norwest Corporation took advantage of the recent drop in government bond yields to lock in low rates on $700 million of new debt.
In the largest sale yesterday, G.M.A.C. sold $500 million of seven-year notes at a price to yield 6.657 percent, or 68.7 basis points more than the seven-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The company would have had to pay a yield of almost 7 percent on the notes if it sold them two months ago at the same spread, or yield premium.
Norwest sold $200 million of five-year notes, just a day after it raised $250 million by selling three-year notes.
Meanwhile, bonds of the Niagara Mohawk Corporation lost value after the utility proposed forming a separate company to free itself from New York State regulation over the generation of power.
