HEADLINE: A Doting Uncle Cuts Back, And a City Feels the Pain

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
IF ever a company looked after the interests of its home city, Eastman Kodak did. The company's principal founder a century ago, George Eastman, had no children and instead nurtured Rochester like a doting uncle. He gave away more than $100 million -- about $1 billion in today's dollars -- mainly to schools, the University of Rochester and local hospitals. He helped start the organization that became the United Way in Rochester. One year he even paid to remove the tonsils of every child in town.
After Eastman died in 1932, his company remained a model of civic sensibility. It resisted the temptation to use its size to negotiate for cheaper medical care for its Rochester employees, a tactic that would mean higher prices for individuals who did not work for Kodak and most small businesses and might push some companies to eliminate health benefits entirely. Many health-care experts have praised the company for an all-for-one and one-for-all spirit that has meant, among other things, that only about 7 percent of area residents do not have health insurance, compared with 15 percent nationally. In all, the move was seen as a fitting legacy of Mr. Eastman, who, according to historians, said "I want to make Rochester the best city in which to live and work." 
But now, with foreign competition growing and Wall Street demanding higher returns, good old Uncle Kodak is beginning to seem a lot less open-handed in town. And many here are worried.
For one thing, Kodak is threatening to desert its longstanding commitment to buying insurance that way. It also encouraged its retirees this summer to join a health plan that excluded two high-priced hospitals, one that was expensive partly because it trained medical students, the other because it subsidized the care of poor people. And Kodak has sharply cut its charitable contributions.
"We're being more careful how we spend our money everywhere in the world these days," said the new George at Kodak's helm -- George M. C. Fisher. "Rochester is no exception -- not only in our factories and work areas but in the community."
Indeed, Mr. Fisher, a Midwesterner who came from Motorola Inc. in 1993, admits that unlike the Kodak's legendary founder, "I personally have not spent a lot of time in the community. I said the best thing I could do for the city was to get the company back on a strong path. Therefore I would spend virtually all my time working for Kodak on business issues."
It is a story that is repeating itself across America -- a corporate benefactor that scales back locally in the name of remaining competitive globally. And it is all the more troubling because even as American companies reconsider their community obligations, Congress is whittling at Government programs that are also part of the safety net.
The cuts being proposed in Washington for Medicare and Medicaid, for example, would drain 10 percent to 15 percent from annual revenues at Strong Memorial Hospital, the University of Rochester teaching hospital, according to the hospital's chief executive, Leo P. Brideau. And at St. Mary's Hospital, which cares for many of Rochester's poor, the cuts "would severely affect our ability to provide these very necessary services to these people," said Susan Sanchez, manager of a center there that cares for 800 low-income patients a month.
For decades, Kodak had a lock on the film-products market. But in recent years it has faced an onslaught from the Japanese giant Fuji and low-priced private-label films made for the big discount retailers, as well as the growing threat of new technologies that allow filmless electronic imaging. Fuji, with a relatively young work force of 5,000 employees in the United States and only a handful of retirees, seems a particular threat to Kodak, with its 54,000 United States workers and 44,000 retirees.
As a result, Kodak is looking for ways to manage its costs that would have been unthinkable some years ago. Company officials quietly told some of Rochester's health care executives recently that unless they could reduce even further costs that are already low compared with those in other regions, Kodak might abandon its commitment to paying the same as everyone else in the community. Instead, Kodak, whose 58,000 employees and retirees in Rochester and their families account for 15 percent of the privately insured population, would start negotiating for discounts on medical care the way most big companies -- including Kodak -- routinely do in other cities.

FEW people in Rochester know much about this threat, not even the Mayor, William Johnson. But some who do mince no words. "We are not interested in beggaring our neighbor," said Helen Darling, a benefits executive with the Xerox Corporation, another big local employer. "We shouldn't say 'we want a better deal and the hell with the rest of the people.' "
Executives of some smaller businesses here also like the one-price-for-all system. "It's like one huge pool that makes it real nice for us," said Stanley Sarat, vice president of Ferronics Inc., a manufacturer with 85 employees.
Kodak has also recently told 16,000 Rochester retirees who are eligible for Medicare that starting Jan. 1, for the first time, they will have to pay part of the cost of their supplementary insurance premiums -- unless they sign up for a health plan called Preferred Care Gold that costs the company less money than other plans.
Preferred Care Gold is a first for Rochester. Unlike managed care plans in most cities, which exclude many doctors and hospitals, Rochester's two main insurers, Preferred Care and Rochester Blue Cross and Blue Shield, had always offered the services of all seven area hospitals. And 90 percent of the city's 2,000 doctors were available to patients covered by both companies.
But the new Preferred Care Gold plan excluded two hospitals with higher costs and higher prices. The first was Strong Memorial, the prestigious university hospital that George Eastman helped start in 1920 and was named for Henry A. Strong, the businessman who had financed the young inventor. The cost of training medical students adds 10 percent to 20 percent to Strong's costs, said Mr. Brideau, the hospital's chief executive.
The second hospital was St. Mary's, which serves about half of Rochester's indigent patients. The new plan also omitted some 400 doctors affiliated with the two hospitals.
Many company retirees were outraged. "We feel betrayed by Kodak," Hugh I. Race, 67, a retired sheet-metal worker, said last week. Mr. Race said that, upon his retirement in 1993, he had been promised in writing that his free health insurance -- covering any doctor or hospital he chose -- would continue for the rest of his life. Mr. Race said a group of Kodak retirees were consulting lawyers about filing a class action lawsuit against the company. "If they get away with this," he said, "what next?"
Many in the medical community were also alarmed. Dr. William Stein, an internist affiliated with Strong Memorial, criticized the exclusions and said he would refuse to take his patients who chose Preferred Care Gold to another hospital. "I made my voice heard through patients I have had for 30 years," he said. "I told them to call Preferred Care" and complain.
The protests have paid off, at least for now. Kodak executives said they were surprised that Preferred Care had excluded St. Mary's and Strong. And after some scrambling, both hospitals were brought into the Preferred Care Gold plan. Kodak made a one-year commitment to pay on the side for Strong's medical education; the hospital agreed to cost restraints acceptable to Preferred Care.
St. Mary's struck a deal of its own with Preferred Care after threatening to pull out of an arrangement that helps the company comply with a state requirement that health maintenance organizations recruit Medicaid members as well as more lucrative enrollees. "If we're good enough for their Medicaid program, we ought to be good for their Medicare people," said Stewart Putnam, the chief executive of St. Mary's.
Kodak has caused concern to Rochester on at least one more front: corporate philanthropy. Still the town's biggest giver, Kodak has cut what it donates to charities nationwide by 35 percent, to $13 million last year from $20 million in 1988, and to the local United Way by 17 percent, to $3 million.
It hasn't helped that Kodak has also cut its work force in Rochester by 40 percent since the mid-1980's, to 34,000. Not surprisingly, donations by Kodak employees to the United Way of Rochester have also dropped.
At first glance, Kodak's hard line on medical costs, which exceed $200 million annually at a company with revenue last year of $13.56 billion, might seem hard to understand. After all, Kodak and other employers here such as Xerox and General Motors say their health costs have been 20 percent to 33 percent lower in Rochester than in other cities for several years. But Mr. Fisher said that Kodak fears "that advantage is slipping away from us" as costs creep up in Rochester, while slipping in places like California where large employers win discounts on medical care for their workers. In such places, plans are also more exclusive about which doctors and hospitals they accept.
"As the leading industrial concern in this part of the state," Mr. Fisher said, "we really need to take the lead in bringing health care costs back to a rate of improvement just to make sure we don't lose ground relative to the rest of the country."
That demanding stand -- trying to improve on something that already looks good -- is typical of Mr. Fisher and many other executives these days. It is one reason that Kodak's board sacked his predecessor, Kay R. Whitmore, and ushered in Mr. Fisher, and one reason that Kodak shareholders have seen the value of their holdings in the company and a spun-off chemical division increase 56 percent since Kodak said in October 1993 that he was taking over. And many people in Rochester, while they fear any cuts in philanthropy, also acknowledge that without a financially healthy Kodak, the community will only suffer more.
"Everyone in this town loves George Fisher," said Jennifer Leonard, head of the Rochester Community Trust, a local charity organization. "On balance this community and its charitable organizations would rather have a strong Eastman Kodak with rising employment than worry about a relatively small drop in corporate giving."

EVEN as it limits its financial obligations, Kodak is looking for ways to help the community. A newly formed Rochester Health Commission -- led by a Kodak senior vice president, Michael P. Morley -- has been charged with seeking consensus in addressing health care issues.
Mr. Morley said the commission's top issue is to examine health care systems, from ones in which employers cut their own deals to ones like that used in Rochester. He said the health commission would also look at such local issues as how best to finance medical education at Strong Memorial and other hospitals, how to keep down the number of uninsured people and how to eliminate 700 hospital beds as health care increasingly shifts to doctors' offices and walk-in clinics.
These questions will be hard to answer. Meanwhile, Kodak still has "a significant commitment to community rating," said David E. Edwards, the company's benefits director, using insurer jargon for a one-price-for-all system like Rochester's. "The question is, can the local leadership and the commission and those who made this commitment get the community to adopt the 'best practices' " of managed care in other cities?" By that, Mr. Edwards meant finding ways to eliminate unneeded or inappropriate medical care that drives up prices.
If the commission cannot initiate important changes in Rochester's system, "employers and others will look for other, much more competitive alternatives," he said.
To be sure, the growth of medical costs in Rochester has slowed. Blue Cross rates have risen 2.9 percent for health maintenance organizations in the area this year and 2.5 percent for traditional coverage, close to the country's latest general inflation rate of 2.6 percent..
"But other communities are making significant improvements faster than we are," said Art Aspengren, president of the Rochester Industrial Management Council, an employer group that includes hospitals.
Dr. Stein, the internist, agreed that "the rest of the country has passed us by" in saving money -- for example, by discharging patients from hospitals more quickly. He thinks Rochester hospitals and doctors can change their ways by mutual agreements, without emulating California, the mecca of managed care, "where physicians are out of work and hospitals have closed."
But many benefits consultants who promote managed care say California should be a role model. By contrast, the Rochester H.M.O.'s have little control over doctors and hospitals because they do not pick and choose among them, said Brian Younger, a partner with Andersen Consulting.
The cures, however, could be worse than the disease. If the city loses its one-price-for-all system, "there will be more people uninsured, and that raises costs again," Mr. Aspengren said, when the uninsured show up in emergency rooms with advanced illnesses that might have been caught at an earlier, less costly stage.

HEADLINE: Time to Check Gas Gauge on Equity Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The fuel that propelled United States equity markets to record heights in the first nine months of the year -- strong economic growth, low interest rates, improvements in productivity and expanding corporate profit margins -- is running low, making several investment and mutual fund strategists increasingly wary about the outlook for stocks.
"We've had an incredible rally, but looking ahead, the economic news isn't likely to be as good," said Theresa Hamacher, chief investment officer for Prudential Mutual Funds. "Stock valuations are extended, and at some point we're going to see a selloff." 
 That could be disappointing for the thousands of individuals who have flocked to mutual funds recently -- investors who have overwhelmingly put their savings into funds that invest in American stocks -- and to the fund companies that just closed the books on three stellar quarters.
Those parties can take little comfort in the lessons of history. According to Ibbotson Associates, a Chicago investment consulting firm, only four times since 1927 have stock prices risen more in the first nine months of a year than they did in 1995. In three of those years -- 1927, 1933 and 1987 -- the market cooled off in the fourth quarter.
Nor can mutual fund investors -- particularly those whose funds have fueled big gains by loading up on technology stocks -- find solace in the possibility that Congress will cut the capital gains tax later this year. While a cut is often promoted as a way to draw new money into the market, the immediate impact could be less than positive. Investors have used two previous cuts in the rate as an excuse to convert big paper profits to the real thing.
What's a mutual fund maven to do? "There is a better case to be made for bonds than for stocks over the next nine months or so," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. Ms. Hamacher concurs. "In our mutual funds that can hold bonds, we are finding they are as good a value as many stocks," she said.
Such predictions upend the fund results of this year's first three quarters. Mutual funds that invest primarily in stocks put together a stunning nine months, with the average domestic equity fund gaining 26.9 percent, including 8.92 percent in the third quarter, according to Morningstar Inc., a fund analysis company based in Chicago.
Other types of equity funds produced impressive gains, too. Specialized funds -- focusing on specific market sectors, like technology and banking -- rose 23.5 percent on average through September and 8.7 percent in the third quarter. International stock funds heated up in the third quarter, rising 4.88 percent, more than doubling first-half gains and putting the group ahead 7.7 percent for the year.
Bond funds, while not keeping pace with the red-hot equities market, have still had a fine year. The average domestic fixed-income fund gained 11.8 percent in the first nine months, including a 2.1 percent return in the most recent quarter. Municipal bond funds rose 11.1 percent, including 2.34 percent in the most recent quarter.
Things could get better for bond funds, but many mutual fund investors are not in position to take advantage of a bond rally. "We often find that fund investors have a lot of money in C.D.'s and equities, but don't have enough in bonds," Ms. Hamacher said.
As a rule of thumb, an investor's age is a good target, Ms. Hamacher said, for the percentage of a portfolio that should be in fixed-income products. "If you've gotten caught up in the euphoria of the stock market rally and have plunged all your life savings into technology funds, maybe you should start looking at some alternatives."
Any further strength in the stock market will depend almost solely on continued growth in corporate profits, Mr. Metz said. That growth "is waning and will continue to wane," he said. "The overall momentum of the market is gone."
Mary C. Farrell, market strategist at Paine Webber Inc., finds that estimates of future earnings "remain very, very high" despite signs of a slowing economy. She expects profit growth for companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index to slow sharply this quarter. And next year a number of companies will find quarterly profits lagging behind or, at best, running even with this year's results, she predicted.
Among smaller companies, the current level of market optimism is more misguided, Ms. Farrell said. "For most small-cap companies, analysts are holding estimates that are way out of whack with the reality of a soft landing" for the economy.
While she doesn't view current stock market valuations as extreme, "the next few months will be a difficult few," she said.
"We really need an interest rate cut on the short-term end to make a strong case for upward momentum in the stock market," Ms. Farrell said. "Or it would be nice to get that capital gains tax cut."
Be careful what you ask for, warns Geoffrey Brod, vice president and equity analyst at Aeltus Investment Management, a money-management arm of Aetna Life and Casualty Company, based in Hartford. Capital gains rates have been cut twice before, in 1978 and 1981. "In both instances, the market experienced a nasty selloff over the next three to six months," he said, as the lower tax rate encouraged investors to take profits on winning positions.
Mr. Metz thinks even less of a tax cut. "A capital gains tax reduction is likely to put a lid on the stock market for as far as the eye can see," he said. "It will motivate a lot of sellers to take action and it will encourage no new buyers."
Meanwhile, any profit taking in the near future will probably be concentrated in the sector that has produced the greatest gains so far this year: technology. In fact, that happened to some degree last week when an analyst at Soundview Financial Group, a Stamford, Conn., firm that specializes in technology companies, cut his investment rating on the stocks of several semiconductor companies. It was the first such rating cut by the firm in three years, and it triggered a technology selloff.
James Townsend, chief executive of Soundview, said the firm still expects strong third-quarter and fourth-quarter earnings from most companies in the semiconductor group. But he notes that chip makers could have a tough time beating this year's spectacular earnings results beginning in the first quarter of 1996. Supplies of certain types of chips are beginning to catch up with demand, Mr. Townsend said, which could lead to lower prices.
Any disappointment in technology earnings could lead to a broad selloff in the group, because expectations continue to be so high. So while none of the strategists mentioned here are outright bears on the stock market, they do expect slower growth in the American economy to be the rule, rather than the exception.
That is one reason why mutual fund shareholders should not forget about overseas opportunities, said Ms. Hamacher, the Prudential strategist. "Economic growth is generally better overseas, and the markets have more attractive valuations," she said.
European countries offer the strongest economic growth in the world, even as many countries are undertaking structural changes, Ms. Hamacher said. Pacific Rim markets, by contrast, "are clearly fairly risky, but long-term economic growth can be the greatest there," she said.
"Those markets have lagged as well," Ms. Hamacher said, "and we are finding some good values."
But she warns against venturing into Latin American markets, which "are having trouble getting back on track," she said.
"I think there will be an opportunity there," she said, "but right now the underlying political and economic changes are not as compelling" as in other regions.
All the factors mentioned by the market strategists matter more to investors whose horizons are relatively short than to those who expect to remain invested for decades to come. To the long-term fund investors, a stock market correction of 5 percent to 15 percent in coming months could be nothing more than a minor blip -- in retrospect, of course. While it's happening, it might be frightening indeed.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1044 words

HEADLINE: Diary

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

PARKING
Delivered, Presumably, Dent-Free
In a test run in Augsburg, Germany, an automatic rotating disc brought three cars to their parking slots. The promised waiting time at this fancy new garage: 2.5 minutes
 
PUBLISHING
Those Business Week Papers
Let's see. First Procter & Gamble sued Bankers Trust, saying it had been led down a too-risky investment path. A mass of papers quickly piled up -- lawyers tend to be good at that -- and a judge decided some of them weren't quite ready for public consumption. Then Business Week got hold of the sealed papers and smelled a scoop, a judge said no, and all sorts of First Amendment hell broke loose. Last week some smoke cleared, as the judge unsealed the documents, which seemed to bolster P.&G.'s case by disclosing losses at other companies from derivatives sold by Bankers Trust. But the free-speech issue was left smoldering, for the judge also insisted he had the right to stop publication. Now it's in the lap of the appeals courts.
 
CHARITY
Throwing Big Money at Cancer
It's all too familiar these days: a takeover, a merger, a little board-room back-scratching, and some executive walks away with a sum that would boggle the mind even if it lost a couple of zeroes. But last week came a stunning variation: the mind-numbing sum was going not to an executive but to science. Jon Huntsman, who made about $1 billion in chemicals, lost both parents to cancer and battled it twice himself. That was enough to prod him to say he'd give $100 million to a cancer research center at the University of Utah. That may be walking-around money to Ted Turner, but it's the largest individual gift ever to medical research. "It's been 26 years since a man walked on the moon," Mr. Huntsman said, and we're still battling cancer. He wants to win this one.
 
AUTOS
Speaking Out at Chrysler
The seat belts are off at Chrysler. Last week the chairman, Robert Eaton, lashed out at those he said wanted to "trash" the company -- mainly Kirk Kerkorian and Jerome York. He said Mr. Kerkorian, who now owns nearly 15 percent of Chrysler, "has no real knowledge" about what's happening and is merely out for "personal gain." He said Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. York -- the former Chrysler executive who's now in Mr. Kerkorian's camp -- are merely harming other shareholders by trying to gain control.

 
REAL ESTATE
Japanese for 'Low Rent'
Japanese real estate prices are so high they're almost an international joke (so long as someone else is paying them). So when you hear that they've plummeted -- by two-thirds or more -- in recent years, does that mean they're out of the stratosphere? Not exactly. You'll still spend $6,000 or so (every month!) to rent a modest suburban house, perhaps $4,000 for a one-bedroom Tokyo apartment; this is Japanese for "plummet." And it may not even last. Last week the I.M.F. forecast a recovery for the battered Japanese economy in 1996, though it did lower its estimate for the nation's growth this year. Rent 'em while you can.
 
CAREERS
The Mailroom Gambit
It is, so it's said, the American way: if you're near the top of your field, you make a good living. So you'd think that Jay Bonin, who's in the top 200 or so Americans in his chosen field, would be riding high. If he'd been a lawyer, he might have been one of the hundreds of that profession at the Simpson defense table; if he played baseball, he'd be out there spitting with the richest of them. But Mr. Bonin's great talent is chess. Yes, there's $1 million in prize money in the world championship match that was speeding toward a conclusion last week atop the World Trade Center, but in chess, if you're not at that pinnacle, you'd better have a day job. Mr. Bonin, brilliant at chess, makes a few thousand a year at it; by day, he's a mailroom clerk.
 
INNOVATIONS
Making Cats Easier to Love
There are, those tireless statisticians tell us, 63 million cats in this country. There'd be a lot fewer if it weren't for one Edward Lowe. Cats, you see, smell. Built for the desert, they use water with enviable efficiency, but the downside is that their urine . . . well, you know. To fight the odor, people tried sawdust, sand, wood shavings, but they weren't much help. Then one day in 1947 -- a watershed day in feline history -- Mr. Lowe had a neighbor try a dried, granulated clay used to sop up grease spills in factories. And, yes, Kitty Litter was born -- along with what is now a $600 million annual industry. And Mr. Lowe? In 1990 he sold his business for $200 million. And last week he died at age 75.
 
OPPORTUNITIES
Gulps of Premium Juice
Who has the most impact on this marvelous capitalist machine we inhabit? Well, one week it might be Bill Gates, the next week Newt Gingrich, and the next, Steven Spielberg. Last week, of course, it was 12 faceless jurors in a Los Angeles courtroom. They spoke, and this mighty economy -- which prides itself on packing every second chock full -- ground to a halt for long, long minutes. You could have heard a stock drop, if any had been trading; you could have heard the phone ring, if anyone had called. The jurors spoke, and whole conglomerates were born -- reported $1 million sales of photos of the reunion of the defendant (what was his name?) and his children, tales of $50 million pay-per-view blowout interviews, other interview deals, book deals, and then probably books about the book deals. And, yes, talk of a television drama series based on the lives of two DNA experts. And it's only just begun.
 
HEALTH CARE
Medicare Plan Under Fire
Medicare may well need patching up, but the Republicans' notions about how to do it took a lot of flak last week. First came the American Medical Association, which has kept silent for much of the recent debate but now voiced concern that limits on payments would scare too many doctors away. "It would be a major blow," said an A.M.A. spokesman. Then the A.A.R.P. joined the fray, saying Congress was cutting "too much, too fast" from projected spending. Newt Gingrich has been trying to get the elderly on his side, but he doesn't seem to have succeeded. And in a final attack, the head of the American College of Physicians said bluntly, "We are not on board."

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: Why the Market Likes Johnny-One-Notes . . . And Is Skeptical Of One-Man Bands

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
A FEW weeks ago, when Robert E. Allen, the chairman of AT&T, announced his plan to break the giant company into three pieces, he cited the stock market as one reason. "The market value of AT&T was being buried," he said. "Investors couldn't understand the strategy of the combined companies." And the market promptly agreed, sending AT&T's stock skyward.
Yet the market also loved it when Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, made his move to buy Capital Cities/ABC in a $19 billion deal that will expand Disney's reach into more areas of the media and entertainment world. 
 It seems that Wall Street can't make up its mind.
The reality is a little different. The focus sought by Mr. Allen is, in general, more highly valued by investors than the breadth Mr. Eisner is after, a new analysis conducted for The New York Times shows. The analysis, by Stern Stewart, a financial management advisory firm in New York, examined the 1,000 largest companies in market value. Companies less than five years old were excluded, as were financial services, real estate and electric utility companies.
The researchers found that the stock market does prefer "pure plays" -- one-business companies -- although the fact that these companies are usually small adds to their luster. The market is more skeptical about the value and future of big, complex, multibusiness corporations. And investors seem to believe a variation on Gresham's Law: A bad business will drive out the value provided by good ones.
Stern Stewart used two key measures, which it had devised, to reach its conclusion. The first, "economic value added," looks at how a company is doing in the books. It tracks whether a company is earning, on an operating basis and after taxes, more than its cost of capital. In 1993, the most recent year examined, only the single-business companies on average made money, when profits were adjusted in this way.
Judging from the second indicator, a comparison of each company's market value with all the capital that has been plowed into it over time, investors intuitively know that focus is better: they bid up stock prices of companies whose businesses are most concentrated.
On average, one-business companies created $2.27 in market value for every dollar invested in them, while companies with five or more businesses yielded $1.55. Put another way, the average market premium over book value was 127 percent for one-business companies, versus 55 percent for companies with five or more businesses.
The trend is so powerful that 79 focused businesses delivered more in market value than the $4.23 produced by the USG Corporation, the top performer in the most diversified batch.
The analysis did not take into account how dividends might have improved shareholder returns. But managers who could not even muster $1 of market value for every dollar entrusted to them are not doing much for shareholder wealth.
Individual companies with any number of businesses may shine, of course, -- H & R Block, the tax preparer, is one example of a complex business that generated nearly $7 in market value in 1993 for every dollar of capital invested in it. But the findings bolster the long-held suspicion that investors in general do better betting on focused companies.

GRAPHIC: Charts lists companies earning 1.5 percent or more above what they paid to raise capital and companies that created at least $6 in market value for every dollar of debt and equity invested.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Heliport: New Lease And Quiet?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Residents of the high-rises along First Avenue in the 30's enjoy sweeping East River views. But for years, they have endured the staccato thunder of helicopters taking off and landing at the East 34th Street Heliport. Every few minutes, all day and late into the night, the whomp-whomp-whomp of propellers cutting the air halts conversation and drowns out televisions and stereos.
"Awful, terrible," said Luce Lauzon, who lives opposite the heliport at 401 East 34th Street. "It's nonstop. We have to keep the windows closed." Although the triple-glazed panes are designed to muffle noise, Ms. Lauzon said she has to keep the air-conditioners on so her children can sleep. 
 After years of such complaints, some relief is in the offing. The city's Economic Development Corporation, which oversees the heliport, said in an application for a new 10-year zoning permit that takeoffs and landings will be cut 47 percent next year, to approximately 28,000 or an average of 77 per day. "We're trying to balance the needs of the city's economy with the community's concerns," said Adam Brodsky, a development corporation spokesman.
But the proposed reduction does not appear to satisfy long-suffering neighbors. On Wednesday, Community Board 6 is expected to adopt a resolution calling for flights to begin at 8 A.M. and stop at 8 P.M. instead of the current 7 A.M. to 11 P.M. The board is also seeking a complete ban on weekend flights. "Give two days of peace and quiet so residents can enjoy the neighborhood they pay so dearly to live in," said William Oddo, its transportation chairman. The board's vote, however, is not binding on the Planning Commission and the City Council, which have the final say on zoning applications.
Right now, the heliport and its operator, National Helicopter Corporation of America, are in a legal limbo. National Helicopter's lease lapsed last week -- and the heliport's last zoning permit expired in 1976. For many years the company was unaware that a permit was needed, said Jay Segal, a lawyer for National Helicopter, and the application's environmental analysis turned out to be complex.
Mr. Oddo maintains that the site is ill-suited for aviation. "You have the world's busiest heliport operating on a postage stamp-size facility, no more than an acre," he said. Most flights are for sightseeing, which he said would be better handled at the heliport off Wall Street or the one along the Hudson River near the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Both are in less residential areas and closer to tourist activities.
The East 34th Street Heliport's nearest neighbor, New York University Medical Center, complains that noise and fumes it generates bother patients and have forced the hospital to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on filtering. "The fumes cause eye, ear, nose and throat irritations and can get to the point where they are nauseating," said Jean Goldberg, an N.Y.U. environmental official. "Our Gimbel Gardens are virtually unusable because of the odors."
Mr. Segal, the lawyer, defended National Heliport. "They try to operate in a way that is the most safe and least noisy," he said. "The heliport provides a valuable service as a key part of the city's transportation system and as a thing tourists really like to do." He also pointed out that the heliport existed before most of the high-rise apartment towers nearby were built.
But pointing to the lack of both a lease and a zoning permit, Mr. Oddo of C.B. 6, called the heliport "an outlaw operation for two decades." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN/CLINTON;
Fur Trade Wanes, But Its Cradle Finds New Life

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
When Tom Gigi started in the fur business 40 years ago, West 30th Street from Avenue of the Americas to Eighth Avenue was thick with rack runners, jobbers and sewing-machine operators. "During lunch, you'd be forced into the street by the crowds," recalled Mr. Gigi, 65, a coat manufacturer. "It was a great time to be a furrier."
Although it remains the heart of the nation's fur trade, these days the fur district is more likely to house accountants or photographers than pelt merchants. "This used to be strictly a fur neighborhood, but we've seen a significant change in the past five years," said Vincent Terranova, executive vice president of Bernstein Real Estate. The company, which owns or manages 10 area buildings, says fur-related businesses have been supplanted by a hodgepodge of users, from newspaper publishers to carpet dealers to light-fixture makers. 
 Those furriers who survive tend to be concentrated in a handful of buildings, like 150 West 30th Street and 345 Seventh Avenue, Mr. Terranova said. Conversion of other bulky loft space south of Pennsylvania Station usually requires costly removal of storage vaults and refrigeration equipment. At 17 percent, the area's vacancy rate is much higher than a decade ago. Current rents on West 30th Street range from $8 to $12 a square foot, compared with $10 to $20 in the garment district, a few blocks north, where the economic picture has brightened somewhat in recent years.
But New York's fur industry has been buffeted hard by animal-rights advocates, a weak economy, cheap imports and a string of warm winters. And the future, some industry analysts say, looks even bleaker.
Nat Berkowitz, who opened Miller & Berkowitz furriers in 1950, knows only too well how times have changed. Customers who once bought a new coat every five years now make do with older furs or squeeze into those that do not quite fit. In summers past, his chilled vault at 224 West 30th Street overflowed with 8,000 coats left for storage by loyal clients. This year, the number is down to 6,500. "People would rather save the money," Mr. Berkowitz, 66, said. "It used to be that when you drove up the New York State Thruway to the Catskill resorts, there would be a mink stole hanging in every car window."
When Maureen Locke was looking for space to open her company, Versailles Lighting, the fur district was an obvious choice. Her husband's family has run Mechutan Fur on West 30th Street since the 1920's. "The fur business is going down the tubes, but I think this is a great neighborhood," said Ms. Locke, who has rented an entire floor above Miller and Berkowitz since June. She cited the district's reasonable rents, generous space and proximity to mass transit. "I can see Penn Station from my window," she said. "You can't beat that." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: U.S. Doesn't Stint on Defense Readiness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Andrew Cockburn's "Swords Into Stock Shares" (Op-Ed, Oct. 3) incorrectly asserts that the Defense Department has slighted readiness to keep its procurement budget high.
From its peak in 1985, defense spending has fallen by 40 percent after inflation, and procurement is down 70 percent. The number of men and women serving in the active-duty military is 33 percent lower today than at the end of the cold war. 
 But this peace dividend has not come at the cost of readiness. In the drawdowns following World War II, Korea and Vietnam, readiness slipped badly. By contrast, the Clinton Administration has kept readiness high, favoring training, operations and maintenance over procurement. Our forces have performed well, wherever called -- in Rwanda, in Haiti and in the skies over Bosnia.
"The demands upon our forces these last two years have reinforced the wisdom of putting readiness first . . . near-term readiness today remains at historically high levels," the Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman, Gen. John Shalikashvili, recently told the Senate Armed Services Committee.
Other points in the article are wrong. In particular, Mr. Cockburn incorrectly states Defense Secretary William Perry, the Director of Central Intelligence, John M. Deutch, and Paul Kaminski, Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Technology, "controlled" a defense contractor that received a small contract from the Defense Department. They do not control any Defense contractors.
An investment partnership in which they have interests, which they have not been able to sell, helped finance about a dozen small companies, including several that have won defense contracts. They have recused themselves completely from any dealings with these companies, and the Senate Armed Services Committee has approved these arrangements.
 
KENNETH H. BACON
Assistant to Secy. of Defense
for Public Affairs
Washington, Oct. 5, 1995

HEADLINE: Why Debt Ceiling Matters to Us All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roger C. Altman's "Real Price of Default" (Op-Ed, Oct. 1), on the possible consequences of a default on the United States debt because of Congressional refusal to raise the debt ceiling, only hints at the immediate catastrophic consequences of such an action. 
 The dollar is the international transaction currency: most international transfers of funds are made in United States dollars. The short-term United States Government securities market is closely tied to the international as well as domestic transfer of funds. Short-term United States securities serve as a source of liquidity and as a repository for temporarily idle funds.
If the debt ceiling is not raised, making it impossible to service these short-term obligations, they will become illiquid, instantly drying up the pool that serves international and domestic banking in its transfer function.
The dollar will then immediately lose its status as the global transaction currency. Holders of dollar assets in any form will sell to avoid losses. The resulting free fall in the international value of the dollar will force stringent currency controls and quickly terminate our ability to import such vital commodities as oil, except for direct payment of gold or foreign exchange.
Given the vast holdings of United States dollars and United States Government obligations in overseas private portfolios, no amount of central bank intervention will prevent such a disastrous flight from the dollar.
Even if Congress should rue its action the next day and raise the debt ceiling, international trust in the stability of our Government and its obligations will be compromised forever. A gallon of gas may cost $6. Is this what we want?
 
RICHARD HYSE
Oswego, N.Y., Oct. 2, 1995
 
The writer retired as professor of economics at SUNY.

HEADLINE: Pfizer's Role In Groton Schools

 BODY:
Kudos on your article ("For Groton, a Pfizer Commitment," Sept. 3). I would like you to know that this commitment is expressed in ways that were not described in the article. 
 The Pfizer Corporation has made a major commitment to advance the quality of science and mathematics programs, not only in the Groton public schools, but also in schools throughout southeastern Connecticut. In Groton, Pfizer has provided modern equipment to upgrade middle school science labs and has provided opportunities to our science teachers to work with Pfizer research scientists during the summer months. These teachers have been able to enrich their classroom instruction with this real world experience. Also, Pfizer encourages its employees to volunteer in our school in a variety of capacities. Pfizer then supports their employee volunteerism by donating funds to the schools in which they work. They are good neighbors who set a high standard for business-education partnerships. We are fortunate to have Pfizer in Groton.
GEORGE M. REILLY
The writer is Superintendent of Schools in Groton.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Taking Heart in New York City

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
NEVER mind that Newt Gingrich and other New York bashers prattle on about the city. New Yorkers are harder on themselves. Never mind that for years Bleak Street has replaced Broadway as the economic thoroughfare. Take heart, New Yorkers -- from the outside, the city seems to be looking better.
"The whole perception of New York is that it has come back," said Dick Wolf, a television producer who has been filming "Law and Order" in the city for six years. Mr. Wolf began shooting a second series, "New York Undercover," two years ago. This year three more dramatic series, "Central Park West," "New York News" and "The Education of Matt Waters," are using the city as their backdrop, giving its streets and skyline their most pervasive television presence since the 1960's. 
 Although the city continues to lag behind much of the nation in job growth and business expansion, 1995 is proving to be a boom year, at least through the lens of the entertainment industry. In contrast to the 1980's, when the city's economy was driven mainly by finance and real estate development, economists say its most vibrant businesses now range from tourism to movie production, restaurant sales to computer software design.
Business executives and people in the arts say public sentiment about the city is shifting. More people want to be here, in the flesh or through the vicarious jolt of television and movies. Enhancing the city's reputation has been the influx of Hollywood luminaries like Steven Spielberg and Demi Moore.
Movie production has soared. City records show that a record high 157 movies were filmed last year, 56 more than in 1993. Patricia Reed Scott, commissioner of film, theater and broadcasting, said the 1994 television and movie production had pumped $4.3 billion into the city economy. Part of the resurgence in movies and television comes from hard-won concessions from local production crews whose 1990 labor dispute with the Alliance of Motion Producers brought filming to a virtual standstill. A settlement the following year laid the plans for this year's busy workload, Ms. Scott said.
Sales figures are not available for the city's 15,500 restaurants, but they had 129,300 workers in June, 3,300 more than a year earlier.
 
Multiplex and More
 "It's a boom time around here," said Michael O'Neal, owner of O'Neals', a West 64th Street restaurant that has been buoyed by increased attendance at Lincoln Center and several nearby movie theaters, including a huge new Sony multiplex. Business at O'Neals' is up 10 percent this year. And coming soon to the area are a Barnes & Noble bookstore and an enlarged Tower Records. The cultural density alone promises to make it a crossroads for glitterati, literati and assorted esthetes.
The number of passengers arriving at LaGuardia, Kennedy and Newark airports rose 2 percent during the first half of this year, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The city's Convention and Visitors Bureau said hotel occupancy rose 4 percent in the first half of this year. Attendance at Broadway shows rose 12 percent, and ticket sales at tourist attractions like the Empire State Building and the Statue of Liberty rose 14 percent in the same period.
 
The Dollar and the Pope
 The city's appeal to foreign tourists has increased partly because of the low exchange rate of the dollar. A surge in visitors is particularly apparent this month because of the Pope's visit and the 50th anniversary of the United Nations.
Still, stubborn problems persist in the local economy, many of them rooted in the boom and bust of the 1980's. The city continues to lose jobs to Westchester County, northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn. Banking, once one of its fastest growing industries, is now hemorrhaging jobs. A series of mergers and takeovers, including the proposed merger of Chemical Bank and Chase Manhattan, has reduced employment by 6,800, or 5.2 percent, over the last year, according to Federal data. Total employment in the city has risen only slightly, to 3 million from 2.9 million a year ago.
But economists say conditions in the city could be worse. "The fear was that New York would fall off when national growth slowed down," said John Weiting, New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "But the city has held up well, and that has to be considered good news."
Another sign of promise, analysts say, is the recent spate of takeovers of television networks, including ABC and CBS and the Turner Broadcasting System, which is based in Atlanta but would have a New York City parent, Time Warner Inc., if its proposed merger is completed. Unlike corporate acquisitions that have led to layoffs, the media marriages could benefit the city. That is because the network takeovers have been spurred in part by Federal deregulation of broadcast entertainment, which will enable them to move more freely into film production and syndication.
"These New York companies can now deliver to larger audiences," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of economics and urban planning at New York University.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
One Revolution Is Enough in Mexico

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
WHEN the price of rice shot up in the Philippines recently, thousands of people shut down the country's public transportation and set tires ablaze in Manila's streets to protest. When the Government of Mexico jacked up the price of tortillas for the third time this year -- making the flat corn cakes 50 percent more expensive than they were in 1994 -- nary a whimper was heard.
Mexico has been through a tough year in very serious ways -- impoverishment caused by a deep economic crisis, humiliation at having to beg the United States for help in solving the crisis and seemingly endless political scandals involving the ruling elite. A million more people are out of work than were a year ago, interest rates for a while topped 100 percent, and a series of assassinations still have not been satisfactorily solved. 
 But Mexicans today seem totally unwilling to mount sustained protest, let alone a revolt, against such conditions.
What's going on? Isn't this the Mexico that is famously proud of its 1910 Revolution, the Mexico always ready to give asylum and encouragement to revolutionaries from its Caribbean and Central American neighbors?
Curiously, perhaps, the reason Mexicans can show such remarkable self-restraint in the face of modern corruption, poverty and inept administration is that they know so much about rebellion -- not just the romance, but the cost.
This is a country where the names of Emiliano Zapata, Francisco "Pancho" Villa and other heroes of the 1910 Revolution are inscribed in gold letters on the walls of congress. The Mexican national anthem begins "Mexicans, onward to the shout of war."
At the same time, the country abhors violence, mostly out of bitter memory. The 1910 Revolution quickly succeeded in overthrowing the dictator Porfirio Diaz. But for most of the next decade Mexicans fought among themselves for power. A million Mexicans died. And in the end, the poor people for whom the Revolution had supposedly been fought were little better off than before, leaving the revolution unfinished.
 
Revolution Si, Rebellion No
 So one Revolution seems to have been enough. The political party that emerged from the chaos came to be called, incongruously, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, as if that one revolution could be institutionalized, providing a font of insurrectionary rhetoric without the need to ever launch another rebellion.
There have been other times in Mexico's recent past when it seemed that the country was set to blow, and only some thin strip of patience kept the country from crossing into chaos. Ten years ago, when an earthquake shattered great swaths of the city and left more than 10,000 people dead, the event was likened to a quake in Nicaragua in 1972 that proved a mighty spur to the uprising that later toppled the Somoza dictatorship there; in that case, even the middle class could not stomach the government's feeble and corrupt handling of reconstruction.
"The question everyone wanted to ask then was whether this earthquake was going to cause a revolution in Mexico too," said Manuel Camacho Solis, the former mayor of Mexico City.
Mr. Camacho said that discontent did grow in Mexico at the time, and that the country perhaps flirted with the possibility of widespread violence, but then backed away. In the process, Mexico made notable progress toward legitimizing local political organizing. Still, the P.R.I. remained in power, as it does to this day, and Mexico continues to be remarkably willing to bend without breaking.
Among the countries of Latin America, Mexico has traditionally been the most complacent, and in that regard most stable, said Jorge G. Castaneda, a Mexican political scientist who has studied opposition movements. He attributes Mexico's remarkable stoicism in part to the country's long and suffocating colonial past.
"It was in many ways the strongest colonial state, so it follows that it should have the weakest civil society," Mr. Castaneda said. "You can't have it both ways."
Mexican institutions have also done their part to keep the Mexican people in line for much of this century. Labor and the Government have long been allied, a condition that means unions often seem to have everything but workers' rights in mind. That became clear last May 1, Mexico's Labor Day.
At the time, because of the economic crisis, millions of people could not pay their debts and inflation had raised prices 8 percent in April alone -- an increase equal to the total for 1994.
Against that background, the Government braced for the worst during the May Day parade, traditionally an occasion for the unions to blow off some steam. But the cigar-chomping 95-year-old leader of the Mexican Confederation of Labor, Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, cancelled the parade, saying there was nothing for workers to celebrate (or, evidently, to protest against).
Social fuses are not always so easily extinguished. On Jan. 1, 1994, several hundred Maya Indians and disgruntled farm workers led by a small group of intellectuals shocked Mexico and the world by rising out of the Lacandona rain forest in Chiapas and declaring war on then-president Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
The rebels, calling themselves Zapatistas, vowed to march into Mexico City, but they found the rest of the country unwilling to pick up the revolutionary banner. In the end, the Zapatista uprising, by raising fears of chaos, probably helped the P.R.I. win the presidency again in August, following a campaign in which the party promised peace and stability.
 
Resignation as a Virtue
 With the demise of the Soviet Communist Party, the P.R.I. has taken over as the longest-ruling political party on Earth. Going 66 years without a change of power in Mexico has numbed many Mexicans, who see political activism as futile.
"Resignation," wrote Octavio Paz, referring to himself and other Mexicans, "is one of our most popular virtues."
Living in a seismically active region of the world also has contributed to a kind of fatalism about natural shocks and disasters. Economic crises return regularly as well (usually coinciding with the end of the six-year presidential terms).
The Zapatista call to arms did push some people like Anatolio Franco Bonifaz to take control of their own destinies, but not at all in the way the armed leaders of the movement had pictured. When Mr. Bonifaz, 30, was laid off as a waiter last April because the economic slowdown, on top of the Chiapas uprising, had dried up the resort business, he was angry and frustrated.
He went to see his brother in the dirt-poor Indian town of San Andres Larrainzar, where peace talks between the Government and the Zapatistas were about to start. Anticipating the hundreds of journalists, Government officials and onlookers who would crowd the village, Mr. Bonifaz and his wife opened a restaurant called "The Dialogue" in his brother's living room.
"I did it because of the same necessity as always here in Mexico," he said. "The only form of hope here is to continue to work."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
It's Amtrak Against Everyone on the Road

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DECLINING budgets make for shifting alliances. But would you believe the Highway Users Federation siding with the American Public Transit Association?
Against Amtrak? 
 Amtrak needs money, which is setting off a philosophical debate over subsidies by one mode of transportation to another, and by people of one economic class to another. And the rail line's quest for money has made the highway lobby -- oil companies, car manufacturers, construction interests and others -- a little nervous.
Since it was created in 1971, Amtrak has received over $13 billion, including nearly $1 billion for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. The railroad now covers 81 percent of its operating costs from revenues, up from 48 percent in 1981. But Congress wants to eliminate subsidies soon.
Amtrak believes it could run without operating subsidies, if it had the capital for newer trains and better tracks. So it set its sights on a permanent source, a half cent of the 18-cent-a-gallon Federal gasoline tax.
 
Congress's Nickel
 The half penny is part of a five-cent increase that Congress put into effect in 1990. Beginning this fiscal year, 2 1/2 cents was supposed to go to the Highway Trust Fund, with half a cent going to the fund's mass-transit account.
It is a scrap, as taxes go, bringing about $2.50 a year from the average car. But the total comes to about $600 million.
The Senate Commerce Committee approved the idea of earmarking the money for Amtrak. But in the House, the chairman of the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, Bud Shuster, Republican of Pennsylvania, is not warm to the idea.
"Taking money out of the highway trust fund for Amtrak violates a basic commitment that we made, the first contract with America," he said. "It was between Dwight Eisenhower and the Congress, and it was, you pay your gasoline tax and we'll use that money to improve the nation's highways and bridges."
Amtrak's proposal also set off the public-transit lobby, its former ally, which is determined to keep what it has managed to siphon from the fund. "The half penny belongs to mass transit," said Jack R. Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association. "Both Amtrak and the nation's transit providers are woefully short. Does weakening Peter to strengthen Paul help the traveling public?"
The road lobby is siding with the transit systems. Healthy bus and rail systems around cities reduce congestion far more than Amtrak does, says William D. Fay, president of the Highway Users Federation.
But what really worries Mr. Fay more than the half cent is that the Senate bill would let the states use highway money from Washington to help finance Amtrak.
And the states like Amtrak. When its board voted in April to cut about 22 percent of the system's miles, eight states stepped up with money to avert cuts. In all, states pay Amtrak about $70 million a year.
The road lobby also says this results in poor people with cars helping pay for richer people who ride trains. "It's a middle-class subsidy," said Charles J. DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute.
But rail riders have subsidized others before, according to Philip M. Martin, an aviation consultant with Gellman Research Associates, of Jenkintown, Pa., and a former operations analyst at Conrail. The railroads had a trust fund, like the airlines and the highways, he said, but it was folded into the general fund in 1962. At that time, he said, "neither the air trust fund nor the highway trust funds were self-sufficient; they were still taking money from the general fund to pay for projects."
At a news conference where Amtrak made its pitch for the half cent, the Mayor of Meridian, Miss., John Robert Smith, extolled the city's new center where buses, taxis, airport limousines and trains all come together. "These modes should feed each other, not feed on each other," he said.
In principle, all parties agree.

HEADLINE: Black March Stirs Passion and Protests

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Life is desperate and dangerous in Al Brown's faded neighborhood here. Drugs and poverty are efficient cold-blooded killers, and in the middle of any day of any week, it is easy to find dozens of young black men hanging out on the streets with no place to go to earn bread or pride.
But these days, Mr. Brown, a community advocate on Chicago's West Side, is more hopeful than he has been in years because of an upcoming blend of political parade and religious revival meeting in Washington called the Million Man March. The brainchild of Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, the march is stirring passions and debate. 
 March organizers hope that one million black men from all walks of life will answer Mr. Farrakhan's call for "A Holy Day of Atonement, Reconciliation and Responsibility" and gather in Washington on Oct. 16 to pray and protest and promise to return home better men.
"Finally, somebody is doing something," Mr. Brown said the other day as he passed out march fliers to young men along a sorry stretch of Madison Street. "The situation in black America is so bad now that it almost doesn't matter what that something is as long as it's some kind of action."
The goals of the march are vague, but it is generating excitement and arguments in black neighborhoods and on radio shows around the country. Some black men say the march represents a fresh bold step toward black unity and self-reliance in a national climate of racial tension, mistrust and government cutbacks.
For others, who say the idea of unity is laughable because black women have been told not to come, the march could signal the beginning of a regressive retreat into self-segregation and conservative politics.
Salim Muwakkil, a Chicago writer who plans to attend the march, likens it to the largely white men's Christian movement of so-called traditional and family values, the Promise Keepers, flavored with black nationalism.
"Historically, black people have always turned to black nationalism during hostile racial times," he said. "The Republican Contract With America shocked black people into believing that white America was finished with civil rights. Everywhere I go, people are talking about the march. I think it will be pivotal."
Mr. Farrakhan calls his march "a day of atonement," a chance for black men to apologize to "their women" and to God for not taking better care of their families.
It is also an opportunity, the Muslim minister says, for black men to declare to the country that they are ready, willing and able to serve and protect their own communities and children without the advice or consent of the government.
But even some supporters of the march, like Mr. Muwakkil, say they are put off by the talk of "atonement" because it seems to focus on black men more than on what many of them see as the real source of the nation's racial heartache: unemployment and institutional racism.
"The atonement talk certainly has the whiff of blame the victim," Mr. Muwakkil said. "But a lot of people are ignoring that. They say, 'That may be Farrakhan's reason for marching, but my reason is to let white America know we ain't going to take it any more.' "
The Rev. Henry J. Lyons, president of the largely black National Baptist Convention, which has 8.5 million members, said he was advising his followers not to take part because of theological differences with Mr. Farrakhan's Muslims and because women have not been included as full partners or participants.
"Because of these very strong differences," Mr. Lyons said, "I cannot under any circumstances support this march."
But dozens of other Christian ministers, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis, the national director of the march, are encouraging the men in their congregations and organizations to attend. Even the American Jewish Congress has "enthusiastically" endorsed at least the goals of the march, said the group's executive director, Phil Baum.
"But we are concerned with it being organized by Mr. Farrakhan," Mr. Baum said, adding that he was "disappointed that so many of our friends in the black leadership" have apparently embraced Mr. Farrakhan. In a news release, the Congress called Mr. Farrakhan "one of the country's most prominent and unrepentant public bigots."
On Tuesday, Mr. Jackson met with several leaders of Jewish groups in New York to discuss the goals of the march. Mr. Baum said the meeting was helpful, but his concerns about Mr. Farrakhan's role remained.
In Washington, a White House spokesman said that President Clinton supported the march's goals of having people think about their responsibilities to families, themselves and communities but that he had some concerns about the gathering.
Adolph Reed, a black professor of political science at Northwestern University, who does not plan to be one of the million, said, "The message of Farrakhan's march is fundamentally conservative and blatantly sexist."
March organizers say that since black women have made countless sacrifices for their families and communities over the years, the march is a signal that it is time for black men to stand up and relieve them of their burden. The women and the men who do not go are being asked to observe "a day of absence" by staying indoors and not shopping.
"But Farrakhan," Mr. Reed said, "is not really rocking any boats of the white elite. This is his ploy to be designated as a legitimate race spokesman or, at the least, to get on the guest list of 'Nightline.' "
Mr. Farrakhan proposed the march more than a year ago but for months received little support for his vision beyond his Nation of Islam.
But, in recent months and weeks, with affirmative action under attack, jobs steadily disappearing from the inner city and police abuse and corruption scandals from Philadelphia to Los Angeles, a cross section of black leadership has climbed onto Mr. Farrakhan's bandwagon.
Ministers, nationalists, Pan Africanists, fraternities, sororities, Elks, Masons and the Congressional Black Caucus have endorsed the march.
Still, no one knows how many black men will actually show up in Washington. Estimates run from 50,000 to more than one million. Mr. Chavis said more than 11,100 buses and 100 airplanes had been chartered to take people to the march.
The "march," in fact, is envisioned as more of "a gathering" by organizers, who envision an assembly 23 blocks long, facing the Capitol. They say they chose to hold it on a workday to show a willingness to sacrifice a payday.
In Oxford, N.C., population 8,000, the funeral home owner, George W. Wright, is the local march organizer. He said people there could afford only one bus but if they had the money, "we could fill at least three."
"I'm paying for the one bus we do have," Mr. Wright said. "I personally know hundreds of people who would like to go and can't afford to. They can't take off of work because it takes every penny and nickel to provide for their families."
In Chicago, organizers say nearly 50,000 men will board buses and go to Washington. Every Monday night for months, dozens of black men and women have met in a church on the city's South Side to plan the march and raise money.
"The grass roots are on fire," said the Rev. Al Sampson, a Chicago march organizer.
Mr. Chavis, the former director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he expected more than 1.2 million black men to attend. If even half that number shows up, the march will more than double the size of the famous 1963 March on Washington, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. electrified 250,000 men and women of all colors with his "I have a dream" speech, imploring the country to live up to its ideals of fairness.
The march has been shrouded in other controversies, including charges of sexism.
"The emphasis on black manhood as a solution is dangerous," said Michelle Boyd, a 25-year-old black graduate student. "Women are put on the back burner. That's not the direction we should be going in. Our flags ought to be going up."
In a concession to women, march organizers have added Rosa Parks, the civil rights legend, and Maya Angelou, the poet, to the list of speakers.
A committee is putting the finishing touches on the march's manifesto, and organizers say they intend to begin registering eight million unregistered voters in time for the election next year.
In the beginning, the march was more spiritual than political. Talk of God and morality remain central, but political issues have elbowed their way onto the agenda as the idea for the march has spread and pulled together a diverse group of supporters. Robert T. Starks, a professor of political science at Northeastern Illinois University in Chicago, is the chairman of the march's manifesto committee.
"We know what we are going to ask for," Mr. Starks said. "We're just refining the words. We're talking about racism and cutbacks in education. We're talking about redistricting and forcing blacks out of office. We have a political agenda. There's no doubt about that."
In Chicago, it is Mr. Brown's self-appointed mission to persuade more brothers to make the trip.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Brown, along with C. B. Johnson, who runs a drug prevention and treatment program, and Marion Jackson, a volunteer with an anti-drug program, gathered up a bunch of march fliers and charter bus sign-up sheets and went into the streets searching for recruits.
One of their stops was the Moler Barber College, a school for both men and women, where Mr. Johnson asked Marian Parker if he could leave some fliers. "It's time for us as black men to stand up," he said.
"That's right," Mrs. Parker said.
"It's time for us to atone for our actions," Mr. Johnson said.
"Right on," Mrs. Parker said. "Could you leave some more of these? I got a shop on the South Side."
Willya Holmes, a poet who was getting her hair done, asked Mr. Johnson: "Where do you go from here? This march is just one day."
"That's true," Mr. Johnson said. "The real work starts on Oct. 17, when we get back home."
"What are you going to do?"
"I'm going to stand up and be a man."
"It takes a march for you to do that?" asked Shantelle Weathers, 19.
"Naw," Mr. Johnson said. "I do that anyway."

Recently, he, C. B. Johnson, center, and Larry Hairly recruited for the event, in Washington on Oct. 16. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Proud of Gains, Finance Ministers Encourage Dollar's Rebound

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Finance Ministers of the world's seven biggest industrial nations today welcomed the dollar's recent climb on currency markets and made clear they do not think it has risen too high.
In a strikingly self-congratulatory statement issued after a day of talks here, the ministers said they welcomed "the orderly reversal in the movements of major currencies that began following their April meeting," when a weak dollar checked its slide and the strong Japanese and German currencies began to decline. 
 The ministers said they would "welcome a continuation of these trends consistent with underlying economic fundamentals," indicating that they would like to see the dollar move a bit higher and the yen lower, but without pricing American exports out of foreign markets or making Japanese goods too inexpensive here, further swelling the United States trade deficit.
The ministers also reaffirmed their commitment "to reduce imbalances and cooperate closely in exchange markets," a veiled warning to foreign exchange dealers not to push the currencies opposite their recent favorable trends, a move that could possibly bring another round of coordinated intervention by the nations' central banks.
The ministers of the so-called Group of Seven -- the United States, Britain, France, Italy, Canada, Germany and Japan -- agreed that all their countries must do more to reduce budget deficits in order to lower interest rates and stimulate global economic growth. But they also said that "in most countries the conditions for continued growth and employment gains are in place and inflation is well under control or declining."
But at a news conference after the meeting, the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, entered a caveat on Japan. He said that Japan's latest stimulus package might succeed in ending four years of economic stagnation there, sparking more growth and increasing foreign imports, but he warned that Japan must also be ready "to take additional measures" if the recovery proves disappointing.
The First Deputy Prime Minister of Russia, Anatoli B. Chubais, also attended today's meeting, and the ministers congratulated him on signs that Russia's economy appeared finally to be pulling itself out of its recent collapse, helped by large foreign loan infusions and debt forgiveness. They urged Moscow to stick with the painful austerity measures that the ministers said are now starting to bear fruit.
Finally, the ministers asked the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to start preparing money to help in the post-war reconstruction of Bosnia if current peace efforts succeed.
Representatives of the world's developing nations, meanwhile, appealed today to the United States Congress to restore planned cuts in America's contribution to a key international aid agency. Finance ministers of the so-called Group of 24, which represents the developing world in international monetary negotiations, asked Congress to "reconsider the magnitude of U.S. contributions" to the World Bank's soft loan agency, known as the International Development Association, "in order to attain the level originally committed."
Such reconsideration, the ministers said in a communique, "should take into account not only the enlightened long-term self-interest of donor countries but also the moral and social issues involved."
The appeal came as House and Senate leaders are to meet next week to thrash out a compromise American aid bill that may cut the United States contribution to the development association by half or more.
