HEADLINE: Buchanan's Tough Tariff Talk Rattles G.O.P.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: FORT DODGE, Iowa, Oct. 3

 BODY:
When Republican contenders for President swing through Iowa's farm towns searching for votes in the first caucuses of the electoral season, there is a monotonous ring to their economic prescriptions for America.
A flat tax, cutting the Internal Revenue Service down to size, slashing taxes on capital gains and inheritances and re-engineering Medicare are advocated by all the candidates. And almost all endorse the traditional favorite cause of the Republican Party, free trade. 
 But not the economic maverick of the Republican race, Patrick J. Buchanan. Mr. Buchanan, the former speechwriter for Richard Nixon and communications director for Ronald Reagan, who is rolling through Iowa in a giant Winnebago ("Caution: Future President Aboard" proclaims its bumper sticker) with a message of unapologetic economic nationalism. People seem to be listening -- particularly his rivals for the nomination, whom Mr. Buchanan is dragging to the right -- and that only makes the former conservative counterpoint of CNN's "Crossfire" all the bolder.
He is striking a surprisingly responsive chord here and in New Hampshire, drawing respectable crowds and placing second or third to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas in polls, and often neck-and-neck with Senator Phil Gramm of Texas. Both men have supported President Clinton's free-trade initiatives and Republican strategists say Mr. Buchanan's early success is forcing the two lead candidates to adjust their rhetoric to capture his following.
The White House is trying to capitalize on the shift: top Administration officials including Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin have seized on Mr. Buchanan's campaign as the embodiment of a new and dangerous form of isolationism.
Mr. Buchanan calls it pragmatism. Big budget deficits? How about helping finance the Federal Government with a 10 percent tariff on every import from Japan, Mr. Buchanan tells his audiences here, until its trade deficit with the United States disappears? For the Chinese, a 20 percent tariff, a quick way to teach them a lesson early about running up Japanese-scale trade surpluses and imprisoning dissidents. As the crowds warm up, Mr. Buchanan goes into his plans for a "social tariff" on products made in Mexico and other developing economies to "insulate us from un-American competition with workers making 75 cents or a dollar an hour."
Japan and Germany, he argues, "are countries out to win industrial supremacy, which leads to economic supremacy, which then leads to military and geopolitical supremacy." "If we don't put America first, who will? You think the Prime Minister over in Japan will? No way."
Mr. Buchanan's solutions -- including a five-year suspension of all immigration until American wages begin to grow again -- are denounced by his many critics as an isolationist and protectionist fantasy, an emotional appeal to workers who long for a return to the workplace stability of the 1950's and 60's, when America's economic power in the world loomed far larger. Certainly Mr. Buchanan's strategy would overturn the economic order pursued by Republican and Democratic administrations for 50 years and violate the country's trade accords with its biggest economic partners -- accords Mr. Buchanan says must be scrapped anyway because they undercut America's ability to control its own economic destiny.
Mr. Buchanan's views are the polar opposite of the Clinton Administration's economic policy of the past three years. Now, many in the White House view his candidacy as a chance to cast the Republicans as extreme isolationists who are unable to distinguish between short-term pain and long-term strategies for enhancing both American exports and American influence. Mr. Christopher referred to Mr. Buchanan recently as "the strident voice" on immigration and economic integration with the world, whose views are the antithesis of the "Administration's conviction that we should not erect barriers around this country."
Speaking along with Mr. Christopher in Washington, Mr. Rubin also referred to Mr. Buchanan, saying, "I think it should be very important in the '96 campaign to have a debate on international economic policy -- whether we should retreat, or continue the path that the President has taken, which is to engage with the world and take a true leadership role."
But Mr. Rubin concedes that Mr. Buchanan has struck a real chord, one linked to the insecurity felt by a wide variety of American workers despite three years of solid economic growth, and growing confidence about America's competitive prowess. That insecurity is not only one of Mr. Clinton's largest challenges as the campaign approaches, it is one of the reasons the Republican Party is going through such a wrenching change.
Mr. Buchanan is betting that the national mood has swung in his direction, and "what will come out of this is a new kind of coalition -- Perot people, right-to-life groups and gun owners, and economic nationalists."
"My problem is the Republican establishment," he said.
To travel with Mr. Buchanan these days is to witness the rapid fraying of the free trade, pro-big business philosophy that has dominated the Republican Party for decades. Like the freshmen Republicans, he makes corporate America his favorite target, arguing that his tariff system would teach them a little patriotism by penalizing firms that ship jobs to Mexico or Singapore and then export their products back to the United States.
"If the corporate chieftains don't care about the U.S.A.," he says, in a line that regularly draws big cheers, "I don't care about them."
After a rally in a hotel here, Mr. Buchanan said, "Economic nationalism can move these folks." Many of the 100 farmers and small business owners at the rally said they were drawn by Mr. Buchanan's fervent opposition to abortion and to any American participation in United Nations peacekeeping efforts in Bosnia, Rwanda, "or anyplace else where we have no national interest." But many others said they were followers of Ross Perot, and found in Mr. Buchanan an economic ideology compatible with the one Mr. Perot espoused in the 1992 campaign.
He goes considerably further, however, than Mr. Perot ever did. Mr. Perot fought the North American Trade Agreement, and turned the debate into a far broader argument over whether free trade remains in the American interest. Mr. Buchanan has taken the next step, regularly denouncing the far bigger world trade accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, that was passed in a lame-duck session of Congress in November, with support from Mr. Dole and Mr. Gramm.
Most of Mr. Buchanan's audiences seem only vaguely aware of the details of the treaty, which lowered tariff barriers around the world. But they perk up when Mr. Buchanan starts an attack on the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based group that, under the treaty, became the new arbiter of international trade rules and that would almost certainly find his unilateral tariffs on Japan and China a violation of those rules.
In Mr. Buchanan's stock speech, the trade organization becomes another example of how the United States has "handed off its sovereignty" to non-Americans, placing its future in the hands of "organizations that give Fidel Castro a vote that is equal to America's." If he wins office, he told Iowans this week, "we're out of NAFTA, and we're out of the W.T.O."
"When I raise my hand to take the oath of office, this whole new world order is coming crashing down," he vows.
The tariff talk makes farmers understandably nervous, because it would invite retaliation against agricultural products -- Japan's biggest import from the United States. Mr. Gramm has already told Iowans that Mr. Buchanan's tariffs would turn their state "into a dust bowl."
"This isn't all that fertile ground for the tariffs argument," Mr. Buchanan concedes. "It goes over better in New Hampshire."
Not surprisingly, Mr. Buchanan skips past any discussion of the millions of jobs created as the American economy expanded in recent years, and dismisses the Administration's claim that the North American Free Trade Agreement supports 2.5 million jobs and has "protected" 700,000 jobs that were threatened by Mexico's downturn. He spins out a stream of examples of plant closings and consolidations that he characterizes as the price of free trade: Eveready Battery Company's operations moved from Iowa to the industrial outskirts of Singapore, the use of low-paid Mexicans by one of Iowa's biggest beef packers. History, Mr. Buchanan insists, is on his side. "Look at the period of 1865 to 1914, the era of our highest tariffs," Mr. Buchanan said over breakfast here as his shoestring campaign -- he travels with only one aide and his wife, Shelley -- prepared for several hundred miles of travel. "Real wages soared. American manufacturing became the envy of the world. I don't care what the economists in all those think-tanks in Washington say about the benefits of free trade -- I once believed all that, too, when I was with Nixon and Reagan. But the case has never been proven."
Mr. Buchanan insists that he is not trying to insulate the American economy from worldwide competition. The question is whether such arguments have much staying power on the campaign trail, where trade -- with all of its complexities, and long-term, short-term trade-offs -- has never survived as a topic of debate. Mr. Buchanan, however, promises to keep going as long as his campaign coffers hold out.
"This is a great way to make a living if you're unemployed," he said after a morning speech to college students.

HEADLINE: U.N. Aides See Congress As Impeding Reforms

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Keenly aware of repeated calls from Washington for reform, the highest-ranking American official in the United Nations system asked the leaders of the international organization to come to a meeting later in October with concrete, written proposals for better management and cost-cutting. He was prepared for action.
The meeting, which would have brought together agency directors from headquarters around the world, has now been canceled. It was a victim of a budget crisis brought on in large measure by the United States' failure to pay its past assessments and threats from Congress of severe future cuts in contributions. 
 "The tragedy is that those who say they want United Nations reform are cutting off at the knees the Americans who are able to deliver it," said James Gustave Speth, the official whose meeting was scratched. "The United States will pay dearly for squandering years of past investment in the United Nations, right at the moment it is beginning to pay off."
Mr. Speth, who is administrator of the United Nations Development Program and holds the rank of Under Secretary General, is also the coordinator and adviser on reform to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. A Clinton Administration appointee, Mr. Speth directs much of his criticism at Congress, where committees dealing with spending on foreign affairs are now controlled by Republicans opposed to participation in many international organizations.
Mr. Speth's agency, which assists 136 poor nations with development and represents the United Nations in a diplomatic role in capitals abroad, faces a cut. It could lose up to 45 percent of its budget request, down to $60 million to $70 million, when a Congressional conference committee meets on Wednesday to decide on what are called voluntary contributions beyond the fixed assessments owed to the United Nations organizational budget and peacekeeping.
Mr. Speth, a founder of the independent World Resources Institute and its president until 1993, said in an interview on Wednesday that Congress was "making reform synonymous with cuts."
"The whole reform effort has become associated in the minds of many countries here with severe financial cuts in all U.N. budgets," he said. "Many governments see this as an effort to create a small 'boutique' U.N. and not an institution that can help the world overcome the huge problems it faces."
But to people at the United Nations, the American policy looks bipartisan. Despite President Clinton's speech on Friday in which he called for the United States to pay its bills, the Administration is still linking reform and payments. An Administration official said in an interview after the speech that this was deliberate and would not change.
"The reality of the U.N. system is that without a strong and powerful motivation, nothing really changes," this official said. "That's why we're determined to combine reform and financial issues and not pretend there is no linkage."
Throughout the United Nations system and in its missions, officials say that if the trend continues, it will not be long before the United States will begin to lose leadership positions in major agencies. Americans now head Unicef and the World Food Program, in addition to the Development Program.
Europeans, who argue that the aggregate contributions of the European Union are overtaking American payments in many areas, waged a strong campaign to capture Unicef earlier this year. After intense lobbying by Madeleine K. Albright, the American representative at the United Nations, aided by Hillary Rodham Clinton, Carol Bellamy, former City Council Chairman in New York, was selected instead of a European.
"It's not much fun to be an American working here these days," an administrative staff member said this week, adding that there had been a significant rise in resentment toward Americans not felt since the end of the cold war.
John L. Washburn, a former State Department official and political adviser to the previous Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said, "The law of perverse consequences has set in on reform."
But Mr. Washburn, who serves on the board of the United Nations Association of New York, a support group, said the United Nations must take a lot of the blame for Congressional and public attitudes because it did not "stand up for itself" or explain better what it does. He added that the United Nations also did not draw enough on private American organizations working on similar world issues, groups that could build bridges to the public.
"We're dealing in Congress with people who don't know the United Nations at all," an official who monitors Congress said recently. Another United Nations Congressional liaison officer said that over the last year, hostility toward the organization had become so pronounced that requests for meetings even to present information had been denied.
Congressional leaders, including Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican who heads the House International Relations Committee, and Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, have directed much of their criticism at the bloated size of the United Nations bureaucracy and waste.
Mr. Speth, calling this image of the United Nations "simply wrong," said that the institution had already improved its management and that it was the best vehicle to deal effectively with huge global social problems like disease, hunger, population, migration and the environment.
"Poverty is growing faster than population," he said. "There are scores of countries where progress is going backwards rather than forwards. Rich countries are not going to be able to build a wall around themselves and shut themselves off. These problems don't need passports.
"If we don't, as an international community, deal with these problems in a preventive, early, humane way, we will pay very dearly down the road for the neglect."

HEADLINE: Black Conservatives, Meeting in Capital, Say Answers for Their People Lie in G.O.P.

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
J. Kenneth Blackwell likens big government to the Mad Hatter's tea party: as guests make a mess at one place setting, they move down to the next one, never cleaning up the messes they leave behind.
Mr. Blackwell, the Treasurer of the State of Ohio, is a conservative Republican, a critic of big government and a champion of family, work, education, faith and freedom. He is also black. 
 "Limited government is conservative, and I believe that because of my parents, Dana and Joyce Blackwell, not because of Pat Buchanan or Phyllis Schlafly," Mr. Blackwell said.
That remark brought laughter and applause of agreement here today at the second annual National Leadership Conference, a gathering of black conservatives sponsored by National Minority Politics magazine, a nine-year-old publication with a black conservative message.
At a time when their neighborhoods are coming apart under an onslaught of social ills -- from teen-age pregnancy to the high percentage of young men in the criminal justice system -- blacks are looking for answers in everything from the coming Million Man March, organized by Louis Farrakhan, to efforts to re-energize longtime civil rights organizations like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Mr. Blackwell and a number of other black conservatives believe that the answers lie in the Republican Party.
The term "black Republican" has been a virtual oxymoron ever since the New Deal. Indeed, national polls suggest that only seven percent of blacks today consider themselves Republican.
But while the numbers remain small, there was evidence during the 1994 election campaign that blacks were developing an increasing interest in what has become a Republican message of conservative family values.
One of those who want to see the trend accelerate is Jack F. Kemp, who spoke here today to an audience of about 100 conference participants. Mr. Kemp, former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, won applause not only with a rousing call for "unleashing the power of enterprise" of the poor but also for saying Republicans had to deal with their own lack of past action against segregation and racial bias.
"It is inconceivable that America can move into the 21st century unless it deals with its white-black relations," said Mr. Kemp, who chided his party for not doing more to attract black voters.
Offering an example of missed opportunities, he drew on a passage from "Parting the Waters," Taylor Branch's 1990 book about the civil rights era. The book recalls that after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was jailed in Atlanta for an old traffic violation during the 1960 Presidential campaign, the Democratic nominee, Senator John F. Kennedy, called Mr. King's wife, Coretta, to express concern. The Republican nominee, Vice President Richard M. Nixon, was dissuaded from doing so for fear of losing the votes of Southern whites.
"Nixon went from a 70 percent approval rating among blacks to 10 percent" during the campaign, Mr. Kemp said. "Kennedy, who had no record on civil rights, went from 10 to 70."
"The Republican Party made a mistake about not talking" of racial discrimination in general, Mr. Kemp said, "because I think most white people in this country -- and I'm not talking about Mark Fuhrman or the skinheads, but most white people -- feel that we're all in this together. This is at the heart of the feeling for General Powell."
All the current crop of Republican Presidential candidates were invited to address the conference, but only two accepted. One was Representative Robert K. Dornan of California, whose talk was scheduled for tonight. The other was Patrick J. Buchanan, who spoke this afternoon.
Mr. Buchanan, whose nostalgic elegies on a bygone America appeal mostly to whites, touched on race only briefly before focusing on economics, his opposition to the the North American Free Trade Agreement and his proposal to impose a five-year suspension on immigration.
"We've got to create economic bonds, and that will solve some of the problem," said Mr. Buchanan, who described blacks as "solid and stable and natural allies and friends of the Republican Party."
Reiterating his distaste for affirmative action, he said: "We've got to end all discrimination. We can't cure past wrongs by creating new ones."
There was considerable sympathy for Mr. Buchanan's stance against affirmative action, and the audience gave him, as it gave Mr. Kemp, a standing ovation at the end of his talk. There was a lot less enthusiasm, though -- indeed, no response at all -- when he described O. J. Simpson's acquittal as an "injustice."
Most in the audience were young people, in their late 20's or early 30's. Many of them said the Republicans offered a genuine alternative to the Democratic Party, which, they said, takes for granted support from the black civil rights establishment.
At the same time, they said, the Republican Party must do more to reach out to blacks.
"The African-American Republican vote could be the untapped gold mine for the Republican Party," said Henry McKoy, a black State Senator from North Carolina. "But you have to court the black community. Democrats have put up a sign in the black community: 'Republicans, off limits.' Republicans see the sign and go away. I walked right up to it and kicked it down, because the Democrats and the liberals have not been serving that community."
Mr. McKoy pointed out that he had won as a Republican in a county that is 62 percent Democratic and 28 percent black.
Despite a renewed interest in the Republican Party, though, there will have to be a sea change before blacks as a whole flock to it, said David Bositis Sr., a political analyst for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black research organization.
"The black community has strong sentiment for using government to solve problems," Mr. Bositis said in an interview from his office here. "That is not the way the Republicans feel. That is the crucial dividing line between Republicans and Democrats."
Mr. Blackwell disagrees. For his audience today, he defined a difference between conservatives and liberals: A liberal sees a drowning man 50 feet from shore, throws a 100-foot line and lets his end go. A conservative throws a 25-foot line and holds tight.
"We're looking for someone to hold the line," he said. "But the swim will do the man good."

HEADLINE: PLAN FOR TAX CUT NEARS A KEY TEST

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Congress returns on Tuesday to plunge into a final and potentially decisive struggle with the White House for control of the national fiscal destiny, led by a test of Republican muscle on a central issue: tax cuts.
That test comes next week in the Senate Finance Committee, which just last week approved a contentious plan to reduce projected Medicare spending by $270 billion over seven years. Now, it is scheduled to take up a Republican proposal to cut taxes by $245 billion over the same period as part of a sweeping bill that covers health, welfare and other spending totaling a third of the entire Federal budget. 
 In his radio address today, President Clinton called on Congress to defeat the Republican measures saying: "They may call it a tax cut, but if you are a working American it will feel like a tax increase to you."
The tax cut will die without the votes of all 11 Republicans on the panel; the Finance Committee's nine Democrats are united against it. This weekend at least one of the Republicans, Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, indicated he was still undecided.
In an interview, Mr. Murkowski said he would propose next week that much of the money now earmarked for a tax cut be used instead to start paying down the national debt, which stands at $4.9 trillion. The money Mr. Murkowski proposed to tap, about $170 billion of the $245 billion, is a so-called dividend that some experts say the economy would generate from the healthy effects of balancing the annual Federal budget. The Republicans in the Senate have always said that dividend should be set aside to help pay for a tax cut.
"I happen to think that when you're packing a deficit of $165 billion a year and an accumulated debt of $4.9 trillion and you're paying about 14 percent of your budget for interest on the debt, that you'd better do something about it," he said. "Fiscally responsible economics dictates that you put this economic dividend into reduction of our accumulated debt."
Mr. Murkowski said he was "obviously outnumbered" by his fellow Republicans and he predicted that some legislative package that includes a tax cut would work its way out of the committee and onto the Senate floor.
But if he holds fast, the Republicans could face a standoff, because another of their ranks on the panel, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, has vowed to oppose any seven-year tax cut below $245 billion.
The tax issue is but one headache in what promises to be a season of political migraines for the Republicans and their revolutionary budget-cutting proposal. Despite Republican predictions that their spending plans will be complete before Thanksgiving, few experts expect the budget wars to end before the December holiday season, and some say they could spill into next year.
Many say part of the Government will grind to a standstill, halted by the lack of a legal budget or authority to borrow, before the fight ends.
The Democrats, who have mounted feeble opposition to the Republican plans so far, spent their one-week recess on a publicity blitz, charging repeatedly that Republicans are plundering Medicare to finance a vast shift of tax money to the rich.
President Clinton today stepped up his criticism of the Republican tax package claiming it would add up to "$148 billion worth of direct and indirect hidden taxes which will hit working Americans hard."
"Most unbelievably of all," Mr. Clinton said, "17 million working families who seek to share in the American dream will have to pay $42 billion in income taxes through reductions in the Earned Income Tax Credits for working families."
Some Republicans acknowledged last week that the Democratic attacks were finally drawing blood, but said they knew that spending reductions in popular programs would not be met with wild enthusiasm. "Frankly, we expected it would be at this level a month ago," said one Republican aide on the House Ways and Means Committee, the Senate Finance panel's counterpart.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, another Republican on the Finance Committee, said he believed the panel would produce a spending bill with the full $245 billion tax cut and that Mr. Clinton would veto it. But he predicted the two sides would eventually strike a deal.
"Deep down, he has pretty good instincts on this stuff," Mr. Hatch said of the President. But as long as Mr. Clinton and the Democrats "keep demagoguing the tax issue, Republicans are going to stick it to them, frankly," he added.
But a showdown with Mr. Clinton is at least weeks away. The Republicans' most immediate concern is to keep their narrow House and Senate majorities intact and push their budget through Congress. And while the party has proved amazingly unified so far, some annoying splits developed in recent weeks and the biggest trials lie ahead.
The House and Senate have passed most of the 13 bills, totaling about half the budget, that will pay to run the Federal bureaucracy and some programs in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. But their versions often differ markedly, and so far lawmakers have approved three compromises and rejected three others.
The House stunned its leaders late last month and voted down a compromise military spending bill when a cadre of populist Republicans, including some who wanted to cut weapons spending to reduce the deficit further, bolted to the Democratic column. Some of the same deficit-cutters joined Democrats to defeat a compromise version of the Interior Department's budget, arguing that the bill gave mining companies mineral rights that should be sold at a huge profit.
Those bills were supposed to be relatively simple to enact. Far more serious differences split the Republican right and middle -- as well as the Senate and House -- over spending bills that cut social programs and environmental spending, finance anti-crime programs and pare spending on foreign affairs.
Congressional leaders hope to get the spending bills to Mr. Clinton's desk by Nov. 13, the day the Government's temporary spending authority expires. Others believe that no more than eight or nine bills will be finished by then and that Congress and the White House will clash again, inevitably, over how to finance the Government while they dicker.
The giant spending bill that will eventually contain a tax cut, dubbed the reconciliation package, is an even dicier proposition.
The legislation, which is primarily written by the Finance and the Ways and Means panels, authorizes spending for Medicaid and Medicare, welfare, trade, farm programs and a raft of other benefits and entitlements. Republicans want to cut or slow sharply the growth of most but they differ over how much and how.
The House and Senate, for example, are far apart on the outline of a crucial formula for distributing Medicaid money to the states. The Senate Agriculture Committee favors deep cuts in farm subsidies; the House has yet to agree on anything. The House would deny welfare to unwed teen-age mothers and other recipients' newborns; the Senate would not. Both are torn over proposals to trim spending on student loans.
The House version, to be unveiled on Wednesday, should be easily shepherded to passage by Speaker Newt Gingrich and his aides. Not so, however, in the Senate, where nobody is allowed to amend the reconciliation package, but anyone can try to cripple it by moving to strike portions they do not like.
Democrats will move to strike scores of politically raw provisions dealing with taxes, Medicare reductions, abortion, welfare and farms, among others. Whether the Republican majority can hold its handful of moderates and resist those moves is debatable.
"What comes out of the Senate could look considerably different from what they originally have put before them, and that could make reaching a compromise with the House even more difficult," Robert Reischauer, a past director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now a scholar at the Brookings Institution, said in an interview. "What they're doing is so complex, so fraught with political dangers that it will be very difficult for them to wrap everything up and have it on the President's desk by the middle of November.
"If they have a reconciliation bill, and I still think the word if is appropriate, it wouldn't reach the President's desk until Thanksgiving recess at the earliest."
At which point, everyone agrees, Mr. Clinton will veto it, and the negotiations will begin.
Such delays would not matter much: Medicare and other benefit programs would merely keep running at their current paces until the Government's legal authority to borrow money -- that is, to engage in deficit spending -- is scheduled to run out on Nov. 15. Unless it can rack up higher deficits, the Government cannot pay its debts and will go into default.
Mr. Gingrich has expressed a willingness to raise the debt ceiling during negotiations in Congress and, later, with the White House. But with each extension, it will become less certain that the right-wing populists in his party will fall into line.
"Once Congress has produced a bill and sent it to the President, and he has vetoed that bill, you would think you would have a season for compromise," Mr. Reischauer said. "But some of the participants here seem to be in no mood for compromise."

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
Educator Who Calls for Higher Expectations -- Rudolph F. Crew

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Alone among the candidates for schools chancellor interviewed last month by the New York City Board of Education, Rudolph F. Crew had a simple request: he first wanted to wander around a city public school.
And so a visit to an elementary school on the Upper West Side was hastily arranged for Dr. Crew, who has led two West Coast school systems but never has worked in New York. Roaming through the hallways and lunchroom of Public School 9 on West 84th Street, Dr. Crew chatted amiably with teachers and students, helped one child mop up a spilled carton of milk and stooped to accept a hug from a small boy who had no idea who he was or what he was doing there. 
 "Mister," the boy asked, "do you work here?"
Last night, the Board of Education answered that question by naming Dr. Crew the leader of the country's largest public school system -- a job he had not said for sure whether he would take.
In deciding to offer the post to Dr. Crew, 45, the board's president, Carol A. Gresser, said that she and a majority of her colleagues were impressed by his belief that the only way to raise the achievement of urban children is to raise standards and expectations. It is a philosophy shared in New York by one of Dr. Crew's early mentors, Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, whom he would succeed.
"I wear a pin that says, 'Children first,' " Mrs. Gresser said. "His visit to that school tells me he feels the same way. That means a lot."
Dr. Crew, who became Superintendent of Schools in Tacoma, Wash., two years ago, has won support for the three goals he set out to achieve -- increasing parental involvement, improving attendance and raising scores on standardized tests given in the district of 31,000 students.
He has made so much progress that the Tacoma Public School Board extended his contract last July. On Friday night, its president issued a strong statement imploring Dr. Crew to honor that contract and remain as Superintendent until 1998.
"He is devoted to the success of every child, regardless of their station in life" said Byron Haley, a Tacoma board member. "He has brought back self-esteem to the teaching staff, the children, and certainly the community."
But some national experts on urban education wonder whether Dr. Crew has the credentials to run a school system of more than a million students. New York has twice as many teachers as Tacoma has students.
His previous administrative experience includes stints as the deputy superintendent and Superintendent of the Sacramento, Calif., schools, with a student population of 51,000, and, previously, the deputy superintendent's job in Boston.
"He's known as strong on instruction and curriculum and he has a good sense of the problems that racial diversity presents to a system," said one educator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "But his breadth of experience is nothing like that of the most recent chancellors. Not even close. That is not to say he may not be up to it, but it is going to be a big stretch for him."
Raised in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Dr. Crew is not entirely unfamiliar with New York City. He told the board that his father, who worked for I.B.M., often brought him along on weekend trips to Harlem, where he played in jazz clubs.
Dr. Crew's affection for children extends to his personal life. He and his second wife, Cathy, share seven children, four from his previous marriage and three from hers.
If he accepts the job, Dr. Crew would be the second black to lead the city school system. He received most of his education in Massachusetts -- a bachelor's degree in management and economics at Babson College in Wellesley, and a master's in urban education and a doctorate in educational administration from the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.
It was while enrolled in the doctoral program that Dr. Crew spent a year as an intern under Mr. Cortines, who was then the Superintendent of Schools in Pasadena, Calif. Dr. Crew has cited Mr. Cortines, who worked hard in New York to bring the fundamentals of teaching and learning to the fore, as an early mentor.
Dr. Crew first worked in a classroom in Pasadena, teaching social science and English to high school students from 1973 to 1975.
But he quickly crossed over into school administration, becoming, at 24, principal of a 300-student high school in Claremont, and, later, assistant superintendent of a 4,000-student district, Duarte. Both are in Southern California.
Dr. Crew returned to the East Coast to work in Boston from 1985 to 1987 as the superintendent of curriculum and instruction. This past summer, he was one of four finalists for the superintendent's job in Boston, but he abruptly pulled out, citing his commitment to Tacoma.
In his two years in Tacoma, a working-class community on Puget Sound where the school system and the local paper mill are among the biggest employers, Dr. Crew has striven to raise standards. He has required high school students, for example, to take an additional year of mathematics, English and science, and two years of a foreign language.
The effort parallels that of Mr. Cortines, who last year began requiring every high school student in New York to take college-preparatory math and science.
In Tacoma, as in Boston, Dr. Crew has embraced the principles of the Efficacy Institute, an organization in Lexington, Mass., that trains teachers to instill in their students the expectation and anticipation of success. Dr. Crew has incorporated the institute into an instructional program for Tacoma teachers on which the district is spending nearly $2 million over four years, with about $414,000 going to the institute itself.
Dr. Crew has also stressed the importance of giving individual schools greater say in how they are managed, with the active involvement of the teachers' union and parents' groups.
"We now have monthly management meetings where a range of problems get aired," said Theresa Tommaney, the president of the union, the Tacoma Education Association. "That didn't happen under the previous superintendent."
Last month, Dr. Crew made it into the pool of 15 finalists under serious consideration by the New York City board and left a strong impression on many board members after his interview two weeks ago. But he withdrew from consideration the following day, saying he had much work to complete in Tacoma.
Late last week, however, as the board renewed its interest in him as a compromise candidate acceptable to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, he began to send out a flurry of conflicting signals -- reassuring Tacoma officials that he was not seeking the New York job while indicating, in a nearly two-hour conference call with the board, that he would not rule it out if he were drafted.
Precious little is known about how Dr. Crew would run the New York City schools, or about Dr. Crew himself. Board officials said that their investigators had completed a preliminary background check on him that showed nothing unusual. But he still must submit to a physical, as well as a more substantial inquiry by the city's Department of Investigation.
In a brief interview on Friday, Dr. Crew would only say that he looked forward to "exploding the mythology about the educability of poor and urban children."
Echoing other Tacoma officials, Mr. Haley said he would miss Dr. Crew's broad smile, sympathetic ear and warm ease in relating to children. But he said he did not plan to stand in Dr. Crew's way.
"We all really appreciate what he has done," he said. "I guess the bottom line is he made a difference."

HEADLINE: Marines Seek Peace With Okinawa in Rape Case

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: NAHA, Okinawa, Oct. 7

 BODY:
For at least one day this week, this island had some peace. The big guns that fire shells over Highway 104 were silent. The deafening planes that drown out the lessons at elementary schools were grounded. No parachutes dropped from the sky onto the small practice field -- or into the residential neighborhood nearby.
Most of the 18,000 United States marines in Okinawa held a "day of reflection" to contemplate the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan schoolgirl, for which three American servicemen have been charged. Regular training was suspended on Thursday and the marines spent the day in lectures and discussion groups on topics like the "core values" of the Marine Corps, alcohol abuse and the customs and culture of Okinawa. 
 The day of reflection was part of an unusual outpouring of contrition by the United States military. But while the Pentagon could silence the guns and planes, it has not been able to silence the controversy generated by the rape and by the presence of so many American military bases, which take up 20 percent of the land on Okinawa's main island.
The incident has added new strains to the relationship between the American military and the local people. And it is raising questions about the behavior and training of the American troops here.
To a man, the marines interviewed said the suspects in the rape case were not representative of the corps. "Those people who chose to do that, they are not marines, in my opinion," said Pfc. Chad Ellis.
But the United States Government is acting as if the case is part of a systemic problem. Gen. Charles C. Krulak, the Commandant of the Marine Corps, flew here specially from Washington to meet with troops. Discipline is being tightened and the sale of alcohol at stores on the bases is being halted at 9 P.M.
"There are some people who would love to limit it only to the action of a few bad apples," Iva Hosaka, who works as a community liaison for the United States military in Okinawa, said on the day of reflection. "But that's what this day is all about. We have to self-police."
The troops have raised money to help compensate the rape victim. The American Government will also pay compensation.
The public displays of contrition are in part aimed at keeping the outcry from the Okinawans in check. The incident has given new momentum to calls by some Okinawans -- though by no means all -- to remove the bases at a time when the United States and Japan are trying to justify their necessity with the end of the cold war.
"The Rock," as some servicemen call Okinawa, is the largest Marine post outside the United States. In addition to the 18,000 marines, there are 11,000 from the other services here, together accounting for 29,000 of the roughly 45,000 American troops in Japan.
Including civilians and dependents, the 54,000 Americans here live a somewhat isolated life. While many develop friendships with local people, others venture no farther off-base than the nearby honky-tonks. The bases contain American-style shopping centers and wide expanses of well-cropped grass that are out of character in crowded Japan, contributing to feelings of envy among Okinawans.
Into this atmosphere came the rape. According to Japanese authorities and American military officials, four servicemen on a day off began talking about committing such an act. One apparently could not believe the others were serious but left. He later helped identify the suspects.
According to the indictment, the three defendants accosted the girl on a street at about 8 P.M. They beat her on the face, pushed her into the back seat of the car, covered her eyes and mouth with tape and tied her wrists and ankles. They raped her on the back seat and restrained her by hitting her in the face and stomach, causing injuries that required two weeks to heal.
The three men, who were indicted on Sept. 29 and could face up to a life term in a Japanese prison, were identified as Marine Pfc. Rodrico Harp, 21, of Griffin, Ga.; Marine Pfc. Kendrick M. Ledet, 20, of Waycross, Ga.; and Navy Seaman Marcus D. Gill, 22, of Woodville, Tex.
To some Okinawans, this is just the latest indignity at the hands of the Americans, who captured Okinawa in the closing months of World War II and occupied it until 1972, 20 years after the occupation of the rest of Japan ended.
Some older people noted that the rape occurred almost 40 years to the day after an infamous "Yumiko-chan incident," in which a 6-year-old girl named Yumiko was raped and killed by an American serviceman.
The Okinawa government reports that there have been 4,700 crimes committed by servicemen, including 12 murders of Japanese civilians, since 1972. According to Stars and Stripes, the American military newspaper, Americans in Okinawa accounted for 4.2 percent of the population but 11.5 percent of felonies like murder, rape and robbery.
But even Okinawan officials concede that reported crimes have declined remarkably, from more than 300 a year in some years in the 1970's to 98 in 1994. An English-language document prepared by the Okinawa government in May about the problems associated with the bases does not even mention crime.
Rather, the report, and people in Okinawa, mention such things as ear-splitting aircraft noise, artillery practice in which shells fly over a public highway and denude a scenic mountain, aircraft crashes and parachute drops that go astray, like the time a military trailer dropped on a house in 1965, killing a child.
But what appears to grate more sharply than the daily annoyances is the sense of being deprived of their history. A peaceful trading kingdom before it was annexed by Japan in the 1870's, Okinawa has lost much of its culture and native language but is still viewed by other Japanese as second class. Many Okinawans say the Japanese Government is as responsible as the Americans for the fact that Okinawa, which accounts for less than 1 percent of Japanese territory, houses 75 percent of the American bases in the country.
A focus of Okinawa's anger in this case is the Status of Forces Agreement, which sets legal guidelines for American military personnel. Under the agreement, American servicemen caught by the Japanese for crimes committed while off duty can be detained and interrogated by the Japanese police. But those who are in United States custody, like the three suspects in the rape case, are not turned over to the Japanese authorities until after they are indicted.
Okinawans say this impedes their criminal investigations and puts the Americans above the law, encouraging more crimes. In some cases, servicemen vanish into their bases, out of reach of the Japanese police, after committing offenses.
American officials say they cooperated fully in the recent rape case and played a key role in tracking down the suspects. Still, as part of the response to the rape, a United States-Japanese committee is reviewing the Status of Forces Agreement. In Germany, the United States military has some discretion to turn over suspects before they are indicted and Japanese officials have suggested this might be an acceptable solution for Japan as well.
As for the bases, a poll taken by the local government a few years ago showed about 80 percent of Okinawans favor removing or reducing them.
But interviews with people here suggest opposition to the bases is not that fervent, mainly for economic reasons. Okinawa is the poorest of Japan's prefectures, with an unemployment rate twice the national average of 3.2 percent.
Okinawan officials say the bases now account for only 5 percent of the economy here, down from 15 percent in 1972. The number of Okinawan employees on the bases dropped to 7,900 in 1992 from 20,000 in 1972. Rather than helping the economy, the government argues, the bases are hampering it by taking up room needed for industry and commerce.
But some Okinawans wonder if profitable uses can be found for the land. Okinawa is too remote for manufacturing, especially when the strong Japanese yen is making all of Japan unattractive for factories. Tourism, the main industry here, is also hurt by the strong yen, which makes it less expensive for Japanese sun worshipers to visit Guam or Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Republicans Attack Shift In Cuba Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Republican Presidential candidates have attacked President Clinton's new Cuba policy, accusing the Administration of seeking to extend full diplomatic relations to Fidel Castro's Communist Government.
On Friday, just hours after Mr. Clinton announced plans to loosen travel restrictions and take other steps to increase people-to-people contacts with Cuba, Bob Dole, the Senate Majority Leader and Presidential candidate, said the new policy "has undermined the supporters of democratic change in Cuba." 
 Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, another Republican candidate, said Mr. Clinton's policy was extending the suffering of the Cuban people and "putting out the welcome mat to Castro instead of tightening the noose around his aging neck."
At issue is not only Cuba policy, but the support and votes of Cuban-Americans.
Even as the two Republican candidates sought to appeal to Cuban-Americans, White House policy makers predicted that many Cuban immigrants would support the policy because it would ease the suffering of the Cuban people.
Administration officials said Cuban-Americans would be pleased that the President's new policy would make it easier for them to visit sick relatives in Cuba and finance human rights organizations there.
The new policy would also allow Cuban-Americans to send money to relatives who are suffering from disaster and would permit a greater flow of students, professors, artists and members of the clergy between the United States and Cuba.
Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat, said the reception in his state was mixed.
"There are some who resist any opening, whether it's to the Government or Cuban people out of fear that it will rebound to Castro's benefit economically or in political prestige," he said.
"Then there are others who want more visitations and contacts and would have liked the President to go further. He has struck a good balance."
Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat from Hudson County, N.J., who faulted Mr. Clinton's policy as contradictory, nonetheless accused the Republicans of pandering to Cuban-Americans.
"The Republicans are playing politics with this -- there's no question about it," Mr. Menendez said. "They certainly know the sentiments of the Cuban-American community."
Cuban-Americans in Florida represent a vital voting bloc in a state with 25 electoral votes and are an important source of contributions for candidates.
In its defense, the Administration argues that it is carrying out a two-track approach that Congress called for in the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992: maintaining the trade embargo while increasing people-to-people contacts, which, the Administration says, will spur the flow of democratic ideas into Cuba and lead to the end of Communism.
Richard Nuccio, the President's special adviser on Cuba, said: "The embargo by itself is not sufficient to help the Cuban people produce change. We have to take more steps to actively engage them."
Cambio Cubano, a Cuban-American group that favors talks with Cuba, said it "cautiously welcomed" the policy shift.
But the powerful Cuban-American National Foundation, which has clashed with Mr. Clinton, gave only a mild rebuke, saying the new policy was "unlikely to have any significant impact" on the Castro Government.
Many Cuban-Americans sympathized with Mr. Dole's statement that despite the push in Congress to tighten the embargo, "President Clinton has unilaterally decided to ease the 30-year-old U.S. embargo."
Mr. Dole and many Republicans assert that the new policy is a step toward establishing full diplomatic relations with Cuba -- something the Administration denies. They say that expanding contacts will do more to prop up Mr. Castro by providing him with hard currency than to undermine him by sowing Western ideas.
Administration policy makers said they had recommended the new policy to the President because they were frustrated that the embargo had done little to push Mr. Castro out.
These policy makers said the new policy was inspired by what many Eastern Europeans leaders said was pivotal in overthrowing Communism: increased contacts with the West.
The Cuban-American National foundation said that if Mr. Clinton were serious about hastening Mr. Castro's demise, he would support, rather than oppose, a bill approved by the House that would seek to squeeze Mr. Castro by punishing foreign companies that invest in Cuba. Mr. Dole has pledged to bring the bill to a vote on the Senate floor soon.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Will Play Flop After the Star Leaves Town?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
WITH Pope John Paul II pulling up stakes this morning, an unavoidable question is whether he leaves a lasting imprint on "great, great New York," as he put it yesterday in Central Park. This city, he said the day before, is "considered by many to be the zenith of modern civilization and progress" (although the Pontiff did not say clearly that he puts himself in the ranks of the many -- and he never even had to endure the uncivilizing effects of a New York traffic jam).
John Paul II touched many hearts during his few days here, and not just among Roman Catholics. But what will become of his recurring theme that the city and country must continue to embrace the immigrant stranger and tend to those poor in pocket and spirit? 
 Will lawmakers eager to neuter health programs and social services now hang their heads and repent? Will the Mayor and Governor, both Roman Catholics, heed their spiritual father and beat their budgetary pruning hooks into antipoverty spears?
In short, did anyone out there who is graced with power hear this visiting Pope?
Peter F. Vallone, a daily communicant and City Council Speaker, says yes. But then, Mr. Vallone also acknowledges that some may call him an unreconstructed optimist. "He leaves a positive feeling," Mr. Vallone said. "I think it will make a difference for legislators. Maybe we can all rethink our positions, including Mr. Gingrich and everyone else talking about cutting everything. When you see 100,000 people on the Great Lawn, and there's the man talking about giving to the poor and sheltering them, you've got to rethink it all. If nothing else, those people on the lawn vote."
 MAYBE he's right. But this city can be relentless in absorbing special events and leaving only faint traces. More important, many New Yorkers feel, is the mood in Washington, and it may take more than papal intervention to reverse policies that are reducing the city to helpless supplicant.
"Does the Pope's visit give a lot of people hope?" asks the Rev. David Toolan, associate editor of America, a Jesuit public-affairs weekly. "Yes. But in practical terms, is that going to change people's attitudes toward the welfare system, or who will be schools chancellor? Probably not."
It may take time to learn the full meaning of this papal visit. Attendance at Mass grew in Denver after John Paul II went there in 1993, and maybe the Archdioceses of New York and Newark will be as fortunate. It would be nice to think that New Yorkers will be kinder to one another from now on. But that may fall under the heading of miracles.
Fact is, papal trips have had their greatest impact on countries where the situation is truly desperate. In Poland, anti-Communist resistance was spiritually sustained by its native son in the Vatican. He has benefited the poor and politically suppressed in parts of Asia and Africa that rarely get international attention except when the Pope comes through. For all its troubles, New York is not that bad off.
PERHAPS a better question is what imprint the city leaves on John Paul II.
Is he aware, after 112 countries over 17 years, that he could have spared himself the wear and tear simply by going to Elmhurst, Queens, where, the last census shows, exactly that many nations are represented?
He must know that New York is not just the Big Apple but also the Big Microphone. "New York looms large for him because it is the communications capital," says Victor Simpson, a reporter for The Associated Press based in Rome who has accompanied John Paul II on most of his voyages. "He realizes that this world is dominated by the communications industry. The man is not naive."
But who can say if the Pope truly sensed New York's finger-snap pace? He came, after all, as pastor, not tourist. At least he got to see Central Park and the United Nations. A play would have been nice, too.
As a matter of fact, a musical version of a play that he wrote in 1960, "The Jeweler's Shop," was to have had a run this month in a small theater at St. Clement's Episcopal Church on West 46th Street. But the cash ran low, and the production was canceled.
A lesson for a Pope: This can be one tough town.

HEADLINE: William White, 92, Former Bank Regulator, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
William R. White, an accidental banker who followed a circuitous path to become New York's youngest Superintendent of Banks during a critical period in the 1930's and then spent a quarter-century as a top officer of what became the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Lewisburg, Pa. He was 92.
Mr. White never intended a career in banking. Indeed, his son David said yesterday, until his father worked his way through Bucknell University in Lewisburg, all he wanted to do was to make a decent life for himself outside Coudersport, an impoverished farming community in north-central Pennsylvania, where his own father had broken with a family subsistence farming tradition to eke out a living by operating a general store. 
 While at Bucknell, Mr. White finally made a firm career choice: to become a lawyer in New York.
After obtaining his law degree from Columbia in 1929, Mr. White did become a lawyer, but he made the fateful mistake of joining a firm, Chadbourne & Whiteside, that did so much legal work for the New York State Banking Department that for a year Mr. White did little else but work on state banking matters.
He also apparently did the work uncommonly well; well enough, anyway, that he caught the attention of the state's Banking Superintendent, Joseph A. Broderick, who persuaded him to accept an appointment to the department's legal staff in 1930.
Six years later, at 32, he was named by Gov. Herbert H. Lehman to succeed Mr. Broderick as Superintendent.
The 1930's was a heady time to be a bank regulator in New York. For one thing, the Depression had taken a heavy toll on the nation's financial institutions, causing many banks to fail, putting even more in severe jeopardy and uncovering a range of abusive or unsound practices that needed corrective attention.
For another, far more than it is today, New York was the nation's banking capital, and the state's banking department had enormous responsibilities for the nation's financial stability.
With the exception of the Bank of America in California and Continental Illinois in Chicago, all of the nation's largest banks were based in New York City and operated under charters from New York State, not from the Federal Government.
As a result, with perhaps half the nation's financial assets under his supervisory control and with with broad regulatory jurisdiction over everything from reserve requirements and interest rates to the minutiae of specific loan and other banking practices, the Superintendent had the combined powers of today's Comptroller of the Currency and the Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
Although the worst of the banking crisis was over by the time he became Superintendent on Jan. 1, 1936, Mr. White, who had been deeply involved in the department's activities as he worked his way up the administrative ladder, had plenty on his plate.
In addition to his day-to-day duties, Mr. White, who persuaded the State Legislature to put a cap on interest rates charged by small-loan companies, also spearheaded an overhaul of the state's banking laws that at once strengthened New York State's position as the chartering agency of choice for the nation's largest banks and foreordained its decline.
The revamped regulations were considered so advanced that they served as a model for those later adopted by the Federal Government, which eventually lured the big banks to the Federal fold.
Mr. White resigned his post in 1942 to become a vice president of the old Guaranty Trust Company, which later merged with the Morgan Bank to become Morgan Guaranty Trust.
As the officer in charge of Guaranty's operations in a region running from New York to Maryland, Mr. White had reason to welcome the merger with Morgan. As Superintendent on March 21, 1940, he had presided over the demise of J. P. Morgan & Company's long and storied role as a private bank by approving its certificate of incorporation as a state-chartered bank.
He may have become a banker by accident, but when it came to his retirement, Mr. White, an avid hunter and fisherman, left nothing to chance. In 1944, he bought a 21-acre Dutchess County farm situated in the middle of the famous hunting and fishing preserve operated by the Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club in La Grange, N.Y. When he retired as a Morgan Guaranty senior vice president in 1968, he moved there full time.
Besides his son, of Chatham, N.J., he is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; another son, William Jr., of Venice, Fla.; a daughter, Deborah Anderson, of Hilton Head Island, S.C.; seven grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William R. White (Matar Studio, 1980)

HEADLINE: Fractious Reformers in Russia

 BODY:
Hard as it is to handicap next year's Presidential race in America, it may be even harder to unscramble the presidential field in Russia, where elections are scheduled for June 1996. With Russian politics fragmented and the electorate in a surly mood, anything seems possible, from reaffirmation to repudiation of the economic and political reforms fitfully championed by President Boris Yeltsin.
Along with parliamentary elections later this year, the outcome of the presidential race will be vitally important not only for Russia but for the United States and the rest of the world. A reversal of reform, or an aggravation of Moscow's already chronic political instability, could quickly ripple through the post-cold war international landscape, touching everything from peace prospects in the Balkans and Middle East to the size of the Pentagon budget. 
 Mr. Yeltsin has not yet disclosed whether he plans to run again, but his ill health and low popularity make his re-election doubtful. Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, who has been a guardian of reform as well as an effective administrator, announced last week that he does not plan to run for president. His declaration sounded definitive, but there was speculation in Moscow that it was merely a temporary maneuver to placate Mr. Yeltsin, who reportedly feels threatened by the growing popularity of his Prime Minister.
The crucial question is whether anyone with national credibility will carry the reform banner into the campaign, and enjoy the undivided support of democratic voters. One declared candidate, Grigory Yavlinsky, an economist and strong advocate of reform, has yet to show the capacity to unite Russia's unruly democratic forces.
If the divisions among reform politicians persist, which seems likely, the next president could well be a nationalist, Communist or other candidate who wants to restore some degree of authoritarian rule, reassert Russian influence in the former Soviet republics and rebuild the Russian military. Communists won 22 of 24 seats in the Volgograd regional parliament last week.
The most popular potential presidential candidate at the moment is Aleksandr Lebed, a former general who has called for a restoration of order in his chaotic country, citing the example of Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Chile.
General Lebed's appeal cuts across political lines. During the failed 1991 coup attempt in Moscow, he led the troops that came to the defense of Mr. Yeltsin and his democratic supporters. He was also an early and strong critic of Moscow's misguided military campaign in Chechnya. Less appealingly, in recent years he used the 14th Army under his command to protect Russian interests in the Dnestr region of Moldova, essentially intervening in the affairs of an independent nation.
Mr. Chernomyrdin's announcement certainly will not help the prospects of the centrist party, Our Home Is Russia, that he established earlier this year, ostensibly with Mr. Yeltsin's blessing. The longer Russia's democrats bicker among themselves, the harder it will be for one of them to prevail next June.

HEADLINE: '95 PLAYOFFS;
Some Pedestrian Pitching Can't Stop the Braves

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Once again, Greg Maddux pitched a less than masterful game in the playoffs. Once again, it didn't matter. For the second time in this series against Colorado, Atlanta's extraordinary hitting more than compensated for an ordinary performance by Maddux.
If Maddux was not in his usual Cy Young Award form tonight, Fred McGriff formidably recovered his stroke with two home runs and Marquis Grissom pushed his series average above .500 with five hits as the Braves advanced to the National League Championship Series for the fourth consecutive time with a 10-4 victory over the Rockies at Fulton County Stadium. 
 Atlanta will open the N.L.C.S. on Tuesday in Cincinnati after dispatching the free-swinging Rockies three games to one in the divisional playoffs. The Braves quickly fell behind, 3-0, as Maddux had another unsettling start, but Atlanta pummeled Colorado's sore-shouldered Bret Saberhagen for four runs in the third inning for a lead that would escalate impressively.
"McGriff was the difference, and Grissom," Atlanta Manager Bobby Cox said. "We were waiting for somebody like that to do that. Our club can be very explosive and it was tonight."
Maddux is indisputably baseball's best pitcher, one headed for his fourth consecutive Cy Young Award after a 19-2 regular season. Oddly, though, his career playoff record is a pedestrian 2-2. Even though he won, Maddux allowed 10 hits, 4 runs and home runs to Dante Bichette and Vinny Castilla, while again exiting after seven innings.
However, the Braves are an accomplished playoff team, one that becomes particularly imposing with the suddenly awakened McGriff in the cleanup spot. Instead of waiting to catch Colorado in the late innings, as they had done in the first three games, the Braves knocked Saberhagen around, grabbed the lead and held it indomitably.
McGriff's regular-season average slid nearly 40 points, to .280, spurring talk that the Braves would not re-sign the free-agent first baseman. He did not quiet the talk by hitting .231 with no home runs and a single run batted in during the first three games of this series. Tonight, however, he broke out with three hits, including the pair of homers, and drove five runs across the plate with incredible economy. He swung his bat a grand total of three times all night.
"It's a lot easier to hit when the count is 2-0 and 3-0, than being in the hole 0-2 and 1-2," McGriff said. "You're always working to get ahead in the count. I laid off bad pitches tonight. I got some pitches to hit and I hit them well."
Grissom, meanwhile, batted .524 (11 for 21, 3 home runs) for the series after hitting a tepid .258 during the regular season upon coming to Atlanta from Montreal. His five hits tonight were a club record for a playoff game.
"We knew we had a great player when we got him," Cox said of Grissom. "He hit .258 this year, but he hit a lot of balls hard. He just didn't have a lot of luck. When he gets on base, he can steal, and he sets the table for the big guys. He makes all the difference in the world."
Maddux had been ordinary in Game 1, which Atlanta won despite its ace giving up nine hits, three runs and a two-run homer and failing to get either the decision or a single strikeout.
But Cox, who is using three starters in this series, did not hesitate to send Maddux back to the mound on three days' rest. He was vulnerable again, and Colorado took a 3-0 lead in the third as Bichette punched an 0-1 pitch over the right-field fence.
This was no time to panic, however, and relief came immediately as Atlanta took a 4-3 lead in the bottom of the inning against Saberhagen, whose sore shoulder will require arthroscopic surgery in the off season.
With two outs, Grissom and Mark Lemke singled, then Chipper Jones sliced a two-run double down the left field line, just beyond the glove of a diving Bichette. McGriff followed with a two-run, opposite field home run beyond another futile leap by Bichette, and a 3-0 Colorado lead became a 4-3 advantage for Atlanta.
McGriff made the score 7-3 in the fifth by cuffing a 3-0 pitch off reliever Kevin Ritz over the left-field fence. Then, as the Braves batted around in the sixth, the Rockies walked Jones intentionally and brought in the left-hander Mike Munoz to face the left-handed hitting McGriff with the bases loaded.
The strategy backfired as McGriff poked a two-run single past first base, putting the Braves comfortably ahead 10-4 and comfortably back in the National League Championship Series.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Braves' Marquis Grissom sliding into second as the Rockies' Eric Young jumped away. Grissom banged out five hits for a series average of .524. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Foreign Policy 3.1

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
On the front page of The Financial Times the other day was a picture that caught my eye. It showed Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, holding talks with Jiang Zemin, the President of China. The caption made it sound like any meeting of world leaders. It said the two men held "very cordial" talks, in contrast with their "frosty" summit of 18 months ago.
Bill Gates has met Jiang Zemin twice in 18 months. Hmmmmmm, that's once more than Bill Clinton. That's no accident. The Chinese believe they need Bill G. more than they need Bill C. Which raises an interesting question: Does Microsoft have a foreign policy? 
 I asked Steve Ballmer, the No. 2 man at Microsoft, who oversees the software giant's worldwide operations from its headquarters in Redmond, Wash. Mr. Ballmer says Microsoft doesn't have a foreign policy per se. But it does have a global business agenda. Since Microsoft today has twice the market value of General Motors, it's worth looking at that agenda because it is bound to influence U.S. foreign policy.
When I asked Mr. Ballmer what policies his company's Washington office was pushing these days, he gave me a quizzical look and said, "We just put our first person there." I had to laugh. Can you imagine how many people the Big Three auto makers have in Washington, and Microsoft, a $50 billion company, just opened a Washington office. Mind you, Microsoft has an army of p.r. firms, and lawyers aplenty to defend it against antitrust suits, but except for help with copyright violations, Microsoft doesn't much look to Washington.
In part this is because it has a virtual worldwide monopoly. Like one of the great sea powers of old, Microsoft today controls access to the modern lanes of communication. Microsoft operating systems run 85 percent of the world's personal computers. Microsoft doesn't need Washington to open doors for it because foreign governments are begging Microsoft to come in and translate Windows 95 into their languages, so they can get on the information highway. Describing his contacts with foreign leaders, Mr. Ballmer put it this way: "People say, 'You have this technology. We hear it's changing the world. Tell us how it can help us.' "
It's intriguing to talk to Mr. Ballmer about where Microsoft sales are booming, as an indicator of which countries are hot and which are not. China has the greatest potential, not just because it has 1.2 billion people but because its birth control policies restricting every family to one child mean there are often two sets of grandparents and two parents -- that is six adults -- saving to buy a computer and software for each kid.
Mr. Ballmer says Japan is just now taking off for Microsoft products, while Israel is so far advanced it has one of the few Microsoft development centers outside Redmond. But Microsoft's hottest market in the Middle East is Saudi Arabia. Iran and Egypt are nil, but India and Brazil are booming. The one European democracy that is slipping is France. Says Mr. Ballmer: "I don't want to say [France] has fallen behind," but "the penetration of PC's relative to population was quite high in France. That's not true anymore."
Is what's good for Microsoft good for America? When I asked Mr. Ballmer whether Microsoft was even an American company, he said: "We like to think we are a company based in America that is a global company. In every country we are Microsoft. Not American. Microsoft. Microsoft Japan. Microsoft Italy . . ." That does not mean it is indifferent to America. Microsoft needs a cutting-edge U.S. technology market to design, test and perfect its products for global sales. Also, since America is the leader in information technology, laws and standards set here are copied abroad.
While Microsoft is a coldblooded economic giant, its technology, along with that of its competitors, can foster democracy in ways G.M. never could. Its software is making it possible for individuals to communicate horizontally, through the Internet, across international boundaries, and to create groups and information pools that are outside all government authority. To take full advantage of that software, societies have to become more open, deregulated and interactive. Says Mr. Ballmer: "Once you let people on the Internet, the control aspects are reasonably out the window."
It's too early to predict what all this will mean for U.S. foreign policy, but I do predict this: It will be shaped to a significant degree by decisions taken in Washington.
Redmond, Washington.
