HEADLINE: Advisers Are Mostly Sticking With Stocks

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
STAYING in this year's stock market can seem downright greedy.
After all, fund investors are sitting on some of the most impressive gains ever. Stock funds rose 27 percent, on average, while technology funds turned in nearly double that gain in the first nine months. 
 So with the year winding down, the temptation is strong to take profits and retreat from the high-risk world of stocks until the market becomes a bit less choppy than it has been in recent weeks, while third-quarter earnings disappointments trickled out.
The investment advisers who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times two years ago acknowledged that they, too, had felt such psychological tugs in recent weeks. But when approached for their quarterly review, the five advisers only fiddled with their holdings for the final months of the year; not one moved out of stocks.
"You're always worried when the market goes up that far that fast, but we're a long-term portfolio," said Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management in Wellesley, Mass. Each of the portfolios was intended to grow for 20 years.
Moving out of the market now would be a big mistake, Mr. Kobren said. "You can't base the decision on whether you're up or down in your position," he said, "but what the prospects are for the market." And the prospects for this market remain good, he and other investment advisers said.
"We're staying fully invested because we don't think that stocks are overvalued in terms of next year's earnings," said Sheldon Jacobs, editor of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. Besides, "the Presidential year tends to be an up year for the market. Of course, we reserve the right to add some cash if circumstances change."
Jumping out of the market now would present another quandary: when to get back into stocks. "That smacks of classic market timing, and historically, no one has been able to time the market successfully," said Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla.
Although market sentiment may change, and so may investment wisdom, one factor remains a constant. Stocks are critical to staying ahead of inflation in the long run. "The only way I can get long-term market returns is to be in the stock market," said Mr. Evensky, in a comment that reflects all the advisers' views.
 Profit-taking was practically nonexistent in the five portfolios. Mr. Evensky moved some money out of a general stock fund and into a real estate fund, a category that has lagged behind the stock market for some time. Specifically, he reduced his stake in SEI Capital Appreciation to 16 percent from 18 percent, and added that share to Cohen & Steers Realty.
The one area of the market most worrisome to the advisers is the scorching technology sector, which has gained an incredible 47 percent in the first nine months of this year. None of the advisers hold any technology specialty funds, so their exposure is limited to what can be found in their diversified stock funds.
Mr. Kobren says he has already positioned his portfolio to cope with the possibility of a correction. The Fidelity funds with heavy tech exposure -- Export Company and Midcap Stock -- in his portfolio have been balanced by two funds that would serve as a cushion -- Canada and Value. With that accomplished, he saw no reason to make any changes for the end of the year.
Among the five portfolio managers, Mr. Jacobs retains the lead. His portfolio has grown from $50,000

when the contest began on July 7, 1993, to $70,000 -- a gain of 40 percent. Mr. Kobren is a very close second, with a portfolio gain of 39 percent. The two managers have kept pace with the 40 percent total return on the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mimics the Standard & Poor's 500. But on average, the portfolios have gained 31 percent, several points behind the overall market.
All the portfolios made money in the third quarter, but only Mr. Kobren kept up with the 8.9 percent average gain for general equity funds, reported by Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. Mr. Kobren, who designed a portfolio of all-Fidelity funds and keeps it simple with just five funds, was helped along by a 13.7 percent spurt in Fidelity Export, a growth fund begun just a year ago.
The portfolio performance, tracked quarterly by Lipper, excludes taxes, because many people invest retirement money in tax-deferred accounts. Transaction costs and sales charges are also excluded. The five experts can choose funds open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, although the portfolios are intended to grow for 20 years.

IN the category of fine tuning, there were a handful of changes. Mr. Jacobs is adding Invesco Balanced, which buys stocks and bonds, and dropping Fidelity Convertible, whose performance he termed disappointing. Similarly, he is replacing Mutual Beacon with Mutual Shares. Both are growth and income funds, and both have five-star designations, the highest from Morningstar, the fund analysts in Chicago. While acknowledging that the two funds have similar returns, he said that Mutual Shares had eked out a better performance recently. So far this year, Mutual Shares has gained 27.0 percent, compared with 23.1 percent for Mutual Beacon.
John Rekenthaler, editor of the Five-Star Investor at Morningstar, is replacing Janus with Fidelity Stock Selector, which behaves much like the overall stock market but has a good record of beating the S.& P. 500. (So far this year, it is running well ahead of the S.& P., with Stock Selector up 37.4 percent against 29.7 percent for the overall market.) Stock Selector, he says, will become a core holding of the retirement portfolio.
He is dumping Fidelity Global Balanced in favor of Ivy International. "I bought Fidelity Global Balanced as something of a flier, expecting that Fidelity had finally figured out international investing and would be able to translate its domestic stock success overseas," he said. "Clearly, I was too optimistic."
Mr. Evensky, who added to his realty portion, also wants to increase his exposure to small-cap and midcap stocks, so he is replacing the Vanguard S.& P. 500 index fund with shares in Schwab 1,000, with twice as many holdings.
Jack A. Brill, who limits his investment choices to funds that specialize in "socially responsible" companies, is adding a new fund: Calvert Capital Accumulation, which buys mid-cap stocks and is handled by three investment management firms.
Socially responsible funds set their own objectives, but as an example, they may steer clear of companies that make weapons and cigarettes or that have poor records in environmental matters, either creating excessive waste or refusing to switch to recycled products. The number of socially responsible funds has grown rapidly, and now exceeds 30, but Mr. Brill's choices are still substantially more limited than those of the other advisers.
In the interest of moving to a better performer, Mr. Brill is switching from Calvert Investment's global equity fund to Citizens Global Equity, formerly known as Working Assets Global Equity.
Not all of Citizens' funds appeal to him, though. He is dropping the company's income fund in favor of Calvert Social Investment Management Growth. This way, he keeps the bond portion of his portfolio constant, but positions himself to benefit from Calvert's team approach to management.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
Heliport: New Lease And Quiet?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Residents of the high-rises along First Avenue in the 30's enjoy sweeping East River views. But for years, they have endured the staccato thunder of helicopters taking off and landing at the East 34th Street Heliport. Every few minutes, all day and late into the night, the whomp-whomp-whomp of propellers cutting the air halts conversation and drowns out televisions and stereos.
"Awful, terrible," said Luce Lauzon, who lives opposite the heliport at 401 East 34th Street. "It's nonstop. We have to keep the windows closed." Although the triple-glazed panes are designed to muffle noise, Ms. Lauzon said she has to keep the air-conditioners on so her children can sleep. 
 After years of such complaints, some relief is in the offing. The city's Economic Development Corporation, which oversees the heliport, said in an application for a new 10-year zoning permit that takeoffs and landings will be cut 47 percent next year, to approximately 28,000 or an average of 77 per day. "We're trying to balance the needs of the city's economy with the community's concerns," said Adam Brodsky, a development corporation spokesman.
But the proposed reduction does not appear to satisfy long-suffering neighbors. On Wednesday, Community Board 6 is expected to adopt a resolution calling for flights to begin at 8 A.M. and stop at 8 P.M. instead of the current 7 A.M. to 11 P.M. The board is also seeking a complete ban on weekend flights. "Give two days of peace and quiet so residents can enjoy the neighborhood they pay so dearly to live in," said William Oddo, its transportation chairman. The board's vote, however, is not binding on the Planning Commission and the City Council, which have the final say on zoning applications.
Right now, the heliport and its operator, National Helicopter Corporation of America, are in a legal limbo. National Helicopter's lease lapsed last week -- and the heliport's last zoning permit expired in 1976. For many years the company was unaware that a permit was needed, said Jay Segal, a lawyer for National Helicopter, and the application's environmental analysis turned out to be complex.
Mr. Oddo maintains that the site is ill-suited for aviation. "You have the world's busiest heliport operating on a postage stamp-size facility, no more than an acre," he said. Most flights are for sightseeing, which he said would be better handled at the heliport off Wall Street or the one along the Hudson River near the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Both are in less residential areas and closer to tourist activities.
The East 34th Street Heliport's nearest neighbor, New York University Medical Center, complains that noise and fumes it generates bother patients and have forced the hospital to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on filtering. "The fumes cause eye, ear, nose and throat irritations and can get to the point where they are nauseating," said Jean Goldberg, an N.Y.U. environmental official. "Our Gimbel Gardens are virtually unusable because of the odors."
Mr. Segal, the lawyer, defended National Heliport. "They try to operate in a way that is the most safe and least noisy," he said. "The heliport provides a valuable service as a key part of the city's transportation system and as a thing tourists really like to do." He also pointed out that the heliport existed before most of the high-rise apartment towers nearby were built.
But pointing to the lack of both a lease and a zoning permit, Mr. Oddo of C.B. 6, called the heliport "an outlaw operation for two decades." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN/CLINTON;
Fur Trade Wanes, But Its Cradle Finds New Life

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

 BODY:
When Tom Gigi started in the fur business 40 years ago, West 30th Street from Avenue of the Americas to Eighth Avenue was thick with rack runners, jobbers and sewing-machine operators. "During lunch, you'd be forced into the street by the crowds," recalled Mr. Gigi, 65, a coat manufacturer. "It was a great time to be a furrier."
Although it remains the heart of the nation's fur trade, these days the fur district is more likely to house accountants or photographers than pelt merchants. "This used to be strictly a fur neighborhood, but we've seen a significant change in the past five years," said Vincent Terranova, executive vice president of Bernstein Real Estate. The company, which owns or manages 10 area buildings, says fur-related businesses have been supplanted by a hodgepodge of users, from newspaper publishers to carpet dealers to light-fixture makers. 
 Those furriers who survive tend to be concentrated in a handful of buildings, like 150 West 30th Street and 345 Seventh Avenue, Mr. Terranova said. Conversion of other bulky loft space south of Pennsylvania Station usually requires costly removal of storage vaults and refrigeration equipment. At 17 percent, the area's vacancy rate is much higher than a decade ago. Current rents on West 30th Street range from $8 to $12 a square foot, compared with $10 to $20 in the garment district, a few blocks north, where the economic picture has brightened somewhat in recent years.
But New York's fur industry has been buffeted hard by animal-rights advocates, a weak economy, cheap imports and a string of warm winters. And the future, some industry analysts say, looks even bleaker.
Nat Berkowitz, who opened Miller & Berkowitz furriers in 1950, knows only too well how times have changed. Customers who once bought a new coat every five years now make do with older furs or squeeze into those that do not quite fit. In summers past, his chilled vault at 224 West 30th Street overflowed with 8,000 coats left for storage by loyal clients. This year, the number is down to 6,500. "People would rather save the money," Mr. Berkowitz, 66, said. "It used to be that when you drove up the New York State Thruway to the Catskill resorts, there would be a mink stole hanging in every car window."
When Maureen Locke was looking for space to open her company, Versailles Lighting, the fur district was an obvious choice. Her husband's family has run Mechutan Fur on West 30th Street since the 1920's. "The fur business is going down the tubes, but I think this is a great neighborhood," said Ms. Locke, who has rented an entire floor above Miller and Berkowitz since June. She cited the district's reasonable rents, generous space and proximity to mass transit. "I can see Penn Station from my window," she said. "You can't beat that." ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: Second Homes: Not Prime Time

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
ELEANOR WILSON had an auction a couple of Saturdays ago, when, she said, the local auctioneer "came and took all the lovely things away."
As she spoke, she sighed; it was a swift, offhand gesture, one so expressive and encompassing of her 40-foot living room that it was easy to imagine polished 200-year-old highboys and beautifully faded turkey-red rugs and Italian paintings strewn around the place like toys in a child's playroom. 
 But even bare, the house is romantic: an old mill in Stockbridge, Mass., with the big brown mill wheel visible out the double doors to the deck, the dark autumn water rushing through the sluiceway below.
Ms. Wilson came up from New York City one weekend in 1947 to try out for a show at the Berkshire Playhouse. Driving up from Great Barrington, through the mountains, she vowed to someday buy a house and settle down. In 1955, she bought the mill house at auction; she became both actress and producer; she gave parties; she settled down. Now, she is worried her vision is failing and she won't be able to drive much longer. She is selling the mill house.
In the late 80's, her house -- a fantasy of Life in the Berkshires -- would have sold in a flash and might have been priced higher than the current $450,000, according to Richard S. Jackson Jr. of the Wheeler and Taylor Realty Company, who listed the house in June. But things are very different in the vacation-home market in New England, according to brokers interviewed. "I got you an offer," Mr. Jackson whispered to Ms. Wilson one recent afternoon. "But it's so low I'm not even going to tell you."
"What is it?" the white-haired woman asked eagerly. "I'll call you," he replied. The offer, he said later, was for $250,000.
George Ballantyne, the vice president of Sotheby's International Realty in charge of the company's listings from Maine to Fairfield County, Conn., said that the number of sales of luxury vacation properties -- houses selling for over $400,000 -- was down 50 percent from last year in some parts of his territory.
For lower-priced beach bungalows, ski chalets and forest-enveloped farmhouses, from New England to upper New York State to New Jersey to Pennsylvania, the market is erratic. But generally, the mid-range vacation or second-home properties -- from $300,000 to $500,000 -- seem to be a tough sell almost everywhere, while the lowest-priced properties are selling about as well as they did in 1994, a year real estate brokers heralded as the end of the recession, although now are not so sure.
IN places like Long Beach Island, N.J., a long strip of beachfront with a boardwalk and concession stands blazoned with colorful signs, the upper end has slowed to a crawl. But Charles J. Traina, an agent with Prudential Zack Realty in Long Beach Island, said that houses selling for between $140,000 and $280,000 were moving at a pace equal to last year. On the mainland, in Ship Bottom and Manahawkin, Mr. Traina said, 90 percent of the homes he sold in the 80's were vacation homes. The figure has now dropped to 50 percent, he said.
According to Mr. Traina and other realtors, some customers say they are reluctant to put disposable income into supporting a mortgage that may not remain tax-deductible. Congress has repeatedly threatened to take away the second-home mortgage interest deduction. "The whole political atmosphere has changed, and people don't know what's going to happen," he said.
The customers also seem wary of taking on a property that requires any work or substantial regular maintenance, he said. When the market was booming, even the wealthier buyers liked "fixer-uppers"; they brought in their architects and decorators and transformed the rambling old wrecks into rambling old summer houses. But now, agents say, even the well-to-do see a highly taxed or high-maintenance second home as a risky investment.
"What I'm seeing is a move away from maintenance-intensive properties, in areas like Newport, the Berkshires, in different areas of Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire," said Mr. Ballantyne, who has been selling in the region for 12 years. "There's always been a large summer community in Manchester and Dorset, Vt., for example, and so far, there's only been one sale this year I know of -- from all brokers -- of more than $400,000."
A year ago, he added, there were several sales there over $1 million.
In Newport, R.I., a traditional summer resort for Bostonians and New Yorkers, there has been only one sale of great magnitude in the last 18 months, the Sotheby's executive said. "Seacliff on Bellevue Avenue sold for $1.225 million earlier this month," he said. "If you compare that with three years ago, Fairholme was sold for $3.5 million and Wyndham sold for $2-plus million."
In Grafton, Vt., the historic village restored under the leadership of a foundation, Bob Barrett of Barrett and Company Real Estate said that the market for vacation and second homes still seemed to be falling, paralleling the market for all of Southern Vermont.
WITH few exceptions in New England, brokers are reporting that their customers -- for almost every price level of vacation house -- are fewer in number, and harder to convince. Weekend and vacation home buyers don't really have to buy, said one agent after another, so they can weigh their options. In many cases, they may decide to "consolidate" their money into a bigger, better, newer primary residence, Mr. Ballantyne said.
Privately, agents say buyers of second homes may be reluctant to invest in New England because of perceptions about its economy -- reports of plant closings and layoffs cheer neither realtors nor prospective buyers.
Then again, today's second-home buyers may just be feeling more adventurous; agents say they have seen might-have-been buyers pack up and head for an Art Deco apartment in the South Beach section of Miami, a 200-acre lodge in the Finger Lakes region of New York, a ranch in Wyoming and land bordering a whispering, sparkling trout stream in Montana.
Closer to home, in the Hamptons and along the Jersey shore, in the Poconos and in New York State closer than the Finger Lakes, the market varies widely.
Agents in the Hamptons report strong sales in the premier properties and a flat or decreasing market for 1970's and 80's contemporaries north of the main thoroughfare, the Montauk Highway.
The lower Jersey shore, around Cape May, is selling to Philadelphians, according to agents, but the upper part, including Long Beach Island, appears to be struggling, they say. Imposing properties in the Adirondacks are beginning to show some vitality, and within the last year, some wealthy buyers -- including Robert and Blaine Trump and Liam Neeson and his wife, Natasha Richardson -- headed for Millbrook, N.Y., where they can buy privacy and a 37-acre "gentleman's farm" on a hill for several million dollars.
In Westchester, not usually thought of as a second-home location, buyers of such homes are frequently older than elsewhere, and the properties they purchase are also out of the usual vacation-home pattern, according to Alix Sara Prince, a vice president at Julia B. Fee Real Estate. She said the bulk of the second-home buyers there are retirees, who may have sold their big home in the neighborhood, bought a primary residence in Florida or the Carolinas and decided to buy one of the new condominiums, like Doral Greens in Rye Brook, where units sell for $350,000 to $750,000, in order to keep up their friendships -- and their golf games.
"The young people are bypassing us, heading for the up-counties of New York State and Connecticut," she said.
Sam Strong, of the agency that bears his name in Old Lyme, Conn., Has put three houses in the Fenwick and North Cove sections of Old Saybrook under contract at more than $1 million each in the last two months. But he said that vacation houses were "a tough sell; the second-home market is heavily depressed."
"The buyers feel it is harder to justify spending a lot of money on a second home, as opposed to the 80's when people thought, 'Maybe this is a bit extravagant, but what the heck -- it'll be worth a couple hundred grand more in a year,' " Mr. Strong said. "Now they ask if I think they could get their money back if they have to sell."
Despite his own major sales recently, which he said "broke down 50-50 in terms of primary home/second home buyers," Mr. Strong estimated that the vacation home market was down about 30 percent in his own area, on Long Island Sound about two hours from midtown Manhattan.
"They want big and they want new," said Mr. Strong, adding that one man bought a $1.25 million house in Hamburg Cove recently -- and ripped it down to build a new one. "The old dream of old and quaint is gone," he said. "Now they want something with absolutely no work."
Those who are buying expensive vacation homes tend to be younger, according to agents almost everywhere. "They are more apt to be the 30-year-old computer whiz and his family," said Mr. Ballantyne, the Sotheby's director.
Mr. Ballantyne reported that there were pockets that appeared to be coming back strong: Cotuit and Osterville, on Cape Cod, he said, had "pretty impressive" sales this year, and he predicted the number of sales there would surpass last year's number.
At the same time, brokers report vacation home sales in the lowest ranges are selling. Mr. Strong said that "beach-cottagey" houses priced between $100,000 and $180,000 were selling "pretty well."
"It's houses in the $300,000 to $600,000, $700,000 range that are hurting," Mr. Strong said, paralleling the comments of other local realtors.
In the Hamptons, realtors agree that more and more people are buying houses, not just for the summer, but for weekends year-round. And they agree that the biggest houses are selling the best -- and for prices that in many cases are higher than they have ever been. They also agree that poorly built, poorly designed houses from the 1970's and 1980's -- especially if they are north of the main highway -- are not moving.
Frederick Butti, office manager of Dayton/Halstead Realty in East Hampton, said he was not sure that this year was as good as last year in terms of second-home sales. "Last year was very strong, and it has quieted down this year," he said. "The high end is moving, but the under $250,000, $300,000 range is just starting to get moving. The year started very slowly."
FRANK NEWBOLD, of Braverman Newbold Brennan, said that for his agency, sales of blue-chip properties -- large estates and even land in prime locations -- were up about 25 percent over sales two years ago.
He gave as an example a 2.4-acre wooded building lot on Briarpatch Road in the Georgica section of East Hampton Village, considered a prime spot. Three years ago, he said, the plot sold for $450,000; last week, it closed for $650,000.
Increasingly, he said, buyers are looking for "a protected place, with views of far fields, a glimpse of the water or a Village setting under a 100-year-old elm tree; they keep using the phrase 'a sense of place.' "
Right now, Mr. Newbold has a couple of properties for sale -- an Arts and Crafts cottage for $398,000 and an Italianate mansion for $1.35 million -- that he said exemplify the need for a "sense of place" and also satisfy the prospective buyer's increasing insistence on a place that needs no renovations.
Rose Cottage in Bridgehampton, on the ocean side of the highway, has been on the market for a year, but its former price of $425,000 was reduced to $395,000 at the end of the summer, when the tenants left and it could be showed more easily.
"It's been restored down to the last shingle and the last rose," said Mr. Newbold. "You don't walk in and say, 'I've got to find a painter;' there's literally thousands of roses planted in the 1920's, when it was built, dripping all over the place."
In Sag Harbor, Boxwood, on Main Street down the road from the Whaling Museum, is the kind of "maintenance-intensive" place that agents say is increasingly difficult to sell.
An 1860 ship captain's house with six bedrooms and a library with bright yellow walls and a gas fireplace, the house came on the market in the last month and is owned by an antiques dealer, so has been furnished and maintained to perfection.
Because the house requires substantial upkeep, Mr. Newbold said, "you've obviously lost some of the market: the buyer who says, 'It's a great place -- I'd like to come here to dinner once.' " Nevertheless, he predicted it would sell -- eventually.
"It'll be sold to the person who walks in, their jaw drops and they say: 'I've just got to have it,' " he said.
Like his colleagues in New England, Mr. Newbold reports that second-home buyers are young. But they have entirely different interests than their 1980's Hamptons counterparts, he said.
"Ten years ago, they wanted to know where the hippest disco was," he said. "Now they want to know where the nearest day care is -- the streets are crowded with strollers. They want to know how they can join the nature preserve, and they want to sign up for the tour of historic homes."
BESIDES the Hamptons, there are other areas that New Yorkers are choosing; one young woman with a husband and a 2-year-old daughter said her choice for a weekend house would be Buck Hill Falls, in the Poconos.
"It's like going to camp for grownups," said Mary Kelly Selover, a design writer and editor who rented there for five weeks and is looking at houses to buy. "You get up in the morning and drive half a mile to play tennis as long as you want; you go home and make lunch, you pick up the kids; you jump in the pool, you hop out and play a quick nine holes of golf. You drive to the farmer's market; you have a drink and make dinner; at nine o'clock you go to bed with a good book. It's very comfortable."
The buyer of a house in Buck Hill Falls does have to join the Buck Hill Falls Association for about $2,300 a year, no matter how big or small a house one purchases. But for that, the homeowner gets to play golf and tennis for a nominal fee, attend the band concerts and send the children to the camp club, where they can swim in the children's pool. They also benefit from the security force.
"It isn't a kind of security team that carries guns," said Virginia Hood, who runs a real estate company there. "One time a bat flew into a woman's house and the security people were called to get it out."
The comfortable, safe, camplike aura of the place -- built as a Quaker summer meeting place at the turn of the century -- is enveloping, said Ms. Selover. "There's security, and you can get people to clean the house and take care of your children. Why would I want to go on vacation and work like a dog?"
Ms. Hood has a variety of houses for sale in Buck Hill Falls now, from a $129,000 gambrel-roofed bungalow on 1.7 acres with the "grand mountain view" to a quaint old $425,000 wood and stone "cottage." While Buck Hill Falls, along with Skytop and the rest of Barrett Township, remains "a buyer's market," the realtor said her sales were "rolling along" -- especially in the last two weeks.
"I don't know what it is," she said. "I heard from somebody that things are getting better in New York City, and we're tied to them, but we're so busy we've taken in five contracts this week." Two of them were in Buck Hill Falls, she added, where she sells primarily second homes. One house is being bought by someone from New York; the other buyer is from New Jersey.
"I'm just crossing my fingers," she said, "and hoping it's going to last."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1405 words

HEADLINE: Common Cause

BYLINE: By William Finnegan; William Finnegan, the author of "Crossing the Line: A Year in the Land of Apartheid," is currently writing a book about race and downward mobility in four American communities.

 BODY:

BLACK LIBERATION
A Comparative History
of Black Ideologies in the
United States and South Africa.
By George M. Fredrickson.
390 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $30. 
 GEORGE M. FREDRICKSON'S "White Supremacy: A Comparative Study in American and South African History," published in 1981, was a masterpiece of sorts. By looking at the practice of racial subjugation as it developed in two widely separated societies, "White Supremacy" managed to illuminate each country's cruel history from new and arresting angles. The book's signal flaw was its dearth of black actors. Even allowing for its focus on white rule, the virtual invisibility of blacks in its pages was weird, seeming to suggest that the victims of racism had passively suffered their oppression. Now, as if to correct this impression, comes a long-awaited companion volume, "Black Liberation: A Comparative History of Black Ideologies in the United States and South Africa."
Mr. Fredrickson, the Edgar E. Robinson Professor of United States History at Stanford University, has again found a rich field for comparative study. He finesses the problem of the fundamental difference between the situation of black South Africans, an indigenous majority, and that of African-Americans, a minority whose ancestors were transported slaves, in part by elevating status over demographics (thus finding black South Africans under white rule "a minority in terms of their access to political, social and economic power") and in part by strictly limiting his historical canvas. "Black Liberation" begins in the mid-19th century. It elides both the American slave rebellions and the southern African wars of colonial conquest, and it effectively ends in the 1970's, before majority rule was really visible on the South African horizon.
While further limiting himself to "a study of protest on behalf of racial equality rather than of revolutionary action," Mr. Fredrickson defines protest broadly enough that he includes, for example, a lengthy discussion of the black Christian separatist movement known as Ethiopianism (in both its American and southern African variants), reaching backward to Prester John and forward to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In passing, Mr. Fredrickson relates the philosophical lineage of Ethiopianism to the reaction against the Enlightenment. What we have here is not, obviously, social history, culled from primary sources to reconstruct ordinary lives, but intellectual history, concentrated, as the book's subtitle says, on "ideologies" and deriving its material mainly from public statements, published writings and the work of other historians.
Black Americans and black South Africans actually have, as it is said, a history together. Turn-of-the-century South African black leaders who visited the United States, like Sol Plaatje and John Dube, were inspired by Booker T. Washington's Tuskegee Institute, and they subscribed to The Crisis, the magazine of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, then edited by W. E. B. Du Bois. Early African-American missionaries and musicians who visited South Africa left lasting impressions, and Christian millenarian movements in the Transkei region after World War I believed that black American aviators were coming to liberate them from white oppression. More practically, African-American political pressure was crucial to the imposition of the international economic sanctions that helped defeat apartheid.
But "Black Liberation" is less concerned with specific interactions than it is with close cross-referencing. At its best, this comparative method yields shrewd generalizations. For example, the combined spectacle of Northern Republicans enforcing the black franchise in the Reconstruction South while, in the Cape Colony, the British authorities were defying their Afrikaner subjects by creating a partial black franchise produces the observation that, in both cases, "adherence to liberal ideals of equal rights helped to enable one ethnic or sectional division of the white population to maintain its hegemony over another."
Or, in a discussion of the great (if fleeting) success of two black populist movements in the early 1920's -- Garveyism in the United States and the Industrial and Commercial Workers' Union in South Africa -- comes this: "The eclectic and ambiguous quality of populist ideologies is a source of strength when it comes to organizing relatively inarticulate people who know that something is terribly wrong but resist abstract and rationalized interpretations of what it is." Mr. Fredrickson's account of these populist movements is particularly strong, showcasing his ability to relate tidy intellectual history to the sprawling mess of facts -- how, say, Garveyites in Cleveland or Los Angeles might actually have picked and chosen among Marcus Garvey's ideas.
There is, moreover, a good deal of resonance between contemporary politics and some of the ideas treated here in their historical context, on the American side of the story especially. When Frederick Douglass opposes the idea of free homesteads for former slaves after the Civil War, arguing that "if the Negro cannot stand on his own legs let him fall," the modern affirmative action supporter is given pause (after the pause, Douglass seems, to me anyway, to have been disastrously mistaken). In what Mr. Fredrickson calls Ethiopianism's "romantic racialist conception of black moral superiority," the roots of Leonard Jeffries's crackpot essentialism are plainly discernible.
And yet recent history, which is to say the postwar period, is this book's weakest suit by far. American and South African racial politics "diverged decisively," as Mr. Fredrickson notes, after World War II, with the great apartheid crackdown starting in the same year (1948) that Harry Truman, worried about the black votes he needed for re-election, ordered the desegregation of the armed forces. Mr. Fredrickson attempts to compare the American civil rights movement of the 1950's and early 1960's with the South African freedom struggle of the same era through the prism of Gandhian nonviolent resistance, a philosophy to which leaders of both movements partly subscribed. Even after allowing for the basic differences between the challenges each movement faced -- the American struggle had, for a start, the United States Constitution on its side -- this approach creates a skewed version of events, particularly in South Africa, where Mr. Fredrickson's efforts to hold movement leaders to a Gandhian standard become scolding and silly.
A historian of the United States first and foremost, Mr. Fredrickson is not always on solid factual ground in South Africa. He chides Nelson Mandela, on flimsy evidence, for ignorance of the history of African Christianity. Seeking to trace "the spirit of Gandhi" in his brief sketch of the events of the last 20 years, he draws a misleading distinction between the above-ground anti-apartheid coalition of the 1980's, the United Democratic Front, and its underground ally, the African National Congress. He describes the U.D.F.'s campaigns in 1989 as "the first disciplined nonviolent actions against specific segregation policies since 1960," when in reality the group had been leading peaceful boycotts and demonstrations for a good five years by then (as Mr. Fredrickson himself acknowledges elsewhere). This tendentiousness -- not to mention the passionate brief the author carries for Christian activists, whom at one point he calls "fearless men of God" -- dulls and distorts the last section of an otherwise magisterial book.
The breathtaking triumph of democracy in South Africa has lent a poignant additional symmetry to Mr. Fredrickson's twin comparative studies. In the introduction to "White Supremacy" he expressed a hope that oppressed South Africans, locked in a seemingly hopeless struggle for freedom, might take heart from the successes of the American civil rights movement. Now, 14 years later, in the epilogue to "Black Liberation" his valediction is the opposite: that the moribund campaign for racial equality in this country might look to South Africa for lessons. In a sense, though, both countries today face the same challenge: how to translate formal political rights into economic progress and social hope for the millions who are still poor and still profoundly disadvantaged.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 22; Column 4; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 686 words

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Jim Usry's Town

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
IT was a fine crowd that helped the comedian Slappy White blow out 74 candles on his cake at the Hickory House Bar last Saturday. Past and current nightclub owners from New York and Philadelphia arrived in expensive cars and limousines. Former dancers, musicians and stagehands from Atlantic City's nightclub era (of which Mr. White was a mainstay) greeted each other like old friends.
But while Mr. White was the guest of honor, it was the host, James L. Usry, who got all the attention. Tall and lean at 73, the former Mayor of Atlantic City -- ousted in 1990 while under a corruption indictment -- worked the room much as he had in the 1940's, when he was maitre d'hotel of the Club Harlem on Kentucky Avenue and a basketball star with the Harlem Globetrotters. 
 Between greetings, Mr. Usry was asked how he had spent the last five years. Keeping a low profile, he replied. He is a substitute teacher in the public school system. He sits on the boards of the local Salvation Army and of Lincoln University in Pennsylvania.
It was anything but a low profile that he kept for six contentious years as Atlantic City's first black Mayor. He rose to power in the public school system as a charismatic teacher and administrator with strong community ties. And when he ran for mayor of a city whose government seemed permanently racked by corruption scandals, he was greeted as a primary example of what Thomas H. Kean, then Governor, called the "politics of inclusion."
Mr. Usry was an advocate for housing, education, affirmative action and welfare programs that would benefit Atlantic City's black majority. And many of the city's most visible improvements, including the redevelopment of the Northeast Inlet neighborhood, were planned when he was Mayor. But he could not rein in a highly factional ized, racially and economically divided city.
His seeming failure to promote the interests of the casino and hospitality industry over those of his cronies -- a few of whom have since been jailed on bribery and extortion charges -- put him at odds with state government and journalists. Then, in July 1989, while he was recovering from shoulder surgery and under the influence of painkillers, he accepted an envelope containing $6,000 in cash from a local businessman named Albert Black. He told Mr. Black that he would use the money to buy tickets for children and elderly people who couldn't afford the $250 admission to a fund-raiser for his re-election campaign.
On the morning of July 27, state troopers awakened him at home, handcuffed him and took him to the National Guard Armory, across Absecon Boulevard from the Hickory House Bar. He and 14 others were charged with taking part in an influence-peddling conspiracy. In 1990, he lost his re-election bid to James Whelan, who is still Mayor.
All the major charges against Mr. Usry were later dropped when he pleaded guilty to improper reporting of campaign contributions and agreed to do 60 hours of community service with the Salvation Army.
Today, in Atlantic City, Mr. Usry's downfall still draws the kind of racially polarized comments that have become a dismal mantra in city after city. "No one believes -- for one instant -- that Jim Usry was corrupt," said John Whittington, chairman of the Atlantic City Housing Authority, who is black. "Jim was a victim of the same kind of racism you see in every municipality in this country." For his part, Mr. Black, who is white, said the Usry prosecution "was absolutely and unequivocally not racially motivated."
Mr. Usry says his past no longer bothers him. "I believe God is good all the time," he said. "I pray morning and night that this stigma will be lifted." And despite the stigma, he said, he has had "a good life."
"I knew everybody who was anybody at the Club Harlem," he went on. "I've met the Queen of England. I've been to Africa, Europe and Israel." Although he is still a Republican "in good standing," he said his days in politics were over.
Mr. Whittington disagreed. "This is a small town," he said. "There's no way an ex-mayor is going to stay out of the picture."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 13; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: The Pope vs. the Culture of Death

BYLINE: By Paul Baumann; Paul Baumann is the associate editor of Commonweal magazine.

DATELINE: NOANK, Conn.

 BODY:
It is probably not a coincidence that Pope John Paul II has come to America only six months after posting his sternest rebuke yet of modern -- essentially American -- mores and culture.
"Evangelium Vitae" (Gospel of Life), the papal encyclical released in March, envisions a deepening, almost Manichaean struggle between "a culture of death" and "a culture of life." Abortion and euthanasia, the Pope argues, are threats to democracy. He says that our liberal society is myopically concerned with efficiency and increasingly characterized by a war of the powerful against the weak. 
 The Pope attributes an erosion of respect for human life to our exaggerated individualism and to the materialism, hedonism and moral relativism it fosters. He says we have turned a blind eye to the "necessary conformity of civil law with the moral law."
For Americans, schooled to respect the ideal that civil and moral law are separate entities, it is jarring to hear this admonition that they should be brought exactly into line.
The centerpiece of the Pope's argument is that there are certain objective moral facts that cannot be altered, even by our society's instincts toward moral pluralism, compassion and majority rule. Abortion and euthanasia are crimes, he says, and societies where such killing is allowed will invariably revert to barbarianism and list toward totalitarianism.
Strong words. The encyclical was enthusiastically received by Roman Catholics on both ends of the ideological spectrum. Conservatives cheered the absolute sexual norms while liberals applauded the criticism of materialism. Yet the reaction of those in the wary middle, Catholic or not, was muted. It is possible to agree with the Pope's judgment about the moral precariousness of modern life and yet question his stringent critique of contemporary culture.
Americans rightly detected a note of very European petulance in the Pope's reaction to the diversity, the rough and tumble, of American pluralism. Americans are a notoriously pragmatic lot, and being lectured to about the theoretical foundations of democracy by those with little practical experience of democracy arouses an instinctive skepticism.
Looking at myself and my neighbors, I'm not so sure that hedonism is an overwhelming temptation. Though I believe that abortion is killing, I honestly do not know to what extent its legalization has corrupted the larger moral tenor of our lives. I can imagine worse crimes, and hear about them every day.
Neither is consumerism the simple manifestation of greed that the Pope implies it to be. It is much more the inevitable result of a culture of very competitive individualists. It is, for better and worse, the signature of mass democracy.
Democracy, the Pope rightly notes, cannot be an end in itself; the popular will is not infallible. But most Americans, perhaps even most American Catholics, are not convinced that counseling tolerance on issues such as abortion, where moral views seem irreconcilable, is a first step on the road to totalitarianism. Much of our history tells us otherwise: This country's increased tolerance of religious differences and sexual orientations in the latter half of this century has hardly paved the way for despotism.
Nor is there a clear connection between pluralism and any inevitable disregard for the value of human life. It seems quite possible that a society lacking the Pope's "objective moral order" could still protect an unborn child's right to life.
Still, I don't know many people who aren't disoriented by the increasing reach of technology, the craven tone of popular culture and the economic insecurity of our achievement-driven society. I am not eager to find out how much more abortion or uncurbed consumer appetite American society can tolerate.
I wish the Pope were more persuasive, that he were more American. What he has to say about human solidarity and what the well-off owe the underpriveliged needs saying, especially in a nation of driven individualists. Yet his moral certitude spooks the baptized and unbaptized alike, for it seems to deny the moral ambiguity that is inherent in a pluralistic society, the conflicting ideas of right and wrong that come from so many voices.
We need a variety of moral authorities -- the family, the state, religion -- to make our way through this ambiguous moral terrain. To take its rightful place among these voices, Catholicism must accept the fact that sexual and moral pluralism is inseparable from the democratic freedoms it otherwise celebrates.
Labeling American society a "culture of death" captures one truth, but ignores many others. In modern democracy, error must retain certain inviolable rights, so that greater error cannot get the upper hand.
Stripped of its absolutist accent, the message of John Paul II might obtain some significant resonance in the country he called an "extraordinary human epic" this week. To a remarkable extent, his speech at the United Nations on Thursday, in which he celebrated the relationship between freedom and pluralism, did just that.
In the emerging struggle against the spiritually stultifying effects of technological society, American democracy and Catholicism need to join forces. The continuing tragedy is that they so often conspire to excommunicate each other.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 9, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 129 words

HEADLINE: More Taxi Medallions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I enjoyed Peter Passell's column on New York City taxis (Economic Scene, Oct. 5). If the problems with the city's taxis (poor service, suppressed wages) can be attributed to artificially limited supply, the solution is to raise the number of medallions. 
 This would be resisted by those who own medallions. To overcome that resistance, while doubling the supply, every current owner of a medallion could be given another medallion with the stipulation that it must be put in use or sold.
This process can be repeated every year until the supply of medallions is effectively uncontrolled. Current medallion owners would receive fair value for their investment, and the monopoly on medallions would end.
 
OLIVER KARLIN
New York, Oct. 5, 1995

LENGTH: 1799 words

HEADLINE: Candidates Seek Early Earful To Avoid a Rejection at Polls

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The 30-second television commercial opens with a bleak scene of a lonely Senator Bob Dole trudging through the snows of New Hampshire in 1988 -- a pointed reminder of how he lost the crucial primary there after refusing to sign a pledge against new taxes.
As haunting music plays, an announcer warns: "New Hampshire rejected Bob Dole because we didn't trust him on taxes. We were right." Then come examples intended to tag Mr. Dole as a big taxer. 
 This attack advertisement was not produced by any of Mr. Dole's rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination but by his own campaign. As Mr. Dole braces for the inevitable televised onslaught from his opponents, his campaign decided the best way to prepare itself was by creating the roughest advertisements imaginable against the Senator. So Mr. Dole's media advisers dreamed up slick sample ads -- complete with slogans, background music and narration -- like those they expect from Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator.
Two weeks ago, the campaign showed these test commercials -- which, of course, will never actually make it on television -- to four small groups of Republicans in Manchester, N.H., and in Nashua, N.H., who said they will vote in the state's primary. The aim was to gauge potential voters' responses and use them to create more test advertisements answering the attacks.
It has been nearly two decades since political operatives learned that "focus groups" of voters can be as effective in determining how to peddle candidates as they are in peddling bars of soap. They played an integral role in helping Bill Clinton in 1992 as he wended his way through accusations of womanizing and draft dodging, and his advisers have consulted them ever since. His advisers are already using them for the 1996 campaign.
But most striking this year is that the major Republican campaigns are assembling focus groups much earlier than in the past. Some have become so reliant on them that they say they do not dare broadcast a commercial without testing it first.
These groups' discussions can run from policy minutiae to, well, mammals. The Dole campaign recently asked focus groups to name the animals the candidates reminded them of. According to an internal Dole campaign memorandum, the most popular descriptions of Mr. Gramm were "weasels, foxes, hyenas, ferrets," though some gave him positive points for being tenacious by calling him "bulldog" and "tortoise." The memorandum, which was made available by the Dole campaign, said Mr. Buchanan was likened to "mostly tough, smaller and combative animals" like "pit bulls, badgers, wolverines."
It found that Mr. Dole was described at times as a tenacious and even "a bit plodding survivor" like a "mule, draft horse, tortoise, German shephard." Some participants offered "elephant," given Mr. Dole's long service to Republicans. Others, saying he was "too quick to compromise," suggested "chameleon, kangaroo, zebra."
These groups do not always provide a rosy picture of how a candidate comes across. In an internal memorandum, Linda DiVall, Mr. Gramm's pollster, noted that the Senator did not make a good first impression with some voters in New Hampshire who looked at a sample Gramm commercial and video. "Thank God for the mute button," one man said. One woman observed, "Has a voice you don't want to listen to." There also were positive remarks, of course, like the man who said, "If anyone can accomplish balanced budget goal, he can."
For Republicans this year, the obvious target is Mr. Dole. Since he is far ahead in the polls, his competitors are asking focus groups to dissect his public appearances. They are hoping for unexpected insights that might help them topple the Senator.
All the while, the campaigns are seeking ways to fine-tune their own messages. Mr. Dole's aides, for example, said they learned through focus groups how best to cut the legislative jargon from the majority leader's speeches.
"The way we have used focus groups is to explore reactions that you can't measure in surveys, such as reactions to the tone and style of a candidate's delivery," said Whit Ayres, Mr. Alexander's pollster. He said Mr. Alexander presents himself as an "outsider versus an insider" more often than "Governor versus Senator" because that contrast did not test as well in focus groups.
But Mr. Ayres and other pollsters say it would be a mistake to be guided too much by the sometimes scattered observations from focus groups. "Focus groups are useful but are frequently overused," said Mark Penn, one of Mr. Clinton's chief pollsters. "They're too easily pointed in one direction or another and should be used for base exploratory work, not for drawing as many conclusions as I see people using them for."
According to Ms. DiVall's memorandum, Mr. Gramm's focus groups underscored some of the Senator's weaknesses in New Hampshire, where the first primary is tentatively set for Feb. 20.
"Knowledge void on Gramm is still immense," Ms. DiVall wrote in the memorandum dated Sept. 28, which was obtained by The New York Times from a rival campaign. "Nobody knew anything about him. Women were totally confused on his position on affirmative action and abortion." While she found that the groups did not cite "a mean-spirited dimension" of his personality, they had other reservations, including: "have no knowledge of him," "too concerned with process over issue" and "revelations in Packwood diaries raise concern about his ethics and integrity."
Ms. DiVall also said that people raised questions about the Senator's wife, Wendy. In the past, rival campaigns have accused the Senator of playing down his wife because she is Korean-American.
"Women had a curiosity about Wendy in the 60-second spot, and some felt Gramm was hiding her." Ms. DiVall wrote. "The video was received positively as they got to know more about her." She also recommended dropping a clip from an ad showing Mr. Gramm with the actor Charlton Heston, saying, "Charlton Heston no longer is quite the big pull he used to be."
On the plus side, Ms. DiVall found that "the primary controversy," -- in which Mr. Gramm has been accused of not fighting to keep New Hampshire's position as the state with the first primary -- "was not brought up by a single individual."
The impact of focus groups can already be seen in the choice of issues candidates are emphasizing. "The trade issue with men is a big plus for Buchanan," Ms. DiVall advised. "At some point, we will have to engage him on this issue, but not until greater definition has been provided of Gramm."
The memorandum also found that viewers were not impressed with a video that mentioned that Mr. Gramm tied Mr. Dole in a straw poll in Iowa in August. "Iowa straw poll is meaningless -- it was bought," according to a response recorded by Ms. DiVall.
Asked today about her memorandum, Ms. Divall said, "It's meant for our internal strategy team, not for public distribution." But she emphasized the positive findings, saying, "We've got a world of potential to grow, and with Senator Dole it's the opposite. He's got a tenuous lead due to familiarity and party loyalty."
The three Republican campaigns using focus groups most extensively -- Mr. Dole, Mr. Gramm and Mr. Alexander -- allowed a reporter to view videotapes of their groups. While the campaigns selected sessions that put their candidates in the best light, the access gave an unusual inside look at how these groups function.
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, agreed to show a reporter the test advertisements the campaign's media adviser, Stuart Stevens, created against its own candidate to demonstrate that the Senator could endure the roughest televised assaults on his most vulnerable issues. The voters signaled their responses by turning dials on hand-held electronic meters. Mr. Reed showed the results by superimposing these ratings on the advertisement in a graphic display like the chart of a heart beat. The results showed that Mr. Dole's support did not fall appreciably.
"We've thrown the kitchen sink at Dole and none of it sticks," Mr. Reed asserted. "Voters respect his character and stability and trust his leadership skills. It's pathetic that our opponents' strategy is totally based on Dole slipping."
But advisers to Mr. Gramm and Mr. Alexander counter that their focus groups show that Mr. Dole is vulnerable because, at age 72, he is older than the other candidates, and because he is prone to compromises.
Focus group participants are selected by independent agencies. They are paid to watch videotapes of candidates and, prompted by a moderator, offer their opinions about everything from the candidates' messages to their clothes. They are not told which campaign is sponsoring the focus group.
"I hate to be prejudiced one way or another, but I think he's too old," one woman said of Mr. Dole at an Alexander focus group of eight people sitting around a rectangular table in New Hampshire.
A woman across the table agreed, saying, "You see someone going in that office and two years later they look terrible, Clinton looks awful."
At a focus group organized by the Gramm campaign in Ankeny, Iowa, outside Des Moines, four women and five men who identified themselves as devout conservatives sipped cans of soda and ate potato chips as they offered mixed responses about Mr. Dole's personality.
"He does project himself well," one woman said. "I just don't like him personally. He's a mean-spirited person; kind of a nasty guy."
An older man, recalling Mr. Dole's 1976 campaign with Gerald Ford, chimed in at the other side of the table, "He was a hatchet man when he ran for Vice President."
When Ms. DiVall, who was the moderator of the group, asked whether Mr. Dole or Mr. Gramm "comes across with the strongest sense of conviction," almost everyone picked Mr. Gramm.
But when she asked, "Which one looks more Presidential?" the consensus was Mr. Dole.
One participant said that the video clips of Mr. Dole talking about his service in World War II were far more genuine than those of him weighing in on the budget. "When Dole was up there talking about his experience in the service, he was talking from his heart at that time," the man said. "You could tell the compassion." He added that Mr. Dole "doesn't always do that the other times."
One woman observed what Mr. Gramm often says about himself: He does not make a great first impression. "First impression isn't real good, but the more I look at him the more I like him," she said. "I wish he had a little bit more charisma just because there are people who are just going to look at the face on the t.v. and make their mind up at that point."

HEADLINE: Haves and Have-Nots Revisited

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Visitors can hardly miss the theme of Telecom 95. The slogan "Connect!" appears on everything from giant placards to palm-sized telephone calling cards at the quadrenniel meeting of the international telecommunications industry, which continues through Wednesday. But in the view of some skeptics, a better slogan might have been "disconnect."
Although more than 50 countries constructed elaborate national pavilions to illustrate the explosive growth of their telecommunications industries, the poorest nations of the world are clearly not sharing in the wealth. According to a study by the International Telecommunication Union, which sponsors the convention, the poorest 48 countries are falling even further behind developed nations in the growth of telecommunications infrastructure. 
 The hard facts do not invalidate the central theme of Telecom 95 -- that digital technology is revolutionizing telecommunications and erasing the boundaries that separate the telephone, computer and media industries. But the revolution's inequality does take some of the shine off a business that has celebrated itself here as both a one-stop shop for the Information Age and a force for positive political change in the world.
"The present reality is that the technology gap between developed and developing nations is actually widening," said Nelson Mandela, the President of South Africa, who spoke at the gathering's opening ceremony. "Most of the world has no experience of what readily accessible communications can do for society and the economy."
Even the most enthusiastic of industry executives acknowledged that the world could find itself divided into telecom "haves" and "have-nots." Michael T. Masin, vice chairman of the GTE Corporation, described telecommunications in a speech on Thursday as a "liberation technology." But he conceded that some major regions of the world, notably Africa, had not benefited from its emancipating influence.
In fact, the rate of growth of telephone lines in African countries like Chad, Zaire and Niger, badly lags behind the growth even in other developing countries like China, Egypt and India. The I.T.U., an agency of the United Nations, has organized a new development fund called Worldtel that aims to help poor countries build rudimentary telephone networks.
Pekka Tarjanne, the Secretary General of the I.T.U., said Worldtel hoped to raise $500 million from public and private sources in the next year. "These are countries that need help to pull themselves out of their misery," he said.
But some countries may be beyond help, at least for now. Bert de Graeve, a vice president of Alcatel Trade International, a division of Alcatel-Alsthom, the French telecom giant, which specializes in bringing phone service to developing countries, said that companies had little incentive to invest in Africa because of political instability on much of the continent and a dearth of investors willing to share the risk of building networks there.
In the telephone-rich economies of Western Europe and the United States, there are no lack of companies vying to offer services -- particularly to high-volume business customers. The current craze is the multinational alliance: a group of companies that pool their communications networks, marketing and sales forces to offer one set of services to customers across several geographic markets.
MCI Communications and BT (the former British Telecommunications) promoted their joint venture, called Concert. The Sprint Corporation and its two European partners, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom, sought to allay fears that government regulators would spike their proposed venture, Phoenix. And AT&T tried to explain its World Partners venture, a loose federation of telephone companies from Europe and Asia.
But while these alliances look and sound formidable, customers who do business with them are considerably less enchanted.
"Most alliances are almost worthless," said Arthur F. Cipolla, the director of telecommunications and information security at Motorola. He said the existing alliances have been consistently unable to provide his company with reliable, affordable phone service outside major financial centers like London and Frankfurt.
Mr. Cipolla and his counterparts at nearly two dozen multinational corporations have formed a consortium to voice their opinions to major phone companies. Among their chief goals: Persuading the big alliances that it is more important to offer dependable phone service in more remote locations like Nairobi, Kenya, or Kiev, Ukraine, than it is to offer high-speed data-transmission services between New York and London.
"Anyone can do that," Mr. Cipolla said. The trick, he said, is getting a good phone line to Nairobi.

HEADLINE: Proposed Insurance Rules On H.I.V. Set Off Uproar

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 7

 BODY:
The New Jersey Insurance Department has provoked an uproar among medical experts and state civil libertarians by quietly proposing rules that would allow health insurers to screen new applicants for the AIDS virus and to reject those whose tests are positive or who refuse to be tested.
As the administrative proposal came to light, the State Medical Society and civil rights advocates protested that the policy could allow insurers to circumvent existing Federal and state laws that forbid insurers to deny coverage to applicants who have AIDS virus, H.I.V. 
 The Insurance Department said the proposed rules would apply only to new applicants to group health programs, the kind offered by large employers. It said that people enrolled in programs for fewer than 50 employees would not be affected, citing a state law prohibiting the use of H.I.V. testing for that category. Critics of the proposals said that state and Federal laws ban H.I.V. testing for all medical coverage, setting the stage for a contest over what the law says and means.
"It is almost incredible that they did this," said Neil Weisfeld, deputy executive director of the New Jersey Medical Society. "All of us in the field of health care are shocked that the Department of Insurance went ahead with this proposal without consulting, so far as we can tell, a single health care provider in the state."
The proposed rules were published without announcement in the Oct. 2 issue of The New Jersey Register, the state's rule-making publication. A 30-day comment period expires on Nov. 1.
Ed Martone, director of the New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union, said the proposed change would diminish the civil rights of people who have AIDS.
"AIDS was added to the handicapped section of the civil rights law 10 years ago, to lower the real or perceived barriers for people with this condition," Mr. Martone said. "This proposed rule brings us back to where we were 10 years ago in terms of health insurance."
The proposed rule changes were authorized by Andrew J. Karpinski, the Insurance Commissioner who recently resigned under criticism that he had concealed what was viewed as a conflict of interest with an insurance firm he owned before becoming Commissioner.
"The proposed rules apply to all life and health insurers transacting business in this state," the proposal reads in part. "Insurers may ask whether the applicant has tested positively for H.I.V. infection and/or experienced any of a list of symptoms including symptoms of H.I.V. infection."
If a series of tests for H.I.V. are positive, "then the insurer may decline coverage for the applicant," the proposal says. At a later point, it adds, "If an applicant refuses to submit to an initial or repeat screening of the immunoblot test" -- an H.I.V. test regimen -- "then the insurer may decline coverage."
The Insurance Department appeared to have been caught off guard by the strong criticism of the proposed rule changes. The department maintains that the changes were made to comply with new reporting rules enacted by the Legislature earlier this year, as well as to assure that health insurance applicants are given the fairest, most up-to-date test for the presence of H.I.V. They pointed out that the department would take public comment on the proposed changes until Nov. 1, after which they could become law without legislative action.
Insurance Department officials said a 1986 department policy banning AIDS and H.I.V. testing for health insurance did not have the force of law. The new rules are silent on the question of the Americans With Disabilities Act, whose ban on discrimination against H.I.V.-infected people has been interpreted to forbid screening health insurance applicants for H.I.V.
The department acknowledged that state law forbids AIDS screening for individual health insurance applicants as well as for members of company policies covering up to 49 people, but said that the large group insurers handling bigger corporate accounts were allowed to screen for the immunodeficiency virus.
"Since they already do it, these rules require that they do it in a fair manner and that they use the latest science," said Kathleen Bird, a department spokeswoman. In any case, Ms. Bird said, it is unlikely that a group carrier would screen all applicants for coverage since it would be "economically unfeasible" to do so.
Marc Buro, the Insurance Department's director of legislative affairs, made much the same point. "Current law," he said, "does not empower the Insurance Department with the ability to stop insurance companies from making underwriting decisions based on health status."
But Mr. Weisfeld of the State Medical Society strongly disputed this assertion.
"Health insurers do not test," he said emphatically. "Life insurers test, but when you go in for health insurance, the company does not say, 'O.K., go in for a physical, and on the basis of our tests, we'll decide whether or not to insure you.' That does not happen, and one would hope that the State Insurance Department were aware of this."
Mr. Weisfeld said that allowing group health insurers, the kind that cover most workers, to screen out people with H.I.V. and AIDS would only increase medical expenses down the road, both because sick people without insurance tend to aggravate their condition, and so end up costing more to treat, and because ultimately they are likely to become dependent on publicly financed Medicaid insurance.
"I don't know if they did their legal reserch, but I know they didn't do their policy research," he said, "and I also know they didn't do their financial research, because if you bring people in for treatment earlier, you get a lower bill than if you bring them in late."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has so far declined to comment on the issue, saying she needs time to study the facts. A senior member of her administration, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the spirit behind the proposed rule changes was nothing less than a step toward forcing individuals to face the consequences of behavior that exposes them to AIDS.
"There is a body of opinion out there that AIDS is a behaviorally based illness," the official said. "It is preventable to the extent that if you do not engage in certain conduct, you will not be at risk for this condition. I think that opinion is an element in the mix here."

HEADLINE: With Few Efforts at Tracking, Many Fugitives Avoid Trial

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: FREEHOLD, N.J.

 BODY:
Robert Fuhr's voice choked when he remembered the day his 11-year-old daughter accused her stepfather of molesting her.
"If I had seen him then, I would have blown him away," Mr. Fuhr said. 
 But the stepfather never appeared for his trial here, and for the past 10 years Mr. Fuhr has tried to get the Monmouth County authorities to track him down. It has been particularly frustrating, because for much of the last decade the stepfather, Richard A. Cano, has been living with Mr. Fuhr's ex-wife in Martin County, Fla.
And although Mr. Fuhr gave Monmouth County authorities Mr. Cano's address in Florida, prosecutors say budget constraints, a shortage of personnel and missing information have prevented his arrest.
"I might as well have told them to look in the Sea of Tranquillity on the Moon," Mr. Fuhr said. "This is a failure of the entire system."
Every year, several thousand New Jersey criminal trials are suspended because defendants fail to appear. There are almost as many fugitives as there are inmates serving time in New Jersey prisons.
Prosecutors in Monmouth County say they sympathize with Mr. Fuhr, but insist they do not have the people to track down every defendant who does not appear for trial. It can be especially difficult to find those who flee to other states, where the authorities depend on local police departments to catch the fugitives, usually after an arrest for other offenses or a traffic stop.
"In many cases, there is no downside to becoming a fugitive," said Alton Kenny, Monmouth County's first deputy prosecutor.
Despite efforts by New Jersey court officials to address the fugitive problem, the number has remained steady in recent years at around 25,000, compared with the 25,699 inmates in state prisons.
In 1992, Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of State Supreme Court appointed a committee to investigate why the number of fugitives had been increasing steadily since the early 1980's. The committee estimated that about 60 percent of fugitives fled to avoid prosecution. The remaining 40 percent fail to appear in court because of their own negligence or because of administrative problems.
Robert Seidenstein, the spokesman for the Supreme Court, said that as a result of the committee's work, the courts have improved administrative procedures for record-keeping and scheduling. Since 1992 the number of fugitive cases has leveled off, he said.
But he said that only increased enforcement would significantly reduce the number of fugitives.
"Ultimately the solution rests in the resources available for investigation and apprehension," Mr. Seidenstein said.
But prosecutors and court officials in New Jersey maintain they are overburdened by a vast increase in criminal trials related to drug enforcement efforts, and John Kip Cornwell, an associate professor at Seton Hall Law School, said their counterparts around the nation face a similar problem. "The issue boils down to a lack of resources," he said.
Professor Cornwell said public pressure had led law enforcement to focus at times on certain classes of fugitives, like fathers who had failed to make child support payments, or on particularly dangerous criminals. But he said most police departments had little time to devote to searching for interstate fugitives.
"It is basically an economic reality," he said.
In the case of New Jersey v. Cano, charges were filed after 11-year-old Brandi Fuhr told summer camp counselors in August 1985 that her stepfather had sexually abused her over a five-year period in Florida, where she had been living with her mother, and in New Jersey. Mr. Fuhr, who had joint custody of Brandi at the time, immediately contacted the police in Monmouth County.
"In this case, with the young lady present here in New Jersey, we wanted to present the case to the grand jury as soon as possible," said Mr. Kenny, the first deputy prosecutor.
A warrant was issued for Mr. Cano in New Jersey. But because he had never been arrested and processed by the police, the authorities did not have fingerprints or a photograph to identify him. Without these identifying details, the prosecutors said they could not send a warrant over the F.B.I.'s national computer network.
So, even though Mr. Fuhr told Monmouth County prosecutors that Mr. Cano was living in Martin County, the authorities there were not alerted. Prosecutors said that even if an interstate warrant had been issued, the police in Florida would not have been able to arrest Mr. Cano without fingerprints or a photograph to identify him.
"Without identifiers to put into the system, no matter how many times they give them an address, it is not going to make any difference," said Jessica Oppenheim, the deputy attorney general who reviews prosecutors' performance for the New Jersey Attorney General's office.
Prosecutors acknowledge that investigators could have made a greater effort to identify Mr. Cano. As Mr. Fuhr has pointed out, investigators might have obtained his fingerprints from his military records. They also might have obtained a photograph from his former employer, a New Jersey I.B.M. plant, or from an acquaintance.
But prosecutors said the office did not have the investigators to chase all the people who flee from criminal charges. They often face the difficult decision of suspending a search because a more pressing case demands the available resources.
"You have to prioritize on who you are going to look for," Mr. Kenny said. "We take this case seriously. But is this case going to be different than somebody who is suspected to be a serial rapist, a child sexual murderer? Yes."
Even in cases where the authorities have easy access to fingerprints or photographs, prosecutors rely on local police departments to track fugitives, Mr. Kenny said.
"It happens all the time," he said. "You are going to make the attempt. You are going to ask the local department to check the address. They go, he is not home. The number of checks is dependent on them."
"This is a serious crime," he said, referring to Mr. Fuhr's case. "I am not going to say it is not. But in this circumstance, that is realistically the best that is going to happen."
Mr. Fuhr, who was awarded sole custody after the charges were brought against Mr. Cano, said he prodded prosecutors for about two years after the indictment, in September 1985; he was unaware that the case had been declared inactive by the County Prosecutor's office by December of the same year. After the first few years, Mr. Fuhr said, he tried to put the matter behind him.
In late 1994, as part of a periodic review of old cases, the Monmouth County Prosecutor's office contacted the Fuhrs to ask whether they had any additional information about the case. Brandi Fuhr, who had recontacted her mother several years before, told prosecutors that Mr. Cano had been arrested for driving with a suspended license in Florida.
Prosecutors said they could use photographs from the driving arrest to fill in the missing information on Mr. Cano's warrant. They told Brandi Fuhr, now 21 years old and a college student in Connecticut, that they would move ahead with the case if she still wanted to testify. Miss Fuhr said prosecutors had handled the case "like it was shoved under somebody's desk," but she said she wanted Mr. Cano arrested.
"It is awful," Miss Fuhr said. "I hate it. It has stirred up my life again."
Martin County sheriff's investigators say they have tried unsuccessfully to arrest Mr. Cano several times in the last six months. Although they are continuing their search, they now believe he has fled to another part of Florida.
Both Mr. Fuhr and his daughter said Mr. Cano might have gone underground after the sheriff's unsuccessful attempt to find him. Mr. Cano did not return several telephone calls to his wife's Martin County address.
The Fuhrs said they were glad the police had taken up the case again, but they have little confidence that the authorities will ever catch Mr. Cano.
"I can't wait to sit in court and see his face," Miss Fuhr said. "I still have dreams and nightmares about it. It won't be over for me until he is in jail."
