HEADLINE: PULSE;
New Homes

 BODY:
After rising steadily since 1991, single-family housing starts and sales in the New York metropolitan region are expected to decline this year. The slowing of the market comes despite the current low mortgage rates. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage in the New York region was 7.82 percent on Sept. 22, down from a high of 9.39. percent in December of last year. Experts attribute the stagnant housing market to the general slowing of the economy in the area, particularly the lack of new jobs.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Balance the Power

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.

 BODY:
Peace will not come to the Balkans as a result of inserting outside peacekeepers. Peace will come only when Serbs, Croats and Muslims strike a balance of power that makes aggression too costly.
After being jerked around for more than two years by the British and French, President Clinton was forced by Congress to exert NATO leadership. Primarily as a result of the belated application of air power against Serbian forces, the tide of war turned, making possible a serious cease-fire. 
 Now the U.S. President is being jerked around again. Last year, our European allies elicited a promise from him to put in 25,000 American ground troops to police a peace agreement.
But we have since learned that the only time progress was made in Bosnia was after peacekeepers were taken out. Putting outside troops in is a step backward into the morass that existed before our air strikes.
Clintonites say he's "given our word." But can a President without public debate or Congressional support, and with no emergency, commit substantial U.S. forces to open-ended police duty anywhere?
No. Secretary of State Christopher's claim that to withhold U.S. ground troops would mean "the end of NATO" is rhetorical blackmail.
I am a card-carrying interventionist. All the wrong people -- Pat Buchanan and the military "experts" who mistakenly foresaw disaster in using force to stop Saddam Hussein -- are my strange bedfellows in opposing the insertion of outside troops today. Clinton is already denouncing all Americans who denounce his wrongheaded strategy as "isolationists."
Clinton's model is Haiti. He was right to use force to build democracy there: it stopped an invasion of refugees. But Bosnia ain't Haiti.
Our First Armored Division in Europe was designed and equipped to take on a Soviet tank offensive, not to patrol mountain borders of a Bosnia we deliberately keep weak. Nor is Bosnia Berlin, to be defended by great powers in sectors, with Tuzla the new Checkpoint Charlie.
Bosnia already has 120,000 troops, all the troops it needs today to defend its whittled-down borders. They are mainly Bosnian Muslims, with some indigenous Croats. What those troops need is defensive arms, the training to use those arms, and the sustained air cover to give them the time to get that training.
Here's where Clinton has been snookered again by Europeans who want no Muslim state on their Continent. They keep claiming that lifting the embargo on arms for Bosnian self-defense would prolong the war.
Time has demonstrated how mistaken that defeatist European story is. One-sided arming led to war; only by equipping Muslim troops with comparable firepower can a balance be struck that could lead to peace.
The Serbs attacked because they thought they could conquer; they will not attack again if they think they will be beaten back. Nor will a well-armed Bosnia become irredentist if Muslims know that Western air power would then be turned against them.
What's a workable interventionist strategy for Congress to consider?
1. NATO's air arm, primarily American, should maintain control of the skies over the original Bosnia, ready to retaliate disproportionately to violations of the peace agreement. Air power was underrated in warmaking; let's not underrate it in peacekeeping.
2. NATO nations and Russia should manipulate economic sanctions and incentives to induce Serbia and Croatia to cooperate with what's left of Bosnia.
3. The arms embargo keeping Bosnia weak should be lifted forthwith. Mr. Clinton should lead the West to join nations like Pakistan, Turkey and Saudi Arabia to finance purchase of antitank, antiaircraft and intelligence-communications equipment.
4. A NATO team, including Americans, should set up training centers in Croatia to ready Bosnian troops for self-defense.
An imbalance of power in the Balkans always leads to war. Defense Secretary Perry's expressed expectation that Serbs will give up their arms to enable Muslims to achieve a balance of power is ludicrous.
The Congress should restrain the President from blundering into Bosnia's occupation. Instead, we should use the weapon that works -- the credible threat of harsh punishment from the air -- to enforce a peace among military equals.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Scandal Costs Daiwa Its Chairman and President
The president of Daiwa Bank, Akira Fujita, resigned his post early today to take responsibility for a $1.1 billion bond trading scandal. And the company's chairman, Sumio Abekawa, will leave his post by March. 
 Daiwa has been the center of international attention since Sept. 25, when the bank said Toshihide Iguchi, a bond trader, had covered up $1.1 billion in bad trades by forging as many as 30,000 trade slips. Analysts said the resignations were expected, given the nature and size of the losses. [Page D7.]
 
A Trade Pact's Trade-Off
When Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo, comes to Washington tomorrow, the North American Free Trade Agreement will weigh heavily on his talks with President Clinton, whose economists had once said it would create 170,000 jobs in its first year. That has not happened, in part because of the severe recession in Mexico. Now, many businessmen and economists say, the way to assess the trade pact is by looking at corporate efficiency, not job creation. [A1.]
 
A Fatter Reserve for Disasters
World finance ministers meeting in Washington agreed on the creation of a $50 billion special fund to halt financial hemorrhaging in disasters like the one that overtook Mexico almost a year ago. [D2.]
 
Figuring Out What Won't Hurt
With hundreds of thousands of workers afflicted with repetitive strain injuries, those who seek user-friendly furniture and computer accessories are faced with a dizzying assortment of ergonomic products. But there is no consensus on what is "ergonomically correct." [D3.]
 
Italy Investigating Company Losses
Financial investigators raided one of Italy's powerful industrial holding companies, Gemina S.p.A., which is controlled by Fiat's Agnelli family, in the wake of unexpected losses. The investigators are looking into the possibility of balance-sheet fraud. [D2.]
 
A Disparity in Phone Development
More than 50 countries built elaborate pavilions at Telecom 95 to illustrate the growth of their telecommunications industries, but the world's poorest nations are not sharing in the wealth. According to one study, the 48 poorest countries are falling further behind in telecom munications growth. News analysis. [D4.]

Raising On-Line Ethical Questions
A newsletter report that included information from the Internet without crediting the original researchers has raised issues of copyright and ethics. [D3.]
 
Arguing About Added Programming
A group of lobbyists got what they wanted from the pending CBS deal -- more educational programming for children -- but their success has provoked an outcry. Lawrie Mifflin: Television. [D5.]
 
A Legal Dispute on Court Cases
While law librarians struggle to organize court opinions electronically and put them on the Internet, small publishers are marketing data bases and CD-ROM's that offer legal reference materials. But electronic and on-line services are being outgunned by the company that dominates the print market. [D5.]
 
Tangled Up In the Web
Hollywood, never shy about transforming social phenomena into big-screen extravaganzas, has cast its eye on the World Wide Web and its millions of users. But technological realism has sometimes been lost. [D5.]
 
On Promoting and Presidents
Assessments of Presidential politics ran through the deliberations of the 86th annual meeting and business conference of the Association of National Advertisers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Patent Holder Gains Ground
International Gift Express is advancing in its claim that its patent covers the sale of digital information like music and software over computers. Sabra Chartrand: Patents. [D2.]

LENGTH: 583 words

HEADLINE: U.S. and Mexico Rush Talks On Tire and Wine Disputes

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8

 BODY:
In a rush of last-minute talks, United States and Mexican negotiators are trying to reach progress on key trade disputes under the North American Free Trade Agreement, which American officials were determined to resolve before President Clinton meets Mexico's President this week.
The disputes involve the sale of American wines and tires in Mexico and the operations of door-to-door package delivery companies, mainly United Parcel Service. American officials urged Mexico to settle them so President Clinton would not have to confront President Ernesto Zedillo with them when they meet on Tuesday in Washington. 
 In talks in Washington late last week negotiators made headway on a deal that would make it easier for American tire makers to sell in Mexico, officials of both countries said.
But Mexico did not budge from its longstanding opposition to cutting tariffs on American wines.
American officials have made it no secret that resolving the wine and tire disputes is part of President Clinton's re-election calculus. Most hurt by Mexico's high tariffs are wine producers in California, a $9 billion industry in a pivotal state in Presidential voting. The company worst hit by Mexico's tire regulations is Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, which has its headquarters in Ohio and also employs about 2,000 people in a plant in Texarkana, in the President's home state of Arkansas.
But a crushing recession in Mexico, coupled with stiff resistance from Mexican industries, has made the Government here reluctant to open its markets further. An American official said the Administration was "a little surprised" at Mexico's inflexibility, especially after President Clinton provided $12.5 billion in loans this year to save the Government from financial collapse.
American wine makers now pay 16 percent tariffs on sales in Mexico. Under the North American trade accord, wine duties are scheduled to drop to zero over 10 years. But wines from Chile, a major competitor, will enter Mexico duty-free beginning next year under a separate trade pact.
To win votes for the North American accord in 1993, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, promised the California Congressional delegation that within 120 days of passage he would get Mexico to agree to reduce the tariffs more quickly. Now two years later Mexico has refused to negotiate about wine tariffs.
As for tires, until this week Mexico insisted that American tires must carry labels in Spanish molded in the sidewall. It required American companies like Cooper Tire to have their tires inspected in the laboratories of competing companies in Mexico.
A new Mexican proposal would allow tires to be sold with stickers translating the sidewall information into Spanish. Still in dispute is whether the American companies can carry out their own inspections.
On the other issue, Mexico has refused to give permits to United Parcel Service to use trucks bigger than vans to transport packages on Mexican highways. Mexico has acknowledged that it is obliged under the trade accord to allow U.P.S. to use the big trucks, but argues that it must first issue complex new regulations for the trucking industry to define the difference between small packages and regular cargo.
U.P.S., which employs 1,400 people in Mexico, this week gave Mexico a "failing grade" on its compliance with the trade accord and warned that its operations here were so severely hampered that it might have to shut them down.
